The conspirators somehow gained access to names, Social Security numbers and other information on the state databases.UPDATEë_(9/15/2011): The source of the breach was found to be two dishonest employees. ë_On October 28, 2010 a call center supervisor was fired for negotiating to sell the Medicare numbers of disabled and elderly Floridians to an informant. A second Department of Children and Families (DCF) employee was also caught selling sensitive information. Each employee repeatedly misused access to a DCF computer system to obtain the information of people who applied to DCF for food stamps, cash benefits, and Medicaid. One dishonest employee was sentenced to 36 months in prison and three years of supervised release on June 30, 2011. ë_The other is scheduled to be sentenced on November 21, 2011 and faces a maximum of ten years in prison for health care fraud charges, five years for authentication feature fraud, and two years for each aggravated identity theft charge.
Thieves took 30 computers and electronic devices from the office.  Personal information of clients may have been on some of the computers.  This included credit card information for some clients.

Company: McDonald's, Arc Worldwide, Silverpop Systems Inc.
Description of incident: Hackers were able to access the information of McDonald's customers. ë_People who signed up for online promotions or newsletter subscriptions may have had their email addresses, contact information and birth dates exposed. ë_McDonald's uses a company called Arc Worldwide for its marketing services. ë_The breach was through Arc Worldwide's business partner Silverpop Systems Inc.

Company: University of Pittsburgh Medical Center Shadyside Hospital
Description of incident: In February of 2008, an employee disclosed the names, dates of birth and Social Security numbers of patients in exchange for personal gains. The patient information was eventually used to file false tax returns. The former employee was indicted on 14 counts.UPDATEë_(7/05/2011): A former employee has pleaded guilty to taking the names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth of 19 Shadyside patients. ë_The employee gave the patient information to other people who then filed fraudulent 2008 tax returns.UPDATE (10/21/2011): The former employee was sentenced to one year of probation for disclosing the information of 19 UPMC patients.ë_ He claims he was intimidated into giving away the information and that the people who collected $84,190 in fraudulent tax returns returned to Zambia.

Company: Holy Cross Hospital, Office of Dr. Elliot Stein
Description of incident:
A criminal investigation uncovered 38 patient files.  The files contained names, addresses, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and descriptions of initial diagnosis from Emergency Room visits.  An investigation that began in June showed that an employee was responsible; that employee was fired.  The employee may have inappropriately accessed 1,500 patient files between April 2009 and September of 2010.  The Hospital now limits the amount of key personal data included in the type of documents involved in the incident.UPDATEë_(2/17/2011): Five other suspects have been arrested within the past month. ë_Authorities learned of the fraud ring in May of 2010.UPDATEë_(4/15/2011):ë_A former Holy
Cross Hospital employee was sentenced to prison for disclosing patient
information.ë_ The woman was
sentenced to 24 months in prison with 12 months of home confinement, followed
by three years of supervised release.ë_
After being caught selling patient information from her employer, she
pleaded guilty to disclosing individually identifiable health information.UPDATEë_(6/21/2011): It was revealed that one of the other suspects is being charged with selling information from the office of Dr. Elliot Stein in Aventura. A criminal investigation uncovered lists of patient information from Dr. Stein that included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and health information.

Thousands of personnel documents were found in a dumpster. ë_W-4 forms, employment applications, and other employee documents were found by the news team FactFinder 12. ë_Social Security numbers, addresses, and phone numbers of people across the country were exposed. ë_It appears that the files were dumped because the office was closing.UPDATE (11/29/2011): Lone Star Funds (LSF) owned Lone Star Business Solutions.ë_ Lone Star Business Solutions managed the LSF restaurants which included Lone Star Steakhouse & Saloon, Texas Land & Cattle Steak House, Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steak House, and Sullivan's Steakhouse.ë_ The documents exposed in this breach were left behind after LSF decided to move the restaurant management business to Dallas.The Kansas attorney general's office investigated the breach and Lone Star Steakhouse (LS Management Inc.) was fine $200,000 for the improper disposal of confidential employee records.

Customers who used their credit cards on UConn's Huskydirect.com sports gear website may have had their personal information exposed in a data security breach.  A hacker was able to access the Huskydirect.com customer database and may have viewed billing information with names, addresses, telephone numbers, credit card numbers, expiration dates, security codes and email addresses.  The Huskydirect.com database is run by an outside vendor.  People who made purchases offline are not at risk.UPDATEë_(1/31/2011): Some people who were affected by the breach have recently reported fraudulent charges.UPDATE (2/19/2011): Additional details reveal the exact number of names that were on the customer database, the fact that the perpetrator used an administrative password, and the fact that Fandotech, the company that was hosting and managing the site, was not following correct web security procedures.

Company: Adult Industry Medical Healthcare Foundation (AIM Medical Associates P.C.)
Description of incident: Over 12,000 current and former adult film performers had their names, home addresses and other personally identifying information posted on the internet.  It appears that information from people who tested for HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases at the Adult Industry Medical Healthcare Foundation (AIM) was obtained somehow and misused.UPDATEë_(5/3/2011):A privacy lawsuit and other troubles caused AIM Healthcare to shut down and file for bankruptcy.ë_UPDATE (7/26/2011): The website that contained the personal and medical information of porn actors, PornWikiLeaks, was forced to shut down after being targeted by hackers.

A dishonest employee was charged with selling the account information of seven to ten customers.  The former employee sold account numbers between November of 2010 and February.  Approximately $39,000 in fraudulent charges may have been caused because of the former employee's actions.

Three people were arrested for tampering with ATMs and making fraudulent charges on customer cards. ë_They allegedly accomplished this by placing small cameras and card readers on at least two ATMs in the San Luis Obispo area.  Over 100 people discovered that fraudulent charges had been made on their cards.  Investigators first became aware of the situation on January 13.

People who used their credit or debit cards to make purchases at the University Book Exchange may have had their financial information taken.  A number of victims have contacted the police, but investigators are still not completely sure that the source of the fraudulent activity is a breach at the U.B.E. store. All or nearly all of those affected by the breach were connected to East Carolina University.UPDATEë_(2/13/2011): At least 100 East Carolina University students have reported fraudulent charges to their accounts. ë_The breach is believed to have occurred between January 5 and 25. ë_

Company: SettlementOne Credit Corporation, Sackett National Holdings Inc., ACRAnet Inc., Fajilan and Associates Inc. (Statewide Credit Services and Robert Fajilan)
Description of incident: Three companies who resell consumer credit reports have agreed to settle with the FTC over charges that computer hackers could easily access consumer data through their weak information security systems. ë_Hackers accessed more than 1,800 credit reports via security flaws in the computer networks used by the companies' clients.UPDATEë_(8/22/2011): FTS has approved the final orders settling charges against the three credit report resellers. ë_The approval comes after a period of public comment. ë_The companies will be required to strengthen their data security procedures and submiit to audits for 20 years.

Two former student employees may have obtained student information and provided it to outsiders. Names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth may have been exposed.UPDATE (10/25/2011): A former student was charged with eight counts of felonies related to the breach. The charges include identity theft and using a computer to commit a crime.ë_ A warrant was issued for a second student.

ACS handles the state of Ohio's automated system for paying and tracking child care providers. ë_An ACS mistake meant that over 8,000 providers were mailed letters with Social Security numbers visible from the outside of the envelope. ë_Some of the providers were childcare centers and only had ID numbers revealed; smaller providers who had their Social Security numbers as IDs face a greater risk.

Someone discovered that they could find information about a relative's name, address, patient ID, date of birth, Social Security number and other sensitive information through an online search that brought up WVChamps.com. ë_WVChamps.com is a CAMC website relating to respiratory and pulmonary rehabilitation for seniors. ë_The information was accidentally posted in a report on September 1, 2010 and appears to have been accessed a total of 94 times. ë_The error was discovered on February 8 of 2011. ë_The breach occurred within the CAMC subsidiary CAMC Health Education Research Institute.UPDATEë_(5/5/2011): Five patients who were affected by the breach filed a lawsuit seeking class action status for all affected patients. ë_The lawsuit alleges four counts against the hospital: breach of the duty of confidentiality, invasion of privacy by intrusion upon the seclusion of the plaintiffs, invasion of privacy by unreasonable publicity into the plaintiff's private life, and negligence.

Records Breached: 50-250 million (No SSNs or financial information involved)
Description of incident: Epsilon, an email service provider for companies,ë_reported a breach that affected approximately two percent ofë_its 2,500ë_clients. Only e-mail addresses and names were stolen. Epsilon has not disclosed the names of the companies affected or the total number of names stolen. However,ë_millions of customers haveë_received notices from a growing list of affected companies (http://www.databreaches.net/?p=17374), making this the largest security breachë_ever.The Secret Service is investigating this breach. Customers are expected to receive targeted spam that has their name and email address, and appears to come from one of the affected companies. These phishing attempts could result in further loss of consumer personal information. People who receive spam should report it to phishing-report@us.cert.gov.UPDATE (05/02/2011): The original estimate of companies affected was changed from 2% to 3% of Epsilon customers.ë_ A total of 75 companies were affected and these companies may end up paying a combined amount of $412 million in damage control. Epsilon itself could pay $225 million. Some estimate the total cost of the Epsilon breach could run as high as $3-$4 billion in forensic audits and monitoring, fines, litigation, and lost business for provider and customers.ë_ Conservative estimates place the number of customer email addresses breached at 50-60 million.ë_ The total of customer emails exposed could reach 250 million.

Company: Delray Beach and Oakland Park Fire Fighters and Police Officers
Description of incident: A Miami man was caught using fraudulently obtained debit cards. ë_The investigation began when 31 Oakland Park firefighters discovered fraudulent tax returns had been filed in their names. ë_The cause of the breach is unknown, but current and former firefighters and police officers of Oakland Park and Delray Beach had the same retirement plan administrator at one point.

Company: Broward County School Board, Private Medical Practices
Description of incident:
Two former employees from different private medical
practice offices were charged with providing confidential patient information
to other members of an identity theft and fraud ring.ë_ Both of these people participated in the identity theft and
fraud ring from early 2009 until February 2, 2011. ë_A former employee who worked for the Broward County School
Board passed along information from a teacher certification database, which
included names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth.ë_ The information was used to
fraudulently add people as authorized users to the victims_Ñé credit card and
bank accounts. The bank accounts of victims were depleted and one person
discovered fraudulent credit card charges of $128,000. ë_In addition to the three former employees, eight other people and the ringleader were also indicted on March 15, 2011.UPDATEë_(9/30/2011): The former Broward School District employee was sentenced to just over five years in federal prison for accessing and selling teacher personal information to identity theives. ë_At least 42 people in Florida had their information stolen; the fraudulent credit card charges that resulted totalled $408,000. ë_The former employee admitted to selling five to 10 Social Security numbers and dates of birth at a time for $100.

Former employees of GunnAllen Financial have been fined by the
U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for failing to adequately protect
customer data.ë_ The former
president and national sales manager broke privacy by transferring the
information of GunnAllen Financial clients over to a new business after or
during GunnAllen_Ñés November 2010 liquidation.ë_
The sales manager was authorized by the president to take a thumb drive
with the information of about 16,000 clients with him to his new job.ë_ The two former employees were fined
$20,000 each and a third former chief compliance officer was fined $15,000 for
failing _ÑÒto ensure that the firm_Ñés policies and procedures were reasonably
designed to safeguard confidential customer information._Ñ The fines are based
on violations of the SEC_Ñés Safeguard Rule, which requires institutions and
financial advisers under SEC jurisdiction to protect customer data and give
customers the opportunity to opt out of having their information shared with
unaffiliated third parties.

During April and May 2010, two men placed skimmers on PNC ATMs in Harmar and Waterworks Plaza.  Both men were arrested in April 2011 and face charges of conspiracy, access device fraud and attempt to commit access device fraud.  One man resided in Pompano Beach, Florida and the other in Astoria, New York.UPDATE (5/11/2011): One of the two men was sentenced to 23 months in prison and three years of supervised release for conspiring to commit bank fraud and access device fraud. ë_Court records reveal that the two men installed electronic skimming equipment onto multiple PNC ATMS in the Western Pennsylvania area. ë_The illegally installed equipment allowed them to record customer bank account information contained on the magnetic strips of debit and credit cards used at ATMs. ë_Fraudulent debit and credit cards were created with this information and approximately $208,000 was skimmed from at least 211 accounts.
A desktop computer, a portable electronic device, or both were discovered lost on November 24, 2010. ë_It is unclear who the data belonged to and what kind of information was lost.

Company: Office of Brian J. Daniels, D.D.S. and Paul R. Daniels D.D.S.
Description of incident: The March 2, 2011 theft of a portable electronic device resulted in the exposure of electronically stored patient protected health information.

Company: Private Legal Practice, Baker Moving and Storage
Description of incident: Twenty boxes of documents with sensitive medical and financial information were lost during transportation sometime around Saturday, April 30. ë_The information was mostly from the office of a family lawyer, but other sensitive documents may have been lost on Highway 101 during the incident. ë_The boxes were being transported to a new Baker storage facility. Baker did not inform the lawyer that the documents had been lost and the incident was discovered when the lawyer's son saw a news report about the incident. ë_The documents appear to be from the 1980's and early 1990's. ë_An unknown amount of Social Security numbers were also exposed.

An office burglary was discovered on the morning of February 4. ë_A server with patient personal and health information was among the stolen items. ë_Patients who were seen by the dentists during the past 30 years were affected. ë_The names of patients and patient guardians, home addresses and dates of birth for patients under 18 were on the server. ë_Account holders who provided insurance information may have had their Social Security numbers and dates of birth on the server. ë_Patients who used AllKids with Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Alabama may have had their Social Security number included in the exposed insurance information. An unspecified amount of customer credit card numbers were also stored on the server.

The February 1 theft of a contractor's laptop may have exposed client personal and health information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the car of an out of state contractor working for the Pregnancy Support and Adoption Services program. ë_It contained personal information that included names, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, dates of birth, driver's license information, health information, family histories, financial statuses and recommendation for readiness to adopt. Individuals who requested a home study in order to adopt a child between 2008 and 2010 were among those affected. ë_
On February 18 of 2011, it was discovered that patient health and personal information had accidentally been disclosed.

Company: Park Avenue Obstetrics and Gynecology, PC
Description of incident: A portable electronic device was discovered stolen on March 25, 2011. It contained personal and health information.

Twenty-eight employees from Unity Hospital and four from Mercy Hospital were fired for snooping. ë_The employees each accessed patient medical information without authorization. ë_Eleven teens and young adults were taken to the two hospitals on March 17 after overdosing at a party. Allegations that employees were accessing electronic medical records for no legitimate reason first surfaced in April.UPDATEë_(6/1/2011): It appears that a total of 32 employees, including 15 nurses, were fired in a single day for snooping.

Dr. Christopher Lockerman was arrested and charged with eight counts of financial identity fraud and one count of theft by deception. ë_Victims lost over $264,000 due to identity theft. ë_Patients of Lockerman's clinic had fraudulent J.P. Morgan Chase lines of credit established in their names. The period during which this took place was not revealed.

The April 3 theft of a laptop from an employee's locked car resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The information on the laptop's hard drive should not have been moved from the Hospital's secure server. ë_The employee resigned after the theft of the laptop. ë_Names, addresses, hospital account numbers, medical record numbers, physician names, dates of service, procedure codes, and diagnosis codes were exposed. Speare has committed to checking for the misuse of patient information.UPDATEë_(5/12/2011): People who were not patients of Speare may have also been affected by this breach. ë_Names, New Hampshire Medical License Numbers, Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) numbers and National Provider Identifiers may have also been exposed.

A computer was stolen from an employee's home during an early April burglary.ë_ It may have contained information from patients who visited the hospital between 1999 and 2008. Patients covered under Medicaid or Medicare may have had their Social Security numbers as well as unspecified information contained in patient reports.

A woman found the sensitive information of more than 60 people in a recycling bin. Social Security numbers, prescription information, patient names and medical histories were all easily accessible.ë_ The employee responsible for the incident resigned after the mistake and Dr. Barnes agreed to upgrade his shredding practices.

Several employees of Huntington Bank resigned and took customer information to a competing financial business.ë_ The employees had been downloading and printing confidential customer records from Huntington's secure database for weeks before they departed.ë_ The customer records included customer names, addresses, telephone numbers, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, bank account numbers and additional personal information.ë_ Former employees also took the files of some customers who had filed active mortgage loan applications.ë_ These files would have included customer pay stubs, W-2s, tax returns and other sensitive information.Huntington is suing the ex-employees for theft of trade secrets.ë_

Partially-shredded personnel records were dumped alongside a roadside. Names and Social Security numbers from University employees employed during 2002 were exposed.A student employee from the Records Management Office had taken two bags of personnel documents for use in a prank.ë_ Both bags were eventually found.ë_

Though Best Buy was affected by the large Epsilon breach, it had a second, separate breach of customer emails.ë_ A former third party vendor experienced a breach that may have exposed customer email addresses.ë_ Best Buy is pursuing legal action and had already ended its business relationship with the vendor. It is unclear why the vendor still had Best Buy customer information.ë_ It is likely that the unnamed vendor's breach affected customers of other businesses as well.

COCC's website experienced an unauthorized intrusion. Students who applied to the COCC nursing program for the current school year, and for a COCC Foundation scholarship for the following school year may have had their personal information exposed.ë_ The potentially exposed information does not include Social Security numbers, credit card numbers, email addresses or COCC ID numbers.ë_ It is unclear which information may have been exposed.

A marked cruiser was left at an autodealership for service.ë_ Its on-board camera was damaged and a laptop used for duty was stolen.ë_ The vehicle was left outside after hours because the dealership manager expecteda police officer to pick the vehicle up after hours.

The March 11 theft of an external hard drive used for backing up the Clinic's electronic files may have exposed patient information. ë_The hard drive was stored in a locked, fire-protected building with very limited access. ë_Many of the files contained patient Social Security numbers in addition to names, dates of birth, addresses and other clinical information. ë_There was a delay in notification due to the fact that there were duplicate files and patient contact information had to be updated. The Clinic has begun to encrypt records and raised the physical security of the files since the incident.

An employee working in a call center accessed customer credit card information for two months without authorization. ë_Customer names, credit card numbers and other credit card information could have been misused by the employee. The employee's actions were discovered on April 4, the employee was terminated, and a criminal investigation was launched.

Policy holders in the Kansas City area were notified that their personal information was accidentally made available to another business client administrator. ë_An employee error causes customer names, addresses, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and types of coverage to be made available to a business client other than the employer of those customers. The incident occurred in March and was corrected within a few minutes. ë_Affected policy holders were notified in early May.

Company: Office of Dr. Leslie Coleman, Staff Providers
Description of incident: A temporary employee from Staff Providers misused patient information. ë_The temporary employee took co-payments from patients while the manager was out of the office. The temporary employee did not have authorization to collect the financial information and made print copies of each customer's credit card during transactions. ë_Patients later called the medical office and complained about fraudulent charges. ë_The temporary employee made at least $1,400 worth of fraudulent charges, but was caught and charged with 11 counts of third-degree identity theft, illegal use of a credit card, and sixth-degree larceny almost immediately. ë_

Two women were arrested for their part in an identity theft ring. ë_At least 26 patients who visited Woman to Woman had their identities stolen by a receptionist. ë_Another worker at the clinic was spotted withdrawing money by using fake IDs. Both women had prior fraud convictions. The two women stole a total of $125,000. ë_It does not appear that the owner of Woman to Woman Healthcare was involved in the identity theft operation.

Hackers accessed the email accounts of 363 Fox.com employees and managed to deface the Linkedin accounts of 16 of them. This same group has attacked multiple Fox related groups such as the Twitter account of Fox15 TV, and the names, phone numbers and email addresses of 73,000 people auditioning for The X-Factor television show on Fox. ë_A text file of the information from The X-Factor participants was placed on a site called Pirate Bay. ë_The hacking group calls themselves Lulzsec. Four Lulzsec hackers searched Fox.com's servers for vulnerabilities and attacked on April 19. ë_Fox.com noticed the breach a week later. Lulzsec claims that it plans to release more hacked information soon.

Company: Eye Care Associates of the San Ramon Valley
Description of incident: A laptop with a lock to prevent theft was stolen from the ophthalmology office on the night of May 8. ë_It contained eye photos and names of 611 patients. The laptop was not recovered.

An employee is accused of stealing more than $170,000 from several customers. ë_The woman was indicted on 15 counts of theft by a bank employee and four counts of aggravated identity theft. ë_While employed at SunTrust between October 2006 and August 2008 the woman allegedly created a loan for someone without their knowledge and forged the person's signature in order to use $15,175 of their money for herself. ë_At least five other people were victimized in similar ways. Another customer had the money from their CD taken. ë_

A woman who worked at Regions is accused of creating 184 fraudulent bank accounts by using the names, dates of birth and Social Security numbers of 149 customers. ë_The woman then filed fraudulent tax returns totaling more than a million dollars and deposited the money into accounts. ë_Her boyfriend withdrew more than $65,000 of this money before the couple was arrested. ë_

Company: Ohio Auditor of State Dave Yost
Description of incident: A state-owned laptop was stolen from the home of a regional auditor for the state Auditor's Office. ë_Financial audits of public offices in northwest Ohio were on the laptop. ë_The employee was suspended for 15 days because a password that opens the password-protected information on the computer was attached to the computer. ë_This was in violation of the office policy and allowed access to the financial records on the laptop.

Four people were sentenced for their roles in an identity theft operation. ë_Between April 30, 2010 and May 29, 2010 an employee of the restaurant was paid $20 per card to use a skimmer to collect customer credit card numbers. ë_The stolen credit card information was used to make fraudulent purchases. ë_The criminals managed to cause between $120,000 and $200,000 in fraudulent charges.

Someone may have hacked into LaMar's credit card processing system and used the information to make fraudulent credit and debit cards. ë_Other businesses in the Omaha area who use a similar credit card processor may be at risk.

A group of employees left Excel Academy and took student information with them to a rival organization. ë_School district superintendents were solicited by the rival academy, Eagle Wings, and shown student information that Eagle Wings should not have possessed. Student names and Social Security numbers were exposed. ë_Excel reported the incident and police launched an investigation. Excel has student information from 33 districts.

Thousands of patients had their medical records compromised by the theft of a laptop. It was being used by an expert witness in a court case between Delta Dental and The Smile Center. The laptop contained a disc with patient information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and health information were on the disc. ë_Patients of the St. Paul office of The Smile Center who used Delta Dental between January 1, 2003 and June 30, 2010 were affected by the breach. ë_The theft happened in early 2011, but patients were not notified until May. ë_Neither organization is claiming responsibility for the breach, but Delta Dental is offering credit monitoring services to affected patients.UPDATEë_(5/31/2011): Delta Dental first learned of an incident on February 24. ë_The theft occurred on February 22. The Smile Center has refused to notify patients of the incident.

A courier was attacked on May 9. ë_The attacker managed to steal the courier's bag and its contents. The transaction records of 800 bank customers were exposed. ë_The information was from May 5 transactions and includes names, addresses, account numbers and any other information on checks processed at the bank. ë_Although a suspect was apprehended, the bag was not found. HarborOne flagged the accounts of customers who may have been affected by the incident.

On May 4, a contractor working for the Interior Department's National Business Center accidentally sent an unencrypted email. ë_There was a security feature in the system software that was designed to prevent such mistakes, but it failed to stop the email from going through. ë_Any information in the unencrypted email was vulnerable for about 60 seconds. ë_The email contained agency employee Social Security numbers and other payroll information. ë_

A woman looking for coupons in a grocery store dumpster found folders of hundreds of employment applications. ë_Insurance information, copies of Social Security cards, driver's licenses and birth certificates were left in the dumpster along with typical information found in employee records. ë_The information was from employees who worked for KB Pizza and the Domino's Pizza stores that were at one time owned by KB Pizza. ë_Neither Domino's nor KB know what caused the information to end up in the dumpster. ë_The Attorney General's office launched its own investigation into KB Pizza to find out how the files ended up in the dumpster.

One of Merlin's customers had their login information compromised. ë_Merlin detected inappropriate search activity on March 22, 2011. ë_Someone without authorization was able to access Merlin's databases for 21 hours. ë_Names, addresses, phone numbers and Social Security numbers were exposed. ë_Merlin began sending notification letters on April 11, 2011.

Company: Peace Officers Research Association of California (PORAC)
Description of incident: Hackers stole the names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, mailing addresses and credit card information of around 2,000 retired public safety officers who were part of the Peace Officers Research Association of California (PORAC). Hackers breached the PORAC data server in early April. ë_Retired associate members from the present back to 2008 were affected by the breach.

Subscribers to the ISP news and review site DSLReports.com have been notified that their email addresses and passwords may have been exposed during a hacker attack on the website during the last part of April. ë_The site was targeted in an SQL injection attack and about eight percent of DSLReports.com subscriber emails and passwords were taken. ë_There are around 9,000 active DSLReports.com accounts and 90,000 inactive accounts.

Company: Community Action Partnership of Natrona County
Description of incident: On February 23, 2011, The Community Action Partnership experienced a breach that involved unauthorized access to the information of 15,000 clients. ë_The type of information and the cause of the breach are currently not available; however a notice that has since been removed appeared on their website on April 7. ë_

Company: Office of Dr. Edalji and Dr. Komer
Description of incident: The April 12 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient PHI. ë_

Paper records with sensitive information were stolen on June 25, 2010. ë_The types of information the paper records contained was not revealed. ë_The breach does not appear to have been disclosed until May of 2011.

On February 16, 2011, an IT incident caused patient information to be exposed. ë_It is not known if the breach resulted from a hack or an accidental release of information. ë_The type of patient information exposed was not revealed.

The April 16 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. Multiple items were taken during the office burglary. ë_Patients who were part of Methodist Charlton's palliative care program between June 6, 2006, and September 30, 2010 were affected. ë_Patient names, ages, sexes, race, marital status, admission and discharge information, hospital account number, physician, insurance company, date of death, chief complaint and type of cancer may have been revealed. ë_Patient religion may have also been exposed. ë_It does not appear that any Social Security numbers were attached to hospital account number or insurance company information. ë_
A flash drive was stolen from an employee's car. ë_It contained the names, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, addresses and phone numbers of fewer than 100 patients.

A man was sentenced to six years in prison for his role in an identity theft scheme. ë_The man and an unknown number of accomplices somehow obtained the personal information of people who had Flexible Spending Accounts administered by United Healthcare Inc. ë_The group then created counterfeit prescriptions for controlled substances by using the information of patients covered by a prescription drug plan sponsored by the Federal Employees Health Benefit Plan. The group sold the prescribed drugs to third parties from September 2008 through April 2009. ë_The Federal Employees Health Benefit Plan lost $72,746 on drugs and services obtained by the criminals.

An employee responsible for moving patients around Provena Covenant was sentenced to eight years in federal prison for identity theft. ë_The former employee accessed patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and other personal information by stealing patient wallets and through other methods. ë_She also used at least one patient's credit card information to pay for access to victims outside of Provena Covenant. ë_At least 100 different names were found at the woman's home. ë_It is not clear if all of those names were related to the former employee's misdeeds at Provena Covenant between 2007 and 2008.

Someone broke into a storage barn on or around Monday, May 16 and took some of its contents. ë_The thief took a bike and may have taken medical records as well. ë_There were several years worth of medical records from dental patients of Comfort Dental. ë_Unfortunately, the owner had not properly secured the barn and could not determine how many records were taken.

The March 28 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptop was stolen from an employee's car on March 28. ë_It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and medical billing codes. Spartanburg Regional has not revealed the number of affected patients.UPDATEë_(7/03/2011): Spartanburg Regional notified HHS that 400,000 patients were affected.

Someone noticed that thousands of intact personal documents had been dumped in an unsealed dumpster. ë_He called a local news crew and they came to recover and store the documents. ë_The personal documents included applications, resumes, check books, federal income tax forms, and even patient diagnosis forms. ë_The information covered a period between 2003 and 2007. ë_A new employee of Tax Matters dumped the documents without shredding them.

A man pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit bank fraud and aggravated identity theft. ë_He admitted to installing skimmers and cameras on Valley National ATMs in September of 2008. He then used the account and identification information to make fake ATM cards. ë_The man and his co-conspirators accessed around 348 accounts and defrauded Valley National of $278,144.

A renter discovered that an employee had taken over 20 boxes of patient information home. ë_The renter had been asked by the owner not to go into the basement of the home, but wanted to clean after a flood. ë_He found the boxes, informed Wake Forest and the employee was fired. ë_The medical records date back at least 10 years. ë_They contained patient names, phone numbers, Medicaid numbers, medical record numbers, medical histories, diagnoses and medications. ë_Wake Forest is filing a larceny report.UPDATEë_(6/4/2011): More boxes have been removed from three additional residential and storage units owned by the employee. ë_The employee was fired on June 1 and has been cooperating with investigators. ë_Wake Forest denied that Social Security numbers were found in the former employee's home. ë_Based on the response of the former employee and other observations, investigators believe that the former employee is a hoarder with no desire to misuse the information. ë_Only 3-4% of the contents of the boxes were sensitive information.UPDATEë_(7/14/2011): A total of 136 patients and 221 medical center employees were affected.

A human resources employee of San Juan Unified uploaded sensitive employee information onto a flash drive. ë_Somehow the information was uploaded onto a website when the employee used the flash drive to perform volunteer work at her church. ë_An employee who Googled their own name discovered that they could also see their Social Security number and other sensitive information. ë_The information was available for six months. ë_ San Juan Unified decided to ban flash drives as a result of the incident.

An employee leaked customer information to members of an identity theft ring. Customer names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, bank account numbers, PINs, account balances, dates of birth, addresses, and phone numbers were obtained. ë_More than $10 million was lost. ë_Bank of America first learned about the breach in 2010; but waited until 95 suspects had been arrested. The group of thieves used the information to modify bank account information and hide the fraudulent accounts they were creating in the names of victims.

A former employee stole more than 500 patient records for the purpose of using them as evidence in a legal dispute with a physician. ë_The theft occurred in September of 2010 and included the medical information of three or four patients, as well as administrative information related to hundreds of other patients.
The March 8 theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of the protected health information of patients.
The March 8 theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of protected patient information. ë_

Veterans and staff had their personal information left unsecured in an open area in the San Juan VA Medical Center. Some of the information included patient care assignment documents with names and Social Security numbers an counseling letters. ë_It is not clear what type of staff information was exposed. ë_The information was supposed to have been shredded. The incident occurred sometime before March 30 and VA Caribbean placed a notification on their website on May 20.

Nineteen computers were stolen during an office burglary on Monday, April 18. ë_Administrative information such as names, addresses, dates of birth, medical record numbers, and health insurance plan ID numbers were exposed. ë_Sensitive medical information such as treating physician names, diagnoses, treatment plans, progress notes, prescriptions, referrals, and authorizations were also exposed. A safe with 16 patient checks and 60 patient credit card receipts was also stolen.

At least 42 people who used their debit or credit cards at the same Murphy USA gas station have reported fraudulent charges to their financial accounts. ë_A local credit union claims that hundreds of people were affected. ë_Reports of fraudulent charges began in late May. ë_An investigation of the card reading devices at the gas station did not reveal any evidence that a skimmer had been used. ë_Thieves are using the financial information of victims to make fraudulent ATM withdrawals in California.

A Memorial Day weekend office burglary resulted in the theft of two laptops and a flash drive. ë_The flash drive may have contained student information. ë_This potential exposure includes copies of Medicaid release forms with student names, parent names and Medicaid numbers.

Company: Texas Department of Assistive and Rehabilitative Services
Description of incident: Current and former employees may have had their personal information exposed. ë_Notification of the incident was sent as soon as Department of Assistiveë_and Rehabilitative Services (DARS) officials learned of the breach. ë_Though a law enforcement investigation is taking place, no information regarding the date of the breach, the cause of the breach or the type of information exposed has been disclosed. ë_

A night custodian made copies of sensitive documents pertaining to criminal cases. ë_He then traded the documents to an outsider in exchange for drugs. ë_Documents were stolen or copied from the district attorney's office between January and June of 2011. ë_The outsider, her boyfriend and the custodian were charged. ë_The woman wanted to use the court records as aids to help her decide who not to sell methamphetamine to. The custodian was on an assignment from Patton Cleaning Co. Inc. ë_The county has a monthly contract with the company. ë_

A student discovered student data files on a departmental EagleNet site while searching the EagleNet portal for his own information. ë_A total of three students accessed the sensitive files and were interviewed. ë_Student names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth were accessible. ë_The information was accidentally placed their by a faculty or staff member and reported on May 23.

Company: LexisNexis, Onyx Collections and Locators Services Inc.
Description of incident: Sensitive information was exposed by a breach at Onyx Collections. ë_Someone connected to Onyx Collections was misusing Onyx Collections' search account to access the personal information of people. ë_LexisNexis discovered the problem after conducting an audit of Onyx Collections. From September 10, 2009 through March 2, 2011, Onyx Collections had access to names, addresses, dates of birth, driver's license numbers and Social Security numbers of at least 74 people from New Hampshire. ë_The total number of people affected nationwide has not been revealed.

A data security firm discovered that SCMLC data was available online. ë_The names and Social Security numbers of around 300,000 people who applied for California workers' compensation benefits may have been accessed by unauthorized parties.

The Epic Games websites and forums were hacked. ë_Hackers may have obtained the email addresses and encrypted passwords of forum users. ë_There is a possibility that hackers may be able to decrypt the passwords. ë_Epic Games reset all passwords and sent new ones to users. ë_Users should also make different passwords for other accounts if their Epic password is the same as the one used for those accounts. ë_No financial information was exposed by the attack.

A virus infected a Penn State Altoona computer that contained the names, addresses and Social Security numbers of alumni, faculty and staff members. ë_The virus appeared on the computer sometime during the spring semester and was discovered on March 15. ë_Those who were affected were not notified until June because the full list of affected people and their contact information had to be obtained by investigators. ë_Only alumni with identical Social Security numbers and student IDs were affected.

A husband and wife who owned the two businesses are accused of conspiracy to commit wire fraud, wire fraud, and credit card fraud. ë_The business owners allegedly made additional, unauthorized charges onto customer credit cards after they charged them for legitimate business transactions. ë_Victor Victoria's was open from August 2009 to July 2010 and Renteria was open from August 2009 to September 2010. ë_

Hackers accessed one of Ravelry's second servers and obtained names, encrypted passwords, and possibly email addresses. Business transactions occur on the site, but no financial information was exposed during the breach. ë_Since hackers may be able to decrypt the passwords and link them to names and email addresses, Ravelry suggested that users immediately change their Ravelry passwords. ë_Users should also make different passwords for other accounts if their Ravelry password is the same as the one used for those accounts.

Hundreds of documents were stolen from the home of the former owner of the escort services. ë_A computer and a large container of files were stolen during the Monday, June 6 burglary. ë_The files contained the names and numbers of clientele as well as appointment logs, schedule books and credit card receipts. ë_Some of the clients used fake names and some had high profile status. ë_Denver Players and Denver Sugar had previously been exposed as prostitution operations.

A court clerk took court documents home in an attempt to hide the fact that she had not done the work. ë_The employee was fired and could be charged with tampering with public records. ë_No malicious intent is suspected. ë_It is believed that the employee hid years of backlogged records and eventually took them home to continue concealing them.

The hacking group known as LulzSec published 180 usernames, hashed passwords, plain text passwords, names and email addresses from the organization. ë_Infragard is a non-profit that attempts to serve as an interface between the private sector, individuals and the FBI. ë_LulzSec targeted the organization because of its connection to the FBI.UPDATEë_(6/24/2011): Infragard Connecticut may have also been breached during June. ë_Lulz Security (LulzSec) claims to have the information for over 1,000 accounts.

The June 3 theft of a laptop from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of consumer information. ë_The laptop was assigned to a PASSPORT case manager. ë_It contained the health information of 43,000 consumers and the personal contact information of 35,000 related clients' personal representatives. ë_

A contract nurse is accused of accessing patient information without authorization. ë_He faces a 90-count felony indictment. ë_He allegedly used the Social Security numbers and other private information found in patient files to open credit cards in patients' names. ë_The nurse was hired through a staffing agency. ë_He worked at Boulder Community between May 1, 2010 and January 7, 2011. ë_Police later notified Boulder Community on May 11, 2011 that the former employee was suspected of stealing patient demographic information from other hospitals.UPDATEë_(9/27/2011): The nurse faces five counts of identity theft and 46 counts of theft of medical records in connection to this incident. ë_The former employee worked at a staffing agency and performed work for numerous Centura Health facilities, the Platte Valley Medical Center, and Boulder Community Hospital. ë_UPDATE (12/6/2011): The nurse was sentenced to six years probation after being charged with multiple felony counts of identity theft and theft of medical records.ë_ It was also revealed that the dishonest employee worked at St. Anthony's Hospital in Lakewood, Colorado.ë_

Company: Office of Dr. Morgan Camp and Associates
Description of incident: An office computer was discovered missing on the morning of June 6. ë_A burglar entered the office and searched through papers and equipment. ë_There was no sign of forced entry. ë_A credit card verification machine and approximately $150 in cash were also taken. ë_Patient information, credit card information and other personal details were stored on the computer. ë_Patients are advised to cancel any cards they had on file with Dr. Camp's office.

The Lending Company's secure database was breached on May 4. ë_A manager reported seeing a computer transferring customer personal information to an external source. ë_Thousands of customers and employees may have had their names, contact information, Social Security numbers and other sensitive personal information downloaded. ë_Customers were originally told that the system had been hacked, but one or more company insiders may have been the source of the breach.

About 100 Associated Credit Union members have experienced fraudulent checking account charges. ë_A breach of check and ATM card information may have been caused by a breach of Associated Credit's processing company. ë_This could mean that customers of other financial institutions connected to the transaction processing company are at risk. ë_The customer information was used to make fake cards and the cards were sold throughout the country. ë_The date the breach occurred is unknown.

A company laptop was stolen from physician's vehicle on the night of April 27. ë_Patient names, dates of birth and clinical information were on the laptop. ë_It did not contain Social Security numbers or financial information.

Records Breached: 1.29 million (No SSNs or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The SEGA Pass website was hit by hackers sometime around June 16. ë_Sega Europe in London operates the website, but customers worldwide may have been affected. ë_No credit card information was exposed, but names, dates of birth, email addresses and encrypted passwords were stolen by the hackers. Sega recommends that customers change login information for other sites if they used the same login information for SEGA Pass. Sega reported that 1,290,755 customers were affected.

A breach of the Teachers Retirement System (TRS) of Texas has been discovered. ë_A retired principal learned that the TRS had mailed an envelope to her bank. ë_Due to the window-style of the envelope, her personal information was clearly visible through the TRS envelope. ë_The number of people affected by TRS's practice is unknown. ë_TRS changed their procedures so that content cannot be seen from the outside of the envelope. ë_TRS also plans to take the sensitive information off of letters in the future.

People who made purchases on the Nashville Zoo website within the past two years are being warned about a website security breach. ë_Investigators discovered that the website was the source of several credit card fraud incidents; the Nashville Zoo is now warning patrons to check their credit card statements. It is unclear when the breach occurred.

Hackers managed to obtain a number of administrative usernames and passwords for the PBS website. ë_PBS became aware of the intrusion when a phony news story was placed on the website in late May. ë_The login information for over 200 database users was later posted on the internet. ë_Hackers then began releasing additional information on the PBS website and member database. ë_The names, addresses, email addresses of subscribers. The hackers claim that they may release phone numbers and passwords of PBS members as well. ë_Wyoming PBS was also breached.

Lockheed Martin experienced a "significant and tenacious attack." ë_Lockheed's security team quickly detected the intrusion and updated security. ë_No customer, program or employee data was compromised, but the attack did cause unspecified damage. ë_A breach at RSA may have led to the Lockheed Martin breach since Lockheed Martin was using RSA's security product or products.

The workers' compensation information of 9,000 current and former state employees was copied onto a private hard drive without authorization. ë_The hard drive was removed from the state offices by an employee, but was recovered. ë_The CDPH security system detected unusual activity on April 5 and the employee responsible was discovered. ë_The employee was placed on administrative leave until the completion of the investigation. ë_Most current CDPH and California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS) employees were affected. ë_an additional 3,000 employees of the former Department of Health Services (DHS) were also affected. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, ethnicity, addresses of individuals listed as next of kin of employees and other workers' compensation information was exposed.ë_

Company: Harrisburg Project, West Aurora School District, Kaneland School District
Description of incident: Two laptops were stolen from a car on or around June 7. ë_The laptops were from an Illinois State Board of Education (ISBE) subcontractor called Harrisburg Project. ë_The ISBE uses the Harrisburg Project as a subcontractor for special education reimbursement purposes. The laptops contained the personal information of over 10,000 students and staff from northern Illinois. ë_Employees were using the laptops for training in data entry.UPDATEë_(6/29/2011): It appears that both student and staff Social Security numbers were on the laptops. ë_Additionally, student names, dates of birth, residential school district and other educational information were on the laptops. ë_Staff names, demographics, teacher certification numbers and work assignments were on the laptops.

Two former students conspired to obtain and sell large databases of faculty and alumni information, change grades and steal funds from the accounts of other students. ë_The two students developed malware that allowed them to capture passwords and gain unauthorized access to the University's network. ë_The students were able to install the malware in a variety of ways. ë_For example, the students obtained the information of other students by inserting a thumb drive into public PCs and personal laptops. ë_Malware was installed on at least one University administrator's computer and the login credentials of a residence hall director were stolen.One of the men pleaded guilty to charges of computer hacking conspiracy and computer intrusion. Charges are pending against the student's alleged accomplice. ë_

Company: Barnes-Jewish Hospital, The Siteman Cancer Center, Washington University
Description of incident: A laptop containing unencrypted patient information was stolen during the weekend of December 4, 2010. ë_It contained the names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, medical records, diagnoses, lab results, insurance information and employment information. ë_The Siteman Cancer Center is a joint venture between Washington University and Barnes-Jewish Hospital. ë_A group of patients is suing all three groups for notifying patients eight weeks after the theft. ë_At least one patient experienced identity theft as a result of the breach.

Company: Tuba City Regional Health Care Corporation
Description of incident: Patient dietician treatment cards were discovered missing. ë_The cards contained patient names, dates of birth, phone numbers, medical record numbers, treatment plans, progress notes, medications, diagnoses, procedures, heights, weights, visit dates, and other diagnostic findings. ë_Tuba City Regional suspects that the cards were misplaced during a relocation and inadvertently destroyed in the facility's trash compactor. ë_The approximate date of the disappearance was not reported; but the discovery was made on or around April 1, 2011.

On April 11, 2011, someone discovered that sensitive paper records had been disclosed to outside parties or accessed without authorization. ë_Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) uses Cahaba for administration of Medicare fee-for-service programs.

A laptop was discovered missing in May. ë_It was held in a locked room in Hurley, but it was not encrypted or password protected. ë_The laptop contained the names, heights, weights, dates of birth, medical record numbers and lung function test results of 1,938 patients who visited Hurley between 2007 and May of 2011. ë_A total of 10 out of 150 of Hurley's laptops were not encrypted at the time of the discovery.
Paper records with sensitive information were misplaced, stolen, or improperly accessed sometime around March 15, 2011.

Around 1,200 patient records were misplaced on May 27 and were buried in a landfill. ë_The box of records contained patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, diagnostic test results, provider notes and correspondence, disability forms and insurance information. ë_An unnamed SGMF vendor is responsible for displacing the box.

Company: Colorado Department of Health Care Policy and Financing (HCPF)
Description of incident: A disk with the information of medical-aid applicants was lost on its way between HCPF and another agency. It contained applicant names, state identification numbers, and addresses. The disk was discovered missing on May 6.

GGC became aware of a potential security breach that could have occurred between June 9 and June 14. ë_A server collocated by 14Market may have been disabled by an outside party sometime during this time frame. ë_It appears that any attempt to hack information from the server during this time failed. ë_Notification letters were sent to customers on July 5. ë_
A computer was stolen from the radiology department of the Jeannette campus of Excela. ë_It contained patient names, dates of birth and types of exam performed.

Company: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Florida (BCBSF)
Description of incident: An April 2011 mailing error caused 3,500 member healthcare statements to be mailed to incorrect addresses. ë_The statements were mailed to the former addresses of members and contained names, insurance numbers, diagnoses codes and descriptions, procedure codes and descriptions, prescription names and provider names.

A man hacked into the websites of multiple businesses; one of them was the Capital Grill website. ë_He was able to obtain email addresses and passwords of registered customers. ë_A total of 250 people from across the businesses had their information stolen. ë_He then tried to use the login information on financial websites. ë_He was able to access the financial accounts of people who used the same email and password combination. ë_A federal judge sentenced him to 10 years in prison.ë_
A computer breach was discovered on June 25. ë_Hackers may have obtained encrypted customer credit card numbers, user names and passwords.

An attack by the hacktivist group Anonymous resulted in the exposure of user names, and passwords. ë_Anyone who signed up on the Universal Music website in order to receive updates about musicians was affected. Anonymous hacked the website as part of its AntiSec campaign, the goal of which is to expose weak spots in the internet security of governments and large businesses.

A hacker infiltrated All Pets Club's computer system. ë_Customer credit card numbers are encrypted after the computer system stores them, but are vulnerable for a short time once they have been swiped. ë_The hacker was able to access the credit card numbers as they were swiped. ë_Police reported that a significant portion of the complaints about fraudulent credit charges in the Branford area have come from All Pets Club customers during the past few months.

Company: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, New York State Department of Taxation and Finance
Description of incident: Two CD-ROMs were lost after being mailed from Morgan Stanley to the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. ë_It is not clear if the CDs were never shipped, fell out of the packaging during shipping, or were lost after being received by the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. The affected Morgan Stanely clients had their names, addresses, account and tax identification numbers, and income earned on Morgan Stanley investments in 2010 exposed. ë_Some clients also had their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_

An unauthorized access resulted in the exposure of faculty, student and staff information. ë_Student names and identification numbers were exposed. ë_The types of faculty and staff information that may have been exposed were not reported.

A hacker broke into three older files on the Museum's computer system. ë_Member names, email addresses, home addresses and phone numbers were posted on Twitter for a period of time. ë_People who signed up for membership events in 2006 and nominees for the Museum's tech awards in 2009 were among those affected.

Two San Antonio city employees pleaded guilty to charges related to using stolen Social Security numbers. ë_One member of the couple stole Social Security numbers from patients at a Metropolitan Health District. Multiple Social Security cards with different numbers were found during a raid of the couple's home. ë_The other member of the couple worked for the San Antonio Public Works Department.UPDATE (12/17/2011): One member of the couple received five months in jail, five months of house arrest, and two years of federal supervision for her crimes and for violating her position of trust as a city employee. She had been hired to work as an administrative assistant for a tuberculosis program at the Metropolitan Health District clinic through a temp agency.ë_ The other member received five years of probation with six months of home confinement.ë_

Walgreens customers saw the prescription information of other customers when they attempted to log into their accounts on the Walgreens.com site. ë_The website problem existed for at least two months and also allowed customers to see the phone numbers, names of prescribing doctors, names of medications, the amount the prescriptions were purchased for and the dates of the purchases. A customer alerted a local store to the problem, but had to contact the media when the problem persisted two months later.

Company: Colorado Springs Hospital - Memorial Health System
Description of incident: A nurse from the occupational health clinic accessed the records of 2,500 Memorial Hospital patients without cause. ë_The nurse had access to patient records through Physician Link, but was not a Memorial employee, and had no medical or work-related reason for accessing the records. She was fired and claims to have used the database to look up contact information for family and friends, as well as for other reasons. The nurse also feels that she was singled out and claims that many other employees in the medical community use databases in this way.
A laptop with employee information was taken from another employee's home on June 25. An unspecified amount of employee information was exposed.

Users who responded to a survey on ethical dilemmas may have had their names and email addresses exposed for approximately 16 hours. ë_The survey results were posted on the Psychiatry Times website on June 7th. ë_The website post contained a link to the responses to the survey questions. ë_This somehow provided enough information for the names and emails or respondents to be determined. ë_The link was deleted and the survey was disabled shortly after the discovery. ë_Users were notified of the error on June 10.

Patient information was stolen from the Hillandale facility and used to file fraudulent tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service. ë_Patients who visited DeKalb's Hillandale facility between July and October 2010 may have had their information exposed. ë_It appears that affected individuals between the ages of 17 and 20 were the group affected by the filing of fraudulent tax returns. ë_The United States Secret Service alerted DeKalb and it is believed that the breach was just one of many similar breaches in Georgia and Alabama. ë_DeKalb did not reveal how the information was taken.

An employee with College Choice's program manager UPromise Investments accessed names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and other contact information for seven months while on the job. ë_The former employee was in charge of withdrawals and deposits. ë_It does not appear that the employee was able to withdraw money from any of the accounts in the Indiana plan. ë_Security measures were in place that prevented the employee from printing or emailing the information.

A vendor failed to restore computer security controls following routine maintenance. ë_A virus was later discovered on a computer that contained names, medical record numbers, genders, dates of birth, and the date and name of radiology procedures for patients. ë_The virus transmitted encrypted data files to an unknown location. ë_The computer was cleaned and had its software re-installed to clear the virus.ë_

Items on display at a bankruptcy auction involving the Kitchen Place included two cabinets with customer information and shelved boxes with employee information. ë_Past customer credit card and bank account numbers, methods of payment and home floor plans were kept in the cabinets. ë_Shelves for sale carried boxes of employee information which included names, Social Security numbers and other personal and payroll information. Anyone looking over the auction items could have accessed the information. ë_At least one person purchased an item that held customer information and subsequently dumped the papers in the parking lot.

Widespread credit and ATM card fraud has been linked to a hack of Mountain Mike's Pizza. ë_The website was infected by malicious software in October; it was detected and removed in April of 2011. ë_Customers who paid by debit or credit card between October of 2010 and April of 2011 are advised to call their financial institution and have their debit or credit card number changed as a precautionary step.

On February 28, 2011 Extreme Pizza discovered that hackers had accessed the point of sales systems of several west coast franchises. The attacks occurred in August and the customer information was misused between that time and January of 2011.

Zpizza was affected by malware on the point of sales system used to process credit and debit card transactions. ë_The breach affected customers who used their credit or ATM cards between September of 2010 and January of 2011 at 12 locations. Customers in California, Montana and Virginia were affected. ë_

Several customers reported problems with their credit and ATM cards after purchasing vacation trips on the website. ë_Customer names, passport numbers and dates of birth were also exposed. ë_The breach appears to be the result of a hacking attack. ë_StudentCity.com first became aware of the problem on June 9. ë_Though 266 New Hampshire residents were affected by the breach, the total number of affected US customers was not reported.

The full names and Social Security numbers of current and former employees were accessible online for nearly nine weeks. Employees who worked for Swedish, but not Swedish Physician Division, ë_in 1994, 1995, 2002, 2003, 2004 and 2006 had their information posted sometime between the middle of April and June 17, 2011. The cause of the accidental disclosure was not reported.

A number of people reported fraudulent debit and credit card purchases. ë_The problems were traced back to a Margarita's computer that had been infected by a virus. ë_Investigators discovered that criminals had sold a number of the customer credit and debit card numbers that were stolen from the system. ë_Margarita's had no obvious security flaws at the time of the breach and has since upgraded its firewall protection.

At least 10 TSA employees who worked at the same terminal had their financial information stolen when they used their credit or debit cards at a compromised machine. ë_Investigators are unsure of the scope of the breach.

Company: Rabjohns Financial Group, MedHQ LLC, Lindy Manufacturing
Description of incident: Hundreds of papers were found along a road in Des Plaines. Some were job applications for Rabjohns Financial Group/New England Financial in Chicago and corresponsing UF forms.ë_ W-2 forms and investment statements from 2009 were also among the papers.ë_ It is unclear how the information ended up in the road.

Records Breached: 9,309 (Unknown amount of SSNs and financial information)
Description of incident: Patients were notified on that a computer or laptop was stolen.ë_ The protected health information of patients was on the computer. The location of the theft was not reported.
The bank account information of 2,499 customers was incorrectly mailed.

It was discovered that an hourly employee of 19 years was forging checks by using the information of companies who were fined for OSHA violations.ë_ The employee had handled checks for 12 years and may have been involved in a larger fraud operation.ë_ The employee was arrested and fraudulently obtained less than a thousand dollars on average from each company.ë_ A total of 759 companies who paid OSHA fines between January 1, 2009 and November 18, 2010 were affected.ë_ One business owner discovered that a fraudulent check had been cashed for $745 after he paid an OSHA fine of $315.

Company: Association of the Blind and Visually Impaired (ABVI)
Description of incident: The names, addresses and bank account numbers of people who wrote checks to the ABVI were misused by a former employee in 2008 and 2009.ë_ The employee was part of a larger check fraud and identity theft operation that was uncovered by police. Clients and donors generally had fewer than one thousand dollars taken from their accounts.

On January 19, 2010, a technical error caused client data to be mismatched during a posting of routine fee statements to the secure online filing cabinets of individual financial professionals.ë_ A limited number of customer fee statements which included client names, Curian account numbers and account balances, and Social Security numbers were made available to other clients for less than a day.

A man found files with names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and phone numbers on his way to the grocery store.ë_ Some were blowing in the wind and others were lying in the street.ë_ All appear to be from Milagros II Home Health in Weslaco.ë_

Medicare Part D beneficiaries enrolled in Prescription Drug Plans may have had their information exposed. ë_A formatting mistake made member names, ID numbers, drug names and dates of birth viewable through the envelope window of letters sent.UPDATEë_(7/27/2011): Current and former Molina Medicare, Healthy Advantage HMO SNP, and ChoicePartners Medicare HMO members were also affected.UPDATE (10/28/2011): An additional 1,378 Windsor Health Plan enrollees were affected as well.

Inmates used the library logs at Passaic to obtain the personal information of other inmates. The inmates then called outside conspirators in order to defraud American Express and inmates of over $450,000.ë_ Fake American Express credit cards were created from the information and used to deposit funds into Bank of America accounts or to make purchases. The scheme occurred between September of 2007 and April of 2008.

Company: Platte Valley Medical Center (PVMC), Centura Health
Description of incident: A contract nurse who was employed by PVMC between May of 2010 and January of 2011 misused patient information. ë_At least 76 PVMC patients became victims of identity theft. ë_The nurse was employed at multiple locations. ë_The former employee may have accessed a total of 142 patient records while at PVMC, and 123 while working in the Centura Health system. He faces 90 felony counts related to illegally accessing patient files and identity theft.

Patient records were left in an abandoned pain clinic. ë_The new owner reported the discovery to police. ë_Hundreds of files with medical information of former patients were discovered. ë_It is unclear if anyone else accessed the information.

The hospital theft of a hard drive resulted in the exposure of current and former employee information. ë_The names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and other information related to employees and their families were on a human resources department computer. ë_A flood on June 23 caused the HR department to temporarily relocate. ë_Workers returned on July 6 and discovered that the hard drive had been stolen. ë_The information dates back at least 12 years.

Belmont Savings Bank has agreed to pay a fine of $7,500 related to a consumer data breach case with the Massachusetts attorney general's office. ë_In May, a bank employee left a backup tape on a desk rather than storing it. ë_A cleaning crew disposed of the tape later that night. ë_Names, Social Security numbers and account numbers were exposed. ë_The tape contained the personal information of over 13,000 customers, but is believed to have been incinerated after disposal along with other sensitive materials from BSB.

A company-issued laptop was determined to be missing. ë_A notification letter was sent to current and former employees on July 13.ë_Names and Social Security numbers were exposed. ë_The number of employees affected is unclear.

Current and former UNLV employees may have been affected by a breach. ë_It is possible that an unauthorized user gained access to a former employee's computer in December of 2008. ë_Employee information that included Social Security numbers would have been exposed. ë_The potential breach was discovered in 2011 during maintenance on a computer in UNLV's Controller's Office.

Company: Lincoln National Life Insurance Company, Lincoln Life & Annuity Company of New York
Description of incident: On April 29, an employee accidentally attached a sensitive file to an encrypted email that was sent to a third-party payroll provider. ë_It contained the names and Social Security numbers of pension plan participants of multiple payroll vendors. ë_The error was discovered on May 17, and notifications were sent in July.

A research associate's laptop was stolen during the course of research with a Tufts professor. ë_The research was being conducted at MGH. ë_The laptop was mostly used for research, but a sensitive file had been uploaded in early 2010. ë_It contained a spreadsheet with the information of applicants who applied to the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Tufts. ë_Applicant Social Security numbers were included in the spreadsheet. ë_The theft occurred in April of 2011 and was reported to MGH. ë_Tufts learned of the breach on June 16, 2011.

On April 15, 2011, law enforcement notified Ascensus of a cyber attack that had affected Ascensus' network and those of other companies. ë_The virus was determined to be a new type of malware and was immediately blocked from Ascensus' network. ë_However, the virus created and may have been able to export files with client names and Social Security numbers.ë_

A man was charged with using a skimming device to take over $200,000 from customer accounts. ë_He was arraigned on 45 counts of identity theft, grant theft, burglary, making fake ID cards and causing losses that exceeded $200,000. ë_He was caught when bank investigators discovered that someone was installing an ATM skimming device on the door of the bank's ATM lobby every Saturday after closing. ë_The device was then removed by the thief early on Mondays. ë_This happened for at least six consecutive weeks. ë_Hidden cameras were also used to record customer pins at the ATMs. ë_Agents were able to arrest the man as he returned to retrieve the skimming device.

The inspector general at the VA found that IT contractors had accessed the VA's electronic health record system without appropriate security clearances. ë_An tipster had left a message about the situation on a departmental hotline in the summer of 2010. ë_Contractor personnel were found to be improperly sharing user accounts when accessing VA networks and the Veterans Health Information System and Technology Architecture systems. Employees of the contracting company were unaware of proper IT security protocol.

Records Breached: 950 (No reports of SSNs or financial information)
Description of incident: The disclosure of sensitive paper records resulted in unauthorized access to personal information. ë_The breach either occurred or was discovered around April 1, 2011.
A laptop that contained information related to SilverPop's Health and Welfare Plan was stolen on April 15. ë_Affected individuals may have had their protected health information exposed.

A relative of a mail room employee discovered sensitive documents at the employee's residence and returned them in June of 2011. ë_The employee had taken home medical documents between November of 2009 and September of 2010. ë_The records consisted of patient names and diagnostic test results. ë_Fifteen of the documents included patient addresses and insurance identification or Social Security numbers. ë_The employee was fired. ë_UPDATE (10/22/2011): A total of 1,438 people were affected by the breach.ë_ The former employee was charged with embezzlement and forgery.ë_ She claims that she was overwhelmed with sorting the documents at work and that she planned to dispose of them properly.

A physician who worked for both hospitals left an external hard drive in a piece of luggage. ë_The luggage was lost in a cab on or around June 21. Information related to inpatient hospital stays from July 10, 2009, to January 28, 2011, may have been on the hard drive. ë_The types of information that could have been on the device include patient names, medical record numbers, dates of admission, medications, and information about diagnosis and treatment.

A dishonest VA worker used his tax return preparation business to submit fraudulent tax returns. ë_VA patient personal information such as names, Social Security numbers and birth dates were used to create fake dependents on people's tax returns. ë_The VA worker then collected fees from customers in exchange for fraudulently increasing the dollar amount of their tax returns. He was convicted in February and sentenced to 11 years in federal prison. The employee handled information from VA patients in North Carolina and Virginia.

A hacker accessed the employee listserv on or around August 4. ë_This allowed an unauthorized party to send an offensive photo and additional lewd messages through the University's mailing list. ë_The listserv is normally only used by administrators to transmit official University business. ë_It is unclear if any information was exposed.
