Company: University of North Carolina - Chapel Hill
Description of incident: Someone broke into the UNC-Chapel Hill judicial office and took the files of 30 students. The break-in was discovered at the beginning of the day on Monday. University student affairs officials contacted each of the students who had their records stolen.UPDATE (8/9/2011): A suspect was caught. He was arrested on charges of breaking-and entering, larceny and possession of stolen goods.

Company: Franklin County Children Services, Parenthesis Family Advocates
Description of incident: A boxes of files were found by a recycling bin. ë_The files contained sensitive information from children with Franklin County Children Services. ë_Medical information, criminal records and other personal documents were left out in the open. ë_The papers have been linked to someone with access to Parenthesis' documents; however the cause of the breach is unknown.

Someone obtained employee names, addresses and possibly Social Security numbers. ë_Fraudulent accounts could be set up with this information. ë_Multiple city employees from different departments received bills from PayPal for purchases they did not make. ë_The fraudulent charges range from $40 to $3,000. ë_It is not clear how the thieves accessed Pittsburgh city employee information. Police officers and other Department of Public Safety employees are among those who were affected.

On May 25, University technology staff learned that unauthorized individuals had installed computer viruses on a University server. ë_It housed a software system for managing confidential information. ë_The names and Social Security numbers or people associated with the University could have been exposed. ë_There was no evidence that unauthorized parties had attempted to download the confidential information.

On August 2, a lecturer working in a student lab discovered that two files on a server could be accessed by faculty members, staffers and students from the College of Business Administration. ë_The files were confidential and included personal information such as names and Social Security numbers. ë_A total of 38 current and former faculty members were affected by the breach. ë_The University determined that the information had not been digitally copied by anyone.

Company: Department of Social and Health Services - Washington
Description of incident: A coding error caused mailing mistakes to be made in July. ë_Medical enrollment forms with the addresses of custodial parents were sent to non-custodial parents. ë_However, no addresses were disclosed in cases involving foster care of domestic violence.

A doctor lost a thumb drive that contained the personal health care information of 474 maternity patients. ë_It did not contain names, financial information or SSNs. ë_The thumb drive was returned to the doctor on June 11 by an anonymous sender. ë_The doctor had not realized it was missing and reported the incident to St. Francis on June 13. ë_The doctor was authorized to remove the thumb drive from the Hospital, but it should have been encrypted and password protected.

An unauthorized person broke into Purdue's computer system on April 5, 2010, and tried to use the server to attack other servers. ë_Purdue staff learned of the breach three days latter and began an assessment. The server was taken offline and staff later determined that Social Security numbers belonging to current and former students who took mathematics courses and a limited number of faculty, faculty family members and contractors were exposed. ë_The Social Security numbers were then matched to their owners and notification was sent to the Attorney General's office in June of 2011. ë_

Company: Reznick Group, AssureCare Risk Management Inc, Colonial Healthcare Inc, Gypsum Management and Supply
Description of incident: Reznick's former service provider AssureCare reported a breach of a server that contained Reznick information. ë_The information from employee benefits plans from 2001 to 2006 could have been accessed by outside parties. ë_Current and former employees and their spouses may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and medical information exposed. ë_The server was accessed by external intruders on May 9 and May 10 of 2011.UPDATEë_(10/13/2011): Employees enrolled in Gypsum's health and dental care plans were also affected.

Company: North Carolina State University (NCSU), Gardners Elementary School, Wells Elementary School, Ashley Chapel Elementary School
Description of incident: A server that contained data from school children in Wilson and Richmond counties was mistakenly put online. ë_The information was gathered between 2003 and 2006 as part of a research study on classroom practices. ë_It included names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth. ë_A concerned parent notified the state Department of Public Instruction after finding the information online. The error was fixed in July, though it is unclear how long the information was available online.

Anonymous has claimed responsibility for a hack of BART's user database. ë_A list with the first and last names, email addresses, passwords, phone numbers, full addresses and other personal information of MyBart.gov users was posted publicly. ë_MyBart.gov users should change their login information for other sites if they used the same login information for MyBart.gov. Anonymous exposed the security holes in BART's database in order to protest BART's temporary suspension of wireless service throughout BART stations. ë_BART had already been criticized for disabling wireless service in an attempt to counter protests over a fatal officer-involved shooting. ë_The MyBart.gov homepage was also defaced.

The Bethesda website was hacked sometime during the weekend of June 11. ë_User names, email addresses and passwords may have been exposed. ë_Users should change their login information for other sites if they used the same login information for Bethesda. ë_The hacker group LulzSec claimed that it had obtained the personal data of over 200,000 users of the game Bethesda game Brink.

Company: Jackson Memorial Hospital, Jackson Health System
Description of incident: An unidentified former employee inappropriatelyë_accessed the the financial information of hospital patients. ë_The employee was fired and the department they worked in was not revealed.

Someone noticed a pile of discarded paperwork and informed a local news station after it had not been removed within a week. Documents with the personal information of dozens of former St. Louis University students were exposed near a dumpster in a back alley. ë_Most appeared to date back to the mid 1990's and correspond to library fines for late or lost books. ë_An SLU security team picked up the papers after hearing about the incident.

Bethesda's website was hacked for the second time in three months. ë_No groups have claimed responsibility for the hack. ë_The breach affected Bethesda's forum user database and occurred on the morning of August 12. ë_Information in the database was encrypted, but all user forum passwords were reset as a precaution. ë_Bethesda is recommending that users alter their passwords for other sites if they were similar to the ones used in the forum.

On April 12, 2011 a report containing the personal information of customers was inadvertently mislabeled and emailed to an incorrect broker-dealer. ë_The report contained information about customer transactions during March 2011. ë_Names, policy numbers, policy values, transaction dates and transaction amounts were exposed. ë_An internal review on May 2 uncovered the breach.ë_

Company: The Health Plan of San Mateo (HPSM)
Description of incident: Member notifications of approval of medical procedures were sent to the incorrect addresses. ë_Each approval letter contained the member's name, address, service requested, and HPSM member ID number. ë_The mistake was discovered on June 9, 2011 and the programming error that caused it was immediately fixed. ë_

Two laptop computers were discovered missing from Mount Sinai's office in Long Island City, Queens. ë_A public notice was made on July 11 of 2011. ë_The laptops contained the names, Social Security numbers and diagnosis information of patients. ë_Mount Sinai encrypted all hard drives that contained confidential information in order to protect patients in the future.

A May 2011 website breach of a third party vendor may have compromised the credit card transaction data of Eye Safety Systems' customers. ë_Customer names, phone numbers, email addresses, addresses, and credit card information may have been accessed. ë_Customers were notified on May 28 and Eye Safety Systems took measures to improve online security.

Two malware pieces were discovered on Energy Federation's server on July 12. ë_They appear to have been inserted on July 7 and July 10. ë_The purpose of the malware was to collect information on the server. Customer names, credit card numbers and expiration dates, and contact information could have been exposed. ë_At least 20 New Hampshire residents were affected by the breach, but the total number of affected customers nationwide was not revealed.

A former waiter was indicted on charges of copying and selling the numbers from 73 customer credit cards. ë_The 16 charges include theft, identity theft, and conspiracy to commit theft. ë_The former employee is believed to have used a skimmer to copy the credit card numbers of restaurant patrons between December of 2009 and April 2010. ë_The employee was caught when two Secret Service employees who had eaten at the restaurant noticed unauthorized charges on their credit cards. ë_

Company: University of Hawaii - Kapi'olani Community College
Description of incident: A worker noticed that boxes of sensitive financial records were out of place. ë_Some boxes were discovered to be missing and officials began searching for them on July 1. ë_The breach was reported to students during the first week of August. ë_It is unclear when the boxes were taken and there was no sign of forced entry into the area where they were stored. ë_The files contained names, addresses, Social Security numbers and credit cards. ë_People who made transactions with credit cards between February and November of 2010 for non-credit classes, transcript requests, or payment of non-resident fees were effected. ë_

A hacker or hackers were able to access Country Corner's website and obtain customer information. ë_Customers may have been tricked into giving their financial information through emails that appeared to be from Country Corner, a fake Country Corner website set up by hackers, or some other method of phishing. ë_It is also possible that customer data was taken directly from Country Corner's computer system. ë_Customers began reporting fraudulent charges and Country Corner's computer system was discovered to contain malware.

A BART Police Officers Association database was hacked. ë_The names, postal addresses and email addresses of officers were posted online. A French national claimed responsibility for the hack and described the BART site as having zero security in place.

A computer file containing the names and Social Security numbers of former faculty, staff and students was accidentally made accessible online. ë_The file contained information from 1999 and could be located through a Google search for 10 months. ë_A change in Google's search engine made the file accessible from September 2010 to July 1, 2011. ë_A person who performed a Google search on his name discovered the breach on June 30.

Hundreds of inmates could have viewed the names and Social Security numbers of guards at Fort Dodge. ë_The information was located inside a desk in an area used as an inmate barber shop. ë_The area was once used as an office, but the furniture was not checked, cleaned or removed before the conversion. ë_The information had been sitting in the desk for three or four months before an officer found it.

Company: Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Flower Mound, Texas Health Partners
Description of incident: An employee's company-issued laptop was stolen on June 21, 2011. ë_The theft was reported immediately, but the laptop was not recovered. ë_It contained 1) physical descriptions such as age, gender, weight, and height, 2) medical information such as date and time of admission, date and time of laboratory order, lab results, dates of service, diagnosis, discharge instruction and summary, name of physician, insurance, procedure, room number, medical history, and medical record number, and 3) personal information that included employer, marital status, phone number, name of account guarantor, and Social Security number for a small number of patients.

A laptop was discovered missing while another breach was being investigated. ë_The two breaches appear to be unrelated. ë_Consultants may have had their names, addresses and bank account information exposed. ë_At least 27 New Hampshire residents were notified of the breach, but the total number of affected people nationwide was not reported.

An unidentified suspected may have accessed the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and bank account information of 28 consultants. ë_The breach was discovered when commission funds were fraudulently transferred into an unfamiliar bank account; this occurred over two commission cycles in late 2010. ë_The cause of the breach is not known.

LulzSec has claimed responsibility for a hack of AZDPS. ë_Hundreds of private intelligence bulletins, training manuals, personal email correspondence, names, phone numbers, addresses and passwords belonging to Arizona law enforcement and spouses were released. ë_LulzSec targeted the AZDPS in order to protest SB1070, an Arizona policy they call racial profiling and anti-immigrant.UPDATEë_(6/30/2011): A second computer attack affected the personal email addresses and passwords of officers. The initial breach of official AZDPS email accounts allowed a hacking group to access the outside accounts of some officers. ë_Hackers were able to post some of the information from the personal accounts, including email messages and pictures.

Company: Citigroup, Inc., Bank of America, Corp.
Description of incident: A breach of an unnamed merchant or merchants may have resulted in the exposure of customer credit and debit card information. ë_Citigroup deactivated the credit cards of affected customers and notified them that Citigroup had been informed of a security breach at a retailer. ë_Within a week, Bank of America also sent new debit cards to some customers after learning that some accounts may have been compromised at a merchant.

Company: Living Healthy Clinic, University of Wisconsin - Oshkosh College of Nursing
Description of incident: A computer security breach that occurred in July may have exposed the information of uninsured Winnebago County residents who sought health services. ë_The information included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and the health records of a limited number of people. The breach was discovered when University technology staff identified evidence of a computer virus on a desktop computer. There was no indication that unauthorized parties attempted to download information.

On June 16, 2011, meridianEMR announced that it had filed a lawsuit against Intuitive Medical Software (UroChart). ë_meridianEMR's Advanced Monitoring System detected copying activities on meridianEMR's server. ë_meridianEMR immediately contacted Intuitive in response to the discovery. ë_A second group called The Shappley Clinic was also accused of accessing meridianEMR's data and placing patients in meridianEMR's system at risk. ë_The lawsuit contends that UroChart and another party have and have had unlawful access to patient information in violation of patient privacy rights. ë_UroChart is accused of violating New Jersey's Computer Related Offenses Act and behaving willfully and intentionally with malice.

An employee took a laptop home without authorization. ë_It contained patient names, dates of birth, the last four digits of patient Social Security numbers, and medical diagnoses. ë_The employee's actions were not believed to be intentionally malicious.

A thief stole a petty cash lockbox from Northwestern Counseling's office sometime between June 18 and June 27. ë_The lockbox contained cash, as well as itemized receipts with client Social Security numbers. ë_Affected clients were notified of the breach in early July.

Company: Lincoln Financial Group, Lincoln National Life Insurance Company, Lincoln Life and Annuity Company of New York
Description of incident: A programming error caused the names and Social Security numbers of current and former retirement plan enrollees to be accessible to unauthorized plan administrators. ë_The error had existed in the database's search function since October 2009. ë_A plan administrator notified Lincoln Financial Group of the issue on July 18. ë_

A personal financial representative lost his laptop on May 23, 2011, and then reported the loss to Allstate Financial on June 13, 2011. ë_Customer policy information may have been stored on the laptop's hard drive. ë_On July 25, customers were notified that their policy information may have been exposed.
Loan account numbers were printed on the outside of envelopes sent to customers. ë_The account numbers were on the line just above customer name and address.

Company: Hawaii State Department of Public Safety
Description of incident: A reporter requested statistics from the State Department of Public Safety. ë_Though the reporter only wanted the number of people who use medical marijuana, he was sent an email with patient names, addresses, plant locations, certificate numbers, and the names of prescribing physicians. ë_Patients became aware of the issue when information was printed in a front-page news story, though no patients were identified.

Company: Child Protective Services, Texas Department of Family and Protective Services
Description of incident: An administrative technician working for Child Protective Services under the Texas Department of Family and Protective Services misused the personal information of at least 70 adoptive and foster parent applicants. ë_The dishonest employee would exchange the information for gifts and money and another person used the information to make fake drivers' licenses. ë_This allowed fraudulent credit card accounts to be opened in victims' names. ë_Both people were caught.

A 21-year old was sentenced to jail after it was discovered that he had broken into his high school's computer system in 2008. ë_He stole tests and changed his grades. Heë_was ordered to pay $15,000, serve 30 days in jail and serve 500 hours of community service.UPDATE (8/26/2011):ë_The former student successfully paid the fine in August.

A former judge was arrested for making false statements to a federal agent. ë_The former judge was attempting to reopen an eating-disorder clinic and tossed old records into a nearby dumpster in June of 2010. ë_Authorities found 15 to 20 boxes of papers with patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, medical complaints, medical diagnosis, treatment information and other health information. ë_When a federal agent asked the former judge about the boxes, he responded that they contained business information without any sensitive medical information.

At least 60 patients had their records stolen by a billing technician during late 2010. ë_The information included names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses and health insurance policy numbers. ë_Many patients who used Medicare Advantage plans at the clinic were affected. ë_The former employee and an accomplice also forged the names of three doctors on prescription forms. ë_The patient prescription information was then used to obtain narcotic prescription drugs worth thousands of dollars. ë_The former employee was sentenced to five years in prison. ë_

Private emails from police officers and other information may have been exposed after the Texas Police Chief Association website was hacked. ë_The hacking group Anonymous claimed responsibility for the attack as retaliation for the arrest of dozens of people suspected of being involved with Anonymous. ë_Specifically, Anonymous claimed that "For every defendant in the Anonymous 'conspiracy' we are attacking two top Texas police chiefs, leaking 3GB of their private emails and attachments."

A couple who worked with New Horizons pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit false statements relating to health care matters. ë_They each face up to five years in prison, a $250,000 fine, and the possibility of restitution. ë_From at least January 1999 through April 2010, they defrauded the Texas Medicaid program by using the names and Social Security numbers of at least 12 inmates and other persons to create "ghost" employees for New Horizons. ë_The false time sheets and inaccurate payroll reports allowed the couple to collect pay checks from the "ghost" employees. ë_One member of the couple also submitted false claims for ICF/MR services to Medicaid. ë_A total of $1,820,359 was fraudulently obtained from the Texas Medicaid program. ë_ ë_

Two students may face criminal charges for hacking into the Birdville School District's network server and accessing a file with 14,500 student names and Social Security numbers. ë_The students are a high school junior and a senior. ë_Students who attended during the 2008-2009 school year may have been affected.

Company: North Macomb PLUS Office, Southwest Macomb PLUS Office
Description of incident: Almost 14,000 documents related to drivers license and state identification applications were stolen from two separate offices over a total of two years. ë_The applications included names, dates of birth, addresses, and in some cases Social Security numbers. ë_The documents were stolen in May or June from secured areas at the North Macomb PLUS Office in Chesterfield Township and from the Southwest Macomb PLUS Office in Warren. ë_The information dates back to 2009.

Harvard's switch to Google "@college" email accounts resulted in the potential compromise of some student emails. ë_Fewer than ten students reported that emails from other students with similar names were forwarded to them. ë_The problem occurred because the email system did not distinguish between the older "@fas" accounts and the newer "@college" accounts. ë_For example, the system would forward emails from ctucker@fas.harvard.edu to the new address of ctucker@college.harvard.com even if the "@harvard" email had been taken by a different student. Students with "@harvard" emails also had their emails forwarded to other students'ë_accounts.

A laptop with sensitive information was stolen from a physician's car on Tuesday, August 16 of 2011. ë_It contained patient information such as name, age, sex, diagnosis, medical record number, and in 178 cases, Social Security numbers. ë_Individuals were notified on September 2.

Three people are accused of using cancer and transplant patient files from Methodist Hospital to make fraudulent purchases. ë_A dishonest employee took the birth dates and Social Security numbers of patients and passed them along to two co-conspirators. ë_The trio then opened accounts and took out loans in the names of at least five patients. ë_They face life in prison if convicted.

The medical records of about 20,000 emergency room patients were posted on a commercial website for nearly a year. ë_It is unclear how the spreadsheet with names, account numbers, admission and discharge dates, billing charges and diagnosis codes came to be on the website. ë_The information was not financially sensitive. ë_The website was called "Student of Fortune" and allowed students to pay for assistance with their school work. ë_The spreadsheet was posted in relation to a question about how to convert the data into a bar graph. ë_A former patient reported the availability of the spreadsheet on August 22.UPDATEë_(10/3/2011): A class-action lawsuit for $20 million has been filed against Stanford University Hospitals and Clinics (SHC) and Multi-Speciality Collection Services, LLC (MSCS). It was filed on September 28 and about $1,000 for each of the 20,000 affected is sought. ë_MSCS is a former billing vendor of SHC and was operating under a contract that specifically required it to protect the privacy of patient information. ë_ ë_UPDATEë_(10/5/2011): The source of the breach was confirmed by the Hospital and contractors. ë_MSCS's marketing agent sent the electronic spreadsheet to a job prospect as part of a skills test. ë_The applicant asked for help through the Student of Fortune website. ë_
A computer was stolen on or around July 29, 2011. ë_It contained the protected health information of 1,200 patients who visited for outpatient alcohol and drug treatment services.

Company: Austin Center for Therapy and Assessment
Description of incident: The July 8 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure ofë_private patient information. ë_Patient names, addresses, Social Security numbers and treatment information may have been obtained from the stolen laptop.

The VA believes an employee's office at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Biloxi was inappropriately accessed without proper authorization on July 21. ë_A number of medical files with veteran names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and other personal information like medical diagnoses were found spread on the office floor. ë_The breach could affect veterans, deceased veterans and VA employees in seven counties in southern Mississippi, four counties in southern Alabama, and seven counties in the Florida Panhandle.ë_

An August 12 office burglary resulted in the loss of several computers and a main computer server with patient information. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, insurance information, and medical records may have been exposed. ë_

A nurse was arrested and charged with grand larceny, ID theft, and scheming to defraud several elderly patients. ë_The nurse collected patient information and texted it to a co-conspirator. ë_The co-conspirator then used the information to obtain fraudulent tax returns in the names of the victims. ë_Over 30 of the 83 victim records found at the co-conspirator's home were from the Brandywyne Health Center.

Dishonest employees who worked at an unnamed dental office and an unnamed law office in the Bay Area were part of an identity theft ring. ë_A total of seven people are facing charges for their involvement in the ring. ë_The charges include identity theft, conspiracy, possession of stolen property, and grand theft. ë_Over $170,000 in cash and fraudulent purchases was taken through the use of sensitive patient and client information from the dental office and law office. ë_UPDATEë_(9/06/2011): The former employee of the dental office was sentenced. He will serve four years in prison for supplying patient information between June and December of 2009. ë_The information was then used to create false driver's licenses and to file illegal change-of address forms. ë_

Sensitive student athlete medical records were misplaced by a coach who was transplanting them to an athletic event. ë_A recently released prisoner found the documents and attempted to sell them back to the University for $20,000. ë_The man was caught, pled guilty to extortion, and was sentenced to two years in prison.

Company: Montgomery County Department of Job and Family Services
Description of incident: A flash drive with sensitive information was discovered missing on August 24. ë_It contained the names and Social Security numbers of people who sought assistance from the Transition Center. ë_

On September 9, Guilford County became aware of the accidental placement of Tax Department files online. ë_The names, bank account numbers, Social Security numbers, and addresses of citizens who had garnishments from the Tax Department were available online. ë_The mistake affected people who submitted checks to the Tax Department between July 2010 and December 2010. ë_The information was available as early as December of 2010 and taken down on September 9 of 2011.UPDATEë_(9/16/2011): At least 1,000 people were affected by the breach.

A CD with sensitive Non-Appropriated Fund retiree information was lost in the mail between Alexandria, Virginia and San Antonio, Texas. ë_The CD never officially arrived after being sent during the last week of August. ë_It contained retiree records with names, Social Security numbers, retirement date, type of retirement, amount of life insurance carried, term data, dates of service, and other retirement data.

Records Breached: Unknown (95 confirmed email addresses and names)
Description of incident: Hackers posted the names and email addresses of hundreds of U.S. Intelligence officials. ë_At least 95 individuals with email addresses from the high security National Security Agency were affected, as well as many others in key positions at the White House, Pentagon, CIA, FBI, the Office of Director of National Intelligence and the State Department. ë_Hundreds of executives at major government contracting firms that specialize in national security projects also had their names, emails, and possibly telephone numbers exposed and work addresses exposed. ë_These organizations include Northrop Grunman, Boeing, General Dynamics, SAIC and CACI.

A minor working at a McDonald's drive-thru repeatedly used a skimming device to obtain the credit card numbers of customers. ë_The dishonest employee swiped credit cards in the skimmer as customers paid for their meals throughout July and August. ë_The credit card information was then used by identity thieves to create duplicate cards with false names. ë_Investigators are actively looking for more victims. ë_Those who may have been affected should call the Sheriff's Office (763) 682-7733.

Over 50 employees of the California State Assembly were warned that their personal information may have been obtained by a hacker. ë_Some lawmakers were affected by the breach. ë_On Friday, officials learned that one of the servers had been breached. ë_It appears that the goal of the hacker or hackers was to overload the Capitol's Internet service. ë_People who participated in a flexible-benefits program were affected by the breach. ë_The type of data exposed was not reported.

A hacker gained unauthorized access to Vacationland Vendors' card processing systems at Wilderness Waterpark Resort in the Dells and Wilderness at the Smokies in Sevierville. ë_The breach occurred on march 22. ë_Customers who used a credit or debit card at one of the resorts between December 12, 2008 and May 25, 2011 were affected. ë_

A man posing as a vendor took two barrels of old X-ray film. ë_The film contained medical data from over five years ago. ë_It had been put aside for destruction or recycling. ë_Authorities believe the thief wanted to extract the silver contained in the films.

The actions of at least one dishonest employee put the personal information of thousands of homeowners into the hands of identity thieves. ë_People who purchased an ADT home security system through Tampa Signal in February may have had their information sold by one or more employees. ë_The personal information exposed included Social Security numbers and dates of birth. ë_fraudulent tax returns were filed in the names of an unknown number of victims. ë_

Company: Ashley Industrial Molding, Inc., AssureCare Risk Management (ARM)
Records Breached: 506 (Unknown number of SSNs and financial information)
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers were able to access Ashley Industrial Molding benefit plan information through AssureCare Risk Management (ARM) on August 9. ë_It is unclear if this incident is related to the ARM incident reported here on August 12, 2011.

A mail sorting machine mistake caused sensitive information to be mailed to unintended patients. ë_The breach was discovered when a patient opened a letter that contained her name and address, but the financial assistance application of a different patient. ë_Names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, and Social Security numbers were exposed.

A May 22 office burglary resulted in the loss of three computers with patient information. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, and other personal information were exposed. ë_A notification dated June 15 was posted on Yanez's website.

Company: Veterans Affairs Illiana Health Care System
Description of incident: An appointment book was discovered missing on July 14. ë_It contained the last names and last four digits of veterans' Social Security numbers. ë_It is unclear where the book was taken from, but it is clear that it was not properly safeguarded.

Company: Medassets Inc., Saint Barnabas Health Care System, Cook County Health and Hospitals (CCHHS)
Description of incident: An external computer hard drive was stolen from a MedAsset employee's car on June 24. ë_MedAsset provides administrative and business services to medical centers. ë_The hard drive contained the personal information of patients who were being considered for governmental benefits at six Saint Barnabas acute care hospitals and patient information from Cook County Health and Hospitals System in Chicago. ë_Patient names, medical center account numbers, medical record numbers, dates of birth, medical center charges, amount paid, health insurance information and discharge dates were exposed. ë_Approximately seven percent of the Saint Barnabas System patients who were affected had their Social Security numbers exposed as well. ë_The six Saint Barnabas Health Care System clinics are:Clara Maass Medical Center - 8,795Community Medical Center - 6,950Kimball Medical Center - 6,785Monmouth Medical Center - 6,443Newark Beth Israel Medical Center - 15,015Saint Barnabas Medical Center - 6,179Also, 32,008 CCHHS patients were affected.

Company: United States Steel and Carnegie Pension Fund, Benefits Administration Services
Description of incident: A CD with the names, Social Security numbers and dates of birth of U.S. Steel Mining retirees and dependents was lost in the mail. ë_Benefits Administration Services (BAS) mailed the CD in August, but it was not received. ë_BAS is still working with the U.S. Postal service to recover the CD.

Students and prospective students who enrolled in or applied to courses in UTSA's Honors College may have had their information exposed. ë_On August 2, a UTSA employee discovered that a system misconfiguration allowed unauthorized users to access names, dates of birth, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, GPAs and other personal information of students and prospective students. Between June 20 and August 2, Honors College users as well as all other UTSA employees with access to the online system could view student information.

At least 16 people reported fraudulent credit card charges after using their cards at the restaurant. ë_The fraudulent charges total $20,000. ë_The owners of the restaurant were evicted for not paying rent and have not been located. ë_Former employees of the restaurant are still waiting for their final paychecks.

Bright House servers which process Video on Demand (VOD) orders were breached. ë_Historical customer data from as far back as June 22, 2011 was exposed. ë_Customer names, addresses, phone numbers, and Bright House Network account numbers could have been exposed. ë_Customers were notified in September.

A hacker accessed a database of sensitive customer information. ë_An Excel spreadsheet with usernames, passwords, email addresses, company names, and other types of personal or business information of 20,000 people was posted online on August 22. No credit cards were accessed and the website was closed until all passwords were changed.

Company: Summit Medical Group, Emory Family Practice, Fountain City Family Physicians, Office of Dr. Kenneth Reese
Description of incident: The September 4 theft of documents from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of patient names and diagnoses. ë_The car was parked at the employee's home. ë_Summit Medical Group account numbers, dates of birth, primary physician's names, names of hospitals, and dates of discharges were exposed.

Hundreds of sensitive dental patient records were found by a street sweeper. ë_They were scattered near a dumpster behind a shopping center. ë_The records appear to be from a dental practice in Lone Tree, a 20 mile journey. ë_The party responsible for the breach is unknown. ë_Billing records with patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses were exposed.

Company: First Priority Life Insurance Company, Blue Cross of Northeastern Pennsylvania, Penn Foster
Description of incident: Around 500 employees were affected by the home theft of a laptop and sensitive papers. ë_A Blue Cross business associate took home reports that contained names, Social Security numbers, and addresses of First Priority policyholders. ë_The reports and laptop were stolen while the home was vacated due to flooding. ë_The laptop was recovered a few days later.

Hundreds of paper patient forms were compromised in May. ë_An off-duty Tampa police officer discovered the records in a Motel 6 in May. The occupants of the motel room were detained on identity theft charges. ë_The forms contained patient names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. The papers included Turbo Tax cards, receipts, and medical records from the Veterans Affairs hospital. At least one veteran had a fraudulent debit card charge.ë_

An unauthorized person may have gained access to Genentech's list of personal information for patients who used Genentech assistance to pay for their drugs. ë_The breach was discovered on August 17. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, email addresses, driver's licence numbers, medical information, and health insurance information may have been exposed. ë_
The theft of a laptop on or around August 11, 2011 resulted in the exposure of protected health information.

Company: Health Research Institute, Inc., Pfeiffer Treatment Center
Description of incident: The July 1, 2011 theft of a desktop computer and network server resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Protected health information from a network server was breached on or around August 8, 2011. ë_The incident may have been an unintended disclosure which allowed unauthorized users to view information, or it may ahve been a hacking attack.

NEA's former public website was compromised by a hacker or hackers on July 12, 2011. ë_People who previously registered with the website in order to use the website's special functions may have had their email addresses and user name and password combinations exposed. ë_Some individuals also had their names, addresses, and dates of birth compromised. ë_Since passwords may have been obtained, individuals who may have been affected should not use their NEA website password for any other accounts.

The theft of a laptop from a nurse's car may have exposed names, dates of birth, genders, Medicaid client identification numbers, procedure codes, diagnoses codes, and other health information. ë_The theft took place on March 10, 2011, but it was not until August that the risk to patient privacy was discovered. ë_A notice was sent on September 9.

Company: Neurological Institute of Savannah and Center for Spine (NIOS)
Description of incident: The July 2 car theft of a computer hard drive may have exposed patient information. ë_Patients who visited NIOS between January 1, 2006 and July 2, 2011 could have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, telephone numbers, and billing account data obtained.ë_

Dozens of students had their names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, and dropout likelihood posted online for several months. ë_The dropout likelihood was included in reports along with other personal details such as academic problems, homelessness, and history of running away from home. ë_The reports were never meant to be posted and a note that read "All student information is confidential. This report must be SHREDDED when no longer in use" was clearly visible at the bottom of each report. ë_An administrator accidentally changed the SAISD site settings and exposed the information at an unspecified time. ë_The total number of students affected was not reported, but it appears that several reports each contained confidential information for 60-70 students. ë_Students appeared in multiple reports.

Company: Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), Financial Tracking Technologies (FTT)
Description of incident: FTT, a contractor working with SEC's ethics compliance program, violated its agreement with SEC by providing names and account numbers to a subcontractor, or subcontractors without permission. ë_An SEC September 16 security review revealed that FTT had failed to comply with contractual obligations. ë_The system was taken offline and FTT was told to terminate all third party access to SEC systems.

It appears that the Social Security Administration accidentally releases the names, Social Security numbers, and birth dates of thousands of living U.S. citizens each year in a database called the "Death Master File". ë_Social Security officials revealed that the number of U.S. citizens mistakenly listed each year is about 14,000, while 90 million are accurately reported. ë_A Scripps Howard News Service review of three recent copies revealed 31,931 living U.S. citizens who'd had their Social Security numbers released to U.S. business groups.

Microfilm that contained the plan enrollment information of benefits members was lost by a delivery service sometime between February and May of 2011.ë_ It contained names, addresses, dates of birth and in some cases Social Security numbers and limited medical information from the 1960's and 1970's.ë_ A vendor received the microfilm from CPS on February 3rd.ë_ The vendor attempted to transfer the microfilm to another company, but learned that the microfilm had been misplaced sometime prior to or during May.ë_ CPS's vendor informed them of the situation on August 23.

Hundreds of sheets were found inside of folders in improperly discarded boxes.ë_ The sheets were easily visible and accessible through sliding doors on 
either side of the dumpster and a firefighter alerted a local newspaper 
to the incident.ë_ The records contained names, Social Security numbers, payroll information, addresses, phone numbers, insurance information, dates of birth, and medical histories from employees and former patients of the Ambulance Association.ë_ It appears that all of the records are from 2003 and 2004.ë_ An Ambulance Association officer admitted to placing the boxes in a dumpster rather than following usual procedure and shredding them.

The August 24 office theft of a hard drive resulted in the exposure of patient information.ë_ No patient information was believed to have been exposed, but an investigation of the breach revealed that the hard drive had been stolen along with a laptop and a desktop computer.ë_ It contained information from people who received Spectrum program services at the Westborough, Worcester, Milford, Framingham, Southbridge, Fitchburg, and Weymouth locations between 2002 and March of 2011.ë_ Inpatient and outpatient names, Social Security numbers, diagnostic codes, medical insurance numbers, addresses, phone numbers, and dates of birth were exposed.

Company: International Association of Chiefs of Police (IACP), Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, Baldwin County Sheriff's Office in Alabama, Matrix Group
Description of incident: Factions of Anonymous and Antisec posted sensitive law enforcement files on the internet on Friday October 21.ë_ Data from multiple law enforcement vendors' and agencies' computer systems were compromised.ë_ At least four groups were affected.ë_ An IACP membership roster , Birmingham and Jefferson County police officer names, Social Security numbers, ranks, addresses, and phone numbers, Matrix Group client and financial information, and data from an unnamed web design and marketing firm with law enforcement customers were exposed.

A mailing error exposed customer bank account information to other customers.ë_ Pages from other customer accounts which included bank account numbers, balances, and transactions were accidentally mailed to other customers in September paper statements.ë_ The error was caused by a printer malfunction.ë_ Wells Fargo temporarily took the printer out of service after the breach was discovered.ë_ At least 50 customers noticed the problem.

An abandoned Indalex plant still contained personnel records. Employee names, Social Security numbers, medical records, addresses, and other sensitive information were exposed when scavengers looking for aluminum and other materials ravaged the abandoned plant.ë_ The plant was closed in 2008 and Indalex filed for bankruptcy in 2009.ë_ Indalex received clearance from a bankruptcy court to officially abandon the plant in 2010.ë_ The damage was discovered when 40 workers from the Stanislaus County jail alternative work program cleared the plant.ë_

A police officer was linked to a tax fraud ring.ë_ The officer accessed the Drivers And Vehicle Information Database (DAVID) in order to give the personal information of around 149 drivers to co-conspirators.ë_ The information was then used to open 184 bank accounts where fraudulent tax return checks could be cashed. An investigation was opened when the insider attempted to recruit someone else.ë_ The insider was suspended without pay until the investigation is completed.
The July 27 theft of a binder exposed patient information.ë_ The binder contained surgical patient labels from August 2004 to July 2011, corresponding dates of birth, and medical record numbers.
A computer with sensitive patient information was stolen sometime between August 5 and August 7.ë_ It held patient names, physician names, medical record numbers, and genotype test results.ë_

A hacker accessed the restaurant's computer system in early August and infected it with a virus.ë_ Customer debit and credit card numbers to be sent to outside parties.ë_ The virus was not discovered until mid-October.ë_ Over 60 of the credit and debit numbers that were duplicated to fraudulent cards were used in Florida.ë_

A breach of a data processor affected Clarinda Bank Iowa.ë_ The type of breach was not reported, and it is possible that other banks were affected by the data processor breach.ë_ Specific bank customers were notified of the breach by letter on October 25.

The information of hundreds of people was discovered in a trash storage location.ë_ The documents appear to be connected to employees of a defunct restaurant named Indigo Joes'.ë_ Paycheck stubs, Social Security numbers, Driver's licenses, and other personal information were discovered.

As many as 5,000 users of the Department of Education's website may have had their information viewed by other users who logged in to the website.ë_ The breach lasted for six to seven minutes and exposed Social Security numbers and other student information.ë_ The site was shut down and examined for 48 hours after the incident.

An anonymous tipster alerted reporters to a breach that allowed the personal information of journalists covering the Pan American Games to be viewed.ë_ The tipster claimed that reporter names, dates of birth, the first five digits of passports, photos, family numbers, and addresses were accessible.ë_ Reporters from across the Americas were affected.ë_ The Guadalajara 2011 Organizing Committee stated that they had deleted the personal information from their database after the discovery.

Seven Holy Cross employees fell for phishing attempts.ë_ The employees had their email accounts attacked and emails containing personal information for hundreds of people were exposed.ë_ Though Holy Cross has a policy of encrypting all emails that contain personal information, these emails were not encrypted.ë_ Those who could have been affected were notified that their Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, dates of birth, financial information and other types of information were at risk.ë_
The September 25 home theft of an employee's laptop resulted in the exposure of PSEG employee information.ë_ Names, Social Security numbers and other personnel information were exposed.ë_

An unecrypted flash drive with sensitive employee information was lost during transportation.ë_ It was mailed to the company's 401k provider, Milliman, on September 8.ë_ An envelope arrived on September 12 without the flash drive.ë_ Employees were notified on October 5.ë_ Current and former employees may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, dates of hire, and compensation amounts from 2009 and 2010 exposed.

An employee who worked at three different branches for Community & Southern Bank was indicted on five counts of theft by taking and seven counts of identity fraud.ë_ The dishonest employee was fired after an internal audit uncovered discrepancies.ë_ Police allege that the employee took $60,000 from client bank accounts, and the total taken could be more than $100,000 if fraudulent loans are included.ë_ Most customers who were affected had fraudulent withdrawals and loans under $1,000.

Company: St. Joseph Medical Center, Baxter, Baker, Sidle, Conn & Jones
Description of incident: A Baltimore law firm called Baxter, Baker, Sidle, Conn and Jones lost a hard drive with patient records.ë_ It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, medical records, addresses, dates of birth, and insurance information.ë_ The law firm was using the medical records of patients who were suing a cardiologist at St. Joseph Medical Center.ë_ The hard drive was lost by an employee during travel on August 4.ë_ Patients were informed in early October.
A laptop was stolen from an employee on August 27.ë_ It contained the names, Social Security numbers, and credit card account numbers of some customers.ë_ Notifications were mailed on September 28.ë_

Company: High Point Regional Health System, Premier Imaging LLC
Description of incident: A former employee was fired after taking patient files home sometime between September 14 and October 6.ë_ The files contained patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, driver's license numbers and insurance information.ë_ A total of 47 patient records were returned, but it is unclear if the employee may still have others.

A physician kept 14 boxes of medical records from former patients in the front window of his building.ë_ A fire that struck the building, the Kunz Opera House, damaged the records and personal property.ë_ Some records were found in the street.ë_ An unspecified number of the damaged records were then buried in a secure location.ë_

Avia received notification of a breach involving an intruder or intruders using a password for the administrative software suite.ë_ The United State Secret Service became aware of the theft of a password that allowed outsider access to Avia Dental Plan member information.ë_ Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, credit card information, and in some cases dependent information, were exposed.

Company: Lawrence Memorial Hospital, Mid Continent Credit Servies, Inc. (Blue Sky Credit), BrickWire LLC
Description of incident: A breach of a website hosted by BrickWire LLC resulted in the exposure of patient names, phone numbers, email addresses, health care providers, payment amounts, dates of payment, credit card information and checking account information.ë_ Lawrence Memorial Hospital's vendor Blue Sky Credit used BrickWire LLC for the online bill-pay service offered to Lawrence Memorial's patients.ë_ The personal and financial information of patients who paid through the website was accidentally made available on the Internet between September 20, 2011 and October 28, 2011.ë_ UDPATE (11/17/2011): It appears that BrickWire left a portal open that contained payment records from 28 LMG patients after doing a system upgrade on September 20.ë_ However, the information of every patient who used the online bill pay system between 2005 and September of 2011 was available in a database that was accessible through the portal.ë_

The names, email addresses, and affiliations of certain people who registered with PRESENT e-Learning Systems' Podiatry program were posted online at Pastebin.com.ë_ An additional 86 people had their names and mailing addresses posted on Pastie.org after registering for a podiatry online tutoring course.ë_ A hacker called "Teku" claimed responsibility.

On September 6, X-ray films were stolen from the Hospital by thieves posing as representatives of an X-ray recycling vendor.ë_ The thieves were most likely looking to strip the silver from the old films.ë_ If any information had been taken from the X-rays it would include patient names, gender, dates of birth, dates of services, medical record numbers, and areas x-rayed.ë_

Company: Behavioral Health Services of Pickens County
Description of incident: A man who purchased a used computer hard drive discovered that it had detailed clinical assessments for patients referred to Behavioral Health Services of Pickens County and a monthly monitoring list of patient referrals from the Pickens County Department of Social Services.ë_ Information about patient drug and emotional problems and pending litigations was on the hard drive.

A man tried to steal X-rays.ë_ Investigators believe he wanted the X-rays for the tiny amount of silver inside rather than the protected health information of patients.ë_ The incident may have been related to other thefts in the Massachusetts and New Hampshire areas.ë_

A man was arrested for his role in the unauthorized collection and use of credit card numbers from over 200 Columbia County residents.ë_ Investigators began searching for a common link between the affected residents in August.ë_ Results of the investigation lead them to overseas activity in Russia and video surveillance from Wal-mart security.ë_

Brownsville ISD discovered that a number of employees had their names, Social Security numbers, disability plan information, and salary information available on a publicly accessible website.ë_ Employees who were enrolled for disability insurance had their information posted in April 2011 on the Employee Benefits/Risk Management website.ë_

ë_ Detailed medical information was discovered on the back of a drawing from a student of Hale Elementary.ë_ An attorney from Sawicki and Phelps donated the firm's old paper to her child's school. A local news team contacted the school after discovering the incident and additional pieces of paper were collected and stored in a secure location.ë_ The number of people affected was not revealed.

The October 14 car theft of an employee's laptop resulted in exposed physician and patient information.ë_ Though the laptop had a self-encrypting drive, it was not functioning properly.ë_ Patient and physician names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and bank account numbers or credit card numbers were exposed.ë_ Some patients also had unspecified medical information exposed as well.ë_

Thousands of patient records were stolen by a former employee.ë_ Names, ages, genders, Medicare coverage information, phone numbers, and dates of birth were exposed.ë_ The employee did not steal the records for ID theft purposes, but rather for their usefulness in contacting potential clients.ë_ The unnamed former employee owns a home health care agency.ë_

A laptop was stolen from the area of MS 399/MS 459.ë_ It contained student information from the 2009-2010 school year such as names, dates of birth, genders, heights, weights, body mass indexes, ethnicity, asthma diagnoses, and influenza vaccination information.
An employee's phone was lost or stolen on September 25, 2011.ë_ Patient health conditions, medical record numbers, and possibly even names could be accessed from the phone.ë_

A patient discovered their own personal information and that of 565 others online.ë_ Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth were exposed.ë_ A chiropractor from the Sitka Wellness Center claims that an electornic medical record software vendor known as EMR4Doctors.com stored the patient information for 9 months in 2008.ë_ The company stopped doing business in 2009.ë_ The information was removed from the Internet.

Contractors responsible for cleaning out the medical office after a storm improperly disposed of a computer that contained sensitive patient information.ë_ Lebanon Internal Medicine Associates left no specific instructions for the removal of the damaged computer.ë_ Patient information dating between November 1999 and August 25, 2011 was exposed and included full names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, account numbers, diagnoses, laboratory test results, and medical insurance information. It is believed that the information was inaccessible due to security measures within the server and flood damage.

On the weekend of October 21, 2011, a Medcenter One laptop computer and a bag containing 11 internal paper forms for processing patient charges were stolen from an employee's car along with valuable personal items.ë_ The forms contained patient name, date of birth, address, phone number, insurance company and policy number, Medicare number, and patient hearing diagnoses. The stolen laptop contained the names and dates of birth for 650 hearing aid patients from 2003 up to the time of the theft.ë_

Several former employees were found to have accessed patient information without authorization and taken the data to a competitor.ë_ Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, lab tests, and lab results were exposed.ë_ In January of 2010, BHL filed a lawsuit against Health Diagnostic Laboratory, Inc., and two former employees for trade secret violations and breach of contract.ë_

A janitor sold patient records to gang members.ë_ The janitor was able to use a master key to access boxes of sensitive information that were due to be shredded.ë_ Some of the locks to the restricted boxes were also broken.ë_ The scheme went on for up to eight months and investigators were able to seize nearly 30 patient records.

A glitch allowed nearly 400 workers from 2002 to 2011 to view the personal information of any employees in MassBay's worker database system.ë_ The information included Social security numbers, home addresses, and other personnel information.ë_

A student ran a Google search on her own name in mid-September and discovered some of her private information online.ë_ Skagit County Health Department was notified.ë_ People who used services at other county departments also had information exposed.ë_ The types of information did not include credit card numbers, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, or addresses, but did include information from receipts for department services.

Customers who used credit cards to sign up for WineLibrary.com may have had their financial information compromised.ë_ Wine Library began investigating the possibility of a breach in October when they received initial customer complaints.ë_ All credit card data was removed from the site on November 11th after an increase in customer complaints.ë_ The hacking incident(s) was traced back to China.

A software testing vendor was robbed of several computers on November 9.ë_ One of the computers contained personal information of YMCA members active in 2008.ë_ Addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, dates of birth, bank account numbers, and credit card numbers were exposed.ë_
A hacker named Kahuna posted three data dumps from the realty company.ë_ The names, email addresses, rental addresses, and payment information for approximately 625 renters were revealed.

A phishing attack exposed the personal information of users with domain names.ë_ The unauthorized access was discovered by 101domain.com when a vendor contacted them to inform them of a breach that affected multiple vendors, including 101Domain.com.ë_ UPDATE (12/20/2011): The websites 101domain.com, bluesit.com, free-domain.com, rerundomains.com, RWGUSA.com, and RWGUSA.net could have all been affected by a server breach at one of 101Domain, Inc.'s vendors.ë_ Encrypted customer names, addresses, email addresses, and in some cases, credit card or PayPal account information could have been compromised.ë_

Company: Jewish Community Services of South Florida
Description of incident: A coordinator at the Jewish Community Services office was arrested on charges of selling Holocaust survivor identity information.ë_ The dishonest employee misused access privileges to collect client names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth of clients who regularly seek help from the Holocaust Survivors Assistance program.ë_ A police informant was offered the information of five clients after contacting the dishonest employee.ë_ The informant told the employee that he wanted the information for tax fraud purposes and was able to obtain 30 identifications for $1,000.ë_ The dishonest employee was captured after handing over 32 sheets of identity information.

Several customers of the UCR Dining Services location reported fraudulent credit and debit card activity to UCR.ë_ On or around November 16, it became clear that registers at UCR food services locations were compromised by a cyber hacker.ë_ Anyone who used a card, including visitors, between the summer of 2011 and November 16, 2011 may have had their financial information obtained. The information includes cardholder names, numbers, expiration dates, and an encrypted version of debit PINs.

The College's On-Campus Student Employment System had a vulnerability that allowed student applicants to see the personal information of other students.ë_ A student applicant notified the College of the problem on November 2 after seeing the information of 12 other students.ë_ The system flaw was fixed within hours, but no duration was given for the breach.

Two students managed to obtain the login credentials for Blairsville High's online security system by repeatedly guessing.ë_ Their attempts began in May and were only discovered during the fall term when one of the students revealed his teacher's Social Security number in class.ë_ Teacher addresses, Social Security numbers, and salaries were exposed.

Documents containing the personal information of current and former student housing residents was stolen during a burglary at the Department of Student Housing office on November 30.ë_ Names, dates of birth, apartment numbers, email addresses, KU ID numbers, and other information, some of it related to student dependents, were on the documents.ë_ The number of affected students was not revealed, but those who were affected were told to be cautious of identity theft.

Residents who owed money to the county health department had their names inadvertently published in a public document.ë_ The names were published in a report to the Board of Supervisors dated July 27, 2010.ë_ The error was discovered at the end of November, 2011.ë_ No patient information was exposed, but the publication of the names in the report constitutes a breach of patient confidentiality laws.ë_ The information was removed from the online report.

Someone hacked into the Extreme Pizza computer system and took information from cards that had been swiped by Extreme Pizza. The thefts date back to September of 2011.ë_ Credit card transactions were moved to a different type of card reader in response to the breach.ë_

A laptop was stolen from an employee's office after a brief absence during working hours at a Dallas branch. The theft occurred on October 31 and those who were affected were notified on November 11. Some affected clients may have had their Social Security numbers exposed, but most could have had their names and account numbers exposed.ë_ Transcend Capital informed clients that their account numbers would be changed in response to the incident and that their accounts would be monitored for suspicious activity.ë_ Transcend Capital also implemented a policy of securing laptops to desks as a result of the breach.

A state government watchdog revealed that confidential personal information was located in an outdoor trash bin.ë_ The documents contained documents related to a job agency for Ohioans with disabilities.ë_ The extent of the breach and the cause of the breach are being investigated.

Some of AT&T's customers experienced coordinated hacking attacks. The hackers were trying to gain customer account information and appear to have used "auto script" technology to determine if AT&T telephone numbers were linked to online AT&T accounts.ë_ Fewer than 1% of customers were affected.ë_ No accounts were successfully breached.

A former employee's laptop was stolen during a home burglary sometime in mid November.ë_ On November 30, the District learned that the former employee's laptop contained confidential records.ë_ Current and former District employees had their names, Social Security numbers and other confidential information exposed.ë_ UPDATE (12/22/2011): It was revealed that a finance director loaded private information onto a personal laptop and took it home to finish work.ë_ Though the finance director's last day with the School District was September 2, 2011, the laptop still contained sensitive data when it was stolen on November 11.

A dishonest employee was arrested for using customer debit and credit card numbers to make online purchases.ë_ The employee was charged with 21 counts of deceptive practice, 21 counts of identity theft, four counts of felony theft, and 17 counts of misdemeanor theft.ë_ Anyone who used debit or credit cards at the Peoria Heights McDonald's between September 15 and October 30, 2011 may be at risk.ë_ The stolen account numbers came from CEFCU debit cards.

An employee was arrested for using a skimming device to collect customer credit card information.ë_ At least 16 people were affected, but more are expected to come forward.ë_ The dishonest employee was underage at the time of the crimes and was held on suspicion of identity theft and forgery.ë_ Customers who used cards at the McDonald's drive through between October 10 and November 9 of 2011 may have been affected.ë_ Investigators became aware of the breach when members of the Washington State Employees Credit Union began filing claims for fraudulent use of their credit cards.

A restaurant manager was found to have sold the identities of U.S. citizens to illegal aliens employed at multiple McDonald's restaurants.ë_ The employee was sentenced in U.S. District Court to 32 months in federal prison for her role in the identity theft scheme.ë_ Fourteen arrests were made and five suspects face federal identity theft charges.ë_ The rest were charged with immigration violations.ë_ It is unclear how many people were involved in the identity theft scheme. Other Mcdonald's managers also stole and sold the identities of U.S. citizens.

Company: Honolulu Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), East West Center
Description of incident: Members of Honolulu's APEC Host Committee may have had their personal information exposed after requesting security clearances to meet with President Barack Obama.ë_ Someone gained unauthorized access to eight East-West Center computers beginning on October 25 by using "unusually sophisticated methods." Committee member names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth could have been acquired.ë_

Between 2009 and July 2011, the owner of Community Tax used confidential information to file false tax returns through Community Tax.ë_ Nearly 1,400 tax returns were linked to the owner over those two years.ë_ On August 31, 2011, the owner was indicted on 32 counts. She faces between two and 27 years in prison, along with three or less years of supervised release, mandatory restitution, and up to $750,000 in fines or twice the cost of her crimes.The dishonest owner illegally obtained names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth, then used the information to file tax returns.ë_ The refunds from the tax returns went to her bank accounts and debit cards.ë_ She also used online filing websites to file false tax returns.ë_ The scheme was uncovered when a criminal complaint was filed.

A supervisor noticed a drive-thru cashier using a skimming device.ë_ The dishonest employee admitted to stealing the information from more than 100 customer cards, and stealing between 15 and 20 accounts during each drive-thru shift.ë_ Another person provided the skimming device and paid the employee $15 per credit account.

Company: Smith and Wollensky, Capital Grille, Wolfgang's Steakhouse, JoJo, Morton's, The Bicycle Club
Description of incident: An identity theft ring that targeted wealthy customers of steakhouses was uncovered.ë_ At least 28 current and former waiters and associates were arrested.ë_ Waiters used credit card skimmers to steal the credit card information of customers who paid with American Express Black cards and other high-limit credit cards.ë_ The crimes occurred between April 2010 and November 2011.ë_ At least 50 victims have been identified.

Company: The Public School Employees' Retirement System
Description of incident: About 2,000 pension fund members had their information placed online when an employee accidentally posted an unencrypted file on a public website.ë_ At least one person saw the information.ë_ The date of this error was not reported.ë_ Member names and Social Security numbers were exposed.ë_

The theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of customer names, Valley Credit Union account numbers, Social Security numbers, and addresses. The laptop was stolen outside of the office sometime before November 4.ë_ No information was given about the number of customers who were affected or who the laptop was stolen from.

Residents who applied for the Massachusetts Commonwealth Solar rebate program had their personal information posted on a government website for 50 minutes.ë_ One user accessed the file during the incident. Names and Social Security numbers were exposed.

An employee was caught with a skimming device after hotel guests complained about fraudulent charges on their credit and debit cards.ë_ The employee managed to get the information after cleaning the rooms of hotel guests. Hotel security was able to determine which employee had taken the credit card information by checking key card information for room activity.ë_ A hidden camera in a mock room showed that the employee was checking the personal belongings of guests and using the skimmer on any cards that were found.

A briefcase was stolen from an employee's car during lunch sometime during the spring of 2011.ë_ The briefcase contained a company laptop that had not yet been encrypted and paper copies of appointment schedules. The laptop contained the information of patients and providers from 18 practices. A recent backup of the laptop files revealed that 5,338 subscriber numbers, 2,777 names with no other information, and 222 names with associated Social Security numbers, dates of birth, subscriber numbers, and phone numbers had been on the laptop. Seventy of the 222 who had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, subscriber numbers, and phone numbers exposed also had their addresses exposed.

An employee took a flash drive with customer information on December 27, 2010.ë_ Someone at the former employee's new company noticed that files from Jeanne D'Arc were installed on a computer at the new company.ë_ Copies of the files were sent back to Jeanne D'Arc.ë_ Jeanne customer names, Social Security numbers, and loan account numbers were exposed.

Company: Amerigroup Community Care of New Mexico, Inc.
Description of incident: Papers were discovered stolen on or around July 15, 2011.

An employee was charged with selling the personal identities of disabled hospital patients.ë_ At least 22 military veterans who received services at the VA in Miami had their information sold.ë_ The employee was worked at the VA Travel Benefits Sections and had access to the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth of disabled veterans who had been reimbursed for travel expenses related to their medical treatment.ë_ The employee was caught late in 2010 after several veterans complained about unauthorized credit card accounts opened in their names.
CDs with personal information were discovered lost on or around August 24, 2011.ë_ Other items with personal information may have been lost as well.

Company: Logan County Emergency Ambulance Service Authority (LEASA)
Description of incident: A laptop was discovered missing on October 1, 2011.ë_ It was either lost or stolen.ë_ It contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and health information from patients. The laptop appears to have not been used to connect to the internet since October 1 and LEAS is attempting to block potential use of the device.

Company: Office of Gene S. J. Liaw, MD.
Description of incident: An unencrypted USB drive was determined to be missing on April 4, 2011. It contained patient names, Social Security number, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, diagnosis codes, and insurance information.ë_
X-ray records were discovered to have been improperly disposed of on or around October 1, 2011. Patient information may have been exposed.
A network server was discovered to have been stolen on or around September 30, 2011. It may have contained patient information.

A temporary employee of Metabasis Therapeutics was assigned to computer help-desk support in 2008.ë_ The dishonest employee somehow obtained unauthorized access to the names and personal-identification information of Metabasis Therapeutics employees and their relatives.ë_ The information was used to open credit cards; the credit cards were used to purchase travel packages, which were then resold. A total of $250,000 worth of Las Vegas air, hotel, and show-ticket packages were purchased on Travelocity.com. The former temporary employee was given a four year sentence in federal prison after being convicted for credit card fraud and aggravated identity theft.
Paper records were found to have been exposed to unauthorized parties on or around May 6, 2010.

Company: Office of Paul C. Brown, M.D., P.S.
Description of incident: An October 14, 2011 office burglary resulted in the exposure of patient information dating from 1993 to 2004.ë_ Office equipment and CDs with patient information were discovered missing on October 17.ë_ Affected patients were mailed notification letters on December 13, 2011 and informed that their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, diagnoses, medical conditions, lab results, medications, surgery records, radiological tests, and other clinical treatment information could have been on the stolen CDs.ë_ The office now plans to install encryption technology and update physical security systems in order to protect patient data from more breaches.
Electronic medical records may have been exposed as a result of the theft of a laptop on or around August 28, 2011.ë_

A physician pleaded guilty to unlawfully obtaining the private medical information of another person.ë_ The former employee accessed the records of several women who were not his patients.ë_ In one case, he was in a sexual relationship with a woman and accessed her information to check if she carried sexually transmitted diseases.ë_ The crime occurred in 2008.ë_ The physician is scheduled to be sentenced on March 26, 2012 and faces a maximum sentence of one year in prison and a $50,000 fine.ë_
On or around June 25, 2011, a breach involving a laptop, a computer, and a network server was discovered.ë_ Patient information was exposed as a result of the breach.
The theft of paper records on or around June 28, 2011 resulted in the exposure of patient information.
Unauthorized access or disclosure of patient information resulted after a breach involving a laptop.ë_ The breach was discovered on or around February 5, 2011.

Company: Silverpop Systems, Inc. Health and Welfare Plan
Description of incident: A burglary that occurred on or around April 15, 2011 resulted in the theft of laptop with patient information.

A laptop was stolen from a St. Charles employee's car in late October.ë_ It contained the personal information of 140 patients who were seen in the St. Charles Bend or St. Charles Redmond emergency room.ë_ The laptop was discovered in brush by an elementary school student in late November.ë_ After the laptop was returned on December 16, it was discovered that attempts to gain unauthorized access to its contents had failed.

Company: University of Mississippi Medical Center and Mississippi State Department of Health
Description of incident: Research study participants may have had their personal information exposed by the theft of a laptop.ë_ The laptop was stolen when UMMC employees left the laptop unsecured for a short period of time against departmental guidelines.ë_ It was reported stolen on October 31, and the employees who left it unsecured were disciplined.ë_ Two databases with research related health information were on the laptop.ë_ One had the age, sex, race, medical record number, zip code, and lab results of 1,400 patients.ë_ The other database contained unspecified protected health information from 75 patients.

Company: Department of Human Services (DHS) Gateway Center
Description of incident: The theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of sensitive information from DHS staff, volunteers, adoptive placements, respite providers, in-home care providers, and foster parents.ë_ People who were fingerprinted at The Gateway Center in Springfield, Oregon between August 2010 and December 8, 2011 may have been affected.ë_ People fingerprinted at The Willamette Street office in Eugene, Oregon between August 2008 and August 2010 may have also been affected.

A possible breach in the security systems used for processing credit card transactions is being investigated.ë_ There is no information on the type of breach or how many customers may have been affected.ë_ The cause of the breach is also unknown.

The email addresses of around 3,200 parents and students were exposed by a computer security breach.ë_ The parents and students received an official looking email that linked to a survey about satisfaction with the school district.ë_ The survey had not been authorized for release.

A November 25 home burglary resulted in the loss of an encrypted data tape.ë_ The tape was inside a backpack that was stolen from an employee's locked car while it was parked at home.ë_ The data tape had names, addresses, and in some cases Social Security numbers of Good News Garage donors dating back 15 years.ë_

Social Security numbers, tax identification numbers, and other types of personal information were exposed on the Virginia Department of General Services website
since 2001.ë_ The database was not
accessible via search engines, but an employee discovered that the information
could be found by anyone doing a focused search on the actual website.ë_ The information was removed after the discovery.
