Someone was able to enter a Ridgewood school building through a compromised computer password.ë_ The breach was discovered during the week of December 14. It is unclear if a data breach occurred during the incident.ë_ Six students have been identified as possible participants in the breach.ë_

Company: Oahu District Tax Office, State Tax Department
Description of incident: Fourteen Department of Taxation employees were placed on administrative leave without pay following the discovery of an internal security breach of the department's tax database.ë_ The breach was found during an audit of the department's security systems and internal controls.ë_ The incidents date from 2008 to present.ë_ It is unclear what types of information could have been exposed.

A student is being investigated by the North Penn School District (NPSD) and Towamencin Township Police Department for hacking into the NPSD computer network.ë_ Computer devices are being analyzed to determine what types of information may have been accessed.ë_ No further information is available due to the ongoing investigation.

A breach of Butler Schein Animal Health's (BSAH) systems (MyVetDirect.com) may have affected clients whose veterinarian's websites were hosted by MyVetDirect.com.ë_ People who placed orders on veterinarian websites that were hosted by MyVetDirect.com may have had their names, credit card information and numbers, addresses, telephone numbers, email addresses, billing and delivery information, and other purchase information obtained.

A contract worker or employee of a contractor may have stolen and misused the personal information of an undisclosed number of customers.ë_ The natural gas utilities serve nearly one million customers in the Chicago area, but state law bars the utilities from disclosing the number of customers affected. However, a November news report revealed that the theft of information had occurred in October and over 100 people were affected.ë_ An employee working in iQor's human resources department was linked to the incident. The employee was fired and faces criminal investigation and prosecution.

People who shopped at Jetro or Restaurant Depot between September 21 and November 18 may have had their credit or debit card information taken by a hacker.ë_ Customer names, card numbers, expiration dates, and verification codes were exposed.ë_ The breach investigation began on November 9 when the parent company became aware of customers experiencing card fraud.

A hacker or hackers outside of the US attempted to gain access to an OSU Internet server. Information on the server included names, medical record numbers, and dianoses of 30 patients who visited the pathology department between the late 1980s and 2004. ë_A roster of students who had received training at the medical center in 2006 was also on the server. ë_Officials do not believe that any personal information was taken during the attempt. A total of 30 patients and 150 students were notified.

A former employee hacked into APA's database, copied patient information, and deleted APA's list. ë_It is not clear exactly how the former employee was able to access the database, but the purpose was to benefit the former employee's new employer. ë_Names, telephone numbers, and addresses of APA patients were taken. ë_APA's competitor, SeeBaby, used the information to create a direct-mail marketing list.UPDATEë_(1/10/2012): The former employee was sentenced to serve 13 months in prison for hacking into the competitor's computer in order to lure away patients. ë_

Company: Pure Med Spa, Brite Smile Brite Skin
Description of incident: A woman alerted a local news station to a stash of improperly disposed information. ë_Credit card applications, patient names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and possibly medical records were found sitting next to a dumpster in a parking lot. ë_The paperwork came from multiple organizations. ë_Among the organizations were two closed branches of Pure Med Spa and Brite Smile Brite Skin. ë_

A janitor who worked at the Ochsner Medical Center in new Orleans and his girlfriend have pleaded guilty to charges related to stealing patient information for personal gain. ë_The janitor stole printouts containing patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and other types of personal information. ë_The stolen information was then used by the janitor's girlfriend to open online accounts under the patients' names. The online accounts were used to make thousands of dollars in fraudulent purchases. The date of the breach is unknown, but the janitor was employed between November of 2008 and June of 2009. Federal prosecutors first brought charges in early December of 2011. ë_

A podiatrist licensed in the state of Maryland operated a podiatry practice called Chesapeake Wound Care Center from his home. ë_Between April 1, 2002 and October 11, 2004, he submitted 80 fraudulent claims to Medicare for podiatry services that had not been performed at nursing facilities. ë_The podiatrist signed a Settlement Agreement with the government on October 30, 2007 after being caught, but then fraudulently billed Medicare advantage plans between October 31, 2007 and July 20, 2010. ë_The podiatrist admitted to submitting false bills for podiatry care by misusing the names and personal information of about 200 nursing home patients. He was subsequently charged with health care fraud and aggravated identity theft. He was sentenced to 54 months in prison, three years of supervised release, and ordered to pay $1,122,992.08 ë_in restitution for the fraudulent billing of Medicare.

Letters dictated by AOMS providers were accidentally uploaded onto a non-secure server in Europe. The information then became publicly searchable via internet. ë_AOMS learned of the breach on October 12, 2011. ë_People who were seen at AOMS for injuries and/or work-related examinations from July, 2009 through October 12, 2011 may have been affected by the breach. ë_No names, contact information, personal information, test results, financial information or Social Security numbers were exposed.

The College's electronic systems have been affected by a series of dangerous viruses since 1999. ë_The problem was noticed in 2012 when the College's data security monitoring service detected an unusual pattern of computer traffic. Further investigation revealed that servers and desktops had been infected across administrative, instructional, and wireless networks. ë_Officials believe that it is likely that using a flash drive to transmit information between a campus computer and a personal computer resulted in exposed personal information. ë_It appears that the viruses searched and transmitted data to sites in Russia, China, and at least eight other countries. Banking information and any other personal information that may have been accessed by visitors, students, staff, and faculty on campus computers between 1999 and January of 2012 could have been exposed.

The Vermont Department of Taxes website accidentally displayed the Social Security numbers of 1,332 individuals and the federal ID numbers of 245 businesses for two hours. ë_The personal data was contained in a weekly group of property transfer tax returns. ë_The three parties who were able to access the information were identified and contacted. ë_

A precinct employee trashed a number of documents after they had been damaged by a flood in the basement of the building. ë_Dumpster divers found the documents and reported that they were readable. ë_The documents, which contained at least one domestic violence report, stolen property records, criminal complaints, and mug shots, were then recovered, secured, and presumably shredded.

A customer checking frequent flyer miles on United Airlines' mobile website was able to view the names, Mileage Plus numbers, future flight itineraries with confirmation codes, and previous trips of other Unite Airlines customers. ë_The information could have allowed anyone to change another passenger's seating assignment or cancel a flight by using confirmation codes and last names. ë_

On December 27, Care2 discovered that their website had been breached. ë_Hackers accessed member login information. ë_Care2 emailed new passwords once members had logged into their accounts. ë_Members should change the passwords of any accounts that share the password that was previously used on Care2. ë_Though Care2 has 17,900,617 members, a "limited number" were affected by the breach.

On November 12, 2011, an encrypted laptop was stolen from the home of an ADP associate. ë_The laptop was encrypted and password-protected. ë_It contained files with the personal information of A.W. Hastings & Co. employees which had been given to ADP for payroll processing. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and addresses may have been exposed.

Hackers inserted code onto the server that hosts GuideYou.com and accessed customer credit card numbers. ë_The CVC2/CVV2/CID codes, customer names, and addresses associated with the credit card numbers were also accessible through the server. ë_The breach was discovered on October 28, but the malicious code had been present since November 19, 2010. ë_

Customers who went to Alamo Drafthouse Cinemas may have had their debit and credit card information stolen due to a theft of information from N/L Entertainment. ë_The Bank of Charles Town is suing N/L Entertainment for failing to prevent the theft, which lead to at least 232 fraudulent purchases made using Bank of Charles Town customer debit cards. ë_The Bank of Charles Town is seeking $29,919.74 in damages plus an unspecified amount in interest. The breach was first noticed and reported to the public in September. ë_Thieves had taken financial information from people who used their debit or credit cards to make transactions between the end of June 2011 to late August of 2011. ë_

Company: Open MRI of Chicago, Nation Wise Machine Buyers
Description of incident: The improper disposal of paper documents resulted in the exposure of health and/or other personal information. ë_The breach was discovered on September 6, 2011.
The misplacement of paper documents resulted in the exposure of health and/or other personal information. ë_The breach was discovered on October 7, 2011.
A portable electronic device was discovered to have been stolen on or around September 8, 2011. The device may have contained health and/or other personal information.ë_

An employee was fired after taking sensitive documents home on or around December 19. ë_Medical records and other documents with patient dates of birth, addresses, driver's license numbers, medical record numbers, and in some cases, Social Security numbers were removed from the hospital against hospital policy. The records were recovered.

An ACLU lawsuit claims that police acted inappropriately during a raid of A Woman's Place clinic.  The lawsuit claims that police not only confiscated around 400 medical records, but read them and revealed sensitive medical information about patients to outside parties.UPDATE (12/28/2012): ACLU is asking that the records be returned. ë_The police were investigating the clinic because it's owner is accused of billing state Medicaid program for services to 37 patients after having her license suspended. ë_Seven pharmacies billed Medicaid for prescriptions she had written after the owner's prescription authority was also suspended.

Between 400 and 450 medical records were stolen from a chiropractic clinic during a January 2 burglary. ë_Files for patients with last names ending in DOD through DRI; ending in ELL through GAT; and ending in GIF through HAL and who had been to the clinic since January 1, 2008 were taken.

Thousands of patient records were found in an unsecured trash can. ë_They contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, medical conditions, and treatment information. ë_The boxes of medical records were traced to Ayuda, whose owner claimed to have been doing little or no business after losing a state contract in September. ë_The boxes were auctioned off after the owner failed to pay the rental fee on a storage unit.ë_

A nurse was fired after accessing patient medical records without cause. ë_The unauthorized access exposed patient vital signs, diagnoses, and treatment notes. ë_Patient Social Security numbers may have also been exposed. ë_The breach was uncovered in November during an audit.

ASU shutdown its online computer system after discovering a breach. ë_An encrypted file containing user names and passwords was downloaded on Wednesday, January 18 by an unauthorized party. ë_All online services were suspended until the night of Thursday, January 19. ë_Students and staff will be required to enter new passwords to access their accounts since there is a chance that some information could have been compromised. ë_

Customers who used debit or credit cards at Ward's Nursery and Garden Center may have had their information taken. ë_Dozens of people from various banks reported fraudulent activity on their cards and Ward's Nursery and Garden Center appears to be a common link. ë_Reports of fraudulent activity date back to December and people who visited Ward's Nursery and Garden Center are urged to check their cards for fraud until the cause of the breach is determined.

VA officials gave veteran Social Security numbers, names, and possibly other information to Ancestry.com in March of 2011 in response to a Freedom of Information Act request from the genealogy site. ë_The records should have only contained the information of deceased veterans, but instead contained the information of over 2,200 living veterans. The information was then posted in 2011 and taken down in January of 2012.

A potential security breach to the City of Point Pleasant's computer system was discovered by an outside agency. ë_Pleasant officials were contacted and an investigation began. ë_Little is known about the breach, though it is believed to have originated from an outside source.

Company: Office of the New York City Public Advocate
Description of incident: The group Anonymous claimed responsibility for hacking and publishing a data base. The database consisted of names, addresses, telephone numbers, email addresses, medical conditions, domestic violence and abuse reports, descriptions of financial hardship, complaints about residential issues, and other very personal details of people who submitted this information via the public advocate's website.ë_ The submissions for assistance date from April 2010.ë_UPDATEë_(12/28/2011): The NYC Office of the Public Advocate released a public notice.

Company: United Jewish Appeal - Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York Inc. (UJA-Federation)
Description of incident: People who donated to UJA-Federation may have had their bank account information taken by a dishonest worker. ë_A worker who led a $2million identity theft ring surreptitiously took pictures of checks given to UJA-Federation during her two years of employment. ë_The dishonest worker also collected donor names, addresses, and account numbers. The information was then sold to other members of the identity theft ring and used to create fraudulent checks and open credit cards. ë_The dishonest worker was fired when the crimes were discovered.

Around 6,500 ACT Explore test results for 8th graders were mailed to incorrect addresses. ë_The breach was discovered when parents began calling the district. ë_Parents were asked to shred the tests. ë_The exact cause of the mailing error is unknown.

A call center employee who worked for a Trilegiant vendor used his phone to take pictures of customer names and credit or debit card numbers. ë_The dishonest employee was seen doing this at least once, but no misuse of customer information had been reported as of December 14, 2011.

Company: Mr. Janitor, Eagle Harbor Country Club
Description of incident: The owner of a cleaning company called "Mr. Janitor" was arrested for stealing personal information from Eagle Harbor Country Club members. ë_An unknown number of members had their information stolen and used to open fraudulent credit cards and bank accounts in their names. ë_The owner of the cleaning company was charged with identity theft of more than $50,000 and/or affecting more than twenty persons.

Anonymous and AntiSec released FFA information which included 22 email addresses linked to IP addresses of newsletter subscribers, 13 email addresses linked to type of credit card and security code number, and administrator login information which included encrypted passwords. ë_The attack was in response to FFA's successful efforts to pressure Home Depot and Lowe's into removing advertisement on a TLC show called "All-American Muslim." ë_The FFA strongly opposed the idea of having a Muslim family featured in a positive way on TV.Anonymous also hinted at an attack on Lowe's for caving into the FFA's demands.

Company: Coalition of Law Enforcement and Retail (CLEAR)
Description of incident: A hacker released member information that had been stored on the CLEAR website. Member phone numbers, residential and email addresses, and place of employment were exposed. Administrator passwords that had easily been decrypted were also released.ë_One person claimed to have used the information to access the email of a police department.ë_The hacker claimed that the attack was a response to the mistreatment of Occupyë_protesters.ë_

On June 14, University of Missouri Health Care officials
failed to receive an expected delivery of copies of patient billing information
and immediately notified the University of Missouri Police Department.ë_ The package had been sent via private
courier to University of Missouri Health Care from a Kansas City bank that
serves as the clearinghouse for the University of Missouri Health Care_Ñés
billing.ë_ The package included
copies of payments received by the bank between June 6 and June 13 and would
have exposed bank account numbers, partial credit card numbers, names and
addresses.ë_ Notification letters
were sent on June 21. University of Missouri Health Care has terminated its
contract with the courier responsible for delivering the missing package.ë_ Affected parties are advised to contact
their banks or credit card companies and change their account or card numbers.UPDATEë_(1/26/2012): Privacy Rights Clearinghouse received documentation that revealed people in Columbia were affected by the breach.

Customer information was accessible through a web search from August of 2008 through January of 2010.ë_ The information included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and account numbers of shareholders in New Hampshire and other locations.

Company: Stone Oak Urgent Care and Family Practice
Description of incident: A computer or laptop was discovered to have been lost or stolen on or around October 23, 2011.ë_UPDATE (12/28/2011): A total of five computers containing medical and personal information were stolen from a physician's office during the breach. ë_A thief had pried open an office door during the weekend of October 22-23. ë_Patients were informed on December 5 that their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, account numbers, disability codes, and diagnoses were stored on the computers.

Company: State of Tennessee Sponsored Group Health Plan
Description of incident: State employees who canceled their health or dental insurance had their information mailed to the wrong address in October.ë_ Each mailing included a certificate containing the information of the recipient and three other letters aimed at other members of the plan.ë_ Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, employee ID numbers, and healthcare insurance coverage dates were exposed. The error was discovered on October 6, 2011.

The academic records database of Santa Clara University was hacked in order to change the grades of over 60 current and former undergraduate students. ë_The breach was discovered when a former student pointed out that her current transcript showed a grade better than the one on a transcript that had previously been printed. Tens of thousands of student records dating back more than a decade were examined. ë_The "sophisticated" hacking incident or incidents had altered student transcripts from all three of the University's schools and changed some grades for courses taken as far back as 2006. ë_The incident or incidents is believed to have occurred between June 2010 and July 2011. ë_Some students received subtle upgrades and others had their grades changed from F's to A's.
Hackers posted data from providencenightlife.net users onto Pastebin. ë_The data included usernames, clear-text passwords, and email addresses. ë_

Records Breached: 5,400 (No full credit card numbers or SSNs revealed)
Description of incident: A customer logged onto her USPS online store account and was able to see the name, address, and the final four digits of another customer's credit card number. ë_The customer alerted the USPS customer service, but was told that the error had already been noted. On October 28, USPS became aware that a coding issue during an update had resulted in an error that exposed credit card information. ë_Customers were notified of the problem on November 8. ë_The error was subsequently fixed.

On September 1, 2011, a spreadsheet containing information on 19,276 students was accidentally made accessible from the internet due to a administrative error. ë_The spreadsheet contained the names, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, majors, class or classes, levels, colleges, student ID numbers, and GPAs of students enrolled as of September 1 of 2011. ë_The problem was corrected on November 2 soon after it was discovered. The spreadsheet had been accessed 15 times by unknown parties between September 1 and November 2. ë_

Hackers were able to access a Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) computer server. ë_It contained files with the personal information of current and former VCU and VCU Health System faculty, staff, students and affiliates. ë_Suspicious files were discovered on the server on October 24. ë_It was taken offline and subsequent investigation revealed that two unauthorized accounts had been created on a second server. ë_While the first server did not contain personal data, the second server did and had been compromised through the first server. ë_Data included either a name or eID, Social Security number, and in some cases, date of birth, contact information, and various programmatic or departmental information. ë_

The information of 2,400 students in grades four through ten was accidentally posted online. ë_A parent discovered the breach after searching their child's name. ë_The student's FCAT scores and Social Security number appeared on a public site. ë_The cause of the unintended disclosure was not reported.

On July 6, 2011, four tape cartridges with sensitive information were shipped in a container from VOI. ë_The container was placed into a cardboard shipping box and shipped. ë_ValueOptions Inc. (VOI) was informed that the package had not arrive as of August 1. An outside agency investigated the loss of the packages until September 22. ë_Notification that the tapes had been lost was sent on November 4. ë_The tapes contained names, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, and plan subscriber ID numbers. VOI processes the benefits information for National elevator Industry's Health Benefit Plan, as well as other organizations. ë_A total of 350 New Hampshire residents were affected by the breach and 6,669 New York residents were affected as well. ë_The total number of people affected from different organizations and across the United States was not reported.

Company: Habitat for Humanity Delaware County ReStore
Description of incident: A number of identity thefts were linked to Habitat for Humanity of Delaware County ReStore. ë_An investigation revealed that hackers had accessed the store's computer system and took customer names and credit card numbers. ë_Detectives believe there are other sources of identity theft that have yet to be identified. The date of the access was not reported, but as many as 444 customers could have had their information taken.

Company: University of Miami Miller School of Medicine
Description of incident: A briefcase containing an unencrypted flash drive was stolen from the vehicle of a University of Miami Miller School of Medicine pathologist on November 24, 2011. ë_It contained the names, medical record numbers, ages, sexes, diagnosis information, and treatment information of patients who had specimens reviewed by the department of pathology between 2005 and 2011. ë_

A December 7 overnight office burglary resulted in the theft of a laptop with patient data. It contained names, contact information, and diagnoses of patients receiving services within the neurology department. ë_The locks to the neurology department were changed after the theft was discovered. ë_

An office burglary on or around January 18 resulted in the theft of two laptops. ë_The laptops contained the records of about 640 patients and had been used for cardiac tests. Though the laptops contained minimal clinical data, they did contain some Social Security numbers and demographic information.

An office burglary that occurred on or around January 24 resulted in the loss of a laptop. The laptop held client records. ë_The company sent a breach notification through Facebook and email. ë_No financial information was on the laptop, but Preferred Skin Solutions still warned their clients about the risk of identity theft.

Company: Metropolitan Life Insurance Company (MetLife) of Connecticut
Description of incident: in November of 2009, a customer discovered that spreadsheet with current and former MetLife customer information had been posted online. ë_MetLife corrected the problem after being notified by the customer and provided two years of credit monitoring and identity theft insurance to customers who had been affected by the breach. ë_The type of information exposed in the spreadsheet and the length of time it was available online were not revealed. ë_Additional negotiations with Attorney General George Jepsen and Consumer Protection Commissioner William Rubenstein resulted in an agreement for MetLife to offer additional protection. ë_MetLife paid an additional $10,000 for a special fund that will reimburse the state of Connecticut's investigative and enforcement costs, or reimburse losses for consumers in the future. Additionally, customers who paid for a security freeze to be lifted or placed will be eligible for reimbursement and Metlife agreed to improve employee personal information protection training policies and procedures.

A cashier pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit access device fraud and aggravated identity theft. ë_The cashier was part of a group of friends who used stolen credit card numbers to make $50,000 in purchases. ë_The cashier's job was to swipe customer debit and credit cards while working at McDonald's.UPDATEë_(2/03/2012): The man who was the ring leader of the credit card scam and recruited the McDonald's employee was sentenced to seven years in federal prison on February 3. ë_He reportedly paid a female employee $10 for each credit card she swiped at the restaurant. ë_About 185 customers were affected and $163,000 in fraudulent charges were made. The dishonest employee pleaded guilty and was sentenced to two years in prison. Three other people were sentenced for their involvement, but the extent of their involvement was not revealed. ë_A fourth remains a fugitive.

Company: Trinity Medical Center (Montclair Baptist Medical Center)
Description of incident: A former employee woman was caught stealing patient information for the purpose of identity theft. ë_Hundreds of pages of information with patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and some medical information such as scheduled procedure were found at the employee'së_woman'së_residential address. The information is from stolen surgery schedules and was taken between March 22 and April 1. The former employee woman was charged with violating the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA).UPDATEë_(2/01/2012): Additional details reveal that the woman was most likely not an employee of Trinity Medical Center and stole the logs of patient information while supposedly visiting a patient. The paper documents were stolen in a flamboyant way as the woman reportedly jumped over a counter to steal the logs. ë_The files included information from people who had visited in 2006 when Trinity was known as Montclair Baptist Medical Center. ë_The logs were recovered on April 8 through a USPS investigation.She pleaded guilty to the theft and was sentenced to 39 months in federal prison on February 1, 2012. ë_She will also serve five years of supervised release after her prison time is served. ë_

A printing error caused thousands of taxpayers to receive 1099-G forms from 2011 with the Social Security number and tax refund of another taxpayer. ë_The mistake occurred because the company was trying to conserve paper. ë_The forms were supposed to be cut below a certain point, but the bottom half remained attached. ë_

Over 50 people who ate at Flores' were victims of fraudulent credit card activity. ë_The damages total nearly $50,000. ë_Hackers used a computer virus to infiltrate Flores' credit card system in December. ë_The owner noticed a drop in business of 15 percent after the breach was disclosed.

VeriSign was hacked repeatedly in 2010. The hackers stole undisclosed information. ë_VeriSign is responsible for the integrity of web addresses ending in.com, .net, and .gov. If hackers were able to obtain certain information, it is possible that .com, .net, and .gov websites could be imitated more easily. ë_Hackers may be able to direct people to faked website and intercept email from federal employees or corporate executives using the .gov addresses. ë_VeriSign officials do not believe that the attacks breaches the servers that support the Domain Name System network, but did not reveal many details about the breach. ë_VeriSign offers a number of services that defend customer websites from attacks and manage website traffic. ë_VeriSign also researchers international cybercrime groups. ë_The security staff responded to the attack quickly, but the breach was not disclosed throughout the company until September 2011.

A security breach caused the personal information of 650,000 President's Challenge participants nationwide to be exposed. ë_Hackers may have accessed participant names, email addresses, dates of birth, and nutritional data. ë_People throughout Indiana University were participating in a Health IU fitness inter-campus competition. ë_No financial information was available to the hacker or hackers. ë_A small percentage and unknown number of Social Security numbers may have been available through other organizations that participate in President's Challenge programs. ë_It is unclear how many other organizations were affected by the President's Challenge hack. ë_

More than 250 people in 30 states were victims of scams perpetrated on Craigslist.com by two New York residents. ë_The women posted phony Craigslist ads for nonexistent jobs and apartments to gather the personal information of victims between February of 2010 and October of 2011. ë_That information was then used to obtain fraudulent state income tax returns, bank loans, and credit cards. ë_More than $75,000 was fraudulently obtained. ë_Early in 2011, workers in the Buffalo office of the state Department of Taxation and Finance discovered that hundreds of state tax refunds were being claimed from only about 10 addresses in the county. ë_The two women were indicted by a grand jury on grand larceny and scheme to defraud charges. ë_The women face up to 15 years in prison if convicted.

An employee of Towers Watson posted unspecified personal information of current and former Sequoia Hospital employees online in October of 2007. ë_Towers Watson is a Sequoia Hospital contractor. ë_The types of information that were posted were not disclosed, but full names and Social Security numbers were included. ë_The information remained online until December 2 of 2011. ë_

The report cards of 101 high school students were accidentally sent to the person listed as their emergency contact. ë_A vendor made an unauthorized change to the computer program that generates report cards. ë_If a parent had a high school student attending the district and was listed as an emergency contact for another high school student, then they received two report cards. ë_Parent names were listed on the report cards of each student, but parents listed as emergency contacts mistakenly received the report cards anyway. No Social Security numbers were exposed. ë_Student ID numbers, schedules, and grades were exposed.

Three students were caught selling quiz answers to students. ë_It was discovered that they had stolen and copied a master key from the janitor's office. ë_They then used the copy of the master key to install keylogging hardware onto the computers of four teachers. ë_The keylogging hardware revealed passwords, which were then used to access the central files of the school network. ë_It is unclear what types of information the students had access to. ë_They used their access to electronically change their grades slightly. The master key copy was also used to access 20 paper tests before they were given. ë_A student who became aware of the black market for quiz materiala reported the students. ë_

The personal information of current and former Regions employees was lost in November after an auditor from Ernst & Young mailed a flash drive and decryption code. The envelope arrived with the decryption code, but no flash drive. The data included information related to 401k retirement plans. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and possibly dates of birth were on the flash drive. ë_Regions employs about 27,000 people in 16 states.

Police stopped a high school student and discovered several sheets of papers with student names, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers in a vehicle. ë_It is unclear how the student obtained the printout and she is accused of using the information to file fraudulent federal income tax returns. ë_

A former employee was able to access the Segmark Solutions computer system. ë_It is unclear if the former employee guessed passwords, used passwords that had not been changed, or used some other method to access the computer system. ë_He then used credit card information in the system to make fraudulent purchases. Damages caused a total of $7,000. ë_The former employee was caught after a six-month investigation and charged with second degree computer crime and illegal use of credit cards.

Unencrypted files that were placed on the faculty web server exposed student information.  Student names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and academic information were placed on the server in December of 2009.ë_ Students who attended UHWO in Fall of 1994 or graduated between 1988 and 1993 were affected.  A much larger number of students who attended the University of Hawai'i Mnoa between 1990 and 1998 were also affected. The files were removed on October 18 after a privacy group notified the University. The server was quickly removed from the network.ë_ The faculty member who accidentally placed the file on the server retired before the breach was discovered.ë_UPDATEë_(11/19/10): A former student is filing a class-action lawsuit on behalf of students affected by the University of Hawaii's multiple breaches. ë_The man attended the Mnoa campus between 1990 and 1998 and claims that he was affected by the this breach and one that occurred in June of 2009. ë_The names of four other people are attached to his Social Security number and his credit has been used in Georgia. Around 259,000 private records have been exposed by the University of Hawai'i since 2005.UPDATEë_(1/27/2012): The University of Hawaii will provide two years of credit protection services and credit restoration services to settle a class-action lawsuit involving data breaches that affected nearly 100,000 students, faculty, alumni, and staff between 2009 and 2011. ë_The settlement is still subject to court approval.

A concerned neighbor noticed that packages were being delivered to an abandoned house. Law enforcement confronted a man who was collecting the packages and found that he had stolen old Windstream customer files and used the information to open fraudulent accounts with online retailers. ë_The man was an employee of Windstream and had taken paper documents from the mid to late 1990s. ë_A second vacant home that served as a delivery location was also found. ë_The former employee was charged with felony identity theft.

Company: Office of Robert S. Smith, M.D., Inc.
Description of incident: An October 17 office burglary resulted in the theft of a laptop. ë_The laptop contained patient names, dates of birth, physicians, and diagnosis information. ë_

An unauthorized disclosure of paper documents occurred on January 31, 2011. ë_The breach may have affected records that date from September 23, 2009 through October 18, 2011. No further details are available.

A laptop and external hard drive containing patient information were stolen from a locked vehicle owned by an Aegis employee on November 22, 2011. ë_The external hard drive contained names and Social Security numbers. It may have also contained driver's license numbers, dates of birth, and phone numbers. ë_Though Aegis provides lab tests, results and medical records were not exposed. ë_
The theft of a computer on or aroudn December 1, 2011 resulted in the exposure of personal information.

A binder containing forms with flu test results for 2011 went missing sometime around December 5, 2011. ë_It contained the information of patients who received a flu test between January 1, 2011, and December 5, 2011. ë_patient names, internal hospital department and internal account numbers, gender, medical record numbers, dates of birth, age, dates of tests, and flu test results. ë_
A total of 771 patient records may have been exposed as a result of a breach that occurred on November 19, 2011. ë_No further details were disclosed.

A laptop with Triumph client and family member information was stolen on December 13. ë_The office burglary was committed by three men. ë_Two of them distracted the receptionist while the third entered a hallway and stole the laptop. ë_People in Davie, Forsyth, and Stoke counties were affected. ë_The laptop contained spreadsheets with names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, insurance numbers, and Medicaid numbers. ë_Notifications went out on February 2 after it was determined that the laptop would most likely not be recovered.

Records Breached: 100 (Unknown number of financial records and SSNs involved)
Description of incident: Approximately 100 out of a batch of 6,200 refurbished Motorola XOOM Wi-Fi tablets were sent to new customers without being completely wiped by Motorola. ë_The affected tablets were resold by Woot.com between October and December 2011. ë_Previous owners may have stored user names, passwords, email addresses, videos, photographs, and documents on the tablets. ë_There is also a possibility that any password-protected sites and applications could be accessed by people who bought the device refurbished. Any customers who purchased and returned the tablet between March and October of 2011 are eligible for two-years of paid credit monitoring services if both transactions took place at Amazon.com, Best Buy, BJ's Wholesale, eBay, Office Max, Radio Shack, Sam's Club, Staples, or a few other independent retailers. ë_Those users are also encouraged to change email passwords, social media passwords, and any passwords used to access sensitive applications on the tablet. ë_Additionally, customers who purchased the refurbished tablets and discover that there is information from a previous user may mail the device back to Motorola for free, have the device reset, and receive a $100 American Express gift card.

Bamastuff.com notified its customers that a breach in its database had been discovered. ë_Customer names, email addresses, billing and shipping addresses, telephone numbers, credit card information, and/or cryptographically scrambled passwords may have been exposed. ë_Customers who bought items between August 1, 2009 and January 16, 2012 may have been affected. Some customers have already experienced fraudulent charges.

An employee of IQCR wrote down names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth from records. The records came from a gas company in Chicago and were processed by IQCR. ë_That information was then used to apply for credit cards. ë_This occurred in October of 2011. ë_The dishonest employee and her partner were caught after people alerted authorities about being declined for credit cards they had not requested. ë_Authorities discovered that the fraudulent credit requests all came from the same computer IP address and went to the same residential address. The couple face 10 years in prison per-identity stolen. ë_Over 100 people were affected by the breach.

A dishonest employee swiped customer credit cards after initial transactions, then processed a second transaction for cash back and pocketed the amount of the second fraudulent transaction from the cash register. ë_A store manager noticed the employee stealing money and reported her. A customer complaint about an unauthorized transaction then revealed the extent of the breach. ë_The fraudulent transaction complains date from May 25 to June 10. Store records reveal that $6,197 was stolen in this way.

An auditor for the Amsterdam Hospitality Group sold credit card information to another man for identity theft purposes. As an employee for the Amsterdam Hospitality Group, the auditor had access to the credit card account information and identifying information of people who stayed at a number of Manhattan hotels. ë_It is unclear which hotels were affected. Over $840,000 in fraudulent credit card purchases were made with the stolen information.

Between the summer of 2010 and February of 2011, a dishonest employee of Top of the Line Marketing passed along names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth for the purpose of identity theft. ë_A police raid uncovered 42 debit cards and a list of 1,200 Maryland residents that had been distributed by the dishonest employee. Some of the information had been used to collect unemployment benefits on prepaid Visa cards. The person who was found with the fraudulent debit cards and list pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit access device fraud and one count of aggravated identity theft. He faces a maximum of five years in prison for the first count and a mandatory two-year sentence for the second. ë_

On October 26, students who had at least one failing midterm grade during the Fall 2011 semester received an email from the office of the assistant dean of students. ë_The email, which informed students of their grade, was not blind copied. ë_Each email recipient could see the email addresses of other students who received the email. ë_No other information was exposed.

On September 26, Aaron's became aware of an office burglary that resulted in the theft of computers, TVs, electronic gaming devices, and other goods. Customer names and Social Security numbers were on one of the computers. ë_At least 1,008 New Hampshire residents were affected, but the total number of affected people nationwide was not revealed.

An employee brought a skimming device to work and swiped customer debit or credit cards at the drive-thru window. The information was then sold to others who used it to make hundreds of fraudulent bank and gift cards. Authorities became aware of the situation in the summer of 2010. ë_Five hundred customers in Tyler were affected, but customers in other areas were also affected.UPDATEë_(8/10/2011): One of the people associated with the restaurant-related fraud ring was sentenced to four years in prison. ë_He pleaded guilty in May to access device fraud and was ordered to pay nearly $95,000 in restitution. ë_He was caught when law officers discovered counterfeit charge card making equipment and hundreds of fraudulent cards during a raid of his home.UPDATEë_(11/02/2011): The dishonest Chicken Express employee who skimmed customer credit card numbers was sentenced to two years in prison and ordered to pay $95,000 in restitution to victims. ë_

The parent company of MetroLux, Metropolitan Theatres, reported an external breach of the local theater's computer system. ë_Someone attacked the data transmission system and stole customer financial information via computer. ë_The issue was first noticed on October 21. ë_The breach was analyzed and new servers were installed. Though the system was confirmed to have been compromised, not all of the 1,180 people who reported fraud had used their credit or debit cards there.

Receipts, credit card numbers, addresses, phone numbers, and other information were found in an easily accessible dumpster that sat outside the closed fitness center. ë_A local news station was contacted and followed up on the story. ë_The dumpster was removed, but it is unclear if the documents were properly disposed. The news story received attention from the attorney general's office and Cardinal Fitness may now face a fine of up to $305,000 for dumping the information.

The office burglary during the weekend of February 4 resulted in the theft of 10 encrypted laptops. The laptops had other safeguards as well as encryption codes. Additional items were stolen. The types of confidential and personal client information that were on the computers were not disclosed, nor was the possible number of people affected. ë_

An Excel spreadsheet with student names, addresses, dates of birth, and college ID's was listed online on a password-protected website. ë_The password protection eventually expired and anyone could access the information online. ë_Valencia College hired an unnamed contractor to create a custom page for prospective students to communicate with the college. ë_The contractor then hired an unnamed sub-contractor to work on some of the website.The breach can be linked to that unnamed sub-contractor.

Hackers were able to access patient names, phone numbers, dates of birth, Metro Community Provider Network internal account numbers, and medical conditions through phishing emails sent to several Metro Community Provider Network employees. ë_Employees received an email that appeared to be from a trusted source and contained a link. ë_Multiple employees clicked the link, which then asked for their email login information. ë_The breach was detected on the same day that it occurred, December 5th, 2011. ë_

More than 500 patients of Lakeview Medical Center homecare and hospice programs had their personal information exposed by the theft of a laptop.ë_ The laptop was stolen from a car belonging to a Lakeview nurse.ë_ It contained names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, medicare ID numbers, and diagnostic information. It is unclear when the laptop was stolen, but the nurse who was involved no longer works for Lakeview.

C.D. Peacock is suing BridgePoint Technologies for faulty IT services.ë_ BridgePoint Technologies was hired in August 2009 and in March of 2010, a breach of C.D. Peacock's virtual private network (VPN) was discovered.ë_ The private network was designed to give remote users access to a centralized network. C.D. Peacock was allegedly advised by BridgePoint Technologies to go around the VPN since it could not be fixed.ë_ Though BridgePoint Technologies allegedly said that this move would be safe, C.D. Peacock experienced a serious security breach almost immediately.ë_ Hackers installed malicious software on its credit card processing system and other network computers in early April 2010.ë_ According to the lawsuit, this allowed hackers to "access the confidential personal data and financial information of" C.D. Peacock customers.ë_ The stolen data was transfered to the hackers' remote system.ë_ The breach was discovered in August of 2010.ë_ BridgePoint Technologies claimed that it had not received a copy of the lawsuit as of February 10, 2012.

Hackers targeted the Dallas Police Department in response to an officer being placed on leave after crashing his vehicle while intoxicated.ë_ A total of 21 full names with employee ID numbers and hire dates, as well as 23 user IDs, email addresses, and passwords were posted online by the hackers.

Three hackers posted an administrative login and password on a public website. A fourth hacker released three logins and password combinations and 540 email addresses. The fourth hacker did not work with the other three hackers, but posted the information on the same day.

Company: Department of Social Services Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
Description of incident: A subpoena by the Department of Social Services revealed the names and Social Security numbers of multiple people. ë_The subpoena was in response to reports that state employees had engaged in food stamp fraud. ë_Instead of separate subpoenas for each individual, a sheet with 40 names and a sheet with 90 names were sent. ë_This allowed state employees who are under investigation to learn that their fellow employees were under investigation, as well as their Social Security numbers.

An employee discovered that it was possible to access current and former employee W-2 forms online via a Google search.ë_ The W-2 form contained employee name, Social Security number, address, earnings, and taxes paid for 2009 and 2010.ë_ The discovery was made on December 23 of 2011.ë_

Sensitive documents were placed in public trash bags.ë_ The bags were opened and the documents were found scattered across a sidewalk.ë_ Confidential patient records which included names, Social Security numbers, unemployment compensation records, copies of benefits cards, and other patient personal information were exposed. Patients dating back to 2006 were affected.ë_

Someone stole thousands of X-rays from Saint Jospeh medical Center.ë_ Authorities believe the X-rays were taken for their silver content rather than for identity theft purposes. They contained patient names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, dates of service, physicians, and some diagnostic information.ë_ Patients who were X-rayed between 2004 and 2005, as well as sometime during 2007 may have been affected.

A computer breach in a CCSU Business Office exposed the information of current and former faculty, staff, and student workers.ë_ A Z-Bot virus designed to relay information was discovered on the computer on December 6, 2011.ë_ The computer had been exposed for eight days and only exposed the Social Security numbers of those who were affected. People associated with CCSU as far back as 1998 were affected.

An unknown number of employee Social Security numbers were mistakenly disclosed after the City responded to a Freedom of Information law request.ë_ The Social Security numbers were included along with payroll data to the entity that requested the information.ë_ City officials verified that the information would not be passed on after the breach was discovered.

Hackers stole credit card information during an attack on Solitude Mountain's credit card system.ë_ The breach was short-lived and a small, but undisclosed number of people saw fraudulent charges on their credit cards.ë_ Anyone who used a credit card at Solitude during the week of February 7 should check their statements for unusual activity.

The information from three Texas agencies was discovered to be accessible on a public server. Sometime between January and May of 2010, data that was not encrypted was transferred from the Teacher Retirement Center of Texas, the Texas Workforce Commission (TWC) and the Employees Retirement System of Texas. It ended up on a state-controlled public server as early as April 2010 and was not discovered until March 31, 2011. Sensitive information such as names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and driver's license numbers could have been exposed.ë_ A spokesperson from the Texas Comptroller's Office claims that the breach occurred because numerous procedures were not followed.ë_ Some employees were fired for their roles in the incident.UPDATEë_(4/13/2011):ë_Approximately two million of the 3.5 million possibly affected are unemployed insurance claimants who may have had their names, Social Security numbers and mailing addresses exposed. ë_The birth dates and driver's license numbers of some of these people were also exposed. The information was accidentally disclosed on a Comptroller's publicly accessible server. TWC provided uninsured claimant records from December 31, 2006 December 31, 2009 to the Comptroller's office in April of 2010 to assist in identifying individuals who may have unclaimed property. ë_The information was sent in a protected manner using Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP), which encrypts the data during transmission over a state controlled network used by state agencies and universities.UPDATE(5/6/2011): Two class action lawsuits have been filed on behalf of 3.5 million Texans who had their information exposed by the breach. The second class action lawsuit seeks a $1,000 statutory penalty for each affected individual.UPDATE (2/13/2012): The cost of the credit monitoring services provided to those affected has passed $600,000. Currently, no taxpayers have linked fraudulent charges to the breach.

Supervisory Union notified all employees that a serious security breach on its financial computer system was discovered and that their financial information may have been compromised. ë_The breach was not described in detail, but employees were informed that payroll would be temporarily using paychecks. ë_Supervisory Union contacted all banking institutions that were involved in direct deposit and informed them that client data may have been compromised. ë_Employees were also encouraged to contact all banking institutions to review their financial accounts, contact their banks, change their email passwords, and avoid clicking on suspicious emails. ë_

A hard drive was discovered missing on February 19. ë_It contained patient personal and medical information related to a bone density machine. ë_Medical information, names, dates of birth, addresses, medical record numbers, and medications from patients who had bone density scans between November 2005 and January 2012 were exposed. ë_The hard drive was designed to work with the bone density machine and specialized software would be needed to extract information.

A hard drive was discovered missing on February 19. ë_It contained patient personal and medical information related to a bone density machine. ë_Medical information, names, dates of birth, addresses, medical record numbers, and medications from patients who had bone density scans between November 2005 and January 2012 were exposed. ë_The hard drive was designed to work with the bone density machine and specialized software would be needed to extract information.

Thousands of documents with sensitive information were found in a publicly accessible dumpster. An investigation began on February 20 when officers were alerted to three dumpsters filled with documents dating back to 2005. ë_The information included Social Security numbers, driver's licenses, phone numbers, and addresses. The landlord of the space leased by Mo' Money appears to have mistakenly cleaned out the office space before Mo' Money's shredding service could access the documents. The IRS is now conducting a federal investigation related to identity theft.

Company: Piedmont Behavioral Healthcare (PBH), Alamance-Caswell LME (AC LME)
Description of incident: A miscommunication caused AC LME to lose access to servers containing sensitive health information. ë_An Alamance County employee mistakenly changed a lock on the facility that housed data servers for AC LME.ë_ë_It appears that AC LME forgot to inform the county that AC LME was extending a contract for server maintenance.ë_ë_Former consumers of AC LME, including those who became PBH consumers on October 1, 2011, may have had their personal health information stored on these servers. The servers are now in the possession of the county and could contain the names, Social Security numbers, medical record identification numbers, addresses, and diagnoses of AC LME consumers. LME officials have not had access to the server room without being monitored by a county employee or with the forensics team assigned to examine the servers.

A former Burger King employee used a skimming device to capture customer information. ë_Customers who used their credit cards at the drive-through during the late-night shift had their information copied, sold, and used to make fraudulent purchases. The dishonest employee, the person who misused the data to create forged credit cards, and two others who made fraudulent purchases were all arrested. ë_A total of $14,000 in goods were purchased.

A steady flow of employees of Weather Shield have been reporting identity theft in the form of fraudulent tax returns. The company, or one of the company's affiliates that had access to employee financial information, must have experienced some type of breach or breaches. Over 60 employees have discovered that someone had already filed and collected their tax returns. Employees experienced the problem for 2010 and 2011 tax returns, but no one has been charged for the crimes.

Documents with names, Social Security numbers, and discharge dates of veterans were discovered unattended in the lobby entrance of Robley Rex VA. An extensive review was conducted by VA officials and they concluded there was no reason to believe any information was misused or that any malicious activity was involved. ë_Neither the reason for the breach nor the details of the breach discovery were revealed.

Company: Law Office of Ashley Bell, Department of Family and Children Services, Court Appointed Special Advocates (CASA)
Description of incident: Sensitive client files were found in a newspaper recycling bin at The Gainesville Times. ë_The files were related to the physical and sexual abuse of juveniles and client Social Security and phone numbers were exposed. ë_The breach may have been caused by a college intern who disposed of the files inappropriately. ë_Some files were as recent as 2009, but all cases were closed.

People who had an unclaimed check or refund from the University of Florida had their Social Security numbers posted on Florida's Unclaimed Property website. ë_The information had been posted in July of 2005 and is from debts prior to that time, but had been posted through January 12, 2012. ë_The University submitted its Annual Unclaimed Property Report to the Florida State Department of Financial Services. ë_The state accidentally posted the Social Security numbers in addition to the usual information. ë_The University of Florida was the only entity affected by the mistake. ë_Students, employees, and vendors may have been affected.

People who were members of the Transformers Club run by Fun Publications became aware that their credit card information had been compromised. Fun Publications conducted an investigation and determined that their e-commerce database had been compromised sometime around January 31. ë_Members were encouraged to monitor their credit cards closely and to consider replacing any cards that were used with Fun Publications for event registration, club store purchases, or other purchases. One member who used similar login information for both the Transformers Club and PayPal realized that his PayPal account had been compromised.ë_

Company: Los Angeles County Police Canine Association
Description of incident: The FBI is investigating an incident that resulted in the information of over 100 law enforcement officers being posted online. ë_Hackers obtained the names, addresses, and phone numbers of officers who are part of the Los Angeles County Police Canine Association (LACPCA). ë_Private emails from officers may have also been obtained. ë_ ë_

The personal information of over 24 members of the LAPD's command staff was posted on a website. ë_Officers had their property records, campaign contributions, biographical information and, in a few cases, the names of their family members posted. ë_This breach appears to be different from the one that affected members of Coalition of Law Enforcement and Retail (CLEAR) on or around December 11.

Company: Office of Dr. Jeremiah J. Twomey
Description of incident: An office burglary that occurred sometime during the weekend of December 31, 2011 resulted in the theft of an external hard drive. ë_The hard drive contained patient names, addresses, medical conditions, and diagnoses. ë_The hard drive also held an unspecified number of patient Social Security numbers and dates of birth.

On September 26, 2011, Hackensack University Medical Center became aware that a dishonest employee had accessed patient information prior to September 1, 2011. ë_A former employee working as a clerk took confidential patient files from an outpatient clinic. ë_The files contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, health insurance cards, and other insurance information. ë_No medical records were taken.

Company: University of Central Missouri Police Department (UCM)
Description of incident: After two documents containing student personal information were stolen, it was discovered that a former University police officer and his wife were responsible.  They used the names, Social Security numbers, and birth dates of students enrolled in 2005 and 2006 summer sessions.  The thieves fraudulently opened bank accounts, received student loans, and applied for credit and debit cards.  The losses total more than $30,000.

A former worker for the Miami-Dade school board misused student information. ë_The dishonest employee worked as a clerk and accessed the student information for the purpose of obtaining fraudulent credit cards with her boyfriend. An unknown number of student Social Security numbers were accessed and used. ë_She was caught in the act of stealing the Social Security numbers in 2009.

Company: Miami Central High School, Miami Northwestern High School, Golden Glades Elementary, Divine Sports Inc.
Description of incident: Divine Sports marketed itself as a non-profit that tutored at-risk youth. ë_It appears that the owner of the company billed the Miami-Dade School District for hours of tutoring that never occurred. The company even created reports for students that did not exist by using the information of real students. ë_Hundreds of thousands of dollars may have been fraudulently obtained over multiple years. The fraud was discovered in 2010. ë_Divine is located in multiple states and the corporate office denied any control over the day-to-day operations of Divine Sports in Miami.

Company: Blue Cross Blue Shield (BCBS) of North Carolina
Description of incident: An employee of BCBS North Carolina accidentally sent an email that revealed the email addresses of all customers who received the email. ë_Customers received the email as notification of changes to their billing cycle on Wednesday, February 29. ë_The employee error meant that anyone who received the email could then send unwanted messages referencing BCBS or unrelated content to other customers who received the email.

An office burglary in October of 2011 resulted in the theft of a laptop and other items. ë_The laptop contained the information of current and former patients. It is unclear what type of information the laptop contained. ë_A widespread notification of the breach was released in March after many patients could not be reached by mail.

Someone accessed student information and posted it on Twitter @LindenLeaks. ë_The information was from the Fall 2011 semester and included grades, majors, phone numbers, and email addresses. ë_The account was eventually deleted from Twitter. ë_The person who originally posted the information online commented that the document had been downloaded nearly 140 times since being posted.

An unsuccessful attempt to access a database was detected by Trident University on November 29, 2011. ë_It contained usernames and passwords of current and former students. ë_The attempt appeared to be unsuccessful and no other information was contained in the database. ë_Trident University offered credit monitoring services despite the belief that the attempt to access non-financial information had been unsuccessful. ë_

Try Media's ActiveStore application was attacked by intruders who were able to intercept and obtain the credit card information of customers. ë_Credit card numbers, expiration dates, security codes, addresses, email addresses, and passwords to user accounts for transactions that occurred between November 4, 2011 and December 2, 2011 were accessed. ë_

A woman found tax return information lying on the ground in front of an abandoned Jackson Hewitt on or around October 22. Hundreds of documents were exposed. The building owner called a shredding company to dispose of the documents, but ended up leaving them outdoors until the disposal company arrived. ë_The person responsible claimed that all the records were over four years old and were difficult to transport from the office. ë_The paperwork came from the Jackson Hewitt office at 1734 Divisadero St.

Company: RJL Insurance Services, LLC, RJL Wealth Management
Description of incident: RJL Insurance Services became aware of a vulnerability in its computer network that may have resulted in the exposure of some electronic files. ë_The information was secured, but some RJL files were accessible for a period of two weeks in late September and early October of 2011. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and medical conditions may have been exposed. ë_

An office burglary on New Year's Eve 2011 resulted in the loss of hardware that contained sensitive personal information. ë_The full names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and medical information of clients were on the hardware. ë_Impairment Resources notified patients in February and then filed for bankruptcy in March. The high cost of handling the breach led directly to the decision to file for bankruptcy.

Company: SF Fire Credit Union, Pacifica-Coastside Credit Union
Description of incident: The December 29, 2011 theft of a laptop from a parked car in San Francisco resulted in the loss of personal information. ë_The information was being used in preparation for a merger between SF Fire Credit Union and Pacifica-Coastside Credit Union. ë_Current and former account holders had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and Pacifica-Coastside Credit Union account information.

BDO was contracted by Rubio's to perform financial auditing services. ë_A BDO employee accidentally removed one or more CD-ROMs from the office. ë_The CD-ROM or CD-ROMs contained a list of Rubio's workers' compensation claimants and a list of people who owned equity shares in Rubio's Restaurants, Inc. ë_The CD-ROM or CD-ROMS appear to have been stolen from the BDO employee's vehicle. ë_The workers' compensation information contained names, claim numbers, medical status, and date of loss. ë_The medical status information included the employees' claim for injuries or illnesses. ë_No Social Security numbers were involved. ë_The partial equity roll list contained names and Social Security numbers.

A security company searching the web for sensitive data uncovered personally identifiable information from IndyMac Bank and Indy Mac Resources employees, and possibly others associated with the firms. ë_IndyMac Bank failed sometime around July of 2008. ë_The information is related to IndyMac employee pension benefits analysis and appears to have been placed on a public web server by an employee of a contractor for IndyMac. ë_People who were employed by either IndyMac firm between January 1, 1999 and January 1, 2005 had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, earnings, hire dates, and other employment related information exposed. ë_It was available as early as January of 2007 and as recently as December of 2011. ë_

On February 10, 2012, DHI Mortgage became aware that a software security breach by external sources had occurred in its Internet Loan Prequalification System. ë_DHI Mortgage immediately isolated the affected server, purged certain affected files, and modified the electronic security measures. ë_People who provided their information online for pre-qualification may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, contact information, marital status, employment information, income, asset information, and liability information exposed.

A laptop was stolen from the home of a nurse on January 18, 2012. ë_It contained the names, dates of birth, partial diagnosis information, and internal codes associated with patients' laboratory tests. ë_The information is from patients of the Adult Sickle Cell Clinic. ë_

A thief or thieves entered Huntsville Hospital and impersonated a vendor in order to collect old barrels of X-rays. ë_Thieves commonly use this tactic to obtain X-rays. ë_The X-rays are then stripped for silver. ë_The X-rays contained patient names, dates of birth, and medical records. ë_There were over 1,000 X-rays, but only 125 to 175 patients were affected.

The theft of 57 hard drives from a BlueCross BlueShield of Tennessee training facility last October has put at risk the private information of approximately 500,000 customers in at least 32 states. The hard drives contained 1.3 million audio files and 300,000 video files. The files contained customers' personal data and protected health information that was encoded but not encrypted, including: names and BlueCross ID numbers. In some recordings-but not all-diagnostic information, date of birth, and/or a Social Security number were exposed. BCBS of TN estimates that the Social Security numbers of approximately 220,000 customers may be at risk. UPDATE (4/29/10): The number of plan members whose data were exposed has grown from 521,761, an estimate made in March, to nearly one million, as of April 2, according to a report issued by Mary Thompson, spokeswoman for the Tennessee Blues.UPDATE (11/3/10): According to a letter sent to the New Hampshire Attorney General's Office, the total number of individuals affected was 1,023,209. ë_BCBS used a three-tier system to categorize individuals affected by the breach. ë_The total includes 451,274 clients whose Social Security numbers were involved, 319,325 clients whose personal and diagnostic health information was involved and 239,730 clients who had personally identifiable information that was neither medical nor their Social Security number. ë_BlueCross Blue Shield also reported receiving fewer than 10 requests for credit restoration services from those who had their Social Security numbers exposed.UPDATEë_(3/14/2012): Blue Cross Blue Shield of Tennessee (BCBST) reached a $1.5 million resolution agreement with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. BCBS of Tennessee kept the drives and network data closet in a facility that was secured by a property management company. ë_The closet was secured by biometric and keycard scan security with a magnetic look and an additional door with a keyed lock. ë_BCBST eventually vacated most of the leased office space. Thieves may have taken the opportunity to steal the 57 unencrypted hard drives from the closet while the space was not fully occupied.
The unauthorized disclosure of paper records sometime around December 22, 2011 may have resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_
The unauthorized disclosure of paper records on November 30, 2011 may have resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_

Company: Department of Medical Assistance Services, Affiliated Computer Services (ACS), Inc.
Description of incident: The unauthorized disclosure of paper records may have resulted in the exposure of the protected health information of people associated with Department of Medical Assistance Services (DMAS). The incident related to DMAS's relationship with Affiliated Computer Services (ACS) and occurred sometime between November 2, 2011 and November 16, 2011.ë_
The February 11, 2012 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of protected health information.

The theft of a laptop on or around November 10, 2011 may have resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_It is unclear if this incident is related to a December 29, 2011 incident that also resulted in the theft of a laptop that contained protected health information.

The December 29, 2011 theft of a laptop may have resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_It is unclear if this incident is related to a November 10, 2011 theft of a laptop that contained protected health information.

A staff member of the University Advisement Center at BYU accidentally included a complete list of international student names, email addresses, phone numbers, and student ID numbers in an email notification about a career workshop. ë_BYU immediately apologized for the error and noted that all of the student information except for student ID numbers could easily be found in the BYU directory.

The personal information of students was accidentally sent in an email attachment as a response to a request for data. ë_The mistake was noticed immediately and all copies of the file were removed from the system of the party requesting data. ë_Student names, addresses, and Social Security numbers were exposed. Humboldt State University warned students to be vigilant about phishing, but stated that it is unlikely the data was misused.

Edmund Optics identified suspicious activity on their website on February 26, 2012. ë_It was determined that a security breach had occurred and that some customer accounts had been compromised. ë_The breach most likely occurred on February 8 and resulted in the theft of some customers' credit card information.ë_The website was secured and preventative measures were increased. ë_

An employee of another company discovered a security issue in Oink. ë_Oink is a "rate everything" application from mobile application developer Milk Inc. ë_The security issue allowed anyone to download personal information of another Oink user by entering another person's username. ë_Folders with associated email addresses, photos, and other user site information may have been exposed. Oink shutdown and the employees of Milk Inc. joined Google for a new project shortly after the issue was discovered.

The theft of a company-issued laptop from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the employee's car while it was at home and contained the names, Social Security numbers, races, national origins, genders, dates of birth, contact information, college affiliations, grade-point averages, and other information of employees. ë_The hard drive was not encrypted. ë_The Kennedy Space Center had planned to have all hard drives encrypted by September 2012 prior to the breach.
Three computers were stolen on December 30, 2011. ë_One of the computers contained the protected health information of patients. ë_

Company: Coca-Cola Company Family Federal Credit Union
Description of incident: The theft of two laptops resulted in the exposure of credit union member information. The laptops were stolen on December 21, 2011 and contained names and Social Security numbers, as well as credit card numbers in some cases.

A woman found over 1,000 detailed abortion records in a dumpster when she went to dump her recycling near a local elementary school. ë_The records included names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, telephone numbers, emergency family contacts, patient health histories, number of children, term of pregnancies, number of previous abortions, reasons for failing to go through with the abortion procedures, and fees paid for the procedures. Many of the records were from 2001 and 2002. ë_The physician who ran the practice admitted to dumping the records without attempting to properly destroy them. ë_His clinic had closed in 2005 after he lost his medical license. ë_The county district attorney commented that he will most likely not pursue a criminal case against the former physician.

Records Breached: 32 million (No SSNs or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The security firm Imperva issued a warning to RockYou that there was a serious SQL Injection flaw in their database. Such a flaw could grant hackers access to the service's entire list of user names and passwords in the database. Imperva said that after it notified RockYou about the flaw, it was apparently fixed over the weekend. But that's not before at least one hacker gained access to what they claim is all of the 32 million accounts; 32,603,388 to be exact. The database included a full list of unprotected plain text passwords and email addresses.UPDATEë_(4/21/2011): The 32 million email addresses and passwords exposed include log in information from social networking sites like Facebook and MySpace. ë_On April 18, 2011 a court ruled that the loss of information caused injury. The court determined that "the unauthorized disclosure of personal information via the Internet is itself relatively new, and therefore more likely to raise issues of law not yet settled in the courts." ë_The court also found that RockYou.com's privacy policy language, which stated that RockYou.com's servers were secure, did not automatically preclude the plaintiff's allegation that a contract had been breached because the plaintiff alleged that the servers were not secure.UPDATEë_(3/27/2012): The Federal Trade Commission is alleging that RockYou violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act Rule (COPPA Rule) by collecting information from approximately 179,000 children. ë_A proposed FTC settlement order requires RockYou to pay a civil penalty of $250,000 to settle COPPA charges. In addition to the penalty, the company would be barred from future deceptive claims regarding company privacy and data security, required to implement and maintain a data security program, and barred from future violations of the COPPA rule.

The October 15 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of unencrypted personal information. ë_Residential housing data was on the laptop. This included names, the full Social Security numbers of some people, and the last four digits of most. ë_UPDATEë_(3/26/2012): Maloney Properties, Inc. agreed to pay $15,000 in civil penalties. ë_The property management firm must also ensure that personal information is not unnecessarily stored on portable devices, ensure that all personal information stored on portable devices is properly encrypted, ensure that all portable devices containing personal information are stored in a secure location, and effectively train employees on the policies and procedures with respect to maintaining the security of personal information. Up to 621 people were affected by the car theft of an employee's unencrypted laptop.
