A man stole 100 debit and credit cards, some bottles of alcohol, and cash from the office of a bar called Pure. The thief managed to use one of the stolen cards at a convenience store before being caught for a separate incident involving robbery by assault. Cameras showed that the man had entered through a ventilation shaft connected to the bar's office.

An H&R Block office manager was caught wearing a disguise near the ATMs of three banks. The employee's vehicle was searched and contained $2,960 in cash, and client records with dates of birth, names, and Social Security numbers. A total of $6,900 cash, H&R Block Emerald Cards, and the personal information of additional people were found at the home of the employee's girlfriend. The number of fraudulent tax returns, victims, and years the employee worked for H&R Block were not revealed.

Company: Department of Child Support Services, International Business Machines (IBM), Iron Mountain, Inc.
Description of incident: On March 12, 2012, the Department of Child Support Services (DCSS) was notified that contractors International Business Machines (IBM) and Iron Mountain, Inc. could not locate several computer devices that had been shipped from Colorado to California. Californians who used state child support services were affected by the loss. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, driver's licenses, names of health insurance providers, health insurance plan membership identification numbers, and employer information may have been exposed. ë_

Company: Health Net Inc., International Business Machines (IBM)
Description of incident: Nine disc drives that contained sensitive health information went missing from Health Net's data center in Rancho Cordova, California.ë_ The drives contained the personal information of 1.9 million current and former policyholders, compromising their names, addresses, health information, Social Security numbers and financial information. The 1.9 million victims include 622,000 California residents enrolled in Health Net HMOs, 223,000 Californians enrolled in Health Net PPOs and people enrolled in Medicare and other plans. The drives were discovered missing on January 21, but affected individuals were not notified until March 14.UPDATEë_(06/07/2011): A class-action lawsuit seeks $5 million from Health Net Inc. and its vendor IBM. ë_The complaint alleges that Health Net and IBM breached their duty of confidentiality and negligently allowed the release of highly personal and confidential information. The complaint alleges violation of California's Confidentiality of Medical Information Act, Cal. Civ. Codeë_ë_ 56; Cal. Civ. Codeë_ë_ 1798.2, which concerns the unauthorized disclosure of customer records; Cal. Bus. & Prof. Codeë_ë_ 17200, California's unfair-competition law; and public disclosure of private facts. ë_The lawsuit is seeking injunctive relief, compensatory damages, declaratory relief, and attorney fees and costs. ë_The citation is Bournas v. Health Net Inc., No.2_11-CV-01262, complaint filed (E.D. Cal. May 11, 2011).UPDATEë_(08/09/2011): Health Net's chief operating officer apologized to customers after it was discovered that the original analysis of the breach was flawed. ë_Around 124,000 Oregon residents who were current members, former members, or employees were believed to have been affected. ë_Health Net discovered that an additional 6,300 Oregonians had their personal information on the stolen computer drives. ë_

Hackers affiliated with LulzSec (Reborn) claimed responsibility for revealing a database of militarysingles.com names, usernames, email addresses, IP addresses, and passwords on the Internet. ë_People who used their same email and password combination for Militarysingles.com and other sites are encouraged to change their passwords. Militarysingles.com is owned by ESingles, Inc. ë_An ESingles executive claimed that no evidence of an attack had been found as of March 28; however, a number of sources revealed that they could download and decrypt sensitive information by following a Twitter announcement.UPDATEë_(3/28/2012): ESingles released a statement claiming that a thorough investigation revealed that the database had not been hacked. A discrepancy between the number of users in the militarysingles.com database, the use of encrypted user passwords, and the fact that the website was already scheduled to be down for maintenance during the time the hackers claimed to have taken it down led ESingles to this conclusion.

On or around March 6, a spreadsheet containing the names and contact information of active and retired Local 522 members was sent by a Local 522 employee to the Sacramento Central Labor Council (CLC). ë_The spreadsheet contained member Social Security numbers, but was only supposed to provide member mailing addresses. ë_The email did not stop at CLC and was forwarded to Capitol Mailing, Inc. ë_The mistake was discovered on March 23 after Local 522 members received mailing labels that displayed their Social Security numbers. ë_

Around 100 customers have reported fraudulent charges to their financial accounts. ë_Investigators believe that Lafrance's credit and debit system was breached electronically in early February 2011. Lafrance Hospitality consists of many businesses. ë_Anyone who has used a debit or credit card at White's of Westport or Bittersweet Farm since February could be at risk. ë_Lafrance updated its security after the incident.

Company: San Francisco Head Start, San Francisco State University
Description of incident: The San Francisco Head Start/Early Head Start database was accessed by one or more unauthorized parties between August 2011 and November 2011. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, contact information, health data, dates of birth, and other personal information may have been exposed. ë_Head Start claimed that the delay in notification of the breach was due to an ongoing law enforcement investigation. ë_It is unclear how San Francisco State University was involved.

Company: United Healthcare Inc., Futurity First Insurance Group
Description of incident: A hard drive containing information on United Healthcare Medicare plan members was stolen from Futurity First Insurance Group. ë_Member names, Social Security numbers, and in some cases, birth dates and private health information were exposed. ë_Futurity First, United Healthcare's sales and marketing services provider, sent the hard drive to a vendor for repair. ë_The hard drive was stolen from the vendor on or around June 28 July 28 and reported stolen on August 12. ë_Futurity First then told United Healthcare on September 14.ë_UPDATE (10/30/2011): Three additional organizations were affected by the breach.ë_ A total of 705 members from Mutual of Omaha Insurance Company, 1,631 United of Omaha Life Insurance Company enrollees, and 3,994 United Health Group Health Plan in Minnesota enrollees were also affected in addition to the 582 originally reported.ë_ Information from the Health and Human Services website also reveals that the hard drive was lost on July 28.UPDATE (11/4/2011): A total of 690 American Continental Insurance Company members from Tennessee were also affected by the breach.

The city of Providence accidentally provided the Social Security numbers of almost 3,000 former employees when releasing information for a public records request. ë_GoLocalProv filed an Access to Public Records Act request in order to obtain information about pension recipients in Providence. ë_The city's legal team responded by emailing a .pdf file with retiree names, dates of retirement, dates for cost-of-living-adjustments, and monthly pension received each month. ë_Social security numbers and employee identification numbers were displayed as redacted in the document, but could easily be read when the .pdf file was expanded or when the highlight color of the document was changed to a light color.

A server management error caused files containing sensitive information to be made publicly accessible between July of 2011 and the breach's discovery on March 13, 2012. ë_A classroom exercise revealed that the information was compromised and the University of Tampa's IT office was immediately informed of the discovery. ë_The University of Tampa then notified Google and asked that the cached file be removed from the search engine. One file included 6,818 records of students who attended in Fall of 2011. ë_Two other files contained the information of an additional 29,540 people and included University ID numbers, names, Social Security numbers, and photos. ë_Some people also had their dates of birth exposed.The IT office at the University of Tampa concluded that the files had only been accessed by the people who reported the breach.UPDATEë_(3/22/2012):ë_Additionally, 22,722 current and former faculty, staff, and students who were associated with the University between January 29, 2000 and July 11, 2011 may have had their information exposed.ë_The IT office confirmed that these files had only been accessed by University insiders as well. The University will not cover the cost of credit monitoring services for those who were affected.

A hacker was able to access the names, mailing addresses, email addresses, dates of birth, usernames, passwords, phone numbers, and credit card details of customers. ë_The breach occurred and was detected on Sunday, March 25. ë_Manhattan Prep removed all credit card information previously associated with compromised customer accounts from their database. ë_Customer account passwords were automatically reset. ë_Customers were also encouraged to change any passwords that were used for both Manhattan Prep and other accounts. ë_

A dishonest Florida State Farm agent was caught selling customer information to a third party.  The former employee was terminated and arrested.  The agent's buyer and purpose for wanting the information was not reported.

On March 6, 2012, an investigation confirmed that an employee of an unnamed State Farm office may have used customer information in an inappropriate manner. ë_An unknown number of customers may have had their names, addresses, credit card numbers, and Social Security numbers misused by the dishonest employee.

On February 15, 2012, Union Bank discovered that a former contractor kept proprietary bank data in his possession after leaving the company on January 31, 2012. ë_The bank data included some customer information such as names, account numbers, home addresses, phone numbers, and email addresses.

Two masked men stole several bags of documents and records from a state courier truck outside the Lawrence Registry of Motor Vehicle (RMV) branch on Wednesday April 4. ë_However, the trash included records from the Wilmington branch of the RMV. Registration transactions, duplicate titles, crash reports, citation payments, rebate requests, and municipal parking records from transactions that occurred between Friday March, 30 and Monday, April 2 were stolen.
A hacker or hackers accessed information from the University of California Riverside. ë_A total of 40 email addresses and corresponding passwords were posted online.

Company: Colt Express Outsourcing Services, CNET Networks
Description of incident:
Burglars stole computer systems 
          from the offices of the company that administers the Internet publisher's 
          benefit plans. The computers contained names, birth dates, Social Security 
          numbers and employment information of the beneficiaries of CNET's health 
          insurance plans. CNET was only one of several clients affected. 
          UPDATE (8/26/08): Among 
          the companies whose staffers have been exposed by the Colt break-in 
          in Walnut Creek, California: Google, Bebe Stores, Alston & Bird, and 
          the California Bankers Assn.
A hacker or hackers posted 35,959 usernames, email addresses, and passwords online.

More than 200 employees were notified that a non-government entity may have seen their personal information. The non-government entity were lawyers for two of three workers who fought a security access suspension against them. It take the Navy 17 months to inform employees at the Naval Facilities Engineering Service Center in Port Hueneme, California, that their Social Security numbers had been inadvertently released.

A hacker or hackers posted administrator usernames and corresponding passwords, as well as the email addresses of 250 state and Plainfield employees online. ë_Some of the information included addresses, phone numbers, and email passwords, and some information was from employee contacts.ë_

Company: Minuteman Civil Defense Corps, Declaration Alliance
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers posted 30 names, telephone numbers, email addresses, and corresponding passwords online. ë_

A payment drop box was broken into sometime during the weekend of March 5. Customers who used the box around that time may have had their banking institution information, check account numbers, addresses, names, phone numbers, and driver's license numbers stolen. ë_PG&E will change the account numbers and passwords of customers who had their information stolen.
A hacker or hackers posted 434 usernames and corresponding passwords, as well as email addresses online.

An external hard drive has gone missing. Approximately 35,000 current and former members of the Arkansas Army National Guard are affected by the loss. The drive included names, Social Security numbers and other personal information which potentially places the affected soldiers at risk for identity theft.UPDATE (5/18/10): The external hard drive containing personal information on over 32,000 current and former Arkansas Guardsmen that was reported missing on February 22 has now been recovered and destroyed. The drive was reported missing by an Arkansas Soldier who used the device as a personal backup of his work related information. This included a copy of the Guard's personnel database which contained personal information on all Soldiers who have served in the Arkansas Army National Guard since 1991.

A hacker or hackers posted email addresses, passwords, and usernames online. ë_Members of similar online forums recommended that users change their passwords for other sites since members often use the same email address, password, and username combination for multiple sites.

A concerned citizen found a box of sensitive medical documents in a dumpster and contacted a local news team. ë_The box contained hundreds of documents that included copies of driver's licenses, prescriptions, signatures, and other patient information. ë_The box was removed by Indiana University Medical Group before investigators arrived. ë_Indiana University Medical Group claimed that the information was accidentally discarded rather than shredded. The documents were properly disposed after being collected.

Company: Bright Directions College Savings Program, Illinois State Treasurer's Office
Description of incident: A mailing error led to the Social Security numbers of over 36,000 people to be visible from the outside of envelopes mailed in October.ë_ Those who were enrolled in the Illinois Treasurer's Office Bright Directions college savings program were affected.

Company: Boston Veterans Benefits Administration Regional Office
Description of incident: Some veteran benefit information was mailed to the wrong addresses on August 25. Of the 6,299 letters sent to incorrect addresses, 3,913 had full Social Security numbers and 2,386 had Veterans Benefits Administration claim numbers.  A program error caused some of the letters to be mailed to the incorrect addresses.

Company: Children's Hospital and Research Center at Oakland
Description of incident: Approximately 1,000 patients received information about themselves and other patients in the mail. According to the Hospital's website "equipment designed to generate, fold and stuff documents for mailing was programmed to fold and stuff two pages rather than one. This programming error caused guarantor billing statements prepared on May 25 and May 26 to be collated and mailed incorrectly."

Highmark notified 3,700 members that documents containing their names, policy identification and Social Security numbers were missing. This is the second such data spill involving the region_Ñés dominant health insurer in four months. In January, the company mailed a premium billing statement to Boscov_Ñés Department Store, a client in Reading, according to Highmark. The envelope arrived damaged and torn; pages were also missing. The pages included the names and other identifying information for 3,700 members.

Company: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)
Description of incident: Notifications of a mailing error are being sent to an unknown number of members who signed up for Term Life insurance underwritten by New York Life Insurance. ë_Offers to upgrade insurance plans were sent to the homes of other members. ë_People's names, member numbers and coverage amounts were exposed.

A system error caused mail to be sent to the wrong addresses. ë_Current and former addresses were mixed up and mail containing an explanation of benefits was sent to incorrect (former) addresses.UPDATEë_(4/15/2011): The mailing error occurred on October 16, 2010 and was discovered in late January of 2011.

United Healthcare notified members of a Deere and Company employee benefits plan of a mistake that led to claims summary statements being sent to the wrong addresses. Dates of services, categories of service, cost of service, and physician names were included.

Law enforcement informed TJUH management that sensitive documents had been recovered during an investigation. ë_Radiology registration documents with patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, home phone numbers, work phone numbers, dates of birth, TJUH account numbers, TJUH medical record numbers, insurance information, emergency contact information, and special radiology studies performed had been stolen from TJUH. ë_It is unclear when the theft occurred. ë_Patients who received services between February 4 and March 22, 2005 were affected. ë_

A hacker or hackers were able to intercept customer information online between August 22 and September 28 of 2011. ë_Customers who were affected may have had their login, password, and credit card information obtained. ë_Anyone who used the same login and password combination for reuseit.com and other websites should change their password. ë_

On March 23, 2012, X-Rite learned that a database server had been attacked by a malicious third party. ë_The names, contact information, and credit card information of customers who made purchases on X-Rite's website pantone.com may have been exposed. ë_
Computer equipment that contained patient insurance information was taken during an office burglary.

An administrative error resulted in recently admitted students receiving an email with the information of all recently admitted students. ë_Student names, addresses, grades, LSAT scores, race, scholarship amount, and other types of personal information were available in the email attachment. No Social Security numbers or dates of birth were in the emailed spreadsheet. ë_Students were encouraged to treat the data with the confidentiality of a lawyer and immediately delete the email. ë_

An employee of Wayne County's personnel department accidentally sent an email with a sensitive attachment. ë_People who were members of AFSCME Locals 25, 409, 1659, and 3309 received an email about health insurance with employee names, ID numbers, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and other information available in an attached file. ë_The mistake was noticed immediately and a follow-up email was sent with instructions to destroy the previous email. UPDATEë_(4/16/2012):ë_About 1,300 union members received the email and it contained the information of over 1,000 employees.
A hacker or hackers accessed information from the Berrien County Sheriff's Department. ë_An unspecified number of people had unspecified types of information posted online.

A printout is missing that 
            contains information about each of NCC's 21,000 students, including 
            names, SSNs, addresses, and phone numbers. It disappeared from a desk 
            in the Student Activities Office.

Two campus computers were determined to have been infected by malware. ë_The breach occurred when a faculty or staff member opened an email that contained a virus. ë_The virus was immediately detected. ë_Faculty, staff, and students affiliated with the school between the early 1990's and the day of the breach may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses exposed. ë_Housatonic's president acknowledged that the cost of handling the breach could be as much as $500,000.

A foreign hacker accessed the information of guests who stayed at the hotel between May 21, 2011 and March 10, 2012. ë_An unspecified number of credit and debit card numbers with corresponding names were accessed, but their associated PINs were not compromised.ë_

Owners of a mini-storage business discovered that Associated Surveyors had abandoned sensitive information. ë_The rent on the storage space had not been paid for over a year and Associated Surveyors and the items in the space were set to be auctioned off. The mini-storage owners decided to properly dispose of the documents in the unit when they found Social Security numbers, Social Security card applications, checks, bank account numbers, tax return forms, and copies of other documents with sensitive personal information. ë_

A Virginia Military Institute (VMI) administrator emailed a spreadsheet with the grade point average of every member of VMI's senior class to the VMI student president. ë_The email should have only contained an attachment with the names and hometowns of potential 2012 graduates. ë_The second attachment was not only emailed to the student president, but was then forwarded to 258 senior students before the student president and VMI administration realized the mistake.

Someone managed to install malware on a Ruby's computer system. ë_Customer credit and debit card information was obtained and used to make fraudulent purchases across the United States and internationally. ë_The breach may have occurred as early as December 2011. ë_

Company: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS)
Description of incident: A UAMS physician sent financial data to an individual who was not a member of UAMS's workforce in February of 2012. ë_Patient identifiers had not been removed from the data and UAMS learned of the error on April 6. ë_Patients of interventional radiology seen at UAMS between 2009 and 2011 had their names, UAMS account numbers, dates of service, interventional radiology procedures, diagnosis codes, charges, and payments exposed.

A flash drive that contained Under Armour employee payroll information was lost by PricewaterhouseCoopers. ë_The information was being transmitted via mail for auditing purposes and went missing on or around April 12. Employee names, Social Security numbers, and salary information could have been exposed. it is unclear how many people were affected in the U.S. Under Armour employs 5,400 people worldwide.

Investigators determined that a breach must have occurred at the grocery store Glenwood IGA after nearly 300 people reported fraudulent charges on their credit cards. The credit card fraud began in early February and unauthorized purchase attempts were made across the globe. The method of the breach is not clear.ë_

A hacker or hackers posted the login information of two website administrators. ë_The information of 8 job users was posted, as well as an additional 3,647 usernames, passwords, and emails. Anyone who used the same username, password, and/or email combination for other sites is encouraged to change them immediately.
A hacker or hackers posted the information of users online. ë_It is unclear if this is related to an identical incident that occurred on October 23, 2011.
A physician's laptop was stolen from her husband's car. ë_The laptop contained patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, phone numbers, and addresses. The laptop was not encrypted. ë_

Company: Saint Mary's Hospital, Naugatuck Valley Community College
Description of incident: A Naugatuck Valley Community College instructor used patient X-rays from St. Mary's Hospital to teach radiology technology. ë_The instructor obtained the X-rays by using his Saint Mary's employee login to access medical records. ë_The X-rays were used without permission and contained patient names, dates of birth, and physician notes. ë_The instructor told students not to disclose the practice.

The theft of sensitive documents from an Oregon State Hospital supervisor's car resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_On Friday, April 13, a printed list of 550 hospital patients that included names, treating physicians, hospital identification numbers, and geographic information was stolen. Additionally, progress notes for 20 patients were stolen that included patient dates of birth, diagnoses, and other information. ë_It is not clear if patients who visited either the Salem Oregon State Hospital or the Portland Oregon State Hospital were affected by the breach.

I man found medical records stacked in a bag in a closet while checking for financial records in the home of his estranged wife. The records date from 2003 to 2007 and involve the information of patients of Sheppard Air Force Base's 82nd Medical Group. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, and in some cases, patient diagnoses were on the documents.

A resident physician printed out the records of 1,500 patients for research purposes. ë_The paper records were stored in a computer bag and the bag was stolen from the physician's car on February 25. ë_The records contained names, health information, and test results. They may have also contained the insurance information of some patients.UPDATEë_(4/20/2012): Medical record numbers, dates of treatments, diagnoses sites, cocci clinical numbers, and test results for HIV, AIDS, Hepatitis, and pregnancy may have also been exposed.

On March 23, 2012, an employee sent an unencrypted document to the personal emails of herself and her son. ë_The document contained the first names of customers and their Social security numbers. ë_Cigna became aware of the incident on March 27 and took immediate action. ë_The employee claimed that she had sent the document to obtain help with work from her son. She confirmed that both she and her son had deleted the email and was fired.

An unauthorized person or persons was able to access electronically-stored information relevant to BullMarket.com. ë_User names, credit card information, billing addresses, email addresses, and/or login information were compromised. ë_The breach occurred sometime between April 3 and April 7, 2012 and was discovered on April 11. Information as recent as June 2005 may have been exposed, but users with recent information appear to have not been affected.

An April 1, 2012 office burglary resulted in the theft of computer equipment with sensitive information. ë_A server that contained customer names and Social Security numbers or driver's license numbers was stolen. Additional information related to customer applications was also on the server.

An unknown number of customers had their personal information entered into the wrong field in a database. ë_The information should have been encrypted but was not because of the error. Customers may have received mail with their credit card number, driver's license number, Social Security number, passport number, or any combination of these elements printed on the outside of envelopes. The issue was discovered in late December of 2011.

A storeroom window at Saint Joseph's HealthCare Clinical Laboratory (HCCL) was discovered broken on February 2, 2012. ë_Two storage boxes containing HCCL lab requisition forms were missing from the center. ë_People who received laboratory services betweenë_October 24, 2011 and November 18, 2011, betweenë_December 13, 2012 and January 5, 2012, and also between January 17, 2012 and January 31, 2012, may have had their names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, addresses, and insurance information exposed.UPDATEë_(4/26/2012): At least 700 patients were affected. ë_Two boxes were discovered missing immediately after the robbery and a third was discovered missing on March 16.

Phoenix Cardiac Surgery inadvertently posted the clinical and surgical appointments of patients on an Internet-based calendar that was publicly accessible. ë_The error went unnoticed for an unspecified amount of time. ë_The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Office for Civil Rights (OCR) investigated the error and determined that Phoenix Cardiac Surgery had a number of Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) violations. ë_Phoenix Cardiac Surgery agreed to pay HHS a settlement totalling $100,000 and to comply with HIPAA. The resolution agreement can be found here.

Backup tapes, laptops 
            and disks containing Social Security numbers, clinical and demographic 
            information were stolen from the car of an employee. In a small number of cases, patient financial data was 
            stolen. UPDATE  
            (9/26/06)
            Providence Health System and the Oregon 
            Attorney General have filed a settlement agreement.  Providence 
            will provide affected patients with free credit monitoring, offer 
            credit restoration to patients who are victims of identity fraud, 
            and reimburse patients for direct losses that result from the data 
            breach.  The company must also enhance its security programs. 
            UPDATE  (7/15/08) Providence Health will pay $100,000 and adhere to a compliance plan 
            under the first ever Resolution Agreement negotiated by 
            CMS (Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services of the U.S. Dept. 
            of Health and Human Services) under the HIPAA Privacy and Security 
            Standards.

            The Corrective 
            Action Plan requires Providence to revamp its security policies 
            to include physical protections for portable devices and off-site 
            transport and storage of backup media. Further, it must implement 
            technical safeguards, such as encryption and password protection. 
            And it must conduct random compliance audits and submit compliance 
            reports to HHS for the next three years.UPDATEë_(4/16/2012): The Oregon Supreme Court struck down a class-action suit against Providence Health Systems. ë_The Oregon Supreme Court claimed that there was no evidence that any of the 365,000 patients who were affected by the breach suffered any financial loss or other adverse consequences.

The University became aware of an unintended disclosure. ë_Files with the information of current and former faculty and former students were placed on a web server that was not secure. ë_The information could have been accessed anytime between 2008 and the discovery of the error. ë_Names and Social Security numbers were exposed.

Company: Office of the Texas Attorney General
Description of incident: Lawyers responsible for challenging a voter ID law in Texas requested the Texas voter database for analysis. ë_The Texas Attorney General's office released encrypted discs with the personal records of 13 million Texas voters, but half still contained Social Security numbers. ë_A state police officer was dispatched to New York, Washington D.C., and Boston to retrieve the encrypted discs when the opposing lawyers revealed that a mistake had occurred.

Employees of Lake Worth School District received email notification of a possible computer security breach. ë_It appears that a former employee may have accessed the personal information of employees and could have misused it. ë_It is unclear if a breach actually occurred. It is also unclear how the former employee may have compromised the district's computer system.

Alumni who graduated before 1985 and requested copies of their transcripts may have been affected by a breach involving accidental disclosure. ë_Certain alumni had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and telephone numbers in an electronic file that was emailed to an individual who would not normally have access to such information. ë_The person who received the email notified the University.UPDATEë_(5/03/2012): This breach was erroneously listed as occurring in Corpus Christi, Texas on this site. The breach affected those who were associated with Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas.

The Pentagon contractor 
            may have compromised personal information. Information such as names, 
            addresses, birth dates, Social Security numbers and health information 
            about military personnel and their relatives were exposed when the data were not encrypted prior to being transmitted online.UPDATEë_(5/05/2012): Though 580,000 households were reported, a total of 867,000 people may have been affected.

Records Breached: Unknown (18 students requested that their grade be altered)
Description of incident: A high school student used the login credentials of his father to change student records. ë_The student's father worked at the school as a counselor. ë_At least 18 students paid for their attendance and course assignment records to be altered. The students who paid for the alterations were suspended. ë_It is unclear if other students had their information accessed or altered. ë_

A former employee used patient information to file false income tax returns. The information of 741 patients was accessible in a binder. ë_The employee worked as an intake coordinator at the Hospital from March 15 to August 18 of 2011. ë_The breach was not discovered until April 18 of 2012. ë_

Company: California Department of Justice, Computer and Technology Crime High-Tech Response Team (CATCH)
Description of incident: In November 2011, hackers accessed and released private email accounts belonging to a retired agent for the Department of Justice. ë_The retired agent was a member of the CATCH. ë_Some of the emails that the hackers released included data that contained the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and other personal information of an unknown number of consumers.

A former employee pled guilty to conspiracy to commit bank fraud and aggravated identity theft. ë_The former employee received $3,000 for his role in the conspiracy and his co-conspirators fraudulently made $84,169.37 from customers. ë_

A former manager of the Thurston Branch of Key Bank pled guilty to charges related to opening a Key Bank account in the name of someone else. He will be sentenced for identity theft and bank fraud. ë_The manager obtained and transferred customer names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth between January and May of 2007. ë_He eventual threatened and intimidated witnesses in August 2010. Key Bank had a total of $44,937.66 in expenses related to the breach.

Hackers were able to access and publicly post over 16,000 law enforcement files online. ë_Sensitive 911 calls, witness and victim statements, names of young crime victims, names and personal phone numbers of SWAT team members, a blueprint that could allow sex predators to avoid arrest, and possibly sheriff employee passwords were posted. SWAT team information such as the unit's operating guide and number of snipers was also posted. ë_Personal information including Swat team member home and cell phone numbers was posted as well. The breach occurred sometime around April 28, 2012.

A Northwestern Memorial Hospital employee was charged with one count of aggravated identity and one count of identity theft. The dishonest employee is accused of stealing the identities of patients to pay off personal bills. ë_Paperwork with the Social Security numbers, credit card numbers, and dates of birth of over 50 patients was found in the employee's home. ë_The dishonest employee's scheme was discovered when suspicious credit card activity related to the opening of utilities in the employee's name.

Company: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Description of incident: An online security breach occurred at the UNC-Charlotte campus and was discovered on January 31.ë_ It is unclear how much information could have been accessed. The number of people affected was not revealed.ë_ An email alert was sent to students and staff on February 15 in order to inform them that a "potentially significant data exposure of its Information Systems" had occurred.ë_ The University also stated that it had corrected the known issues related to the breach.UPDATEë_(5/09/2012): Around 350,000 people had their Social Security numbers exposed. Financial information was also exposed. ë_A system misconfiguration and incorrect access settings caused a large amount of electronic data hosted by the University to be accessible from the Internet. One exposure issue affected general University systems over a period of about three months. ë_A second exposure issue affected the college of engineering systems for over a decade.

Opening Ceremony discovered that an inadvertent breach of security resulted in the exposure of customer names, addresses, credit card numbers, credit card expiration dates, and credit card security codes. ë_The breach was discovered sometime in March and first occurred on or around February 16, 2012.UPDATEë_(5/11/2012): The breach lasted between February 16 and March 21 of 2012. Malware was discovered on the website on March 21. ë_Affected customers were mailed notification letters on May 4. ë_Either the credit card information was stored in an unencrypted format on the site in violation of Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS) practices, or a hacker was able to place something on the site to get credit card information after it was transmitted. It is more likely that Open Ceremony, an online clothing retailer, was not in compliance with PCI.

A Reading Hospital employee made paper copies of sensitive information and used them for training purposes at an unaffiliated educational facility. ë_The incident was discovered the next day and the employee was fired. ë_Patient medical test results, diagnoses, prescribed medications, Social Security numbers, medical histories, and other personal information were exposed.

Company: Lady of the Lake Regional Medical Center
Description of incident: A laptop went missing from a physician's office sometime between March 16 and March 20 of 2012. ë_The laptop contained patient outcomes data from patients in the adult ICU from 2000 to 2008. ë_Patient names, race, age, dates of admission and discharge from the Intensive Care Unit, and results of treatment may have been exposed.

An employee was fired after police informed Massachusetts Eye and Ear that the employee was being investigated for identity theft. ë_The employee had taken and misused patient names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. At least four of the employee's victims came from Massachusetts Eye and Ear, but she had access to the information of approximately 3,600 patients.

Company: Well United Methodist Church, Iowa Correctional Institute for Women
Description of incident: A former inmate was able to obtain and misuse the information of prison church volunteers. ë_The former inmate had held a leadership role in the congregation and was hired as an administrative assistant after being released in 2007. ë_Her position as administrative assistant may have allowed her to misuse the personal information that volunteers were required to submit in order to obtain prison security clearance.UPDATEë_(05/19/2012): The former inmate was sentenced to four years in prison for using the personal information of other church members to fraudulently obtain credit accounts. ë_She had worked as an administrative assistant in the program between her 2007 release and a 2008 probation that sent her back to prison. ë_She was able to misuse the information of 48 people once leaving prison.

Company: Florida Department of Children and Families
Description of incident: The information of Florida child care workers was placed on a state website. ë_The information was not password protected and could have been found through an internet search. An unnamed vendor working for the state of Florida was responsible for placing the information online. ë_Florida daycare workers may have had their dates of birth, names, and Social Security numbers exposed. It is not clear how long the information was exposed.

Cryptic Studios detected evidence of unauthorized access to a user database that occurred in December 2010. ë_Users may have had their account names, handles, encrypted versions of their passwords, dates of birth, email addresses, billing addresses, and partial credit card numbers exposed. ë_Some of the passwords that were exposed were decrypted. ë_Cryptic Studios reset all customer passwords that could have been affected after discovering the breach by performing security analysis. Anyone who uses the same password and email combination for other accounts is encouraged to change their password for those accounts as well.ë_
A hacker or hackers posted email addresses, plain-text passwords, and ID numbers online.

Company: South Shore Hospital, Active Data Solutions
Records Breached: 800,000 (unknown number of SSNs and financial information)
Description of incident: Computer files containing personal, health and financial information of volunteers, patients, vendors, business partners and employees from January 1996 through January 2010 may have been lost by a professional data management company.  Depending on the person's association with the hospital, the information exposed could be full name, address, phone number, date of birth, Social Security number, driver's license number, medical record number, patient number, bank account information, credit card number, diagnoses and treatment.UPDATE (9/10/10): Archive Data Solutions (formerly Iron Mountain Data Products) was revealed to be the company responsible for disposing of South Shore Hospital's records. Archive Data Solutions subcontracted the process to Graham Magnetics, who then lost the tapes in shipping.ë_ The tapes may have also had patient information from Harbor Medical Associates and patient and vendor information from South Shore Physician Hospital Organization.After investigating the incident the hospital decided not to mail notices or offer credit monitoring and identity theft services to those who may have been affected by the loss.ë_ It was determined that the risk of the data being accessed was extremely low and that notifications inside the hospital, on websites, via email and in newspapers would be enough.ë_ In addition, the Attorney General's office of Massachusetts has spoken out against the hospital's decision to skip precautions.UPDATEë_(5/24/2012): South Shore Hospital will pay $750,000 to settle HIPAA violation and state law charges. ë_The breach involved the loss of two of three boxes containing 473 unencrypted back-up computer tapes with sensitive information sometime between February 2010 and June of 2010. ë_A total of $250,000 in civil penalty fines and a payment of $225,000 for an education fund to be used by the Attorney General's Office to promote education concerning the protection of personal information and protected health information was determined. South Shore Hospital was given a credit of $275,000 to reflect the cost of security measures it had already taken subsequent to the breach.

An office burglary on or around March 26 resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Patient files containing names, phone numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and lab work were stolen from a laboratory. It is unclear why affected patients were not notified until two months after the incident.

A Boston Children's Hospital employee misplaced an unencrypted laptop during a conference in Buenos Aires. ë_It contained the names, dates of birth, diagnoses, and treatment information of patients were exposed.

Altrec discovered a potential information security incident involving the American Express credit cards of people who used the site. Customer information may have been compromised between June 2010 and March 2012. ë_The potential breach was discovered on May 7, but a detailed forensic investigation did not uncover any evidence of a security breach. ë_Customer names, addresses, American Express card account numbers, expiration dates, and four digit security codes were stored in Altrec's database and could have been exposed if anyone had accessed it.

A former customer service representative gathered account information directly from two customers during telephone calls and later attempted to use the information for personal purchases. ë_GCI decided to notify all other customers who may have been contacted by the dishonest former employee and warn them to check their accounts for any unusual activity. ë_

Hackers accessed sensitive information from the Glade County Sheriff's Department. ë_Ten names with associated email addresses, plain-text passwords, and usernames were posted online. ë_The information of 192 prisoners was also posted, but most of it could already be found through public records. ë_Prisoner names, genders, birth dates, hair and eye colors, heights, weights, last known addresses, and other details were posted.ë_

A member of law enforcement found a black canvas bag full of payroll files. ë_The bag may have been stolen or misplaced and carried worker names, Social Security numbers, and other personnel information related to taxes. Stacks of files were photographed behind Accurate Accounting. This led to the belief that the files had not been properly stored.

Employees at two Duane Reade stores were caught participating in a credit card fraud ring. ë_One employee at each store was found to have used an unauthorized device to scan customer credit cards prior to processing them through the store's system. People who made purchases at the stores between October 1, 2011 and February 16, 2012 may have been affected.

Company: United States Bureau of Justice Statistics (BJS)
Description of incident: Hackers from Anonymous claim to have leaked 1.7 gigabytes of data belonging to the United States Bureau of Justice Statistics. ë_The United States Bureau of Justice Statistics is part of the U.S. Department of Justice and analyzes data related to crimes in the U.S. The data file was posted on The Pirate Bay. It contained internal emails and the website's entire database.

On April 25, 2012, First Data learned that certain limited personal information about approximately 108,500 merchants who currently process with First Data or who applied for processing services had been shared outside of the company. The names, addresses, and Social Security numbers of merchants who submitted applications to First Data for merchant processing services were purposely disclosed to an outside party in January and February of 2012. ë_First Data later discovered that this action was not clearly permitted in some merchant contracts.UPDATE: (5/29/2012): Bank of America Merchant Services (BAMS), a joint venture between First Data Corporation and Bank of America, was also involved in the breach. ë_The personal information of 15,399 California residents was involved. ë_Of the 15,399 California residents affected, a total of 4,058 residents were merchant customers of BAMS.

Company: Serco, Inc., Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board
Description of incident: One of the computers used by the contractor Serco to support the Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board (FRTIB) was the target of a sophisticated cyber attack. ë_Thrift Savings Plan participants and others who received TSP payments may have had their information exposed. However, there is no evidence that the entire TSP network of 4.5 million participants was breached. A total of 43,587 participants may have had their Social Security numbers, names, and addresses compromised. An additional 80,000 may have had their Social Security numbers and no other information compromised. The attack appears to have occurred in July of 2011 and was discovered through an FBI investigation in April of 2012.
A hacker or hackers posted member names, email addresses, and contact information online.

The March 30 theft of a physician's laptop resulted in the exposure of personal information. The physician had violated VA policy by placing the personal information on his own laptop. ë_Veterans may have had the last four digits of their Social Security number, discharge date, and medical provider name exposed.

Between 300 and 350 transcripts from Summer Language Institute applicants were accessible through the University of Virginia website. ë_The human error was discovered when a student searched Google for an image of himself. ë_Students who applied to the University's program within the last two years may have had their names, transcript information, and Social Security numbers exposed. ë_Technology experts at the University blocked public access to the information and asked Google to remove its cache of the sensitive pages on June 5, 2012. ë_It is unclear how long the information was available.

A hacker or hackers accessed and publicly posted usernames, email addresses, and encrypted passwords from MOAB. Many law enforcement officials and heads of security were among the users who were affected.

On April 2, 2012, Incorporating Services learned that one of their servers was compromised by a malware attack. ë_Incorporating Services began investigating the breach after being informed by their internet hosting vendor and discovered that malicious software had allowed an unauthorized party to access data stored on the server. ë_Corporate officer Social Security numbers and names may have been exposed.UPDATE (6/06/2012): Rackspace has been identified as the internet hosting vendor. ë_Social Security numbers, credit card payment information such as expiration date and CVV, and possibly Automatic Clearing House (ACH) payment information were compromised.

Two people were charged with stealing more than $16,000 from 20 businesses and individuals in the Santa Clarita Valley area. ë_The man and woman were able to commit identity theft and run a check counterfeiting operation by retrieving and reassembling shredded checks from the trash bin of Valencia Self Storage. ë_Hundreds of bank account numbers, fake and stolen IDs and identity profiles, check making equipment, and counterfeiting checks were discovered at their residence. ë_A criminal complaint was filed on April 18 alleging felony counts of identity theft, check forgery, commercial burglary, grand theft, false impersonation, receiving stolen property, and unauthorized credit card use.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_Sixteen names, passwords, and email addresses were exposed. ë_The hack took place on or around February 24 and was reported on May 5.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. Seven administrators' login information including names, usernames, email addresses, postal addresses, and plain-text passwords was posted. The names, email addresses, and reservation information of 32 customers were also posted. The incident took place on or around April 8 and was reported on May 4.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_A total of 18 employee names, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

An unspecified number of eHarmony users were found to have had their passwords exposed after eHarmony investigated reports of passwords being posted on a hacker site. ë_Those who were affected had their passwords reset.

A guidance counselor accidentally sent an attachment with sensitive information to students via email. ë_The email was sent to members of the senior class and the attachment contained the names and student ID numbers of seniors. ë_Student Social Security numbers were used as student ID numbers in most cases.

Someone threw out hundreds of customer documents after the local LA Boxing was taken over by corporate. ë_The documents were found and reported by someone who witnessed another person going through the dumpster. ë_Names, addresses, credit card numbers and account numbers of people who were once gym members were left in a dumpster.

A concerned citizen found a dumpster overflowing with old gym memberships. ë_Member credit card information, Social Security numbers, addresses, and other information. ë_The information dates back from the late 1990s and early 2000s. ë_Memberships were originally from Fitness 1, but Fitness 1 sold the location to LA Fitness in 2000. ë_The hundreds of sensitive documents appear to have been abandoned by LA Fitness when it vacated the space. ë_A former Fitness 1 attorney took the exposed documents out of the dumpster after the discovery.

Company: California Department of Public Health, Bakersfield Memorial Hospital
Description of incident: The theft of a binder from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of sensitive patient information. ë_The binder was stolen on or around May 7 and had information from a survey conducted at the Bakersfield Memorial Hospital. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, ages, medications, room numbers, and medical record numbers were exposed.

On April 2, 2012, an electronic file was discovered on Next Day Flyer's system. ë_The file was storing transaction information for customers who placed orders through the company's website between March 23, 2012 and April 2, 2012. ë_It was discovered when the company found out that an unauthorized person was trying to disrupt traffic to Next Day Flyer's website. ë_The file was removed, but customer names, credit card information, email addresses, and postal addresses may have been exposed. ë_

An April 16 office burglary resulted in the theft of two computers that contained sensitive patient information. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, medical billings, ICD-9 diagnosis codes, and dates of birth were exposed. ë_It is unclear if patients who saw the doctor as far back as 1979 were affected by the breach. ë_Letters to patients who were affected were mailed on June 7.

Emory Healthcare revealed that 10 backup discs that contained patient information are missing from a storage location at Emory University Hospital. ë_The discs were determined to have been removed sometime between February 7, 2012, and February 20, 2012. ë_The patient information was related to surgery and included names, Social Security numbers, diagnoses, dates of surgery, procedure codes or the name of the surgical procedures, surgeon names, anesthesiologist names, device implant information, and other protected health information. ë_Patients treated at Emory University Hospital, Emory University Hospital Midtown (formerly known as Emory Crawford Long Hospital) and Emory Clinic Ambulatory Surgery Center between September of 1990 and April of 2007 were affected.UPDATEë_(6/09/2012): A suit seeking class action status was filed on June 4. ë_The suit seeks unspecified damages over the loss of 10 computer disks containing the personal and health information of between 250,000 and 315,000 patients treated between 1999 and 2007.

Company: New York State Office of Children and Family Services
Description of incident: Investigators were able to arrest an employee of the New York State Office of Children and Family Services after learning about a case of identity theft. ë_The dishonest employee is accused of selling personal information to an outside person and was arraigned on one felony count of receiving a reward for official misconduct in the second degree. He received $500 for accessing and providing the sensitive information of multiple individuals through his workplace.

The FTC has fined EPN, Inc. for failing to implement reasonable security measures. The agency charged that the company did not have an appropriate information security plan, failed to assess risks to the consumer information it stored, did not adequately train employees, did not use reasonable measures to enforce compliance with its security policies, and did not use reasonable methods to prevent, detect and investigate unauthorized access to personal information on its networks. ë_The FTC claims that this failure to implement reasonable and appropriate data security measures was an unfair act or practice and violated federal law. ë_EPN's chief operating office installed peer-to-peer file-sharing software on EPN's computer system and left patient information vulnerable to unauthorized access. Hospital patient Social Security numbers, health insurance numbers, and medical diagnosis codes were accessible on any computer connected to the peer-to-peer network. ë_EPN was barred from misrepresenting the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information they collected. ë_EPN was also required to undergo data security audits and establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program.

The FTC fined Franklin's Budget Car Sales for compromising consumers' personal information by allowing peer-to-peer software to be installed on its network. ë_Any computers that were connected to the peer-to-peer network could have accessed Franklin's network of consumer names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and driver's license numbers. ë_The FTC claimed that Franklin's failed to assess risks to the consumer information it collected and stored online and failed to adopt policies to prevent or limit unauthorized disclosure of information. ë_Franklin's also allegedly failed to prevent, detect and investigate unauthorized access to personal information on its networks, failed to adequately train employees and failed to employe reasonable measures to respond to unauthorized access to personal information. ë_Franklin's settlement agreement bars Franklin's from misrepresentations about the privacy, security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information it collected from consumers. ë_Franklin's must also establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program and undergo data security audits.

Massachusetts General Hospital has 
          put dozens of patients on notice that it has lost some of their confidential 
          medical records, which were left on an MBTA Red Line train by a hospital 
          employee. The MGH employee left the hospital, taking the records with 
          her to do billing work on them over the weekend. The records belonged 
          to at least 66 patients and included private information such as the 
          patients' diagnoses, their names, birth dates and billing information.UPDATEë_(2/24/2011): Massachusetts General Hospital agreed to pay one million dollars to settle violation of privacy charges. http://www.hhs.gov/ocr/privacy/hipaa/news/mghnews.htmlUPDATEë_(6/08/2012): The lost documents consisted of a patient schedule with names and medical record numbers for 192 patients. ë_There were also billing encounter forms with names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, health insurer and policy numbers, diagnoses, and provider names for 66 of those patients.

DocuSign user information was discovered to be accessible through a Google search. The information goes as far back as January 2012, and some information could be even older. ë_It is possible to see private emails, signatures, times, dates, locations, addresses, document names, and email addresses. ë_DocuSign claims that the information is available because a small number of DocuSign users have saved their own personal copies of their signed documents to publicly accessible and searchable locations outside of DocuSign's secure global network. ë_

Company: Warren County Iowa, Iowa Department of Human Services
Description of incident: Warren County residents had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, and other information exposed. ë_A fire destroyed a Warren County human services office on December 4, 2011. ë_Records from the location that were due to be shredded were moved to a secure facility owned by warren County. ë_A county maintenance worker mistakenly moved a container full of the damaged sensitive records back to the destroyed building in early February of 2012. ë_The mistake was discovered on March 14 when the department received a call from a resident near the area who found a DHS paper in her yard.
A portable electronic device was lost or discovered missing sometime around February 7, 2012. It contained sensitive information.ë_The incident was reported on the HHS website.ë_

Company: Office of Dr. Roy E. Gondo
Description of incident: A desktop computer and electronic medical records were stolen or discovered stolen sometime around February 21, 2012. They contained sensitive information.ë_The incident was reported on the HHS website.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from the Masons of California. ë_Names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails were exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from Friendping.com. ë_Passwords and email addresses were exposed.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from the University of New Mexico's electrical and computer engineering department. ë_Usernames, emails, and encrypted passwords were exposed.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from Chrome Crazy online. ë_Customer order details, billing and shipping details, types of motorcycles owned, and email addresses were exposed.

A University of Louisiana Monroe employee's email account was hacked. ë_The hacker or hackers could have accessed the sensitive information of people enrolled in the Upward Bound program. ë_A file in the employee's email included the names, addresses, telephone numbers, and other personal information of 83 high school prospects for the Upward Bound program, two former ULM employees who worked within a related program, a current ULM employee working in a related program, and 35 post-secondary ULM students.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from the South Dakota state website online. ë_Usernames, user IDs, plain-text passwords, and email addresses were exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from Iwacu Online. ë_Usernames, first names, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

A May 3 office burglary resulted in the theft of sensitive documents. ë_The stolen documents were charge tickets and contained Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, insurance information, and diagnosis and treatment information.

A routine check for sensitive information by Memorial Sloan-Kettering revealed that a PowerPoint presentation that was posted on two medical professional websites in 2006 contained embedded private information. ë_The information included patient names, phone numbers, addresses, and in some cases, Social Security numbers. ë_Anyone who accessed and manipulated the PowerPoint presentation could have viewed the information that was used to create certain graphs. ë_A total of five PowerPoint files contained sensitive information. ë_The largest file had data from 568 patients from various states; the second largest contained 112. ë_Three others contained the data of 37, 59, and 112 individuals.

An unauthorized person or persons accessed customer personal information between May 6 and May 10, 2012. ë_The information was associated with pending and recently shipped orders. ë_Customer names, addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, ECS customer account passwords, and debit and credit card information may have been exposed. Specifically, credit and debit card expiration dates, security codes, or access codes may have been exposed. ë_ECS Tuning integrated PayPal's Payflow Pro to add additional security to the ECS checkout process and stopped the storing credit and debit cards for any length of time regardless of order status.

A box that contained paper claims information and X-rays was lost during shipping between an unnamed subcontractor and Delta Dental of Illinois. ë_The paperwork included enrollees' dates of birth, Social Security numbers, and other information that dentists provided on their claims.

A programmer erroneously saved an internal test file onto a public server in January 2010. ë_Current and former employees had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and bank account numbers availableë_on the internet from January 2010 until April of 2012. ë_A total of 3,000 current and former employees were affected, but an additional 500 sole proprietors were also affected. ë_It appears that the file was not accessed at anytime between January 2010 and March 10, 2012. ë_

A thumb drive containing information from a small number of current employees, former employees, and applicants was discovered to have been misplaced from the workstation of an employee sometime around April 16. ë_The drive contained names and Social Security numbers. Those who were affected were mailed notifications on May 16. ë_

The theft of a laptop from the trunk of an employee's car resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_Current and former associates may have had their names and Social Security numbers on the stolen laptop. ë_

UNF became aware of a server breach that exposed Social Security numbers and other sensitive information. ë_Students who submitted housing contracts between 1997 and spring 2011 may have had their information exposed. Multiple servers were affected and secured upon discovery. The information may have been accessed as early as spring of 2011.

Company: Alaska Department of Health and Social Services (DHSS)
Description of incident: A portable electronic device that may have contained protected health information was stolen from the vehicle of a DHSS employee on or around October 12, 2009. ë_The Health and Human Services (HHS) Office for Civil Rights (OCR) began an investigation after the incident. ë_OCR found evidence that DHSS did not have adequate policies and procedures in place to safeguard ePHI. ë_DHSS was also found to have not completed a risk analysis, implemented sufficient risk management measures, completed security training for its workforce members, implemented device and media controls, or addressed device and media encryption as required by the HIPAA Security Rule. ë_Alaska DHSS agreed to pay a $1,700,000 settlement. ë_

Company: BlueCross Blue Shield of North Carolina
Description of incident: A mailing software error caused the private information of current and former Blue Cross Blue Shield members to be mailed to other members. ë_The error was discovered on April 12. ë_The records were more than 10 years old and included patient names, Social Security numbers, type of medical care received, and other protected health information.

A former employee appears to have continued accessing patient names, medical information, dates of birth and medical record numbers.ë_ Patients received soliciting phone calls from a physician at another hospital.UPDATEë_(06/212012): The physician and radiologist responsible for the breach has been fined $20,000 for downloading patient information and using it to promote radiology services at Advanced Mobile Imaging Radiology.

A dishonest employee working as a receptionist for the Minnesota Board of Psychology was part of a fraud ring that included nearly 30 co-conspirators. ë_The receptionist was employed from December 2006 until May 2011. She pled guilty to conspiracy to commit bank fraud and aggravated identity theft and faces six years in prison. ë_Those convicted in the case will be jointly responsible for $358,780 in restitution to victims. ë_Fifteen people have pleaded guilty and 10 others have pleaded not guilty in the case. ë_The identity fraud ring was able to make at least $2 million in fraudulent purchases and bank withdrawals. The fraud ring used a variety of methods that included dishonest employees and theft of sensitive information from cars, businesses, trash cans, and mailboxes. ë_

An IT staff member of Bank of America pled guilty to installing illegal software on Bank of America ATMs. The software caused the ATMs to erroneously dispense money; some of it may have affected customer accounts.

Company: Fidelity National Information Services/Certegy Check Services Inc.
Description of incident: A worker at one of the company's subsidiaries (Certegy Check Services, Inc.) stole customer records containing credit card, bank account and other personal information. UPDATE (8/27/07):The company first estimated that about 2.3 million records were affected but quickly boosted that number to 8.5 million in filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. A California law firm has filed a class-action suit charging Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) and one of its subsidiaries with negligence in connection with a data breach. UPDATE (11/23/07): A former database analyst at Certegy Check Services Inc., has agreed to enter a guilty plea to federal fraud and conspiracy charges in connection with the theft of data. UPDATE (7/7/08):A man has been sentenced to four years and nine months in jail and fined US $3.2 million for his part in the theft of consumer records from Certegy Check Services. UPDATE (7/7/08): A new settlement provides that all class members whose personal or financial information was stolen can get compensated up to $20,000 if they were not reimbursed for certain identity theft losses caused by the data theft. The losses covered could have occurred from Aug. 24, 1998, to Dec. 31, 2010. www.datasettlement.com UPDATE (4/26/10): As part of a class action settlement in U.S. District Court in Tampa, consumers were given the opportunity to elect credit monitoring for one year or bank account monitoring for two years and were able to seek reimbursement of certain out-of-pocket costs incurred or identity theft expenses. Consumers also were able to request credit monitoring at the company's expense immediately after the thefts were announced. The settlement with the Attorney General's office ensures that Certegy will maintain a comprehensive information-security program. This program will assess internal and external risks to consumers' personal information, implement safeguards to protect that consumer information, and will regularly monitor and test the effectiveness of those safeguards. Certegy and its related entities also agree to adhere to payment card industry data security standards as those standards continue to evolve. As part of the settlement, Certegy is donating $125,000 to the Attorney General's Seniors vs. Crime Program for educational, investigative and crime prevention programs for the benefit of senior citizens and the community and will pay $850,000 for the state's investigative costs and attorney's fees related to the case.

Vandals broke into a car dealership that had been closed for four years. ë_Sensitive documents were found scattered all over the parking lot. ë_It appears that the primary purpose of the break in was vandalism, but former customers are being warned to check their credit reports for fraudulent activity.

Forty-three restaurants nationwide may have been affected by a data breach involving unauthorized access to credit and debit card information. Customers who used credit or debit cards between early March and the end of April may have had their financial information obtained by unauthorized parties.UPDATEë_(06/15/2012): Penn Station updated the number of franchise locations affected. ë_They now claim that 80 restaurants in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Missouri, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia, and West Virginia were affected by a point-of-sale processing hack.

A theft ring hacked into the computer system of a Tilted Kilt restaurant. ë_Customers who used a debit or credit card are encouraged to check their bank statements for suspicious activity such as double billing. ë_Fraudulent charges have already appeared on the statements of some customers. ë_It is unclear when the breach occurred, but the Secret Services alerted the pub of the investigation on June 7.

An employee accidentally posted data onto a file transfer protocol site that was not secure on May 3. ë_The data contained customer VISA debit card names, addresses, dates of birth, card expiration dates and checking and savings account numbers. ë_The error was discovered on June 3. The data was accessed, but there was no evidence of identity theft or fraud as of June 12. ë_New cards were issued to 25% of the affected members and the remaining members will have their affected cards deactivated on June 30.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of National Endowment for the Arts and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 13 names, email addresses, and passwords.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of Holy Family University and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included a table with 12 usernames and encrypted passwords.

Victims who reported fraudulent charges on their debit and credit cards were found to have had their payment cards compromised at the Eastern Buffet. The cards were compromised sometime before May 11. ë_Two employees were fired for their roles in the breach and were found to have been working at the restaurant under fake identities.

A hotel employee accidentally downloaded malware to front desk computers. ë_The malware was active for about ten days during the first half of March of 2012. ë_Customer names, addresses, credit card numbers, and credit card expiration dates may have been exposed. ë_

A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of InfoLink and posted the information online. ë_The intrusion appears to have taken place in November of 2011. ë_The leaked data included 46 administrator names, passwords and email addresses. ë_A total of 1,820 client names, email addresses, passwords, payment methods, card types, last four digits of payment cards, and encrypted full payment card numbers were exposed. ë_ServerPronto and CloudPronto affiliates were also affected.

An unauthorized user or users was able to access credit reporting information after managing to pass Experian's authentication process. ë_The unauthorized access incidents took place sometime between October 19, 2011 and February 13, 2012, as well as sometime between November 2010 and March 2012. ë_ Consumers may have had their names, addresses, and truncated Social Security numbers, years of birth, and account numbers exposed.

Company: University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) Health System
Description of incident: The UCLA Health System placed an audit report on billing practices online in May. ë_It was later discovered that an employee had accidentally attached information containing the first name, last name, and five-digit billing code related to at least one patient's emergency department visit in May of 2011. ë_It is unclear how many people were affected and if others may have had additional information exposed.

A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of U.S. Office of Personnel Management and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 37 user IDs and plain-text passwords on the internet.

A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of Stanford University and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included a list of contact information for donors. ë_Names, company association, contact details, and notes about the donors were exposed.

A hacker or hackers accessed the server information of Direct TV and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included administration account information such as 32 email addresses, usernames, encrypted passwords, and a list of IPs that could belong to Direct TV servers.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of T&M Protection Resources and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 10 uersnames and passwords.

A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of Sierra County and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 15 email addresses and passwords; some of the passwords had been decrypted.

A hacker or hackers accessed the website database information of Alaska Structures and defaced the website. ë_Some password information was posted online, but it is unclear how many usernames and passwords were obtained and distributed.ë_

An interesting photo caught the attention of a man passing by a trash container. ë_The photo was among other photos, names, phone numbers, and receipts. ë_The records were tracked to Sears Portrait Studio and the man eventually contacted the local media after failing to get a response from the company. ë_Sears responded to media inquiries and claimed that this was an unusual incident that was against company policy.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of the US Navy and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 36 email addresses and passwords.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of Gridiron Strategies and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 2,109 email addresses and passwords.
A stolen laptop contained patient information. ë_The theft occurred sometime between December 1, 2011 and December 17, 2011.
A hacker or hackers accessed the database information of World of Warcraft Latino America and posted the information online. ë_The leaked data included 256 usernames, email addresses, and passwords.
A hacker or hackers accessed Paper Street Media data and posted it online. ë_A total of 6,209 user names and passwords were posted. ë_Additionally, 169 emails were posted.
A hacker or hackers accessed Mosler Automotive data and posted it online. ë_A total of 218 usernames and hashed and salted passwords were exposed.

Company: ACEware Systems Inc., Lewis-Clark State College,
Description of incident: An unauthorized party was able to access student records from ACEware Systems' server. ë_It contained student registration records from the Lewis-Clark workforce training center. ë_ The records included the last four digits of students' Social Security numbers and partial credit card numbers. ë_
The names and schools of students who met with graduation coaches, as well as their reasons for meeting were not completely removed from distributed meeting materials. ë_

Hackers gained access to York County's web application server. ë_It contained two databases with the information of 17,000 job applicants and vendors. ë_The first database contained about 12,500 names from as far back as 15 years ago. ë_The second database was newer and contained information that had been collected up until August 29, 2011. ë_The intrusion was discovered by the county on August 29 and no new applicants or vendors were affected by the breach. ë_Those who may have been affected were not notified until after a thorough investigation by York County's IT department. ë_No definitive evidence was found for a breach after the nine-month investigation.
