ON or around March 1, 2012, BJ's Wholesale learned that an unauthorized party had used the names, addresses, and membership numbers of an unknown number of members to create new online profiles on BJs.com. ë_Goods were then fraudulently purchased on the website between November 2011 and March 2012. ë_The membership profile information that may have been accessed included Social Security numbers.
The March 20 theft of a laptop and registration forms resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Customer credit card numbers were included in the registration information. ë_

A tax preparer for Triangle Tax Services was found to have information in her possession for the purpose of identity theft. ë_A county deputy pulled the dishonest employee over for a traffic stop and found that she had checks, tax return credit cards, and handwritten names, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers. ë_She faces at least eight counts of identity theft; though it is unclear how many of her 300 potential victims are connected to Triangle Tax Services.

A former bank vice president and branch manager was sentenced for falsifying loans. ë_She used the names, Social Security numbers, and other personal information of family members and bank customers to falsify financial documents between June of 2008 and May of 2009. ë_The woman's fraudulent activities were discovered in 2009 and she eventually pled guilty on February 3, 2012. ë_Her charges included mail fraud, wire fraud, bank fraud, and aggravated identity theft. ë_The dishonest employee was sentenced to 51 months in federal prison, three years of supervised release, and ordered to pay $237,657.88 in restitution.

Company: University of Houston College of Optometry Clinic, La Nueva Casa de Amigos Eye Clinic
Description of incident: The University of Houston College of Optometry became aware that one of their computers was infected with a virus on February 23, 2012. ë_The person responsible for the breach may have been able to access the information for 24 hours. ë_Patient records dating between January 2006 and February 13, 2012 could be accessed from the computer. ë_Patient names, phone numbers, addresses, dates of birth, insurance information, future appointments, current medications, diagnoses, treatment information, vision test results, vision history information, letters from referring doctors, costs of medical services or goods, method of payment, occupation/job, gender, and languages spoken were in the patient records.

People who were members of Tufts Health Plan (Tufts Associated Health Maintenance Organization, Tufts Insurance Company) received letters meant for other members. ë_A programming error caused the addresses of members to be incorrect. ë_Names, medical conditions, and medications were exposed.

Company: Office of Dr. William F. DeLuca Jr.
Description of incident: The theft of a laptop on or around January 16, 2012 resulted in the exposure of patient protected health information. ë_The incident was reported in the HHS website.

Company: Ernst & Young LLP, Cisco Systems, Inc.
Description of incident: Cisco's service provider Ernst & Young experienced a breach involving the information of current and former Cisco employees on March 26. ë_On March 28, Cisco learned that a laptop with employee names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and the stock administration information of a select few had been stolen from an Ernst & Young employee's home.

A dishonest employee accessed HR information with the intention of misusing the information to obtain fraudulent credit. ë_At least 36 Home Depot employees had their names, Social Security numbers, contact information, driver's license numbers, and possibly their financial account information accessed. ë_The incident was discovered on March 15.

Hackers launched an attack against the Formula One website in response to a decision to stage the Grand Prix in Behrain. ë_In addition to a denial of service attack on the official website, government websites were also attacked. ë_The hackers managed to access a database with the names, passport numbers, email addresses, and home addresses of people who purchased tickets for the Grand Prix. ë_The information the hackers posted was altered to protect privacy.

Company: North East School of the Arts
Description of incident: An April 19 car burglary resulted in the exposure of student information. ë_An external hard drive containing letters associated with students who applied to the North East School of the Arts was stolen from a teacher's car. ë_The letters contained applicant names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, phone numbers, and previous school district information.

A hacker accessed passwords and associated email addresses of users of Two Plus Two Forums. ë_It is unclear what types of data and how much were accessed. ë_Anyone who used the same email and password combination for Two Plus Two Forums and other sites should change their password for Two Plus Two Forums as well as the other sites.

Company: State University of New York - Brockport College
Description of incident: Hackers accessed Brockport College's payment system by inserting malware into Brockport College's computer system. ë_Anyone who made a purchase on the campus may have had their credit or debit account information exposed. ë_Brockport College responded by switching to cash payment for all purchases for the rest of the school term.

Hackers were able to access the user names and passwords located on the Three Rivers Park District database. ë_Anyone who has ever made a reservation or registered for a program associated with with the districts 21 parks was affected. ë_No financial information, names, or addresses was exposed. ë_The breach was discovered on April 19 and immediately addressed.

Company: Taco Bell, McDonald's, Wrigley Field, Ralph Lauren Restaurant (RL Restaurant)
Description of incident: Sixë_defendantsë_face criminal charges for their roles in a fraud ring that utilized skimming devices in the Chicago area. ë_Some of theë_defendantsë_were dishonest employees who used a skimming device to read and record customer information as customers made purchases. ë_Others recruited these dishonest employees and some used the card information to make fake cards and fraudulent purchases.

The campus theft of two university-issued laptops resulted in the exposure of alumni information. ë_Though University policy required data security measures, the laptops were not encrypted and did not have a program installed that would allow sensitive information to be deleted remotely. ë_Master's of arts and bachelor's of arts alumni from 1987 through the date of the theft were affected. ë_

Company: New York University Langone Medical Center Hospital for Join Diseases (HJD)
Description of incident: Paper tracking records of tissue issued in orthopaedic surgeries performed at HJD in 2009 and 2010 were mistakenly discarded on or around June 23. ë_It appears that the papers were then compacted and buried in a landfill rather than properly disposed. ë_Patients who were affected had their name, date of birth, gender, hospital, date of surgery, and clinical surgery information exposed. ë_

Company: Helping Homeless Veterans and Families Hoosier Veterans Foundation
Description of incident:
Hundreds of files containing medical 
            histories and Social Security numbers were found in the trash on Indianapolis' 
            east side. The records belong to homeless veterans. A lot of the things 
            inside the folders are confidential information about the clients 
            including Social Security numbers.
The servers of ThePartsBin.com were hacked between April 9 and June 12, 2012. ë_Customer names and credit card information may have been exposed. ë_

An employee's laptop was stolen from a rental car that was left unattended in a restaurant parking lot. ë_The theft occurred on June 2, 2010. ë_The laptop was rendered inoperable within two hours of the discovery of the theft. ë_It contained data related to Fairview health system billing issues and was encrypted. ë_

Sensitive paperwork was left in a publicly accessible dumpster after Restart Behavioral Health Care moved to a new location. Contact information and financial information such as email addresses, phone numbers, names, and check receipts could be found. ë_Social Security card information and Medicaid numbers were also in the dumpster. ë_A local news team contacted the owner of Restart. ë_He refused to comment on the situation, but demanded the return of the documents.

Documents with Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and other sensitive information were found in the home of a deceased VA employee in May. ë_The records were found in a box in the attic of the home. ë_It is unclear why the employee took the information home.

Company: University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center (M.D. Anderson)
Description of incident: A laptop with sensitive patient information was stolen from the home of an M.D. Anderson faculty member on April 30. ë_The laptop was not encrypted and contained patient names, medical record numbers, treatment and/or research information, and in some instances Social Security numbers. ë_Notifications were mailed to patients who were affected on June 28.

Company: San Jose State University (SJSU) Associated Students
Description of incident: A hacker was able to access SJSU's Associated Students information. ë_Associated Students is a student-run non-profit that manages and hosts many SJSU campus services, but it's IT infrastructure is separate from SJSU's. ë_The hacker claimed to have 10,000 student Social Security numbers and driver's license numbers, but it is unclear if this information was actually exposed. ë_The hacker claimed to use an SQL injection to access the information. ë_In addition to Social Security numbers and driver's license numbers, information such as administrative materials, job applications, work schedules, email addresses and passwords from the past 10 years may have been accessed. SJSU denies that information this sensitive was accessed.

The information of former students and applicants was available online. ë_Former students and applicants who signed up for a roommate service online through Levin College of Law in the early 2000s had their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_The breach was discovered in May of 2012; the College of Law stopped using the software for the roommate service in the mid-2000s. Former students and applicants were mailed notifications on June 25.

Police are investigating an identity theft and credit and debit card skimming operation involving a Chinese Gourmet Express. ë_A total of $100,000 in losses caused by fraudulent payment card charges had been reported by financial institutions. ë_At least 300 mall employees and shoppers reported fraudulent transactions between March and June. ë_

A dishonest McDonald's employee confessed to using a handheld skimming device for three weeks to capture drive-thru customer credit and debit card numbers. He then passed the information along to others who used the numbers to produce fraudulent cards and make purchases. ë_A total of 282 card numbers were discovered on a suspect's laptop.UPDATEë_(07/02/2012): The former employee pleaded guilty to an aggravated identity-theft charge. ë_He agreed to playing a part in causing a total loss of more than $51,000. Four other defendants were first caught in October of 2011. ë_They were arrested on suspicion of trying to buy merchandise with counterfeit cards and were caught with a laptop that contained stolen credit and debit card numbers.

An ongoing flaw in Groupon's email link encryption exposes the emails of some Groupon users when specific terms are added into Google searches of Groupon's site. ë_Groupon believes that the problem is caused by users publicly pasting their Groupon deals online. ë_Groupon is working on a solution to exclude the results.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive Contempo Enterprises information online. ë_Login credentials, names, email addresses, and customer data were exposed.

People who were undergraduate students at UAB between 1995 and 2006 may have had their information accessed online. ë_The information included Social Security numbers and academic records. ë_It was accidentally made available on a publicly accessible server for an unspecified amount of time. ë_The breach was discovered on March 27.ë_

An unauthorized user or users was able to access credit reporting information after managing to pass Experian's authentication process. ë_The unauthorized access incidents took place sometime between August 2, 2011 and August 9, 2011. Consumers may have had their names, addresses, Social Security numbers, years of birth, and account numbers exposed.

The owner of North Point Dental accused a former colleague of stealing the information of about 10,000 current and former patients. ë_The men worked together on a political campaign and the former colleague used the patient information to call patients for campaign support as part of his role as the campaign manager. ë_The former campaign manager countered that he had received an email from the dentist encouraging him to take information from an office computer and use it to call the patients. ë_Patients had their names, email addresses, treatment dates, and home addresses distributed to third parties. ë_The information was also uploaded to an online data storage service.

Company: American Stock Transfer & Trust Company, LLC
Description of incident: Mail packages containing the beneficiary statements of certain shareholders for the year of 2011 were mailed to incorrect addresses on April 2, 2012. ë_The statements contained names, tax identification numbers of the intended shareholders, and addresses. ë_Shareholders of a single, unnamed issuer that used American Stock Transfer as a sub-transfer agent most likely had their information mailed to a different shareholder than the shareholder listed on the beneficiary statement.

A CD-ROM disk with IRS W-2 information for Claire's employees was discovered missing from a designated human resources-only area. ë_Claire employee Social Security numbers, 2011 salary, and other W-2 information were on the disk. A total of 150 New Hampshire residents were notified of the breach, but the total number of affected individuals nationwide was not revealed.

A former employee took paper documents with patient information without permission. ë_It is unclear if the former employee meant to use the information for fraud purposes. ë_Patient names, dates of clinic visits, dates for scheduled opiate addiction dosages, and the dosage amounts were in the paper documents. ë_The documents were recovered.

A computer mailing error caused Seton member Medicaid health plan cards to be sent to incorrect addresses. ë_The cards were mailed by Seton's vendor HealthLOGIX on March 9. Seton became aware of the breach when members began calling about receiving the incorrect cards a week after the mistake. ë_Seton Health Plan members enrolled in the STAR/Medicaid plan were affected and may have had their names and dates of birth exposed.

Company: Rhinebeck Health Center, Center for Progressive Medicine
Description of incident: On February 15, 2012, Rhinebeck learned that their unnamed computer vendor experienced a computer security breach. ë_An unauthorized party or parties may have accessed any patient information between November 15, 2011 and December 14, 2011 that was on the Rhinebeck and Center for Progressive Medicine computer network. ë_Patient full names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, phone numbers, account information, health insurance information, credit card information, laboratory tests, and diagnosis information may have been exposed. Anyone who visited either center between January 1, 2002 and December 22, 2011 may have been affected.

Company: Catalyst Health Solutions, Alliant Health Plans, Inc.
Description of incident: An unauthorized disclosure resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_The breach occurred on or around January 1, 2012 and was reported on April 17. ë_This incident was reported on the HHS website.

Company: Anchorage Community Mental Health Services, Inc.
Description of incident: An unauthorized disclosure involving a computer or computers resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_The breach occurred sometime between December 20, 2011 and January 4, 2012. ë_This breach was reported on the HHS website.

A vendor of the broker-dealer, National Financial Services (NFS), used by Investacorp was involved in a data security breach. ë_On or around March 12, 2012, Investacorp learned that an NFS vendor had inadvertently shared electronic files with another federally regulated broker-dealer that also uses NFS's services. ë_The incident occurred on November 29, 2011 and was first noticed on February 13, 2012. The information included client names, Social Security numbers, and certain types of account data. Five Investacorp clients from California may have been affected, but the total number of affected individuals nationwide was not reported. ë_The vendor responsible for the mistake worked with the other broker-dealer to delete the client files from their system. Investacorp then received an executed affidavit from the broker-dealer certifying the destruction of the electronic files. ë_

A team of hackers revealed that they had attacked the University of Washington's system with multiple SQL injections. ë_The first one was detected and fixed by the University of Washington, but a second one went unnoticed. ë_The team of hackers released 31 login and password combinations from a user database and 25 WordPress user login, password, and email address combinations. ë_The attack comes a few weeks after a hacker identified nearly 20 university systems that were vulnerable to SQLi attacks.

Company: Gila County Health and Emergency Services (Payson WIC Office)
Description of incident: A woman found thousands of applications for Women, infants, and Children (WIC) support in a dumpster.ë_ë_Around 1,000 documents were originally reported in the dumpster. ë_Additional documents were discovered when a local news team joined the woman at the dumpster a few days later.ë_The applications included copies of drivers licenses, Social Security numbers, medical information, and many other types of sensitive information. ë_An employee of the state agency said that the forms would normally be properly shredded, but were thrown out in a hurry without being checked.

Company: Cambridge Eastern Education and Development Society (CEEDS)
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of Cambridge Eastern Education and Development Society (CEEDS) online. ë_The leaked data included 12 email addresses and one administrator login and (salted) password combination.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of Epson online. ë_The leaked data included 66 administrator user logins and password combinations. ë_Many of the passwords were weak and stored in an easily readable plain-text format.

Hackers accessed and posted the usernames and passwords of individuals who had access to the UCLA.edu MySQL database. A total of 128 regular users had their names, titles, email addresses, logins, and password hashes posted online.ë_Additionally, the IDs, usernames, salts, and password hashes from 37 staffers were posted online.ë_Three database users also had their usernames and password hashes posted online.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of Gaming Perfection online. ë_A total of 1,784 email addresses, passwords with associated salts, and usernames were exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of NCPC online. ë_A total of 21 names, email addresses, telephone numbers, passwords, and job titles were leaked.

A computer that contained unencrypted personal information was stolen from LifeSize Communications on January 26, 2012. ë_Names, Social Security numbers and other information were on the stolen computer. ë_Those who were affected were sent notifications on March 9.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of Irandefence.net online. ë_The leaked information included usernames, email addresses, passwords, and associated password salts.

Company: Harvard University Health Services, Anna Jacques Hospital, Lowell General Hospital, Saints Medical Center
Description of incident: Two men were arrested for posing as employees of an X-ray removal company in order to steal old X-ray films.ë_ The two men hit multiple locations.ë_ It is believed that their primary focus was the silver contained in the films, however patient medical and personal information was also linked to the X-ray films.ë_ Around 1,000 X-rays were stolen from Harvard University Health Services and a barrel of X-rays was taken from Anna Jaques Hospital.ë_ The men were charged with conspiracy and larceny from a building. The thefts occurred in August, but it is unclear how many other organizations were affected. The men were also linked to a crime or crimes in New Hampshire.UPDATEë_(03/05/2012): The men were tied to thefts and theft attempts at Anna Jaques Hospital in Newburyport and Saints Medical Center in Lowell. ë_
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted database information from arizonasportsfans.com online. ë_The leaked information included email addresses, passwords, salts for passwords, and usernames.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information from the adultinsider.com database online. ë_The leaked information included email addresses, passwords with associated salts, and usernames.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the database information of vBCoderz.com online. ë_A total of 1,290 email addresses, usernames, and passwords with associated salts were exposed.

A technician's USB thumb drive with patient information was misplaced at Georgetown University Hospital. ë_People who were associated with the Department of Laboratory Medicine and visited the Hospital between September of 2004 and September of 2009 may have had their names, medical record numbers, dates of birth, blood types, dates of blood tests, blood test results, summary of clinical histories, and clinician names exposed. The thumb drive was last seen on September 9, 2011, and was discovered missing on the morning of September 14, 2011.

Police officers discovered a large number of credit card receipts and other items during a traffic stop in June of 2011. ë_The driver was then arrested and admitted to using stolen credit card receipts from Comfort Inn & Suites to make fraudulent credit cards. ë_He had stolen around 500 receipts and successfully used two counterfeit credit cards. ë_He was sentenced to five years and 10 months in federal prison and ordered to pay $3,606 in restitution.UPDATEë_(03/22/2012): Additional credit card receipts were found and connected to Brownsville, Texas.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted database information from Bad Boy Tires online. ë_A total of 111 names, emails, postal addresses, phone numbers, and plain-text passwords were exposed.

Two laptops with member information were stolen during an office burglary. Financial and other administrative information were also on the laptops. The laptops did not contain any patient information. It is unclear if the theft of the equipment was politically motivated.UPDATEë_(3/26/2012): The breach appears to have been politically motivated. ë_Two other OB-GYNs had laptops stolen from their offices after speaking out against a controversial Georgia bill.

An HCFCU member filed a complaint in 2011 after suspecting that their information had been improperly used for an HCFCU board nomination process. It became apparent that several employees had added names to nomination petitions, then went to credit union members to have them sign the petitions.ë_Fewer than 500 of the 40,000 HCFCU members had their account information and the last four digits of their Social Security numbers accessed. The employees involved were disciplined and/or had their employment terminated. HCFCU employees are now required to go through a new training process to reinforce policies that prohibit accessing members' information.

A filing cabinet that was full of personnel information was accidentally locked, wrapped, and shipped to a prison in February of 2012. ë_The prison supervisor unlocked the filing cabinet, noticed that it still contained files, and immediately sent it back. ë_Employee driver's license and Social Security numbers were in the cabinet.

A county clerk was the victim of a car theft. She had left sensitive documents for homicide trials in the trunk of her car. ë_The documents were recovered from the car wreckage. ë_Personal information for police officers associated with the homicide trials and names and addresses of witnesses could have been exposed. Documents will be scanned and never physically taken from the courthouse again as a result of the breach.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted Eclipse AeroSpace database information online. ë_The leaked information included email addresses, usernames, names, and passwords. ë_
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted savvyinsider.com database information online. ë_A total of 24 usernames, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

Around 1,500 X-ray films were stolen from SwedishAmerican Hospital on May 31. Someone claiming to be the person responsible for picking up and destroying the films was able to steal them. ë_Patient names, medical record numbers, dates of service, and dates of birth were exposed. Representatives believe the risk of identity theft is low since extracting the silver from X-ray films is usually the motive for similar thefts.

A former employee of Scripps College allowed a personal contact outside of the College to access financial aid application information. ë_The issue was discovered during a review of Scripps College Financial Aid Office processes. ë_It appears that the former employee shared the information to obtain assistance in evaluating applications and preparing potential aid packages. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and other financial information may have been exposed at various times between 2008 and 2012.

Three former Pulaski employees are accused of accessing and exporting the mortgage data of customers. ë_A former loan officer emailed a large file to an outside email account a month before leaving Pulaski. ë_A former closing supervisor also allegedly transferred documents onto a portable electronic storage device before resigning. ë_The data appears to have been taken to a competitor. ë_Pulaski Financial filed a lawsuit against three former employees and their possible new employer, First State Bank of St. Charles, Missouri.

An office burglary that occurred on or around February 19 resulted in the theft of medications and a computer. ë_The computer contained patient names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. It is unclear if the computer was encrypted. ë_The total number of patients affected and all types of information exposed are also unclear.
Sensitive health information in an unspecified format was stolen or discovered stolen on or around February 1, 2011.ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

An unencrypted thumb drive was lost on May 7 and discovered missing on May 8. ë_It contained the names, account numbers, diagnoses, dates of admission and discharge, physician's name, account numbers, and medical record numbers of patients. ë_It is unclear if only one Saint Mary Medical Center in California was affected, and if so, which one. ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

Company: Office of Dr. Stephen Haggard, DPM Podiatry
Description of incident: A theft, possibly of a network server, resulted in the exposure of sensitive patient health information. ë_The theft occurred on or around March 4, 2012 and notifications were available for a limited time after April 22.ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

A former employee may have accessed computer systems without authorization and accessed service files. ë_The incident or incidents occurred between August 31, 2011 and January 31, 2012. Employee personal information as well as patient demographic and insurance information were exposed. ë_It is unclear if the former employee was currently employed at the time of the incidents. ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

A February 27 office burglary resulted in the theft of a computer server. ë_Sensitive client health information such as dates of birth, addresses, treatment plans, and other types of personal information were exposed. ë_The server was not recovered, but the theft was discovered the next morning and a police report was filed.ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

An email or emails with sensitive health information related to a health care premium plan was mistakenly emailed to or accessed by unauthorized people. ë_The incident occurred or was discovered sometime around March 30, 2012. ë_The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.

People who used debit cards to make purchases at Orcutt Burgers may have had their information stolen. ë_Coast Hills Federal Credit Union sent out an alert to clients and reissued an unspecified number of debit cards. ë_It is unclear how the debit card data was accessed and how long the information was at risk. ë_It is also unclear if credit cards were also compromised.

Company: New York State Electric & Gas (NYSEG), Rochester Gas and Electric (RG&E), Iberdrola USA
Description of incident: An employee at a software development consulting firm that was contracted by Iberdrola USA, the parent company of both NYSEG and RG&E, allowed the information systems of clients to be accessed by an unauthorized party. ë_Customer Social Security numbers, birth dates, and in some cases, financial institution account numbers were exposed. ë_A total of 878,000 NYSEG customers and 367,000 RG&E electricity customers were affected. ë_An unknown number of additional customers from both companies who signed up for gas services, but not electricity services were also affected.UPDATEë_(07/12/2012): The Department of Public Service reviewed the NYSEG/FG&E incident and concluded that there was no evidence that any confidential customer information was misused. ë_In addition, the Department of Public Service recommended that both companies further refine their policies, processes, and procedures regarding confidentiality safeguards. ë_The companies were ordered to send plans for handling the costs incurred in responding to the breach and progress reports about the implementation of recommendations.

Customers who used their debit and credit cards at Puerta Grande may have had their payment card information stolen by hackers. ë_Between 50 and 100 people reported fraudulent activity on their payment cards after visiting the restaurant. The restaurant stopped accepting payment cards until a new and secure system could be installed. ë_Only one of the three Puerta Grande restaurants in Winchester were affected.

Company: Toshiba, Toshiba America Information Systems, Inc. (TAIS)
Description of incident: Eleven admin email addresses with corresponding plain-text passwords and ID numbers were posted online. ë_A total of 451 email addresses and plain-text passwords were posted. ë_The hacking group VOID claimed responsibility.UPDATEë_(7/18/2011): Toshiba confirmed that records of 7,520 customers were hacked. Customers may have had their email addresses, passwords and phone numbers taken. ë_It was confirmed that 681 customers had their email addresses and passwords taken.ë_

A group of hackers accessed customer details, credit card numbers, and administrator information. ë_At least a) 28 administrator names, usernames, email addresses, and encrypted passwords, b) 85 affiliate usernames, plain-text passwords, c) 100 user email addresses, usernames, and plain-text passwords, and d) 82 .gov and .mil email addresses and plain-text passwords were posted. The hackers criticized the ease of obtaining the credit card numbers, expiration dates, cvvs, and customer billing addresses which were all in plain text.ë_ The hackers chose not to post customer credit card numbers.

Company: American Express Travel Related Services Company, Inc. (AXP)
Description of incident: A man was arrested in his Los Angeles home for allegedly purchasing and using stolen payment card numbers. ë_The credit and debit card numbers from American Express, Visa, MasterCard, and Discover were in the man's possession between January 11, 2012 and February 26, 2012. ë_The payment card numbers came from hacking the computer systems of a restaurant and a restaurant supply business in the Seattle area. ë_Two people who were associated with the hacking incidents had already been arrested. The man who purchased the payment card numbers is charged with conspiracy to access protected computers to further fraud, to commit access device fraud, and to commit bank fraud; eight counts of bank fraud; six counts of access device fraud; five counts of aggravated identity theft; and two counts of accessing a protected computer without authorization.UPDATEë_(07/20/2012): Customer names and payment card expiration dates were also compromised.

The May 22 office theft of a physician's laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. It is unclear what type of information was on the laptop, but the chief information officer said that "nothing that would be used from an identity theft perspective" was on the laptop.

Hackers associated with the group Anonymous posted donations, emails, personal account information, server information, and other information from APhA's online database. ë_The hackers also claim to have accessed the records of 16,000 patients by hacking the website, but did not post that information. Anonymous claims that the organization was targeted due to its connection to government officials.UPDATEë_(6/09/2012): Some names and addresses were also posted. ë_The data posted included information on over 28,000 visitors, donors, and members.UPDATEë_(07/18/2012): The website was defaced on May 28. ë_APhA immediately noticed and shut down the website and related computer servers. ë_However, names, addresses, and credit card information (excluding security codes) stored on computer servers may have been accessed between April 23 and May 28.

Company: Department of Health and Human Services Maine
Description of incident: A computer system glitch caused the personal information of public assistance applicants to be sent to random addresses in the department's system. ë_The error occurred in December, but was not noticed until June. ë_Multiple rounds of forms had been mailed out by that time. ë_A total of 31 forms contained the Social Security numbers, bank account numbers, and other information of 79 household members.

Hackers accessed at least one Yale database and obtained the details of 1,200 students and staff. ë_Hackers may have obtained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and phone numbers. Additionally, usernames, passwords, and email addresses were published as proof of the hack.

At least one customer reported a glitch that allowed users to log into the accounts of other users without using a valid password. The bug that affected the password authentication mechanism was active from 1:54pm to 5:46pm Pacific time on June 19, 2011.UPDATE (6/30/2011):ë_It appears that an intrusion created the security issue that allowed people to log into user accounts without using a password.ë_Someone logged into multiple customer accounts without authorization on June 19, 2011. ë_Fewer than 100 customers had data downloaded from their Dropbox accounts.UPDATEë_(7/15/2011): A class-action suit was filed that claims Dropbox Inc. failed to secure users' private data or to notify the majority of them about the breach. ë_The plaintiff class would consist of all current or former Dropbox users as of June 19, 2011 whose accounts were breached. ë_Dropbox Inc. is accused of violating California's unfair-competition law, invasion of privacy (including intrusion), public disclosure of private facts, misappropriation of likeness and identity, violation of the state constitutional right to privacy, negligence, and breach of express and implied warranties. ë_The legal citation is Wong et al. v. Dropbox Inc., No. 11-CV-3092-LB, complaint filed (N.D. Cal. June 22, 2011)ë_

Three men have been charged with hacking into 11 Dave & Buster's networks and then remotely installing "packet sniffer" software on point-of-sale servers at locations throughout the U.S. A packet sniffer logs information being sent over a network. In this case, the criminals used it to log credit and payment card data as it was sent from the branch locations to corporate headquarters. The hacking took place from April to September 2007. At Dave & Buster's Islandia, New York, location, the hackers accessed details of about 5,000 payment cards. The information was sold to other criminals who then used the card numbers to scam online merchants. The criminals were able to post at least $600,000 in fraudulent transactions from 675 cards taken from this one store.UPDATE (04/05/2010): In reaching a settlement with Dave & Buster_Ñés, the FTC quietly and without fanfare introduced a new security standard, requiring the company to monitor and filter outbound Internet traffic to block the unauthorized export of sensitive information. The consent decree puts companies on notice that they may face FTC scrutiny and penalties if they fail to use data loss prevention software.UPDATEë_(07/19/2012): A member of the hacking ring was sentenced to seven years in prison. ë_Around 80,000 payment card numbers were taken from the 11 Dave & Buster's locations. ë_It appears that the hacker was part of a larger conspiracy that last between 2005 and 2008 and affected Hannaford Bros. grocery chain, Heartland Payment Systems, TJX retail chain, BJ's Wholesale Club, OfficeMax, Boston Market, 7-Eleven, JCPenney, Barnes & Noble, Sports Authority, and Forever 21. Two other members of the hacking ring were sentenced to 20 years in prison and 30 years in prison.

A former Hartford Hospital employee misplaced a computer hard drive on February 15. It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and medical record numbers.  Not all of the patients who were affected had their Social Security numbers exposed.UPDATEë_(04/07/2011): Connecticut's Attorney General and Consumer Protection Commissioner are investigating the breach and data security policies of Hartford Medical Center andë_Midstate Medical Center. ë_Additional details reveal that the hospital employee misplaced the computer hard drive after taking it home. The Connecticut Attorney General is asking that affected patients receive two years of credit monitoring services, identity theft insurance and reimbursement for placing and lifting security freezes.UPDATEë_(07/10/2012): The Connecticut Attorney General has decided to end an investigation of MidState's practices. ë_The Attorney General claimed to base his decision to close the investigation with no further action on the fact that the Hospital had taken significant actions on behalf of the affected patients.

An unnamed check printing vendor for the University copied data from the University's cashier's office during software upgrades. ë_The information included 30,000 to 40,000 checks that contained student and employee names, University IDs, check numbers, and check amounts. ë_Current and former student, faculty, and staff records older than 2004 may have included Social Security numbers. it does not appear that the vendor acted with malicious intent.

Records Breached: 3 million American accounts (No SSNs or financial information reported)
Description of incident: Hackers were able to access Gamigo's server in February of 2012. ë_Notification of the breach was sent on March 1. ë_Gamigo warned users and advised that they change any passwords for emails associated with Gamigo. ë_The hacked information was released on July 6. ë_A total of 8,243,809 user email addresses and encrypted passwords were posted online.ë_

A customer notified Mission Linen Supply of unauthorized charges on the credit cards of several other customers. ë_Mission Linen Supply discovered that the third party vendor who stores and maintains purchase information for their web stores had a data breach. ë_The unnamed vendor experienced an unauthorized access of their file servers. ë_Customers who made online purchases may have had their credit or debit card numbers, expiration dates, and possibly name and other payment card information compromised. The customer contacted Mission Linen Supply on June 29, but it is unclear when the vendor experienced the data breach.

Five laptops were stolen from an unnamed auditor of Petco's 401(k) Plan between May 18 and May 20. ë_The auditor informed Petco on July3. ë_Current and former employee names, Social Security numbers, and other 401(k) account information may have been exposed. Anyone who was issued a Petco paycheck in 2010, had a 401(k) account and received a distribution, or had a fee deducted from their account in 2011 may have been affected.

A June 11 office burglary resulted in the theft of six laptops and a tablet. One or more of the computer devices included the personal health information of current and former Home Health patients. ë_Information included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, demographics, patient medical treatment profiles, diagnoses, symptoms, medications, treatment notes, and health insurance information. ë_The standard laptop security controls had been temporarily suspended on the devices since they were undergoing a software upgrade.ë_

Company: Upper Valley Medical Center, Data Image
Description of incident: A data breach of Data Image's online billing system may have exposed the private information of Upper Valley Medical Center patients. ë_Names, addresses, hospital account numbers, and balances owed could have been obtained during an 18-month period. ë_Current and former patients were notified that the breach was discovered on March 21, 2012, but could have occurred as early as October 1, 2010. ë_

An employee printed and removed sensitive client information for unknown purposes. ë_The employee was dismissed and steps were taken to reduce the risk of similar employee thefts occurring. ë_The employee removed the documents on February 15, 2012 and was not discovered until Hillsborough County Health Department was notified on May 25. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, phone numbers, patient identification numbers, type of visit, and other protected health information were exposed.

The May 16 office theft of a hard drive resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The theft was discovered the next day and a suspect was caught on tape. ë_Upper Valley Medical Center does not believe any patient information was contained on the hard drive.

Company: New York University Langone Medical Center, Office of Dr. Eric C. Parker, Office of Dr. Patrick J. Kelly
Description of incident: The May 23 office theft of a desktop computer resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The computer was password protected and had security software, but was not encrypted. Patient names, addresses, dates of birth, telephone numbers, insurance information, and clinical information may have been exposed. ë_Additionally, approximately 5,000 patients had their Social Security numbers exposed.

Company: Office of Dr. Luz Colon, DPM Podiatry
Description of incident: The theft or loss of a laptop or laptops resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_The data breach occurred sometime around March 20, 2012, and was reported on July 3, 2012.
A desktop computer was stolen or discovered stolen on August 1, 2011. ë_It contained protected health information. ë_The incident was disclosed on July 3.

The March 28, 2012 loss of a laptop during a routine patient transportation resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_It was encrypted and password protected. ë_The laptop was most likely let on the fender of an ambulance and lost during a route. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and medical data related to services provided by the EMS department may have been on the laptop. Notice of the breach was given on May 24.

The March 29 theft of an unknownë_number of x-ray films resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_Thieves were able to access the secured storage location that contained the old x-ray films. ë_These thefts usually occur for the purpose of extracting valuable precious metals from the films by destroying them. ë_Most of the information on the films was more than five years old. ë_It is unclear what type of patient information the x-ray films contained, but they did not include Social Security numbers. Notice of the breach was given on May 24.

An office burglary that occurred on or around March 30, 2012 resulted in the theft of several computers and electronic devices. ë_The computers and devices may have contained the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, Washington state ID numbers, income or payment information about services, conditions, treatments, or diagnosis information about clients, volunteers, and staff.
A theft that occurred sometime around April 22, 2012 resulted in the exposure of protected health information. ë_The breach was posted on the HHS website on July 3.

An office burglary was discovered on March 26. ë_The theft of lab requisition forms that were kept in a locked cabinet resulted in the exposure of information of patients who received laboratory services between February 1 and March 23. ë_Patient names, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, insurance information, ordering practitioner's name, and types of laboratory tests ordered may have been accessed.ë_

Company: Volunteer State Health Plan, Inc. (VSHP), Comprehensive Counseling Network
Description of incident: Envelopes containing BlueCare member protected health information were damaged while being sent to Comprehensive Counseling Network. ë_Lists of claims containing patient protected health information became separated from the envelopes and were lost. Patient names, BlueCare ID numbers, dates of services, procedure codes, claim numbers, totals charged, amounts paid, provider names and provider addresses may have been exposed. ë_The envelopes also contained check to pay for medical visits that were listed on the claims, but the checks were not lost.

On July 13, MassMutual inadvertently sent a report via secure email that included client information to an incorrect retirement Plan Sponsor. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, and 401(k) balance information were exposed. ë_The individual who received the plan information informed MassMutual of the error immediately and claimed to have deleted the information without storing or printing it.

An employee of Greenplum was robbed of a laptop during a home burglary on or around June 26. ë_Greenplum is a subsidiary of a hospital vendor known as EMC Corp. ë_The laptop contained the information of 7,461 VNA HealthCare patients and 2,097 Hartford Hospital patients. ë_Patients had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, marital status, Medicaid and Medicare numbers, medical record numbers, and certain diagnosis and treatment information exposed.

An annual sales report contained the Social Security and tax identification numbers of people and businesses who sold property in Wisconsin in 2011. ë_The report was available online between April 5, 2012 and July 23, 2012 and meant for real estate professionals. ë_The report was accessed a total of 138 times before being taken down. ë_Sensitive seller information was in an an embedded file included in an Microsoft Access file which showed sales data. A total of 110,795 sales were made in Wisconsin in 2011, but not everyone who made a sale provided their Social Security or tax identification number for the paperwork.

A hacker or hackers used an SQL injection technique to access the plain-text passwords of over 450,000 Yahoo! Voices (formerly known as Associated Content) users. ë_The information was then posted online. ë_Yahoo! Voice users are encouraged to change their Yahoo! passwords immediately. Users from as far back as 2006 or earlier may have had their passwords exposed.UPDATEë_(08/02/2012): A Yahoo! user is suing Yahoo! Inc. for negligence. ë_The user claims that Yahoo!'s failure to adequately safeguard his personal information should result in compensation for himself and other users who experienced account fraud and had to take measures to protect accounts put at risk by the Yahoo! breach.

Financial aid documents with student information were found scattered in the street. ë_It is unclear how the documents got there. ë_Hundreds of current and former students who applied for or received financial aid during 1997 and 1998 may have had their Social Security numbers, dates of birth, federal Pell grant disbursements, and other personal information exposed. ë_

Records Breached: 68,000,000 as communicated by a recent discovery in 2016
Description of incident:
Dropbox users began receiving spam from email sources posing as Dropbox. ë_Many users claim that Dropbox must have suffered a breach because email addresses they used specifically and solely for Dropbox were compromised.UPDATEë_(07/20/2012): Dropbox investigated customer concerns of a data breach but could not find any evidence of an unauthorized intrusion or activity as of July 20.UPDATEë_(07/31/2012): Dropbox has confirmed that some accounts were accessed by hackers. One of the compromised accounts was that of a Dropbox employee. ë_The employee's account contained a project document of user email addresses. ë_Dropbox required some users to change their passwords and increased their security by adding a two-factor authentication system, new automated mechanisms to help identify suspicious activity, and a page that allows users to monitor active logins to their accounts.UPDATE (8/31/2016): Per a recent report on the Dropbox breach in 2012, 68 million of the user account details were leaked on the dark web four years later. The information leaked included email addresses and passwords which were hashed. "It was not previously known how many users were affected by the 2012 
hack, according to Motherboard, which says that the leaked data does not
 appear to be posted on the dark web. A senior Dropbox employee told 
Motherboard that the data is legitimate."

The April 24 office theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptop contained names, dates of birth, and auditory testing data. ë_A public notice was posted on July 20.

On January 27, 2012, MHS learned that at least one employee may have accessed patient information in order to receive fraudulent tax returns. ë_A second employee was later identified and both employees were terminated. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth may have been accessed between 2011 and early 2012. ë_Medical information was not involved. Law enforcement requested that MHS delay notifying patients. ë_On April 12, 2012, letters were mailed to patients who may have been affected.

Company: Patterson Dental, River Arch Dental, Hamner Square Dental
Description of incident: An unencrypted USB memory chip was shipped against company policy. ë_The envelope that contained it arrived at its destination on May 14 with a tear and missing the USB memory chip. ë_Names, home addresses, telephone numbers, email addresses, ID numbers, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, Social Security numbers, dental information, and dental insurance information of patients was exposed.UPDATEë_(08/03/2012): A total of 1,112 Hamner Square Dental patients and 2,533 River Arch Dental patients were affected.

Company: The Surgeons of Lake County, LLC
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers accessed and encrypted the computer server of The Surgeons of Lake County. ë_The incident occurred between June 22 and June 25 and was an attempt to force payment from The Surgeons of Lake County in exchange for the password needed to regain access to the server. ë_The unauthorized user or users had access to names, Social Security numbers, addresses, credit card numbers, and medical information. ë_

MHS discovered a second breach during the process of investigating a dishonest employee's misuse of patient data in January of 2012. ë_Employees of affiliated physicians' offices may have improperly accessed patient information through a web portal used by physicians who provide care and treatment at MHS. ë_Patient names, Social security numbers, and dates of birth may have been accessed during the period between January 1, 2011 and July 5, 2012. ë_

Company: Pamlico Medical Equipment, LLC (Now Vidant Internal Medicine)
Description of incident: A flash drive was lost during transit on or around May 16. Patient names, Social Security numbers, Medicaid numbers, insurance carrier contact information, medical equipment being provided by Pamlico Medical Equipment, service date, price of the equipment rental, and other miscellaneous billing information may have been on the flash drive. The flash drive is believed to have been place with compacted trash that was transported to a landfill. ë_

The May first theft of an employee's password-protected laptop resulted in the possible exposure of protected health information. ë_Patient medical records, reasons for visits, and dates of visits may have been exposed. A notification was placed on the UKHealthCare website on June 21.

A former employee received W-2 information of current and former employees. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, payroll information, and other W-2 information were accidentally emailed to the former employee. ë_The former employee immediately notified the human resources department and confirmed that the information had not been mishandled.

The agency is notifying 475 student-loan 
          borrowers of a breach that involved their financial records. ë_The Office of Student Financial Assistance lost or misplaced 1,186 promissory notes 
          that students signed while enrolled. ë_The missing files include Social Security numbers, names, addresses, 
          birth dates, personal references, and other private and financial information that 
          could be used for identity thief.

Company: Jacobi Medical Center, North Central Bronx Hospital, Tremont Health Center, and Gunhill Health Center
Description of incident: The New York City Health & Hospitals Corporation's North Bronx Healthcare Network experienced a breach. ë_Backup tapes were stolen from an unsecured and unlocked van during transport by GRM Information Management Services. ë_The theft occurred during December of 2010. ë_The information on the tapes was from patients, staff members and associated employees and dated back to 1991. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, patient health information and other patient and employee information may have been exposed.

Company: WellPoint, Anthem/Blue Cross and Blue Shield
Description of incident: A former employee accessed health care professionals' Social Security numbers, names, dates of birth, and home addresses.  Between 2007 and 2010, the employee created fictitious identities and created e-mail addresses, opened bank accounts and credit card accounts.UPDATEë_(05/10/2010): Theë_former employee was sentenced to 28 months in prison followed by three years of supervised release. ë_She was also ordered to pay $2,914.95 in restitution. ë_She pleaded guilty to one count of mail fraud and once count of aggravated identity theft on February 9. ë_Around 40 health care professionals such as doctors, psychologists, nurses, and dietitians were victims of fraudulent financial activity.

Doctors' offices in Tennessee 
            have been accidentally sending patient information, including Social 
            Security numbers and medical histories, to an Indiana businessman's 
            fax machine for the past three years. The sensitive medical information 
            was supposed to be sent to the Tennessee Department of Human Services, 
            but the owner of SunRise Solar Inc. in Indiana, says hundreds of confidential 
            medical faxes having been coming to him.

Three unencrypted computer backup tapes were reported missing on September 8. ë_The tapes were stored in a locked cabinet, which had been temporarily relocated on or around August 10 for a facility remodeling project. ë_The cabinet was not found. ë_The tapes had been stored in the cabinet since 2004 and contained patient information stored between 1994 and 2004. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, insurance information, medical treatment information, and direct deposit bank account information were exposed.UPDATE (10/12/2011): Patients and their guarantors, vendors, and employees at Nemours facilities in Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Florida were affected.ë_ In addition to medical treatment information, the payroll information of current and former employees was exposed.ë_ Nemours took steps to encrypt all computer backup tapes and move non-essential computer backup tapes to a secure, off-site storage facility after the breach.

A laptop was stolen or discovered stolen sometime around March 21, 2012. ë_It contained the sensitive health information of 3,000 people. The incident was posted on the HHS website on June 8.UPDATEë_(08/03/2012): An official notice states that an employee notified Ameritas that their laptop and other items were stolen from their car on March 21. ë_The laptop contained information used to provide group dental and vision quotes, as well as individual member enrollment information for employer-sponsored group health plans. ë_The laptop was password protected but not encrypted. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and places of employment may have been exposed.

A total of 2,457 Nordstrom fsb customers in California were affected by a mailing error caused by an administrative error. ë_Cardholder statements, replacement credit cards, or other correspondence were mistakenly sent to addresses other than those of intended cardholders. The issue was discovered on June 7 and was the result of an attempt to reformat addresses to U.S. Postal Service standards. ë_Those who were affected were notified in June and July.

Paper files, a laptop, and a flash drive were stolen from an employee's vehicle in Wichita. ë_A total of 100 seniors who participated in the Senior Care Act program had their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_An additional 7,000 seniors who participated in the Older American Act program including Meals on Wheels had personal information other than Social Security numbers stolen. This personal information may have included full names, addresses, birth dates, gender, Medicaid identification numbers, case manager name and case manager telephone number.

Company: California Correctional Health Care Services (CCHCS) Regional Administration
Description of incident: A June 11 theft of materials inside of a kiosk mailbox located outside of the CCHCS Regional Administration building may have resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_Documents that included prospective employment candidate responses to employment inquiries with personally identifiable information may have been in the mailbox. ë_California State Employment Application forms and applicable documents include names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, residential addresses, dates of birth, telephone numbers, email addresses, employment histories, education histories, and other employment information of prospective candidates.ë_
An employee was fired after an investigation revealed that patient records were accessed without legitimate cause. ë_The breach was discovered during a routine audit.

Company: CQ Roll Call, The Economist Group, Bloomberg
Description of incident: A group of former CQ employees were able to continue using log-ins and passwords to access sensitive information from The Economist Group after they left. ë_CQ Roll Call is owned by The Economist Group. ë_Many or all of the former CQ employees accessed the information while employed at Bloomberg. ë_Bloomberg has already paid an unspecified amount toë_The Economist Group as compensation for the unauthorized access incident or incidents. ë_It is not clear what type of information was exposed.

A dishonest employee faces six charges of fraudulently using a credit card and 59 counts of identity theft. ë_The former employee apparently used customer credit card numbers to pay tuition and insurance bills.ë_

Around 100 BNSF Railway employees in North Dakota and adjacent states have reported fraudulent Paypal accounts and credit cards being opened in their names. it is unclear how long this issue has been occurring, what sensitive employee information may have been accessed, and how the information was accessed.

A former employee allegedly stole hundreds of applications and contracts while employed between May 2010 and January 2012. He is accused of making at least $40,000 in online purchases and pleaded not guilty to 17 counts of identity theft and one count each of grand theft, false personation, and a drug charge. He faces 15 years and eight months in prison if convicted.UPDATEë_(08/08/2012): The dishonest employee entered a plea of guilty. He faces at least 180 days and up to one year in jail. ë_He is scheduled to be sentenced on September 6.

A UA student ran a Google search and found her private information posted publicly. ë_The data belonged to several thousand people who had submitted their names and tax ID numbers to UA in order to receive payments or reimbursements. ë_Vendors, consultants, guest speakers, and UA students had their names and tax ID numbers exposed in February and early March. ë_Some people had their Social Security numbers exposed in lieu of tax ID numbers. The sensitive data was embedded within a larger set of files being transferred to the UA new financial system. ë_The files were thought to only contain public information.

About 100 client files were discovered missing from a file cabinet in a restricted area. ë_The files contained Social Security numbers and other personal information. ë_A spokesperson for Capital Area Community said that a disgruntled former or current employee may be to blame.

A hacker or hackers accessed and published sensitive information from a Go-Kart Records database. ë_A total of 218 usernames, email addresses, and passwords were posted. Additionally, nine employee usernames, email addresses, and plain text passwords were posted.

An unauthorized party was able to illegally access information maintained by Citi through a source other than Citi. ë_The unauthorized party logged onto Citi's credit card online account access system by using passwords and user IDs. ë_Customer names, addresses, email addresses, account numbers, and transaction information may have been viewed. ë_Customers who were affected were notified, issued replacement cards, and required to create new account login credentials.

Company: Grant Income Tax Bookkeeping and Check Cash
Description of incident: The dishonest owner of the tax preparation business used names and Social security numbers to file fraudulent tax returns for at least 10 people between 2007 and 2009. ë_He is accused of using nearly $8,000 in fraudulent tax refunds for his own purposes. ë_He was indicted on 23 counts of making false claims for tax refunds, four counts of theft of government money, and four counts of aggravated identity theft on March 15, 2012. ë_He pleaded guilty and faces a maximum sentence of 10 year sin prison and a $250,000 fine for each count of theft of government money, a minimum of two years in prison for the identity theft charges, and a maximum of five years in prison with a $250,000 fine for each count of false claims.

Company: Stanford University Medical Center, Stanford Hospital and Clinics, Stanford School of Medicine
Description of incident: A burglary sometime around July 15 resulted in the theft of a computer from a Stanford faculty member's locked office.The computer contained patient information. No medical records or health histories were stored on the computer, but it may have held the Social security numbers of some patients. ë_The computer was outfitted with security software that would detect when and where the computer connected to the internet.UPDATEë_(08/13/2012): The stolen computer was also password-protected. It may have contained medical record numbers, dates of service, and the names of providers and clinics relating to care provided at Stanford Hospital and Clinics or research conducted by the Stanford School of Medicine.

Company: Employee Benefits, Atlanta Police, MARTA Police, Atlanta Fire Department
Description of incident: Two representatives of Employee Benefits attempted to gather sensitive information from employees of Atlanta Police, MARTA Police, and Atlanta fire department employees. ë_They visited several locations and offered upgraded insurance and benefits packages through AFLAC insurance. ë_Employee Benefits is a legitimate provider of insurance, but not of AFLAC insurance. ë_The representatives handed out business cards and their supervisor was called when a police lieutenant noticed that the representatives appeared to be frauds. ë_They were arrested and at least 39 information packets that contain sensitive information were recovered. ë_The two representatives face multiple counts of identity theft and racketeering.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_A total of 15 administrator user names and encrypted passwords were exposed. ë_Three email addresses were also posted.

It was determined that an employee who retired in May copied two electronic spreadsheets with names and Social Security numbers of active and retired GM workers. ë_The file was found on the former employee's computer. ë_It is unclear if the information was misused or if the former employee acted with malicious intent.

A group of volunteers discovered school materials inside of a public dumpster. ë_There were folders containing sensitive student records among textbooks, novels, and workbooks. The folders contained student Social Security numbers, health records, grade reports, and student education forms. ë_An administrative error meant that custodians discarded obsolete materials that had been stored. ë_The items should have been delivered to the district's central warehouse or sold to used-book dealers. The items were recovered and transmitted to the correct locations.

A hacker or hackers accessed Formspring's development server and posted the password hashes of 420,000 users online. ë_Formspring immediately reset all 28 million user passwords and addressed the security issues upon confirming that a breach had occurred.

Phandroid user account details were accessed and posted online by a hacker or hackers. ë_Hackers breached a back end database that powers Androidforums.com. ë_Androidforum usernames, email addresses, hashed passwords, member IP addresses, forum group memberships, and other data may have been accessed.

A security breach affected Nvidia's developer forums. Hashed passwords and other sensitive information may have been obtained. ë_Public information such as birthdays, gender, and location may have been exposed. People who used the forums were given temporary passwords and instructed to choose a new forum password.UPDATEë_(07/13/2012): A Nvidia representative said that its forum has 290,000 registered accounts, its DevZone site has 100,000 accounts, and its research site has 1,200 accounts.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information from High Tech Crime Solutions Inc.'s website by using an SQL injection cyber attack. ë_A total of 8,900 names and phone numbers were posted online. ë_Over 32,000 private messages were also exposed.

A technical error caused a spreadsheet containing an unspecified number of email addresses and upgrade serial numbers to be indexed by search engines. ë_The email addresses from the spreadsheet were not accompanied with any personal information. ë_The spreadsheet was downloaded by 14 different IP addresses and the owners of those IP addresses were contacted.

Close to 20 Olympic College students and employees notified college personnel that their credit or debit card numbers were used fraudulently. ë_The payment cards had all been used at Olympic College. The reports began in late June and the exact cause of the breach was not identified. ë_Credit card transaction systems were removed from the main merchant network as a precaution.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_A total of 1,313 user names and passwords were posted publicly. ë_The account details and name of one administrator were also posted.

Sensitive information that may have been in the form of paper records was improperly disposed of on August 2. ë_Client names, account types, account numbers, tax payer identification numbers, and Social Security numbers may have been exposed. ë_

Company: Kindred Healthcare Inc. (Kindred Transitional Care and Rehabilitation)
Description of incident: An office burglary sometime around June 4 resulted in the theft of a safe. ë_The safe held tapes used for backing up Kindred data related to past, present, and prospective patients. ë_Diagnosis information, Social Security numbers, clinical information, bank account and other financial information, addresses, dates of birth, insurance numbers, dates that services were received from Kindred, discharge locations, daily activities, collections letters, and medications received may have been exposed. ë_People admitted between 2009 and 2012 may have been exposed. ë_

An office burglary resulted in the theft of a safe on January 26. ë_The safe contained unencrypted backup tapes that require specialized software and equipment to read. ë_The tapes contained patient names, dates of birth, genders, diagnoses, and progress notes. ë_

Company: Adult and Child Care Center, Choices, Inc., Diversified Support Services, Midtown Mental Health Center
Description of incident: A hacking incident that occurred on or around May 10 may have exposed the protected health information of patients. ë_The incident was reported by HHS on July 27.UPDATEë_(08/16/2012): A total of 505 clients and family members of clients of Diversified Support Services and 890 clients and family members of clients of Midtown Mental Health Center were affected. ë_Social Security numbers, private health information, and demographic information were exposed.

Company: Office of Dr. Sharon L. Rogers
Description of incident: The June 16 theft of a laptop may have resulted in the exposure of protected health information from psychology patients. ë_The incident was reported on the HHS website on July 27, 2012.

Company: Office of Dr. Jeffrey Paul Edelstein
Description of incident: Someone who had key access to a building containing a computer server stole the server on May 28. ë_Patient data including names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, account numbers, and diagnoses were on the server. ë_The server contained multiple layers of password protection. ë_

Company: University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center (M.D. Anderson)
Description of incident: An unencrypted flash drive was discovered missing. ë_It had last been seen on an employee shuttle bus on July 13. ë_It contained patient names, dates of birth, medical record number, diagnoses and treatment information, and research information. ë_

A notebook containing names and Social Security numbers was misplaced after a blood drive. ë_It was left in a limited-use conference room late in the afternoon and recovered the next morning behind a chair.

Company: U.S. Department of the Interior National Business Center
Description of incident: A compact disc was discovered missing on or around May 26. ë_It had been sent to the National Business Center in Denver, but may not have arrived. The data on the CD was encrypted and password-protected. ë_Unspecified types of personal information may have been exposed.

A CFTC employee received an email on May 21 that linked to a fraudulent website. ë_The employee failed to recognize the email as a phishing attempt and mistakenly entered information on the website. ë_An unauthorized third party was then able to use the employee's account information to access emails and attachments that contained sensitive employee information such as names and Social Security numbers. ë_The incident was confirmed by the CTC in mid June.

Company: Atkinson & Company LLP Consultants and Certified Public Accountants, The Public Employees Retirement Association (PERA) of New Mexico
Description of incident: A computer containing PERA information was stolen from Atkinson & Company. ë_The information was related to a PERA annual audit that Atkinson & Company were hired to perform. ë_PERA current and former members, as well as retirees may have had their personal information on a file on the computer. ë_UPDATEë_(06/15/2012): Names, addresses, financial institution routing numbers, account types, account numbers, payment amounts, and PERA identification numbers may have been exposed. Family members of current and former PERA members may have also been affected.

A laptop belonging to an Oregon National Guard member was stolen and the military is contacting service members who might be affected by the theft. According to the Oregon National Guard, the laptop was stolen from a vehicle. The Guard member had been using the laptop to conduct work from home. Although this laptop is password protected, there is still potential for exposure of individual personal information.ë_UPDATE (7/1/10): The 3,500 National Guard members who were affected have been notified.

The May theft of a laptop that contained Towards Employment client data may have exposed personal information. ë_The laptop was password protected and contained the names, Social Security numbers, and addresses of clients. Towards Employment is altering its policy so that only the last four digits of clients' Social Security numbers are tracked and used.

Company: Sacramento Department of Parks and Recreation
Description of incident: A local news team investigated a pile of materials in a dumpster outside of a parks building. ë_Unused, unopened books and learning materials were thrown out along with sensitive personal information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, dates of birth, addresses, monthly incomes, and copies of driver's licenses dating back to 2005 were found in several abandoned folders. ë_

Company: Lorillard Tobacco, General Agencies Welfare Benefits Program, National Gypsum, Towers Watson
Description of incident: Two unencrypted DVDs containing employee information were lost in transit by a benefits consulting firm.ë_Multiple organizations were involved.ë_ Benefits consulting firm Towers Watson notified Lorillard and theë_General Council on Finance and Administration, which administers the General Agencies Welfare Benefits Program, of the loss in February.ë_ The DVDs contained names, addresses, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers of current and former employees and their family members.UPDATE (6/22/2010): National Gypsum notified the New Hampshire Attorney General Office of the possible exposure of employee data related to this incident in June.

A malware attack on a Neurocare CPU resulted in unauthorized intrusion into Neurocare's computer systems. ë_The attack compromised Neurocare's credentials for accessing a third party paryoll processor. ë_Unauthorized access to Neurocare's payroll system occurred sometime around June 26, but Neurocare's payroll processor immediately noticed the suspicious account activity and addressed the issue. ë_Neurocare was notified and immediately changed system passwords, sent notifications, and began investigations. A total of 19 employees had their personal information accessed, but all Neurocare employees may have been affected.

Company: New York State Comptroller's Office, New York State Assembly
Description of incident: The New York state Comptroller's Office accidentally released the personal information of over 300 current and former state lawmakers and their staff. ë_The information was intended to fulfill a reporter's request for per diem payments collected by lawmakers. ë_The information was posted in a spreadsheet online. The Social Security numbers were accessible on hidden pages within the spreadsheet; though they were initially believed to be hidden from public view. The private information was available for less than a day.

Company: Office of the Circuit Clerk of Madison County, Illinois
Description of incident: Sensitive court documents remained in a recycling dumpster for two weeks because of a missed scheduled pick-up. ë_The court respondent documents included Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, and detailed accounts of why an order of protection was needed. ë_They were removed upon discovery. Some files were from 2007, though the exact group of people who may have been affected is unclear. ë_The information was from closed cases and could be found in the public record.

The owner of a tax preparation business that closed three years ago accidentally discarded several boxes of sensitive records. ë_The records had been picked over before tossed, but sensitive information still ended up in a public dumpster. ë_A concerned citizen found them in a recycling bin in an old supermarket lot. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and invoices were exposed.

Company: U.S. District Court, Los Angeles California
Description of incident: A Los Angeles federal court clerk was identified as the source of leaked confidential information. ë_The clerk was married to a convicted felon who then sold the information from sealed criminal case documents to an identity theft ring. ë_The federal court clerk, her husband, and at least 60 others from the theft ring were caught by an FBI investigation.

People who signed up for employment through the Kelly Services staffing agency may have had their personal information retained by a former Kelly Services employee. ë_Kelly Services retrieved all of the sensitive information from the former employee upon learning of the breach. ë_Names and Social Security numbers may have been exposed. ë_
