On February 24, 2012, law enforcement notified Suddenlink management of an incident involving a former employee. ë_The employee had obtained the personal information of individuals who worked at Suddenlink and AAT Communications between May 22, 2006 and July 21, 2006. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, wage information, and banking information may have been exposed. ë_The former employee was using the information for fraudulent purposes and an investigation uncovered isolated instances of information misuse between 2006 and 2012. ë_The former employee was arrested.

A University employee was discovered copying electronic files onto an external hard drive on February 17, 2012. ë_The hard drive was recovered and the employee was fired. ë_The hard drive contained the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth of University employees and job applicants. ë_It is unclear if the hard drive information was used for fraudulent purposes.

A hacker or hackers accessed WorldPass' online database in early July of 2010 and was not detected until March 5, 2012. ë_The hacker may have obtained the credit card numbers, user names, email addresses, billing addresses, and payment information of customers.

A breach by an unauthorized party was discovered and contained on July 26. ë_The unauthorized party injected malicious code into the Bellacor website on June 7. ë_Temporary files including customer names, addresses, phone numbers, and encrypted credit card information may have been exposed.

A few students accidentally gained access to sensitive student files. ë_It is not clear if the files were physical or electronic. ë_The students notified school authorities immediately and the problem was fixed. ë_It is not clear what types of student information were exposed. ë_

RBS WorldPay belatedly admitted that hackers broke into their systems. In the US up to 1.1 million Social Security numbers were exposed as a result of the breach. Pre-paid cards including payroll cards and open-loop gift cards were affected. RBS stated that PINs for all PIN-enabled cards have been reset. UPDATE (2/3/09): Hackers orchestrated a highly coordinated, global attack on ATM cards involving the theft of a staggering $9 million from ATMs in 49 cities worldwide. Alleged hackers are still at large and could orchestrate another attack. UPDATE (2/10/09): "Certain personal information" of 1.5 million card holders and Social Security numbers of 1.1 million people were compromised. A class action law suit has been filed against RBS WorldPay. UPDATE (5/28/09): RBS WorldPay says it has returned to Visa's and MasterCard's lists of validated service providers. It was recently certified as compliant with Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) version 1.2.UPDATE (4/05/10): Russian authorities have nabbed the man accused of masterminding a coordinated global ATM heist of $9.5 million from Atlanta-based card processing company RBS WorldPay.UPDATE (8/09/10): Sergei Tsurikov of Estonia was brought to Atlanta by the FBI.ë_ He pleaded not guilty to computer fraud, conspiracy to commit computer fraud, wire fraud, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, and aggravated identity theft.ë_ The FBI is in the process of extraditing others involved in the international hack.UPDATE (8/31/10): Another person has been charged with participating in the computer fraud attack.ë_ Vladislav Anatolievich Horohorin is alleged to have used a prepaid payroll card to conduct fraudulent attacks on ATMs in Moscow.UPDATE (9/15/10): A previously unnamed member of the hacking group will be tried in a Russian court for his involvement in the RBS breach. Eugene Anikin's criminal case was forwarded to Zaeltsovskiy District Court in Novosibirsk for consideration.UPDATEë_(2/7/2011): Yevgeny Anikin, 27, pleaded guilty to participating in a hacking ring that stole $10 million from former Royal Bank of Scotland division WorldPay.UPDATEë_(8/21/2012): Sonya Martin was sentenced to 2.5 years in federal prison for fraudulently obtaining over $9 million from an Atlanta payroll company. ë_She was a cell leader in the plan that involved organized computer hacking and ATM cashout schemes. She worked with other members of the network to target 2,100 ATMs in 280 cities around the world.

A computer glitch that occurred when the district changed its student management systems caused some employee Social Security numbers to be exposed. ë_The numbers could only be seen by other employees who were being trained on the new computer program. ë_Employees were notified of the breach.

Unusual activity was noticed on Sailboat Owner's web servers on the morning of February 23. ë_The website was immediately shut down, but sensitive information may have been accessed. Malware had been uploaded to the web server on the morning of February 22. ë_A total of 2,258 unencrypted credit card records were on the server and dated from 2007 until the day of the incident. ë_CVV codes and expiration dates were also exposed.

ON or around January 25, DUHS received notice that its billing subsidiary staff attached copies of outstanding billing statement(s) for services provided by DUHS facilities and/or DUHS-affiliated physicians to support proofs of claim filed in Chapter 13 bankruptcy actions by patients of DUHS. ë_Patient and patient dependent names, addresses, DUHS medical record number, health insurance carriers, and clinical information were exposed. ë_Some patients and patient dependents had their Social Security numbers and dates of birth exposed as well. ë_Notification letters were mailed on March 23 and again on May 18.

A dishonest employee used the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, and Medicare Health Insurance Claim Numbers to steal the identities of at least 24 Idaho customers enrolled in UnitedHealthcare Medicare plans. On January 30, 2012, it was discovered that the former employee may have accessed the information in the United Health Care database in a way that was inconsistent with his job duties and possibly for fraud purposes. ë_The information was taken between June 28 and December 12 of 2011. Affected patients were notified on March 30.

A vehicle containing paper records was impounded overnight. ë_Some papers with the sensitive information of research participants were discovered missing when the vehicle was reclaimed. The breach occurred on or around January 26.

Unauthorized individuals used IDs and passwords of legitimate 
customers to obtain consumers' Social Security numbers, driver's license
 numbers, and names and addresses. 




     Most of the breaches were at the company's subsidiary 
Seisint Inc., based in Florida. UPDATE (4/12/05) An internal investigation at LexisNexis has uncovered evidence that an additional 280,000 records may have been involved in this breach, increasing the total from 30,000 to 310,000.UPDATE
            (06/30/06): Five men were arrested in connection with this 
            breach.

Credit card information from customers in 25 states was compromised. UPDATE (04/19/2005): An additional 
              
              1,300,000 customers were added to the initial estimate of 100,000.UPDATEë_(08/23/2012): DSW was locked in a dispute with National Union over insurance coverage. ë_A federal appellate court ruled that DSW was entitled to insurance coverage of more than $6.8 million in stipulated losses and prejudgment interest.

Company: Fairview and North Memorial Hospitals, Accretive
Description of incident: The July 25 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_It was stolen from a rental car parked in the parking lot of a Minneapolis restaurant. ë_The laptop was in the possession of an employee of the contractor Accretive. ë_It contained the names, addresses, dates of birth, medical information, and Social Security numbers of patients.ë_ A total of 14,000 Fairview patients were affected.ë_ Approximately 2,800 North Memorial patients were affected, but did not have their Social Security numbers exposed.UPDATEë_(1/20/2012): A lawsuit was filed against Accretive Health, Inc. as a result of the breach.ë_Approximately 23,500 patients in Minnesota were affected by the breach.ë_ë_The Minnesota Attorney General claims that Accretive failed to protect patient health care records and failed to disclose its extensive involvement in patient health care. ë_According to the Minnesota Attorney General, Accretive gained access to sensitive patient data through contracts with the two hospitals and numerically scored patients' risk of hospitalization and medical complexity, graded their "frailty," compiled per-patient profit and loss reports, and identified patients deemed to be "outliers." The physical and mental health information included a checklist of 22 different chronic medical conditions that patients did or did not have. ë_This was without the knowledge or consent of patients and the Attorney General argues that patients had the right to know how their information was being used and to have it kept confidential.Accretive tells investors that its contracts with hospitals include risk scoring patients, reducing avoidable hospital admissions, identifying the sickest and most impact-able patients for proactive management, and identifying real-time interventions with significant revenue or cost impact. The lawsuit alleges that Accretive violated state and federal health privacy laws, state debt collection laws, and state consumer protection laws. ë_It seeks an order requiring Accretive to fully disclose to patients: 1) what information it has about Minnesota patients; 2) what information it has lost about Minnesota patients; 3) where and to whom it has sent information about Minnesota patients; and 4) the purposes for which it amasses and uses information about Minnesota patients. In addition, the lawsuit asks Accretive to disclose whether it has sent health data about Minnesota patients to an offshore site in new Delhi, India and requests that restrictions be applied to how Accretive treats and uses patient data.The press release from the Office of Minnesota Attorney General Lori Swanson can be found here.UPDATEë_(08/24/2012): A settlement agreement with Accretive Health was announced at the end of July. ë_The settlement requires Accretive to stop doing business in Minnesota for two years and to pay approximately $2.5 million to the State of Minnesota, a portion of which will be used to compensate patients.

An employee was caught misusing customer information on July 28. ë_The dishonest employee had been improperly using customer names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and credit card numbers for at least two months. An unspecified number of customers had fraudulent online purchases made in their names.

A set of internal emails were sent to various JSCo employees on August 7 and August 13. ë_The emails contained the names, Social Security numbers, and in some cases, dates of birth of other employees. ë_Employees were instructed to delete the email upon discovery. ë_

A doctor was convicted of prescription drug fraud, identity theft, illegal possession of controlled substances, and burglary. ë_She was arrested in January 2009 following a yearlong narcotics investigation and subsequently pleaded guilty to 272 felony counts. The doctor had a drug addiction. She forged the signatures of several doctors and stole the identity of at least 15 patients in order to maintain her drug habit. She was sentenced to a year in jail, five years of probation, completion of a drug rehabilitation program, and completion of 1,000 hours of community service. The dishonest doctor's license was also permanently revoked. ë_

An unauthorized person accessed confidential files that contained current and former students' personal information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, Dates of birth, student ID numbers, phone numbers, students' free or reduced-price school lunch status, and addresses may have been exposed. ë_Eugene School District 4J's notification can be read here:ë_http://www.4j.lane.edu/communications/story/2012/06/11/securitybreachinf...UPDATEë_(07/12/2012): A minor was arrested for possible involvement in the breach. ë_It appears that the teenager may have obtained the login credentials of an employee and used them to access the computer system. ë_Records for approximately 16,000 current students, as well as free and reduced-price lunch records from 2007 were exposed.UPDATEë_(08/25/2012): The student was released from custody and expelled by North Eugene High School. ë_He also posted hundreds of students' confidential information on a computer account to taunt district officials. He is on house arrest and his attorney entered not guilty pleas.
A hacker or hackers accessed and exposed information from Zybez. ë_Usernames, email addresses, IP addresses, and passwords were exposed.

A user ID assigned to Independent Capital Management used to access consumer reports was compromised by an unknown individual. New user IDs were assigned and security was increased. The unauthorized access took place sometime between February 13 and February 15.

Orvis' hosting company notified Orvis that it may have experienced a breach. ë_It received reports from other clients that fraudulent charges had appeared on their customers' credit cards. ë_The customer credit cards had been used for hosted events. The computer database was encrypted, though it appears to have been compromised.

Students and faculty who were associated with the University of Rhode island after April of 2007 may have had their personal information exposed. ë_The information was placed on a server that was not set-up or intended to be used for storing sensitive information. ë_The information was on the College of Business Administration's computer server and included names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, hire year, rank, and limited compensation information. ë_The information was discovered to be publicly accessible on July 31. It is unclear how long the information was available, but unauthorized access had occurred sometime while the information was exposed.

Customers were told to login and change all passwords after unauthorized activity was detected on a database. ë_There was no evidence initially that customer passwords were taken, but customer passwords were immediately reset after the discovery.UPDATEë_(2/07/2012): Hundreds of PHPs (Personal Home Page) have been created in order to redirect users to work-at-home scams.ë_The Russian scam page tricks users into buying a starter kit for a phony internet-based job. ë_Though Dreamhost took steps to ensure that user web pages could not be stolen by resetting the FTP and shell access passwords of all customers, a number of websites hosted by the company have been hijacked to redirect users to the scam page. An analysis of some of the compromised web pages revealed that the January 20 DreamHost breach may not have been what allowed hackers to access the pages. Hackers had installed backdoor PHP scripts in order to access the pages on December 26.

Company: TransUnion LLC, Manufacturers Life Insurance Company (ManuLife)
Description of incident: An unauthorized access occurred sometime between January 22 and February 15, 2012. ë_Trans Union learned of the breach through its subscriber The Manufacturers Life Insurance Company (Manulife). ë_Consumers may have had their credit reports accessed by someone using a client's login credentials. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and addresses would have been exposed.

A Staples cashier is accused of using a skimming device to obtain the credit card information of customers. ë_She is also accused of selling the numbers to another party. A total of $181,000 in fraudulent credit card purchases resulted from the breach. The dishonest employee faces two felonies for criminal possession of a forgery device and first-degree scheme to defraud. ë_She also faces 50 counts of unlawful possession of personal identification and 50 counts of petite larceny.
A hacker or hackers were able to access user records from the inactive forum of a website run by Brazzers. A portion of the compromised emails, usernames, and encrypted passwords were posted online.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted the information from a public Syracuse Police Department website. The usernames and plain text passwords of 39 police officers were exposed.
A hacker accessed user information on an Intel website through a vulnerability. ë_The hacker had access to credit card data, Social Security numbers, emails, passwords, and other details.

A hacker or hackers accessed the Combined Systems website and shut it down. ë_The hackers claim to have struck in honor of the anniversary of the February 14, 2011 Bahrain uprising and to have wiped out the company's web servers. ë_Administrator logins, customer data, and emails were posted online.

The official fan website for the Gossip Girl TV show was hacked and defaced. Usernames, IDs, emails, and encrypted passwords were posted online. ë_Another hacker followed up on the attack by decrypting many of the publicly posted password hashes.

Information from Wallace Community College was posted online by a hacker. The College became aware of the breach after being notified by Databreaches.net. ë_Eight username, email address, and password combinations were posted in addition to 276 username, password, and full name combinations. ë_People who used their same email and password combination for Wallace Community and other sites are encouraged to change their passwords.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information from indianapolissuperbowl.com. ë_In addition to 10 administrator accounts, 2,016 usernames, email addresses, and cell phone numbers were publicly posted.

Company: Internet Marketing Strategies (Internet Marketing Tools), Power-blog.com
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information from the Internet Marketing Strategies website Power-blog.com. ë_Emails, usernames, and encrypted passwords were exposed.

A waiter was arrested for using a skimming device to steal customer credit card information. ë_The dishonest employee was linked to two men who were arrested for using the information. The men would purchase electronic equipment with the stolen credit card information and then attempt to resell it for cash.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information from islamicfinder.org online. ë_Usernames, names, passwords, and email addresses were exposed.

A hacker or hackers hacked LABusinessconnect.com with the intention of exposing the company's wrong doings. ë_A database for adultstaffing.com was contained within LABusinessconnect.com. ë_Administrator information from LABusinessConnect.com was posted. A total of 686 usernames, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

An employee's computer bag was stolen on July 19. ë_The bag contained a computer server back-up that had patient and employee names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, insurance information, medical record numbers, limited clinical information, and addresses.

A student was able to access and distribute information from a classroom management system called PowerTeacher. ë_The student used user names and passwords to access grades, demographics, Social Security numbers, and other personal information. ë_Some parents reported receiving strange calls that disclosed personal information.

Company: Charter One, Dollar Bank, Fifth Third, First Merit, Key, PNC, Total Merchant Services
Description of incident: Ten people consisting of assistant managers, sales representatives, and other employees of banks were arrested for participating in an identity theft ring. ë_Information was stolen and misused between November 2011 and February 2012. ë_

A hacker or hackers accessed and published information from a Public Broadcasting System server or database. ë_A total of 1,598 press usernames, plain-text passwords, and email addresses were posted online. ë_Thirty-six administrator names, usernames, email addresses and passwords were also publicly posted. ë_Finally, 237 names, emails, passwords, and usernames from other sources were posted online.

A hacker may have accessed as many as 12 data files containing detailed information on IT professionals searching for work with Wall Street. ë_First and last names, mailing addresses, email addresses, usernames, hashed passwords, and phone numbers were posted online. ë_Many of the passwords were decrypted and displayed in plain-text. Past salaries, salary expectations, contact information for references, and other types of job search information were also exposed.

A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information from an official Yamaha music website. ë_A total of eight administrator accounts, as well as 1,755 email addresses and plain-text passwords were exposed. ë_

Files containing customer lease documents were discovered missing. ë_The information was several years old and included customer names and addresses. ë_Drivers' license numbers and Social Security numbers may have also been exposed.
Yurman mailed some 1099 forms to the wrong addresses. ë_Names, tax information, and Social Security numbers were exposed.

A dishonest employee obtained and misused the personal information of patients during her employment. ë_She pleaded guilty to one count of aggravated identity and will be sentenced in October. ë_She faces between two and 8.75 years in prison for using the credit card information of cancer patients to make fraudulent purchases.

A dishonest employee was arrested for using a skimming device to steal customer credit card numbers at Chili's. ë_Investigators were able to link another fraudulent credit card crime to a credit card stored in the dishonest employee's skimmer. ë_This led to the discovery of a credit card making machine, a credit card skimmer, laptops, blank credit cards, and pages of names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth at a separate residence.

Documents dating from 1996 to 2007 were found in a recycling bin by a student. ë_Del Mar employee and student names, Social Security numbers, and mailing addresses were exposed. The student reported the discovery immediately and campus officials began an investigation.

A local news team was alerted to a group of scattered documents near a lake and an interstate.ë_ Most of the documents were labeled with an "Eaton Group" stamp.ë_ The owner of the law group and collection service was not sure how the documents came to be exposed rather than properly disposed of. ë_The court case documents exposed names, Social Security numbers, addresses, bank statements, bank account numbers, Mastercard account numbers, and other sensitive information. ë_The papers were collected and properly destroyed, but the owner did not see a reason for concern since most of the information was available in the public record.

A mailing error caused the Social Security numbers of some employees to be visible through the window of mailed envelopes. The employee stock and tax documents were mailed on January 25, 2011 and notification was posted on February 6.

Company: Valley National Bank, American Stock Transfer and Trust Company, LLC
Description of incident: A mailing error caused 1099 forms to be sent to the wrong addresses on January 17, 2012. ë_Names, tax identification numbers, and addresses were exposed because incorrect or multiple addresses were printed on the forms. ë_Information on stock dividends and phone numbers was also exposed. ë_The error was discovered when some of the forms were returned by the post office as undeliverable.

An unauthorized party misused Accucom credentials to make fraudulent $1.00 charges on customer payment cards that were used on affiliated websites. ë_Credit card numbers, names, and billing addresses may have been accessed. At least 12 New Hampshire residents were affected, but the total number nationwide was not revealed.
A mailing error caused the Social Security numbers of National Retirement Fund participants to be printed on the outside of a mailed envelope. ë_Names and mailing addresses were also exposed.

The July 3 office theft of a computer from the Radiology Department resulted in the exposure of patient information. The computer was used to store CT examination images taken between January 1, 2012 and July 2, 2012. ë_It contained pictures of CT scans performed, reasons for the scans, patient names, ordering doctors' names, and patient hospital account numbers.

The Harris County Hospital District was alerted to an issue when they received a grand jury subpoena on February 11, 2011. ë_A dishonest employee was immediately fired for viewing and possibly sharing patient names, Social Security and member numbers, medical record numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, sexes, emergency contact information, payer information, and other medical care information. The Harris County Hospital District decided to send patients notifications on July 20, 2012 after receiving additional information about the breach. The former employee was indicted and will be tried on criminal charges related to the stolen and misused information on September 24, 2012.
The laptop of an employee who works for a BMO Harris Bank vendor was stolen. ë_It contained customer names, addresses, and dates of birth. BMO learned of the breach on June 20.

A staff member found that a cable line hooked to the computers used by inmates had been connected to a line connecting to the entire Concord prison computer system. ë_This may have allowed one or more prisoners to view, steal, or change sensitive records. The network is used to track invoiced and billing for Correctional Industries contracts. Information from the offender management database system "Corrections Offender Records and Information System" may have been compromised as well.

Company: City of New Haven, Rent Rebate
Description of incident: The May 23 theft of an employee's laptop resulted in the loss of sensitive information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the Mitchell Branch Library and contained the personal information of people enrolled in New Haven's Rent Rebate program. ë_UPDATEë_(09/01/2012):ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and other personal information was exposed. ë_A total of 21,000 Connecticut Rent Rebate program participants were affected.

A strap on a garage truck snapped and sent reams of intact financial reports over downtown Boston 
            streets.
TwinSpires.com computer records were breached on August 3, 2012. ë_Customer names, cryptographically hashed Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and email addresses may have been exposed. ë_

Around 180 people who were arrested between August 27 and September 4 of 2012 had their Social Security numbers exposed by an administrative error. A new software update intended to automatically post regular arrest lists on the department's Facebook page and distribute them to media outlets also released Social Security numbers of those who were arrested. The error was discovered within 45 minutes, but between 70 and 50 individuals accessed the information during that time.

Hackers accessed the EPISD server and were able to collect the personal information of students, teachers and other employees. ë_There were names, Social Security numbers, and addresses from approximately 63,000 students and 9,000 teachers on the district's internal network (myepisd.org). EPISD was not aware of the breach until a computer security company noticed hackers bragging about breaking into EPISD's system. ë_Names, ethnicity codes, and student ID numbers for 26 students were posted by hackers named Sy5t3mF41lur3 & t3hblackhatter of H05t_Bu5t0rz.UPDATEë_(09/07/2012): A hacker accused of carrying out the attack is scheduled to plead guilty to two counts of computer fraud and one count of fraud linked to identification documents.

Company: Minnesota Department of Public Safety Driver and Vehicle Services
Description of incident: An internal audit revealed that an employee at an unnamed Minnesota car dealership allowed an unauthorized friend to use his login information. ë_The login information provided access to a vehicle database for processing consumer sales. ë_Consumer vehicle identification numbers, names, addresses, and dates of birth may have been exposed. ë_The employee's friend worked at a vehicle repossession company and may have allowed additional individuals to use the login credentials. ë_The employee who revealed his login information may face criminal charges.

A hacker accessed the company's banking system and issued separate payments totalling $190,000 to banks in Virginia. ë_It is likely that the hacker placed malware in the system in order to make the withdrawal. ë_The malware has yet to be discovered and it is unclear how long ago the hacker first breached the system.

A contractor working for Boston Water and Sewer Commission misplaced a hard drive. ë_The hard drive may have contained customer names, account numbers, meter numbers, phone numbers, addresses, and other information the utility organization recorded. Residents were also warned to be aware of possible calls from people pretending to be from the Commission.

Hackers associating themselves with Anonymous claimed to have obtained the private information of University of Pittsburgh students and alumni. The hackers threatened to release the information publicly unless the University apologized to students, law enforcement, and professors. ë_The University was involved in the arrest of several supporters of Anonymous. Student passwords, dorm information, payment and credit information, parent information, coursework and grades, as well as alumni information may be exposed.UPDATEë_(08/28/2012): Two men were arrested for allegedly participating in a hack of University of Pittsburgh. One entered a plea of not guilty.

Hackers associating themselves with Anonymous claim to have obtained 12 million Apple Unique Device Identifiers (UDIDs) by hacking an FBI agent's laptop. ë_The hackers offered proof of the breach by posting over one million UDIDs. However, both Apple and the FBI are denying that an FBI agent would have access to that information and keep it on a laptop. The hack occurred in March. Apple replaced the types of identifiers the hackers appear to have obtained and will discontinue their use.

A number of PIN pads in Chicago-area Michaels stores were found to have been tampered with. ë_Michaels checked 7,200 PIN pads in 964 US stores. ë_Fewer than 90 pads were found to have been compromised, but the affected pads were in 20 states. Michaels expects the process of replacing the pads to last about 15 days. The number of affected customers is in the tens of thousands. PIN pads in Canada will also be checked.The Chicago-area was the hardest hit; 14 stores had compromised PIN pads. Customers who used their debit or credit cards at Michaels are encouraged to monitor their transaction records. Michaels Stores released an official statement.UPDATEë_(05/19/2011): A suit seeks class-action status and more than $5 million in damages for people whose credit and debit accounts were compromised by the breach. ë_The lawsuit claims that Michaels failed to protect customers from "cyber-pickpockets" who stole sensitive banking information from checkout keypads at stores in 20 states. Michaels is accused of knowingly violating federal and state law by failing to take reasonable steps to safeguard customers' personal information. ë_Michaels is also accused of failing to alert customers as soon as the security breach was discovered. There is now a theory that thieves used a combination of ë_"false card readers", wireless cameras or electronic membranes placed over keypads to collect the PINs and card information of MIchaels' customers. This allowed them to create fraudulent debit and credit cards.UPDATEë_(05/31/2011): A second lawsuit was filed in late May. ë_The new suit also seeks class-action status. ë_It alleges that Michaels failed to safeguard shoppers' credit and debit PINs and other information. ë_The second lawsuit was filed by an Illinois resident who saw over $1,000 in fraudulent charges after making an $18.16 purchase at Michaels.UPDATEë_(06/20/2011): An extensive fraud case has hit multiple areas of Oregon. ë_Over 250 people have reported fraudulent charges related to cards that were used at Michaels stores.UPDATE (06/27/2011): Four suspects were caught making fraudulent debit card transactions on camera. ë_The images have been distributed by investigators hoping that someone in the Beaverton, Oregon area will recognize one or more of the people. ë_Additionally, Michaels now faces a total of four lawsuits related to the data breach.UPDATE (07/13/2011): A number of Iowa residents began reporting debit card fraud that could potentially be related to the Michaels breach.UPDATEë_(03/21/2012): Two men will be sentenced for their roles in setting up phony debit and credit card pads in the 84 Michaels stores. ë_Each pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit bank fraud, one count of bank fraud, and one count of aggravated identity theft. A total of 94,000 credit and debit card account numbers were stolen.UPDATEë_(07/30/2012): The two men were each sentenced to 36 months in prison for conspiracy to commit bank fraud. ë_An additional 24 months were added for aggravated identity theft. ë_The must also pay $42,000 in restitution and will have five years of supervised release.

The WhatGreatSkin.com servers were hit by an organized attack on the afternoon of August 28. ë_Hackers may have accessed customer names, addresses, and credit card details. Customers were warned to be cautious of phishing attempts for Social Security numbers, credit card information, or any other personal information.
An electronic filing report was found during a raid. ë_The report contained tax return information such as Social Security numbers.ë_

Company: Local 2/Hospitality Industry Child & Elder Care Plan
Description of incident: A USB drive was determined to be lost on August 13, 2012. Information from the non-medical program within the SF Culinary, Bartetenders, and Service Employees Welfare Plan was on the flash drive. ë_People who participated in the Child and Elder Care Plan may ahve had their names, Social Security numbers, and addresses exposed.

Company: Northwestern Mutual and One America - American United Life
Description of incident: A former financial planner stole sensitive information from approximately 3,000 clients and used it to open new accounts, make purchases, receive cash advances, and reroute client mail until his arrest in August of 2011. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, contact information, and financial account information were exposed. He was sentenced to two years in prison and three years of probation. ë_He will also have to pay $48,488.66 in restitution. ë_

ERIC began an effort to remove personally identifiable information from their full text documents in August of 2012. ë_The information had been publicly available through other means, but it was appearing more frequently in internet searches and becoming easier to access because of web advances. ë_Access to many full text documents on ERIC's database was temporarily disabled. Every document will be checked for personally identifiable information before being restored.ë_

Unauthorized attempts were made to illegally transfer funds from an HTC bank account between February 1 and February 3 of 2012. The unauthorized party or parties were able to view a limited amount of automated payment records being processed by a third party vendor. ë_Names on customer bank accounts used for automated payments to HTC, customer bank account numbers used for automated payments to HTC, bank routing numbers used for automated payments to HTC, and customer HTC account numbers were exposed. HTC internal databases were not accessed.

A hacker or hackers accessed information from Greene County's web server. ë_Names, email addresses, user names, and passwords may have been compromised. ë_Users who registered the same username, email address, and password combination for other accounts are encouraged to change those passwords as well.
A hacker or hackers accessed faculty and staff usernames, email addresses, and passwords. ë_The information was then posted online.
A hacker or hackers accessed faculty and staff usernames, email addresses, and passwords. ë_The information was posted online.

An administrative change on www.hagerty.com exposed the personal information of consumers. ë_Names, addresses, driver's license numbers, policy numbers, email addresses, phone numbers, and dates of birth were temporarily available online. ë_The error occurred late in the afternoon of February 14 and was corrected during the afternoon of the following day.

Activists who use hacking (hactivists) targeted several American White supremacist groups. ë_A partial list of officers, political candidate information, financial data, and other member information was exposed. ë_

A software security incident caused the personal information of mortgage applicants to be exposed. Unknown external sources caused a breach that compromised customer Social Security numbers, dates of birth, income data, and assets and liabilities information. The breach was discovered on February 10 at DHI's Internet Loan Prequalification System.

A man shot and killed a postal worker in December of 2010 in order to steal his master key. The key was then used by the the man and his partner to access apartment complex mailboxes in the North Miami-Dade area. ë_An unknown number of people then became victims of tax refund fraud.The man was found guilty of 14 counts of homicide, carjacking, robbery, possession of a firearm, and aggravated identity theft in September of 2012. ë_He faces a sentence of up to life in prison.

A local news team was contacted when a concerned citizen noticed folders with student information in a dumpster. ë_Former student names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and phone numbers were exposed. ë_McAllen School District launched an investigation.ë_The news team held the folders and decided to forward them to the Texas Attorney General's office.

A dishonest employee was discovered to have forwarded emails that contained sensitive personal information in late July. ë_The emails included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, financial account information, and medical/health insurance information. ë_

The loss of a physician's unencrypted, password-free Blackberry at an airport on July 1 resulted in the exposure of patient names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, diagnosis information, procedure names, and test results. ë_Lahey Clinic was able to remove all data from the device remotely on July 6. Affected patients were notified in late August.

Company: Lincoln Financial Securities Corporation, Red Boat Advisor Resources
Description of incident: A server that held TIFF images of customer financial applications was accessed by an unauthorized party between January and early April of 2012. Customers who applied for brokerage accounts, life insurance and annuities, and provided other financial applications may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, email addresses, government issued identification numbers, and financial account information exposed. ë_Named beneficiaries and other family members may have also had their information exposed.

A dishonest employee was caught with a backpack full of customer financial information. ë_A resident reported the employee when he saw someone checking his mail for packages. ë_Police investigated and were able to uncover fraudulent activity. ë_At least 10 purchases were made with customer debit and credit cards between January and February.

Over 350 city workers had their information posted on a public server in January. ë_An employee inadvertently uploaded the sensitive information to a public domain server as part of an annual audit. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, salaries, and addresses were exposed.

On February 19, 2010, a laptop belonging to a physician affiliated with the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary was stolen while the physician was lecturing in South Korea. The laptop belonged to a neurologist with a particular focus on ringing in the ears, or tinnitus. The following types of information about affected individuals associated with Mass. Eye and Ear may have been present on laptop, names, addresses, telephone numbers, emails, date of birth and age, sex, medical record numbers, dates of service, medical information, including diagnoses, symptoms, test results, and prescriptions, name and contact information for patient pharmacies, and research participant status. In addition, four individuals_Ñé information also included their pharmacy insurance account number.UPDATEë_(09/17/2012): Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary and Massachusetts Eye and Ear Associates Inc. agreed to pay the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) $1.5 million to settle potential violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Security Rule. ë_An HHS Office for Civil Rights investigation indicated that Mass. Eye and Ear failed to take necessary steps to comply with certain requirements of the Security Rule. ë_These steps include conducting a thorough analysis of the risk to the confidentiality of electronic protected health information (ePHI) maintained on portable devices, implementing security measures sufficient to ensure the confidentiality of ePHI that Mass. Ear and Eye created, maintained, and transmitted using portable devices, adopting and implementing policies and procedures to restrict access to ePHI to authorized users of portable devices, and adopting and implementing policies and procedures to address security incident identification, reporting, and response. Mass. Ear and Eye will also have to adhere to a corrective action plan to address these issues. The full HHS disclosure can be read here:ë_http://www.hhs.gov/news/press/2012pres/09/20120917a.html

A hacker breached a data server located at a Transcend Capital branch during the week of August 20. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, addresses, account numbers, telephone numbers, email addresses, security positions, and cash positions may have been exposed. ë_Clients were encouraged to change their passwords. ë_A total of 236 clients who are California residents were affected, but the total number of clients affected nationwide was not disclosed.

A July 22 Saint Therese office theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The computer was unencrypted; however, it was password protected.Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, health insurer names, dates of treatment, amount billed, and account balances were exposed. Notifications were sent on September 17.

Two University of Miami Hospital employees were using patient registration sheets to inappropriately access patient information. ë_Anyone who was seen at University of Miami Hospital between October 2010 and July 2012 may have been affected. ë_Patient names, addresses, dates of birth, insurance policy numbers, and reasons for visits were exposed. ë_The last four digits of patients' Social Security numbers, were exposed in many cases and full Social Security numbers were exposed in some cases. The dishonest employees were terminated immediately and may have sold some of the information to unauthorized parties.

The January 27 theft of a laptop from a former contractor's vehicle resulted in the loss of patient information. ë_The patient files included Social Security numbers, names, addresses, identification numbers, medical record numbers, dates of birth, admission dates, diagnosis-related information, and discharge dates. The majority of those affected were patients who were treated at the Hospital between December 2010 and October 2011. ë_Some patients who received treatment as far back as 2007 were also affected. The patient files had been downloaded onto the contractor's personal laptop in violation of the Hospital's policy. The contractor stopped working for the hospital in December of 2011.UPDATEë_(09/21/2012): The number of patients who were notified was revised from 34,503 to 66,601.

Company: Central States Southeast and Southwest Areas Health and Welfare Fund
Description of incident: An incident occurred on July 31 that may have caused sensitive health information to be exposed. The information was in the form of paper records that were exposed in some undisclosed way.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive Marquette University information online. ë_Fifteen names, addresses, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

An email that was sent to patients displayed the names of all patients who received the email. ë_The email was sent to patients being treated for HIV or AIDS and inadvertently revealed names and HIV status.

Company: Cabinet for Health and Family Services
Description of incident: An employee was the victim of a phishing attack via email sent by a hacker. ë_The employee's account was then compromised. ë_Unauthorized activity was identified on the account within half an hour and the account was immediately disabled. ë_
The August 18th theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.
The August 4th theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. The laptop contained names, Medicaid numbers, and short summary information used for administrative purposes.ë_
A dishonest intern stole personal information while working at the clinic. ë_The information was used to create and cash fraudulent checks and the dishonest intern pled guilty.

Apex Laboratory learned from law enforcement investigators on July 30 that an unauthorized party or parties accessed their computer systems. ë_Patients may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, gender, and insurance identification numbers were exposed.

A customer using RiteAid's mobile app to check a prescription noticed that he was able to access the names, addresses, and prescription records of other customers. ë_The customer was able to identify some of the problems by using his computer science background. ë_He noticed there was no secure login tied to web service calls made from the smartphone application. ë_The customer was able to correspond with several RiteAid representatives and RiteAid began to address some of the security concerns.

A dishonest employee working as a technician in the surgery department at Howard University Health Sciences sold patient information between August 2010 and December of 2011. The employee was charged with one count of wrongful disclosure of individually identifiable health information. ë_Patient names, Medicare numbers, addresses, and dates of birth may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(09/24/2012): The dishonest employee was sentenced to 100 hours of community service and three years of probation. The probation term includes six months in a halfway house followed by six months of home confinement. ë_She was also fined $2,100. ë_Her illegal activities involved taking the records of hospital patients, selling their names, addresses, dates of birth, and medical numbers to an unauthorized party, and providing blank hospital prescription forms as well. The dishonest employee was paid between $500 and $800 in cash for each transaction. The information was used for fraudulent oxycodone prescriptions. ë_
An August 26 office theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.ë_

A July 24 office burglary resulted in the theft of medical bags and a laptop. ë_Affected patients were mailed notification letters on September 7. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and medical information was exposed. ë_

A licensed clinical social worked accidentally attached confidential client information to an email that was forwarded to town council colleagues. A copy of her and her husband's 2011 income tax returns was also in the email. The email automatically became available to the public and the error was noticed nearly a week later. ë_Unfortunately, the email was also forwarded a second time to a public account. ë_Consequently, the information was publicly available for a week. ë_Many of the affected clients were University of North Carolina students. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, clinical notes about client mental health, payment amounts, and insurance forms were exposed.

Florida International University is in the process of sending notification letters to 19,407 students and 88 faculty members after the university_Ñés IT Security Office discovered personal data may have been exposed over the internet via a database_Ñés external search function. An announcement posted on the FIU website lists the personal data as GPAs, test scores, and Social Security numbers that were stored on the College of Education_Ñés E-Folio software app. This database kept track of student data related to state mastery standards, grade tracking, assignments, and Social Security numbers for both students and faculty.

Letters soliciting dental and vision coverage were mailed to current Anthem customers. ë_A priority code composed of the customer's Social Security number and two extra digits was printed on the outside of each envelope. ë_One customer noticed the error and contacted the media. ë_Anthem admits that an error occurred, but did not reveal the cause. Anthem is working to prevent this type of breach from happening again and was in the process of notifying customers of the error as of May 12.ë_UPDATEë_(10/01/2012): Anthem experienced the marketing mailer error on April 27, 2011. ë_The State of California settled with Anthem in September of 2012. Anthem agreed to pay $150,000 and to make significant improvements to its data security procedures to prevent future errors of a similar type..

Five password-protected laptop computers that contained personal information of registered voters in Robeson County were discovered stolen in September. ë_Voters had their names, addresses, dates of birth, and the last four digits of their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_The computers went missing between July 18 and September 4. They were most likely taken while outside of their normally secured area and left with unsupervised community volunteers. ë_Driver's license numbers may have also been exposed. ë_Those who were affected were mailed letters on September 12.

Company: San Mateo Union High School District
Description of incident: Hackers accessed San Mateo Union High School District's computer system and attempted to use it to infiltrate FBI and CIA electronic systems. The District became aware of the problem when United States Naval Intelligence informed them that the District's servers had been compromised. ë_The hackers appear to have used additional organizations in their scheme.

A postcard mailed to University of Chicago employees contained their Social Security numbers. The cards were mailed on September 24 to remind employees about open enrollment, but also had Social Security numbers printed on the outside.

Company: Brightline Interactive, Army Chief of Public Affairs
Description of incident: An army awards database was found to be available online. ë_The database was being handled by the defense contractor Brightline Interactive and was mistakenly uploaded to a public server at an unknown time. ë_Those who received awards for actions since September 11, 2001 were affected.

Company: Center 4 Health Enlightenment Enrichment Empowerment Renewal Services (CHEERS)
Description of incident: A dishonest employee accessed and misused CHEERS client names, Social Security numbers, and birth dates. ë_She, her sister, and her husband filed 180 tax returns under stolen identities and claimed over $1 million in tax refunds. The three face between three years and five years in prison.
An office burglary resulted in the exposure of personal information. ë_Two or more laptops with donor information and a docking station were stolen.

A pile of thousands of documents were found in the street. Two bags were stuffed with financial information such as tax returns with Social Security numbers. The information was found in the driveway of a model home that had been foreclosed in July 2011.

Company: Monterey Institute of International Studies, Middlebury College
Description of incident: A September 14, 2012 home burglary resulted in the theft of a laptop. ë_The laptop was password-protected and was stolen along with other items. ë_Student names and Social Security numbers were on the laptop. ë_

An internal review revealed a hack of Northwest College servers. ë_One or more hackers accessed at least one folder in the server between May 21, 2012 and September 24, 2012. ë_Over 3,000 employees, 76,000 Northwest College student records, and 200,000 students eligible for Bright Future scholarships in 2005-06 and 2006-07 were affected. ë_Bright Future scholarship data included names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, ethnicity, and genders. ë_Current and former employees that have used direct deposit anytime since 2002 may have had some information exposed. At least 50 employees had enough information in the folder to be at risk for identity theft.

An unauthorized party or parties used Speedy Recovery Services' Experian login to view consumer information. ë_The unauthorized access took place between December 12, 2010 and January 21, 2012. ë_Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and account numbers may have been exposed.

Company: American Stock Transfer & Trust Company, LLC, Mesa Royalty Trust
Description of incident: A mailing error caused personal information to be exposed. ë_Beneficiary statements containing tax information for 2011 were sent by postal mail on April 2, 2012. ë_The statements were mailed to incorrect addresses and exposed names, home addresses, and tax identification numbers of intended shareholders. The error was discovered on April 6.

Company: America Stock Transfer & Trust Company, LLC
Description of incident: Shareholder 1099 forms were sent to the wrong addresses due to a mailing error. ë_Names, home addresses, and tax identification numbers could have been viewed by incorrect parties. ë_The forms were mailed on January 17 and the error was discovered on January 18. ë_
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted online information. ë_A total of 39 administrator and moderator usernames, email addresses, and salted passwords were exposed.

A dishonest employee used a skimming device to copy customer credit and debit card information. ë_The former employee was arrested for stealing and misusing the customer payment information. ë_The fraudulent activity occurred throughout 2011.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted online information. ë_A total of 201 usernames and hashed passwords were exposed.

Company: Isaac Miller Elementary School, Santa Maria-Benita School District
Description of incident: A man noticed dozens of books and documents inside a dumpster near Miller Elementary. ë_The documents contained personal and financial information related to applications for free and recuded-price meals. ë_The books were new and federally-funded. ë_School officials claimed that the documents should have been shredded and recovered the documents and books. The books were donated.

Company: Employ Bridge (Staffing Solutions), Tempo Real Estate Corporation
Description of incident: Thousands of personal documents were found in a recycling dumpster.ë_ The documents likely contained employment information such as full names, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses, and work histories. They were taken from an office in Alpharetta without the company's knowledge or permission.ë_ A landlord with Temp Real Estate Corporation sent a cleaning crew to clean out the office after incorrectly believing Employ Bridge's lease had expired.ë_
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted online information. ë_A total of 3,410 names, addresses, usernames, passwords, phone numbers, and email addresses were taken from bklighting.com and exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted online information from the popular file sharing website. ë_ A total of 4,504 usernames, passwords, and email addresses were exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted information online. ë_A total of 214 usernames, email addresses, and hashed passwords were exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted online information. ë_A total of 44 employee names, email addresses, phone numbers, and passwords were exposed.

The CMS experienced 13 breaches between September 23, 2009 and December 31, 2011. ë_The CMS failed to notify beneficiaries of seven of the breaches in a timely manner. ë_The HHS's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) also alleges that the notifications mailed to beneficiaries did not disclose what type of information had been exposed, the date the breach occurred, or how CMS was working to prevent future breaches.

A hacker or hackers accessed PlaySpans computer system. ë_User IDs, encrypted passwords, and email addresses of online players were exposed. ë_Users are advised to immediately change their passwords and also any similar passwords for other logins associated with compromised email addresses. PlaySpan Marketplace may have also been affected and could be linked to user financial information.

An office burglary that occurred on October 10 resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Paper documents that contained credit card numbers, addresses, and other personal information were taken.

A cyber breach affected Korn/Ferry databases. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, government-issued identification numbers, credit card numbers, and health information may have been exposed. ë_The information may have been available to unauthorized parties for months before the breach was discovered in August of 2012.

Company: PST Services, Inc., Litton and Giddings Radiological Associates, P.C.
Description of incident: Litton and Giddings' janitorial service, PST Services, failed to shred patient billing records before sending them to a Springfield recycling company. ë_The records may have been viewed by unauthorized parties before being destroyed at the recycling center. ë_

A former employee of the University of Maryland Medical Center and three other people collaborated to steal the identities of patients. ë_The former medical center employee allegedly stole the patient information of people who had paid for medical treatment between July 2009 and June 2011. ë_His co-conspirators then used the information to open credit cards, obtain cash advances and make purchases in victims' names. ë_The four people were arrested and face a maximum sentence of 30 years in prison for conspiracy, in addition to charges related to bank fraud and aggravated identity theft.UPDATE (10/12/2012): A former employee was sentenced to six months of home detention and ordered to pay $22,000 in restitution. ë_He claimed that he took the patient records home in order to conceal work that he had not completed and submit false reports. ë_At least two other people used the patient records to commit fraud.ë_

A hacker or hackers managed to transfer $400,000 in city funds to accounts across the country. The cyber attack occurred sometime between Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. ë_City employees may have also had their direct deposit bank account information compromised.

Sensitive information from Southern Environmental Law Center was placed online. ë_Credit card, medical, and donor information such as addresses, phone numbers, and client files were exposed. ë_The data was accessible via Google search for an unspecified amount of time. ë_Southern Environmental Law Center is warning people not to open emails about the security failure or click on any links in emails that appear to be from Southern Environmental Law Center.

Company: United States Navy, Smart Web Move
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers accessed sensitive information and posted it online. ë_Former and current Navy personnel who used Smart Web Move to arrange household moves could have been affected. ë_The compromised database stored 11 years of private information, but only 20 people had their information publicly posted. ë_Usernames, email addresses, security questions and corresponding answers were exposed.

An employee's laptop was stolen from his unattended office between 10 a.m. and noon on September 17. ë_The laptop was password-protected. ë_It contained the information of town employees. ë_Social Security and bank account numbers may have been exposed.

A password-protected laptop was stolen from an employee's home on August 25. ë_It contained two groups of patient data. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, responsible party names, patient addresses, physician names, and billing information for 22,000 patients were on the laptop. An additional 5,000 patients had similar information exposed as well as their Social Security numbers and other non-medical information.

Company: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts (BCBS)
Description of incident: A BCBS vendor misused BCBS employee information. ë_The misuse appears to have been limited to one instance. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, compensation information, and bank account information may have been exposed.
The July 15 theft of an electronic device exposed patient information.

Company: Ecco Health, LLC, Colon & Digestive Health Specialists
Description of incident: A vendor working with patient data for digital conversion from Colon & Digestive lost a flash drive on or around July 16. ë_It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, account numbers, diagnoses, and other protected health information.

An assistant police chief filed a complaint alleging that the chief of policed breached federal privacy law. ë_The complaint alleges that the chief of police received information about ambulance dispatches that was primarily intended for paramedics and other active first responders. ë_He also claims the chief of police forwarded the information to a third party.

Company: Office of Dr. Philip P. Corneliuson
Description of incident: An office burglary resulted in the theft of a computer. ë_The incident was discovered on September 15, 2012. ë_Patient names and Social Security numbers were on the computer.UPDATEë_(10/24/2012): The computer contained medical records and insurance information.

Two unencrypted backup tapes were discovered missing on September 10. ë_They were lost sometime between August 27, and September 10. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, financial account information, driver's license numbers, and transaction records were exposed.

An employee noticed unusual activity on a computer on September 25, 2012. ë_It is possible that former and current members of the Waipahu Aloha Clubhouse had information on the computer that was remotely accessed by an unauthorized party. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, phone numbers, and consumer record numbers dating back to 1997 may have been exposed. Though the Clubhouse services people living with severe and persistent mental illness, no medical records were exposed.

Company: Alabama Department of Human Resources, Vinson Guard Service Inc., Jefferson Davis High School
Description of incident: An alert stating that the United States Attorney's Office is prosecuting cases related to the theft of personal identifying information and misuse of that personal identifying information was released. ë_The information was stolen between January 1, 2009 and March 25, 2011. ë_People from various organizations may have had their information misused to prepare fraudulent tax returns.

Two dishonest employees misused customer credit card information to make more than $26,000 in fraudulent purchases. ë_The two men face a maximum of 10 years in prison and a $50,000 fine for each of six counts of deceptive practices. The men were arrested on July 29. ë_

An Optimum HealthCare claims specialist stole the personal information of at least 32 clients. ë_The documents information was later found on a man who was arrested after a traffic stop in 2011. ë_The man who was arrested never worked for Optimum and the dishonest employee who stole the documents is believed to have separated from Optimum.

An unauthorized party gained access to a physician's identity in order to view patient records. ë_A fraudulent account was created under the doctor's identity in the Washington medical system. ë_Medical information such as drugs dispensed and quantity dispensed may have been accessed before the fraudulent account was shut down.

A dishonest employee was arrested and fired in March after stealing patient information from Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary. ë_The former employee opened fake accounts to avoid paying for electricity. The investigation began in January when one of the victims noticed that her Social Security number had been used to open an account. ë_Names and dates of birth were also compromised.

Company: Abilene Telco Federal Credit Union, Experian
Description of incident: A hacker or hackers were able to access an Abilene Telco Federal Credit Union employee's computer in September 2011. ë_The Bank's online account with Experian was then used to download the credit reports of 847 people. ë_Social Security numbers, dates of birth and detailed financial data were exposed.

Compete Inc. reached an agreement with the Federal Trade Commission regarding the collection of consumer information. Compete agreed to obtain end users' consent before collecting future online browsing data. ë_Compete will also delete or anonymize consumer data already collected and provide direction for removing tracking software installed on the computers of those who had their data collected. FTC charged that Compete failed to adequately describe two products used to collect details about end users' browsing habits. ë_A toolbar and input panel were used to collect extensive information about consumer activities and transmit the information in clear readable text to Compete's servers. ë_All websites visited by, links followed by, and advertisements displayed to Compete consumers were collected and stored.

Hardware at Aultman was discovered to have been infected by a cyber attack. ë_Unauthorized parties may have been able to access credit and debit card information from Aultman gift shop purchases between February and September of 2012. ë_

On May 3, data of all American 
            veterans who were discharged since 1975 including names, Social Security 
            numbers, dates of birth and in many cases phone numbers and addresses, 
            were stolen from a VA employee's home. Theft of the laptop and computer 
            storage device included data of 26.5 million veterans. The data did 
            not contain medical or financial information, but may have disability 
            numerical rankings.  UPDATE 
            (6/29/06): The stolen laptop computer and the external hard 
            drive were recovered.  UPDATE
            (7/14/06): FBI claims no data had been taken from stolen computer. 
             UPDATE(8/5/06): 
            Two teens were arrested in the theft of the laptop. UPDATE
            (8/25/06): In an Aug. 25 letter, Secretary Nicholson told veterans 
            of the decision to not offer them credit monitoring services. Rather 
            the VA has contracted with a company to conduct breach analysis to 
            monitor for patterns of misuse.  UPDATE
            (11/23/07): A federal judge questioned the Veterans Affairs Department's 
            computer security and ruled Friday that lawsuits can go forward over 
            the theft of computer equipment containing data on 26.5 million veterans. 
            The lawsuits have been filed as potential class-action cases representing 
            every veteran whose data was released. UPDATE
            (1/23/09): The Department of Veterans Affairs has agreed to pay $20 
            million to current and former military personnel to settle a class 
            action lawsuit. UPDATE
            (6/16/09): No less than $75 will be paid for any valid claim, up to 
            a cap of $1,500. If your expenses were higher than that, you might 
            want to opt out of the class-action portion so you can file for your 
            actual damages. In that case, you need to file a letter so it is received 
            by June 29, 2009. You have until Nov. 27, 2009, to mail your claim 
            form to VA Settlement Claims, P.O. Box 6727, Portland, OR 97228-9767. 
            Be sure to keep a copy of the claim form, along with your proof of 
            mailing. To download the claim form and to get more information, go 
            to www.veteransclass.com. 
            Read the FAQ and note the particulars on out-of-pocket expenses and 
            actual damages. You also can call (888) 288-9625.UDPATEë_(10/19/12): An investigation into the VA revealed that encryption software has only been installed on 16% of VA computers since the 2006 breach. Six million dollars has been spent on encryption software since the 2006 breach. The investigation began after a 2011 anonymous tip.

Hackers targeted the U.S. National Weather Service website Weather.gov in an attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in U.S. government online systems. ë_The hackers claim to have begun a campaign in response to U.S. cyber attacks in Muslim nations. ë_Partial login credentials and system and network configuration files were accessed and posted online.

The passwords of two University of Georgia (UGA) IT employees were reset and misused by an intruder. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and other sensitive data of current and former school employees may have been exposed. The breach may have begun as early as September 28, 2012.

A data file that contained employment information such as names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, dates of employment, gender, race, home phone numbers, and addresses was accidentally placed on a publicly available web server. The information was available from 2008 until 2011. Faculty and staff who worked at UGA in 2002 were affected.

Equifax settled charges with the Federal Trade Commission after it was discovered that Equifax Information Services improperly sold lists of consumer data. ë_People who were late on their mortgage payments had their information sold to firms that should not have received the information and subsequently resold it to other firms. ë_Equifax agreed to pay nearly $1.6 million to resolve charges that it violated the FTC and Fair Credit Reporting Acts. The settlement prohibits Equifax from providing prescreened lists to unauthorized parties, having poor procedures for releasing prescreened lists, and selling prescreened lists in certain circumstances.

Names and Social Security numbers of people associated with Cornell were publicly available for five days. ë_The information was on a computer in Cornell's athletics department and was accidentally placed online from September 5, 2012 until September 10, 2012.

A cyber intruder injected a virus into the website of the city of Naperville. ë_City officials claim that no resident credit card information was compromised. ë_There is no evidence that any type of information was stolen from the website.
An employee resigned and left with customer account information. ë_Names, Account numbers, account types, and phone numbers may have been exposed. ë_The breach occurred in late July.

Sensitive staff information on a database file was found to have been accessible to all SVSP staff. ë_Staff names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, addresses, and institutional-position information were exposed. ë_The breach was discovered on September 26 and it is unclear how long the information was available.

Company: Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services
Description of incident: The August 31 theft of a briefcase from the home of a contractor resulted in the exposure of nursing home residents. ë_The briefcase contained names, Social Security numbers, Medicaid recipient numbers, and dates of birth. ë_

An unauthorized person may have gained access to the computer network that supported certain 4Access terminals. ë_These terminals were connected to a computer network that allowed merchant transaction processing. ë_The unauthorized entry was discovered on September 24. ë_Check processing information stored in the network such as check writer's name, checking account and routing numbers, address, and driver's license number may have been accessed. No credit card information was exposed. ë_

Laboratory reports for about 6,400 patients were discovered missing. ë_The reports contained bill processing information and charges for laboratory services. ë_Patients who had lab work done between May 1, 2012 and August 31, 2012 had their names, Memorial internal account numbers, lab work dates, and types of lab work exposed.

Unencrypted backup tapes containing ultrasound images from ambulatory sites were discovered missing on September 13. ë_The information was from Providence, Rhode Island between 1993 and 1997 and New Bedford, Massachusetts between 2002 and 2007. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, dates of exams, physicians' names, and patient ultrasound images were exposed. ë_A limited number of current and former patients also had their Social Security numbers exposed. Notifications began on November 5.UPDATEë_(11/10/2012): A total of 14,004 patients were affected.

The September 23 theft of an employee's unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of information of over 100,000 patients. ë_The laptop was stolen from the employee's home. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and diagnosis information of patients taking drugs to prevent blood clots were exposed. Alere became aware of the breach on October 1.
A hacking spree resulted in unauthorized access to the ImageShack server and a Symantec portal. Names, phone numbers, emails, domains, passwords, usernames, and other information were exposed.

An employee may have performed unauthorized searches on clients. ë_The employee is no longer with the company. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and driver's license numbers may have been exposed. ë_The potential breach was discovered in July and clients were notified in October after their contact information was confirmed.

Company: Highlandtown Community Health Center, Johns Hopkins Hospital
Description of incident: At least four people were involved in an identity theft ring that affected over 250 people. ë_One member of the ring was employed by Highlandtown Community Health Center and provided personal and financial patient information that he accessed through his position. The information was used by other ring members to create counterfeit checks and fraudulent state identification cards. The fraud occurred between August and October of 2009.Another member of the ring was employed by Johns Hopkins Hospital and provided the information of doctors who applied for fellowships there. ë_Several ring members rented apartments under the identities of doctors. Two of the members pleaded guilty to conspiring to commit wire fraud and aggravated identity theft. ë_The four members of the ring are required to collectively pay restitution for fraudulently obtained cash, merchandise, and services worth over $188,000.
A device with patient information was discovered lost or stolen on August 15. ë_

The sensitive information of Chicago voters was exposed online due to a mistake by the election authority. A database that included names, the last four digits of Social Security numbers, addresses, and drivers license numbers was accidentally placed online in a publicly accessible place. ë_Only people who applied to work for the board in Chicago polling places on Election Day were determined to have been affected. ë_A forensic investigation firm believes that as many as 1.7 million registered voters had their names, addresses, and voter registration numbers exposed. However the Chicago Board does not believe that information should be considered sensitive.
A hacker accessed the e-commerce site labelmaster.com. ë_Customer names, addresses, credit card numbers, and credit card expiration dates were exposed. ë_

The Bob Ward & Sons website was hacked on June 6, 2011. ë_Customers who made online purchases between May 31 and August 3 of 2012 may have had their names, addresses, and credit card information exposed. ë_Ward became aware of the issue when he received a notice from Discover that revealed some customers had experienced fraudulent charges. ë_

Company: Department of State Bureau of Consular Affairs
Description of incident: A dishonest employee misused sensitive information in a State Department database to obtain fraudulent credit cards. ë_He was part of a conspiracy sometime during his employment between September 2007 and March 2008. ë_The group of conspirators successfully obtained $71,774 and attempted to obtain an additional $133,494 in fraudulent transactions. ë_The dishonest employee pled guilty to conducting illegal transaction with credit cards and agreed to pay $71,774 in restitution.
An employee transported a hard copy of sensitive employee documents home. ë_The employee is not believed to have took the information for fraudulent or criminal activity.

The August 29 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of employee information. ë_Employee names, Social Security numbers, information related to taxpayer I.D., dates of birth, home addresses, and employment information such as salaries were exposed.

A hacker gainedë_access to the ATS system and may have accessed financial information. ë_The attack was discovered on August 1 and financial information was immediately removed from the ATS online system. ë_

A hacker released the names, email addresses, and encrypted passwords of 230 members of Adobe's company database. ë_The hacker claimed to have access to over 150,000 records. ë_Adobe announced that it would reset approximately 150,000 passwords of members of the Connectusers.com site.UPDATEë_(11/14/2012): The 230 people who were affected also had their titles, affiliated organizations, and usernames exposed. ë_A number of those affected were associated with U.S. government agencies such as the Department of Transportation, the Department of Homeland Security, the U.S. State Department, and the Federal Aviation Administration.

The November 6 defacement of Steam forums led to an investigation that revealed hackers had accessed a Steam database with sensitive user information.
