The database contained user names, hashed and salted passwords, game purchases, email addresses, billing addresses, and encrypted credit card information. ë_Users were prompted to change their Steam forum passwords and encouraged to change their Steam account passwords. ë_Anyone using their Steam forum password for other websites should change their password since hackers could have obtained email address and password combinations.ë_Steam is the Valve Corporation's social-distribution network. ë_People who use the company's online gaming content were affected.UPDATEë_(11/16/2012): A judge dismissed a class action lawsuit related to the November 6, 2011 breach. ë_The plaintiffs of the lawsuit used Steam to purchase and access online gaming content. They alleged present and future harm as a result of the breach. ë_According to the judge who dismissed the lawsuit, the plaintiffs did not prove that they were harmed by the Steam breach.

A referral document containing sensitive information was accidentally sent in an email to an unauthorized recipient. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and health concerns were sent to a county social worker. The county social worker deleted the sensitive email and any other existing copies of the document were securely deleted from the network. ë_The WestCoast Children's Clinic will not provide referral forms to outside agencies in order to protect against future inadvertent sharing of private information. ë_Disciplinary actions will also be taken against the employees involved in the privacy breach.

Company: Inova Fairfax Hospital Cardiac Care Center, Inova Fair Oaks Hospital
Description of incident: Someone discovered card skimming devices at an ATM near a gift shop of the Inova Fairfax Hospital Cardiac Care Center and at an ATM next to the Inova Fair Oaks Hospital cafeteria. ë_One device was discovered by a hospital employee who attempted to use the ATM and witnessed the skimmer fall from the ATM. ë_A skimming device was previously discovered at the same Inova Fairfax Hospital Cardiac Care Center ATM in September. ë_It is unclear how long the devices were there and people who used them are urged to check their financial statements.

Company: Florida Hospital Tampa (formerly University Community Hospital Medical Center), Crothall Healthcare, Naval Medical Center (Bob Wilson Naval Hospital)
Description of incident: Three people were arrested for their roles in filing 225 fraudulent tax returns. ë_They face charges of conspiracy, theft of government property, and aggravated identity theft. ë_About $555,000 in refund money was obtained. ë_One of the defendants worked at Florida Hospital Tampa through a maintenance and housekeeping company. ë_Information came from a variety of medical centers in California and Florida. ë_There was an incident where the dishonest worker provided her co-conspirators with a list of names and Social Security numbers from patients seen at Florida Hospital Tampa on January 17 of 2012 and another incident where ER patient names, Social Security numbers, and other information was stolen from Crothall Healthcare in January. ë_

Sensitive patient and employee records were left unsecured in the abandoned medical center. ë_A November 10 auction of office equipment and computers was held in the medical center, but one person reported seeing piles of sensitive documents and being able to access sensitive items like badges of former employees. The person provided pictures of personnel records and other items that should have been secured. A representative speaking on behalf of those responsible for safeguarding private information responded that the pictures were taken behind an area that had been secured with a rope. Additionally, the person claims that one of the computers that was purchased at the auction still contained sensitive information.

Patient information was exposed by the accidental disposal of paper jackets with old radiology films. ë_Patient information such as name, address, age, date of birth, race, sex, name of radiology procedure and radiology procedure date was exposed. ë_The paper jackets were sent to a local landfill.

Company: Westside Park Elementary School Based Health Center
Description of incident: A burglary sometime around October 1 may have resulted in the exposure of patient names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, addresses, dates of birth, health conditions, medications, and other health information. ë_The information was in a locked room that was accessed, but it appears that none of the paper records were stolen. ë_Thieves took a television and other items.ë_

Records Breached: 800 (25 cases of sensitive payment or SSN information)
Description of incident: A computer system error caused sensitive information to be exposed. ë_The breach occurred sometime between August 19, 2011 and September 20, 2011.UPDATEë_(11/28/2012): It appears that the breach was related to a terminated employee who could still access Sierra Plastic Surgery's network after leaving the company. ë_The former employee accessed Social Security numbers, personal contact information, payment information, and other sensitive information in less than 50 instances. ë_It also appears that some copies of patient surgery estimates were printed and subsequently surrendered by the former employee when the breach was discovered in August of 2012. ë_The former employee was seeking information on compensation owed.

A bag of personal items and back-up media cartridges from Soundental was stolen from an employee's car on September 24. ë_The back-up cartridges had patient names, addresses, treatment records, and dates of birth. ë_Social Security numbers were also exposed in some cases. ë_The cartridges had been scrambled to prevent easy access.

A November 26 office burglary may have resulted in the theft of patient records. ë_A safe with computer disks and a laptop computer were stolen. ë_It is unclear if either contained sensitive patient information. ë_The burglars were in the office for 15 minutes and may have taken or viewed sensitive patient information in other areas.

Company: University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS)
Description of incident: A former resident doctor kept the personal information of about 1,500 patients as part of a lawsuit she filed against UAMS. ë_She also claimed to have kept the information for research purposes. ë_UAMS became aware of the issue on October 9 when the former resident doctor used the documents as part of her lawsuit. ë_UAMS learned that she kept additional documents on November 7 and had provided them to UAMS attorneys on June 25. Some patients had their names, addresses, dates of birth, medical record numbers, and dates of service exposed. ë_Other patients had their ages, locations of care, dates of service, diagnoses, medications, surgical procedures, procedure names, and lab results exposed.

A network security incident resulted in the expose of patient information. ë_The breach occurred on August 17.UPDATEë_(11/26/2012): An employee accessed and downloaded patient information without authorization or a legitimate purpose on five occasions between June 29 and September 20 of 2012. ë_Gulf Coast Health Care Services discovered the issue on September 26. ë_Patients who were seen between 1992 and September 20, 2012 may have had their names, addresses, dates of birth, and phone numbers accessed. ë_It appears that the employee was accessing the data for the purpose of helping outside practitioners recruit patients to their own practices. ë_The incident was reported to the FBI, the Sarasota Police Department, and the Florida Department of Law Enforcement.ë_This entry on the Privacy Rights Clearinghouse Chronology of Data Breaches was previously listed as a hack and was reclassified as an insider breach based on new information.

An unencrypted flash drive was discovered lost or stolen on September 25. ë_It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, health insurance information, diagnoses, and progress notes. ë_The information came from patients who participated in the St. John Sports Medicine Program and were treated between January 1, 2011 and July 31, 2012.

Company: University of Virginia Medical Center, Continuum Home Infusion
Description of incident: A handheld electronic devices used by Continuum pharmacists was discovered missing on October 5. ë_The device was not encrypted and contained patient names, addresses, diagnoses, medications, and health insurance identification numbers. ë_Some health insurance identification numbers were Social Security numbers or contained Social Security numbers. ë_Patients who received services from Continuum during the month of September 2012 and potential patients who were referred to Continuum between August 2007 and September 2012. ë_Notifications were sent on November 30.

Customers who used a payment card on www.gotickets.com may have had their personal and financial information exposed. An investigation revealed that an unauthorized group accessed shipping, billing, and credit card data related to purchases made through the website between May 22 and May 30, 2012. ë_UPDATEë_(11/30/2012): At least 105 customers in Maryland may have been affected. It is unclear how many people nationwide are at risk. ë_It appears that GoTickets continued to experience online breaches in July. ë_GoTickets updated their online system to increase password security, reduce the number of administrative accounts used, and took additional precautions against future attacks.

A July 25 office burglary resulted in the theft of at least 33 laptops and iPads. The personal information of an unspecified number of former employees may have been affected.UPDATEë_(11/28/2012): The laptops contained employee names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, passport numbers, credit card information, bank account numbers, and possibly life insurance dependent information. ë_The IT department remotely locked access to the devices after discovering they had been stolen earlier in the same day.

Hackers accessed and leaked information from the Wounded Warrior Project website. ë_A total of 22 administrator accounts with encrypted passwords and emails were released. ë_The hackers did not release the full database of thousands of users' information out of respect to the U.S. military.

A laptop taken from an employee's home on October 11 contained sensitive information. ë_It contained names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, credit card numbers , and other personal information.

The November 15 office theft of several computers may have resulted in the exposure of current and former employee information. ë_PGS believes that the computers were stolen for their hardware and software value rather than the information they contained. ë_Some former and current PGS employees had their names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and possibly other types of information exposed.

The October 10 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_A WeiserMazars employee had a laptop stolen that contained names, Social Security numbers, and in some cases, addresses, dates of birth, 401(k) information, and payroll information for Accume Partner 401(l) Plan participants. ë_WeiserMazars audits the statement of net assets available for Accume Partner's 401(k) plan. ë_WeiserMazars notified Accume Partners on October 31 and Accume Partners sent notifications to those who may have been affected on November 16.
A laptop computer was discovered lost or stolen. ë_It contained a spreadsheet of patient names, dates of birth, health plan ID numbers, and diagnosis information.

Names and Social Security numbers were discovered on the website of the Department of Health Care Services. ë_People who sent their information in order to become a provider of In-Home Supportive Services (IHSS) may have had their information exposed online between November 5, 2012 and November 20. ë_The issue was discovered on November 14 and was not fully addressed until November 20. ë_The list should have only contained provider names, addresses, and provider types. It also contained Social Security numbers that were listed in the column for Provider Billing Numbers. ë_The Social Security numbers were not easily recognizable in this format.UPDATEë_(12/11/2012): Nearly 14,000 people were affected.

A concerned citizen investigated a pile of documents next to a dumpster. ë_The documents contained names and Social Security numbers. ë_A local news team responded to the story and contacted a representative from West Pittsburgh Partnership. ë_West Pittsburgh Partnership began an investigation into how the job placement program documents dating back to 1992 were exposed.

Wilton learned that a malicious user was able to view user information between July 19 and October 2 of 2012. ë_The user had added a file to a computer server that hosts www.wilton.com and www.copco.com. ë_Names, addresses, telephone numbers, and payment card numbers, expiration dates, and security codes may have been accessed. ë_The discovery was made sometime around October 31 and notifications were sent on December 10.The malicious user was unable to access payment card information between October 2 and the discovery of the breach on October 31 because Wilton changed its payment processing system on October 2. ë_Wilton took additional security measures after learning of the breach on or around October 31.

A December 1 office burglary resulted in the theft of an unencrypted computer. ë_The computer contained files that included current and former Mt. Diablo Unified School District employee names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses. ë_People who were employees between 1998 and 2010 may have been affected.

A laptop was discovered lost or stolen on November 5, 2012. ë_The possible theft is presumed to have taken place sometime around October 31, 2012. ë_The laptop may have contained employee names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth.

A former manager was indicted for stealing the identities of patients. ë_He faces a 48-count indictment alleging grand larceny in the third degree, identity theft in the second degree, offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree, and possession of a forged instrument in the second degree. ë_He allegedly used the names and Social Security numbers of patients to e-file fraudulent tax returns and obtain over $200,000 in federal, New York, and New Jersey tax refunds. The scam occurred in 2006 and 2007. It was not discovered until recently since those who were affected were unable to work with investigators. ë_The manager was convicted for similar crimes in the past. ë_He used the information of a deceased and developmentally disabled individual fromë_a Nassau County group homeë_to obtain a fraudulent debit card and was also arrested for credit card fraud near Atlanta, Georgia.UPDATEë_(12/19/2012): The former manager pleaded guilty to 20 counts of second-degree identity theft and offering a falseë_instrument for filing, as well as six counts of criminal possession of a forged instrument and additional charges. He will pay $20,000 in restitution. ë_His sentencing is expected to be on January 25, 2013 and he faces up to four years in prison.

Over 480 registered medical marijuana patients received an email from the New Jersey Department of Health. ë_The email instructed them not to call New Jersey or the dispensary in Montclair to make an appointment. ë_The email did not hide the email addresses of the recipients.

Company: A Caring Hand Home Health Care Services, Inc.
Description of incident: A staffing manager collaborated with the owner of A Caring Hand Home Health Care Services, Inc. (A Caring Hand) to hide Medicaid fraud. ë_Between January of 2008 and October of 2011 the owner of A Caring Hand submitted about 900 fraudulent Medicaid claims for payment for services provided to 30 Medicaid recipients. ë_The Medicaid recipients never received those services and around $630,000 was fraudulently obtained by the owner of A Caring Hand. ë_The staffing manager and other staff members falsified office records at A Caring Hand to cover up the fraud between September 2010 and October 6 of 2011. ë_The staffing manager was sentenced and the owner of A Caring Hand will be sentenced in January of 2013.

A University laptop was stolen from an employee's locked car. ë_Pepperdine learned of the theft on November 12, 2012. ë_The laptop may have contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and/or dates of birth.UPDATEë_(12/11/2012): As many as 8,300 people may have been affected. ë_The laptop had been used for work related to the IRS and contained data from as far back as 2008. ë_About 75 percent of the people affected were students.

Western University of Health Sciences' BanWeb Self-Service Federal Work Study reports were accessible to people who used BanWeb with a Western University of Health Sciences user ID and password. ë_The reports contained names, Social Security numbers, and direct deposit bank account information in some cases. The information was available for an unspecified amount of time. Western University of Health Sciences conducted an investigation and reported that there was no reason to believe sensitive information was accessed by unauthorized BanWeb users. ë_Western University of Health Sciences disabled access to the reports after learning about the breach on November 14. Notifications were sent on December 18.

Customers who used payment cards in several store locations discovered fraudulent charges on their debit and credit cards. ë_It is unclear if a breach affected the physical machines in the stores or if the payment processing system was hacked. ë_The company discovered the issue on December 4 and an investigation revealed that the intrusions began on November 7, 2012. ë_Anyone who used their payment card in a store between November 7 and December 5 of 2012 should closely review their financial statements. ë_Customers are also warned to be suspicious of phishing emails or phone calls. ë_Customers should not give their information out over the phone or respond to emails asking for sensitive information.

Numerous documents containing patient information were found in a vehicle during a traffic stop. ë_A law enforcement officer notified Coastal Behavioral Healthcare of the potential breach on October 10, 2012. ë_The documents contained a list of 136 Coastal Behavioral Healthcare patient names and identifying information dated April 2011. ë_It is unclear how the information was breached and how many additional patients may have been affected.
The data of 1,749 patients was stolen during an October 7 incident. ë_

Paper jackets that held radiology films were thrown away with office trash instead of being properly discarded. ë_The paper jackets contained names, addresses, dates of birth, ages, sex, race, and information on dates and names of radiology procedures prior to May of 2012. ë_The paper jackets are believed to have been picked up by a sanitation company and discarded in a landfill.

Company: Office of Dr. James M. McGee
Description of incident: The September 19 theft of paper records may have resulted in the exposure of dental patient information. ë_

An employee of Grand Teton Storage removed documents from The Children's Center's storage facility after they failed to pay storage bills. ë_A concerned citizen found seven boxes of the old medical records and other personal information next to a dumpster. ë_The information was seven to eight years old and included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and payroll information. ë_A Grand Teton Storage employee acknowledged that a mistake had been made and the employee who improperly disposed of the records will face disciplinary action. ë_Idaho Department of Health and Welfare eventually recovered and secured the records.

A skimming device on an ATM resulted in fraudulent transactions on over 800 accounts. ë_The fraudulent transactions appear to date from October 27, 2012 to November 7, 2012. It is not clear how many skimming devices were involved and where they were located.

An unauthorized party accessed WTH's booking system by misusing the log-in credentials of an authorized user. ë_Encrypted credit card numbers and expiration dates that were stored and could be decrypted in the system were exposed.

The owner of EZ Step and an employee were both charged with conspiracy to commit health care fraud. ë_They were also charged on multiple counts of health care fraud. ë_The charges come from allegations that the two people sought reimbursement by forging physician signatures, fabricating prescriptions and equipment orders, forging patient signatures on delivery forms to misrepresent prescription medication and durable equipment deliveries, and altering valid prescriptions between 2005 and 2007. ë_Arrests were first made in July of 2011.

Company: Skagit Valley Casino Resort, Bally Technologies Inc.
Description of incident: An electronic device was stolen from the home office of an employee of Bally Technologies. ë_The electronic equipment contained names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and bank account information. ë_The equipment may have been stolen for its resell value rather than the value of the information.

Company: State of California Department of Health Care Services (DHCS)
Description of incident: Beneficiary Identification Cards (BICs) were mailed to the wrong recipients between December 10 and December 18. ë_A computer programming error caused the BICs of children being moved from Healthy Families program enrollment to Medi-Cal enrollment to be sent to households of other Medi-Cal and Healthy Families participants. ë_Names, Client Index Numbers, dates of birth, genders, and card issue dates were exposed. ë_People who received incorrect cards were instructed to return them. ë_Stamped envelopes that were addressed to DHCS were sent out with breach notifications.ë_

According to a complaint filed against Walgreens, Walgreens sold confidential information of customers to data mining companies who resold it to pharmaceutical companies. ë_Walgreens is accused of receiving payment for prescription information that only patients had the right to sell. Walgreens sells patient data that includes sex, age group, state, ID number of the providing doctor and the name of the drug that is taken.

Walgreens was ordered to pay $16.57 million as a part of a settlement of a civil environmental prosecution. ë_Walgreens was accused of illegally dumping hazardous waste as well as confidential customer medical information. ë_It is unclear what type of customer medical information was mishandled.UPDATEë_(12/13/2012): The civil enforcement lawsuit was first filed in Alameda County in June of 2012. ë_It was the result of investigations that took place in San Diego County in the summer and fall of 2011. Investigators discovered that "Walgreens routinely and systematically sent hazardous waste to local landfills and failed to take measures to protect" customer medical privacy.

Company: Curb Your Enthusiasm Inc., Home Box Office (HBO)
Description of incident: A software configuration problem caused personnel information stored on a Curb employee's home computer to be accessible through the Internet.  Employees may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses and telephone numbers exposed.

Company: East San Gabriel Valley Regional Occupational Program and Technical Center
Description of incident: A sensitive document was accidentally attached to an email that was sent to students. ë_The attachment contained names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, student attendance information, and information regarding their program. ë_The email was intended to inform students about open positions.

An office theft of an unencrypted laptop on or around December 15 resulted in the exposure of confidential personal information. ë_The laptop contained an Excel spreadsheet with workers' compensation information such as names, Social Security numbers, telephone numbers, and other workers' compensation claim or injury information.

An unauthorized intrusion was detected on the morning of Tuesday November 27. ë_The unauthorized access began on November 26 and access to the breached web application was immediately shut down upon discovery. ë_Customers who completed Rosenthal Collins Group account forms online may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, range of net worth and income, bank names, passwords for accessing the web application, and email addresses exposed.

An employee reported that a portable hard drive was missing on November 23, 2010. ë_The device had last been seen sometime around November 19. ë_The data on the device included information from before July 31, 2009. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, medical record numbers, account numbers, dates of service, race, insurance carriers and insurance numbers, addresses, phone numbers, sex, dates of birth, diagnosis information, allergies, initial referral forms, patient assessments/plans of care, physician orders and/or delivery ticket information may have been on the hard drive.

Someone called Mission Hospital on August 28, 2012 and claimed that he found a flash drive with sensitive patient information in his garage. ë_The flash drive was returned to Mission Hospital via mailed envelope on September 11, 2012. ë_Patients who received services at Mission Hospital between September and November of 2008 may have had their information exposed. The notice that was sent to patients was dated September 14, 2012. ë_It appears that a contractor or employee misplaced the unencrypted flash drive.The flash drive contained names, medical record numbers, and account numbers. Additionally, the flash drive may have contained some combination of date of admission, age, birth date, vital readings, physical examination, gender, race, name of physician, medical history, past and current treatment and illnesses, history of substance use, family history, lab tests and results, imaging tests and results, body weight, physician notes on patient, care plan, employment status and employer, prognosis, diagnosis, treatment recommendations, allergies, medications, comments about patient's appearance, patient health complaint, symptoms, reason for referral, and reason for admission information.

A report containing the names and Social Security numbers of a group of Reyes Beverage Group's California employees was accidentally sent to the personal email address of an employee of Reinhart Foodservice. ë_Reinhart Foodservice is a Reyes Holdings company as well. ë_It is unclear how the email was accidentally sent and why it ended up in the personal email of an employee at a different division.

The owner of a group of childcare services pleaded guilty to defrauding Medicaid of $8 million. ë_She and a co-defendant targeted medicaid recipients in order to enroll them in a program and make fraudulent Medicaid claims for mental and behavioral health services. ë_Additionally, the owner pleaded guilty to misusing at least one therapist's credentials in order to make the claims for mental and behavioral health services. ë_The scheme took place between 2008 and 2012.

The November 27 theft of a laptop may have resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and clinical information may have been exposed. ë_Patients who have received services since 2007 may have been affected.

The October 16 theft of a desktop computer may have resulted in the exposure of patient information.UPDATEë_(12/28/2012): The computer was stolen from the Brigham and Women's Hospital office. ë_Medical record numbers, age, medications, laboratory values and other clinical information may have been on the computer. ë_Up to 615 people may have been affected by the theft.

A team of cyber security consultants discovered vulnerabilities in the Omnicell web system. ë_Unauthorized users could gain control of certain hospital operations run by Integris Health. ë_The issue was immediately addressed by Omnicell.
The theft of paper records may have resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The theft may have occurred on August 13, 2012 and was reported or discovered on November 16, 2012.

An unauthorized disclosure of paper records may have exposed patient information. ë_The breach may have taken place between May 1, 2011 and August 5, 2011. ë_It was discovered or reported on November 16 of 2012.

The office theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_A spreadsheet with sensitive information that could be easily accessed was on the stolen laptop. It is unclear what type of information was exposed, but Social Security numbers, addresses, and medical information were not involved.UPDATEë_(12/21/2012): A Health and Human Services (HHS) notice reveals that the theft occurred on October 1. ë_A total of 683 patients were affected by the breach.

Company: Omnicell, University of Michigan Health System
Description of incident: An electronic device was stolen from an Omnicell employee's car on November 14. ë_The device was not encrypted and contained the medication, demographic, and health information of 4,000 patients from three hospitals in the University of Michigan Health System. ë_UPDATEë_(1/2/2013): A total of 3,997 people who were treated between October 24 and November 13 at three hospitals in the University of Michigan Health System were affected. ë_However, patients of at least 10 Sentara Healthcare and South Jersey Healthcare medical facilities were also affected. A total of 56,000 Sentara Healthcare patients from Sentara CarePlex, Sentara Leigh Hospital, Sentara Norfolk General Hospital, Sentara Obici Hospital, Sentara Princess Anne Hospital, Sentara Virginia Beach General Hospital, Sentara Williamsburg Regional Medical Center, Sentara Belle Harbour, Sentara Independence, and Sentara Port Warwick who were treated between October 18, 2012 and November 9, 2012 were affected. ë_A total of 8,555 patients from South Jersey Healthcare who were either treated or scheduled for admission between June 1, 2012 and November 12, 2012 were affected.

The November 6 theft of an unencrypted laptop may have resulted in the exposure of employee Social security numbers. ë_It is unclear if other types of information were also exposed. ë_A total of 500 employees may have been affected. ë_

A Kaiser Permanente Northern California Region Recruitment employee mistakenly sent an email to unauthorized parties on August 24. ë_Former Northern California Kaiser employees who left Kaiser between 1990 and 2006 may have had their names and Social Security numbers exposed. Kaiser IT Security conducted a detailed analysis to confirm that the recipient did not forward or print the email. The analysis also revealed that the email had been deleted and could no longer be accessed.

A computer repair shop bought used computers on govdeals.com in 2011. ë_The computers were found to have information from city employees when they were removed from storage on January 5. ë_Social Security numbers, pension information, and other personal information from Macon police officers were on the computers. ë_Information from local businesses that was used for city purposes was also on the computers. ë_A total of 39 hard drives, two servers, and two CPUs were purchased and may have contained sensitive information.

Texas Southern University's radio station KTSU gave a volunteer position to a person with a criminal history of credit card fraud. ë_The volunteer was later arrested for allegedly using the radio station's donation drive to steal credit card information. ë_The dishonest volunteer faces up to 300 counts of credit card fraud for attempting to misuse the information on donor pledge sheets.
An unencrypted flash drive was stolen from a teacher's car. ë_It contained student Social Security numbers and other information. ë_

An employee working in human resources was robbed while transporting information between school districts. ë_The employee stopped for lunch and discovered that personnel files containing names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and driver's license numbers had been stolen from their car.
A laptop was stolen from an employee's car on or around December 10. ë_APG employees may have had their names, Social Security numbers, bank account information, and other information exposed. ë_

Fairfax County Public Schools discovered that student names, ID numbers, grades, and other information were posted online. ë_Students enrolled in 9th, 10th, and 11th grade were affected. ë_The information may have only been available for a day before Fairfax County Public Schools began the process of removing it from online. ë_

Company: Electronic Data Systems, Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Services, Alabama Department of Corrections
Description of incident: A dishonest employee accessed the Electronic Data System's database of names and Social Security numbers of student loan borrowers. ë_The former employee then used the information to file false tax returns in 2009. ë_Sentencing is scheduled for December 19, 2011 and involves a minimum of two years in prison, a maximum of 354 years in prison, and a maximum fine of $6,250,000.UPDATE (12/22/2011): The dishonest employee was sentenced to 94 months in federal prison for stealing the identities of student loan borrowers, and for giving them to a co-conspirator who used them to file false tax returns. Tens of thousands of names and Social Security numbers were stored at the employee's home.UPDATEë_(12/17/2012): A second person was sentenced to federal prison for participating in the identity theft scheme. ë_She worked in the central records office for the Alabama Department of Corrections and was able to provide other conspirators with sensitive information from state databases. She was sentenced to 50 months in prison for conspiracy, wire fraud, and aggravated identity theft. Restitution in the amount of $113,000 was also required.

At least eight garbage bags that were left unattended on a dirt road contained sensitive documents. ë_A woman found the bags and reported the issue to a local news team. ë_The paperwork included credit applications with names, driver's license information, and Social Security numbers. ë_
An employee left sensitive loan application documents in a vehicle while at the gym. ë_The documents were stolen and included loan applicant tax returns. The breach occurred in September.

An employee disclosed personal information about workers compensation claimants between October 2011 and March 2012. ë_Workers compensation claimants who received spinal surgery in Southern California between 2004 and 2011 or had urinalysis testing, diagnostics or medical services performed in California between 2006 and 2011 may have had their information exposed.It does not appear that Social Security numbers or other identifying information exposed were used to compromise the security, confidentiality, or integrity of the personal information.ë_UPDATEë_(11/23/2012): About 2,700 workers' compensation claimants were affected.

Company: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company and Allied Insurance
Description of incident: A portion of the computer network used by Nationwide and Allied Insurance agents was breached by cyber criminals on October 3. ë_The attack was discovered on the same day and contained. ë_On October 16, it was determined that names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, dates of birth, marital status, gender, occupation, and employer information had been stolen. ë_Affected parties were identified on November 2 and notifications were sent on November 16.UPDATEë_(11/20/2012): At least 28,000 people in Georgia were affected. ë_The total number of affected people is not known.UDPATEë_(12/10/2012): A total of 28,468 people in Georgia, 534 in Oklahoma, 12,490 in South Carolina, 286 in Maryland, 5,050 in California, 91,000 in Iowa, 170 in Hawaii, 8,000 in New Mexico, and 98,191 in Minnesota were affected. This brings the known total to 244,188. ë_Nationwide/Allied Group reported that the breach compromised the information of one million policyholders and non-policyholders nationwide.

Sensitive records were stolen from a tote bag in a staff member's vehicle on the night of November 18. ë_The records included names, dates of birth, cell phone numbers, email addresses, and emergency contact information.

Hackers were able to guess the answers to student account challenge questions. ë_The email account passwords of at least 28 students were reset and their account information was most likely accessed. The hackers may have been based in Beijing and most likely gathered the information needed to pass the challenge questions from information on the students' Facebook pages.

People who applied online at www.applitrack.com for a job in District 202 may have had their information accessed by a hacker. ë_The hacker sent messages to former and current job applicants and informed them that the Plainfield School District 202 website was breached.ë_UPDATEë_(10/19/2012): A 14-year-old Joliet West High School student was removed from class and taken to a juvenile detention center for his alleged involvement in the breach.

Company: Ohio State University, Harvard University, Stanford University, Cornell University, Princeton University, John Hopkins University, University of Michigan, University of Wisconsin, University of Houston, New York University, University of Maryland
Description of incident: A hacking group called Team GhostShell targeted universities around the world. ë_A total of 53 universities were affected. ë_Most of the data exposed was publicly available, but student, staff, and faculty usernames and passwords were also exposed. It is unclear if any financial information or Social Security numbers were taken from universities.

A hacker or hacker managed to infiltrate and bring down the City of Tulsa's website. ë_It is unclear if any information was accessed, but notifications were sent to people who applied online for jobs or submitted online police reports. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and driver's license numbers may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(10/01/2012): A member or members of the IT department used a third-party firm to test the City's computer system. ë_There was no unauthorized access.

An employee responded to a telephone computer phishing scam. ë_The person was employed by a subcontractor of Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Services (HP ES) named Carewise Health. ë_Unauthorized users were able to remotely access a database of Medicaid client information as a result of the phishing attempt. ë_Eventually HP ES and Carewise Health were able to disable the laptop and notify the Cabinet for Health and Family Services of the breach.UPDATEë_(01/02/2013): The employee revealed information to the hacker in mid-November.

The June 2010 theft of an unencrypted laptop from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The HHS Office for Civil Rights investigated the breach and found that HONI had not conducted a risk analysis to safeguard electronic protected health information. ë_It was also discovered that HONI did not meet a HIPAA Security Rule that required them to have policies or procedures in place to address mobile device security. ë_HONI agreed to pay the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' (HHS) $50,000 regarding potential Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 Security Rule violations. ë_HONI also began taking extensive steps to improve their HIPAA Privacy and Security compliance program since the June 2010 breach.

Anyone who purchased items on www.accesscatalog.com using a credit card may have been affected by a breach that began in August 2010. ë_An unauthorized party may have obtained names, credit or debit card numbers, expiration dates, and payment card verification codes. ë_Centric Group learned of the incident on or around December 13, 2012.

Company: Office of Dr. Calvin L. Schuster
Description of incident: A computer was stolen during an office burglary that occurred sometime around November 5, 2012. ë_The computer contained patient names, dates of birth, and a minimal amount of patient medical information.

Company: EJ Phair Brewing Company and Alehouse
Description of incident: Customers who used credit or debit cards at EJ Phair discovered fraudulent chargers on their payment cards. ë_A hacker or hackers managed to access and misuse payment card numbers once they ran through EJ Phair's system. ë_It appears that customers who used cards at the location between September and late November of 2012 may have been affected.

A breach in a third-party software system used to process credit card transactions in some USC dining halls, including Ronald Tutor Campus Center, Seeds, the Lab on Figueroa St., and Starbucks on the Health Sciences Campus resulted in the exposure of credit card numbers. ë_The breach of USC Hospitality most likely occurred from May 21 to June 21, but may have occurred earlier. ë_Names and contact information were not associated with the credit card numbers.
A breach at Creative Croissants results in the exposure of customer credit card information. ë_It is unclear how the breach occurred and the date of the breach was March 2, 2012.

Employees accidentally threw out hundreds of patient records. ë_The dental records were found by someone looking through a dumpster and the incident was reported to a local news team. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and addresses were exposed. Employees from Bujanda-Wagner's office came to recover the documents.

An employee was fired in May for creating and attempting to mail a list of names and Social Security numbers for purposes of identity fraud. ë_It is unclear if the dishonest employee disclosed the information of other people before being caught. Some patients had already experienced fraudulent activity. People who may have been a patient in one of the Health Department Health Centers could have been affected. ë_UPDATEë_(01/09/2013): The employee worked as a records clerk and was arrested on January 5, 2013. ë_She had worked for Palm Beach County Health Department since 2006 and was charged with several counts of fraud.

Company: Holyoke Medical Center, Caritas Carney Hospital, Milton Hospital, Milford Hospital
Description of incident: A large pile of medical records was found at Georgetown Transfer Station public dump. The reports contained names, addresses, diagnosis, Social Security numbers, and insurance information. A medical billing company known as Goldthwait Associates is believed to be responsible. The medical records are mostly from pathology patients served at the hospitals between 2007 and March of 2010.UPDATE (9/2/10): Holyoke reported that 24,750 patients were affected.ë_ The exact number of patients affected from other medical centers is still unknown. Between 8,000 and 12,000 patients of Milton Hospital were affected.UPDATE (10/11/10): Milton Pathology Associates, P.C. reported that a prior owner of Goldthwait Associates improperly disposed of patient information. Eleven thousand patients were affected.ë_ Milford Regional Medical Center reports that the incident affected 19,750 patients.UPDATEë_(01/07/2013): People associated with Goldthwait Associates, Chestnust Pathology Services, Milford Pathology Associates, Milton Pathology Associates, and Pioneer Valley Pathology Associates agreed to collectively pay $140,000 to settle allegations related to the breach.

An employee kept 200 pages of confidential information in an effort to prove that Woodwinds Hospital was trying to conceal evidence of medical misconduct. ë_The employee was discharged in 2010 for reasons unrelated to removing the information. ë_She claims to have taken them home after being ordered to destroy any information related to incidents that could damage Woodwinds Hospital's reputation.

The theft of a hard drive from the office of an unnamed independent contractor resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_The theft occurred on either October 13 or 14 of 2012 and Workers United learned of the issue on October 25. ë_A database with former Workers United member names and Social Security numbers was on the hard drive.

Hackers were able to access database information from Command, Control, Communications, Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance as well as nongovernmental personnel and people who visited Fort Monmouth. ë_The breach was discovered and addressed on December 6. ë_names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, places of birth, home addresses, and salaries were exposed.

An employee's computer was found to contain malware. ë_The malware infection began on May 21, 2012 and was discovered on November 15, 2012. ë_Files stored on the computer contained billing information with patient names, Social Security numbers, account numbers, medical record numbers, dates of birth, gender, treatment dates, insurance provider names, and account balances.

NECA/IBEM Family Medical Care Plan (FMCP) participants received disclosure documents related to benefits coverage and modifications. ë_The outside of the envelopes in which the documents arrived displayed participant Social Security numbers.

Customers who made purchases on www.wilton.com between October 8, 2012 and January 8, 2013 may have had their credit or debit card information exposed. ë_A Wilton service provider discovered the issue on or around January 8, 2013. ë_A malicious user accessed the website information and payment card numbers, expiration dates, and security codes may have been exposed. ë_Customer names, addresses, and telephone numbers are also at risk.This incident is in addition to the hacking incident that took place between July and October of 2012. ë_That incident was reported on December 12, 2012.

A dishonest intern was caught using a cell phone to illegally photograph patient Social Security numbers and names. ë_The photos were then sent to another person; presumably for fraudulent activity. ë_The office intern was charged with fraudulent use of personal identification information. It is unclear when the breach was discovered since the photos were taken between May 7 and June 19.

A website flaw allowed customers to check the account details of other customers if they knew their phone numbers.  Users' minutes and cell phone models could be viewed in this manner.  This unintentional feature may have gone unnoticed for five years due to a glitch.

Company: Jackson North Medical Center, Jackson Health System
Description of incident: A dishonest volunteer was caught passing patient information to people who used it to file fraudulent tax returns. ë_The volunteer used his smart phone to capture patient records while working in an emergency room. ë_Around 1,200 photos of 566 patient records were found on his phone. The breach was discovered when three men were caught using free wi-fi at McDonald's to file fraudulent tax returns in March.UPDATEë_(01/11/2013): Jackson Health banned volunteers from using cell phone in patient areas in order to prevent similar events from occurring.

Company: West Virginia Chiefs of Police Association, Alabama Department of Public Safety, Texas Department of Public Safety, City of Mobile Police Department, Texas Police Chiefs Association, Texas Police Association
Description of incident: A hacker obtained and revealed 156 home addresses, phone numbers, cell phone numbers, email addresses, and usernames of police officers associated with the West Virginia Chiefs of Police Association. Retired police chiefs, and every current police chief in West Virginia had their information exposed. The hacker was associated with Anonymous.UPDATEë_(08/24/2012): A hacker associated with the attack on West Virginia Chiefs of Police Association and several other law enforcement associations was caught and sentenced to 27 months in federal prison. ë_He was also ordered to pay $14,062.17 in restitution. ë_Alabama Department of Public Safety spreadsheets with information on sex crimes and a database listing descriptions of offenders' cars were posted online. Over 46,000 citizens in the state of Alabama may have had their names, Social Security numbers, license plate numbers, dates of birth, phone numbers, addresses, and criminal records accessed by hackers who attacked the City of Mobile Police Department. A total of 787 police officer names, usernames, plain text passwords, addresses, and other agency information from The Texas Police Association was posted online. ë_The Wisconsin Chiefs of Police Association, the Texas Department of Public Safety, the Dallas Police Department, and the Texas Police Chiefs Association also experienced hack attacks.

At least 65 students received information about the grade point average of 430 students during early January 2013. ë_The breach occurred when a spreadsheet that contained the information and the E-number of 430 students was accidentally made available online. ë_

Over 108 Zaxby's restaurants experienced a breach related to customer credit and debit cards. ë_A number of people experienced credit card fraud and an investigation led to Zaxby's as a common point of purchase. ë_Suspicious files were found on Zaxby's system during the subsequent investigation. ë_

A mobile device that contained both youth and employee records was reported stolen on January 2, 2013. ë_Over 100,000 records were on the device and may have been exposed. ë_The device was taken from a Department of Juvenile Justice office and was neither encrypted nor password-protected. ë_Department of Juvenile Justice policy requires such devices to be encrypted.

Many folders that were found in a landfill dump site were labeled "Radiology Department, Baptist Medical Center." Hundreds of medical records were out in the open, all with sensitive information. Sensitive patient information that was thrown out included names, x-rays, ultrasounds, MRIs, and Social Security numbers. ë_Files from at least five other facilities were found at the same site; however Baptist Medical Center is believed to be the source of the breach.UPDATE (8/5/08):ë_A former employee of Baptist Hospital has been sentenced to two years and one day in federal prison for wire fraud and stealing the identities of patients, according to a Department of Justice press release. Adrienne Denise Stovall, 30, pled guilty in January to one count of wire fraud and one count of aggravated identity theft, which carries a mandatory sentence of two years. Stovall worked at Montgomery's Baptist Hospital from August 2006 to early 2007. Her position gave her access to the hospital's computer system. The system contained confidential information including patient names, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers. Stovall used the information to apply for credit lines and credit cards. http://www.justice.gov/usao/alm/press/current_press/2010_05_05_stovall.pdf

Company: North Los Angeles County Regional Center (NLACRC)
Description of incident: The November 13, 2012 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of consumer information. ë_Names, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, residential information, and medical information may have been exposed.

A concerned citizen found hundreds of documents in a recycling center and notified a local news team. ë_The documents included criminal histories, depositions, medical records, personal phone numbers, and addresses. ë_Most were from the 1990's. ë_Most or all of the information did not need to be shredded because it was considered public record. ë_The local news team contacted a director from the solid waste division and the documents were removed for shredding.

The 2010 theft of a company laptop, a hard drive, and a number of unencrypted backup tapes resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_Social security numbers, credit and debit card numbers, driver's license numbers, and dates of birth were contained on one or more of the devices.Cbr Systems reached a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission in early 2013. ë_Cbr Systems must establish an information security program and be independently audited every other year for 20 years. ë_The full settlement can be found here:ë_http://ftc.gov/opa/2013/01/cbr.shtm

A hacker accessed the webserver used to host stethoscope.com on December 3. ë_The breach was discovered in mid-December during routine server maintenance. ë_Customer names, addresses, email addresses, and credit card information such as numbers, expiration dates, and security codes may have been exposed.

A document with sensitive Worker's Compensation claim information was accidentally sent out with an email to a limited number of Antioch Unified School District employees. ë_Social Security numbers and other information related to current and former employees that reported injuries were exposed. ë_The incident occurred on January 18 and people who received the email were instructed to remove and destroy any saved information contain in the email. Those who received the email were also instructed to provide written verification that they had removed and destroyed the information.

A former Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare food service employee was indicted on 31 counts of filing false tax returns, wire fraud, false claims, and aggravated identity theft. ë_He and two others are believed to have participated in a conspiracy that led to $818,000 in fraudulent claims. ë_The employee worked for Tallahassee Memorial HealthCare for three years. ë_He gathered patient names and dates of birth from food tray receipts when he delivered food to the rooms of patients in August of 2011 and stole emergency room data sheets from the trash. The information was then passed to the two others who participated in the conspiracy.

Company: Texas Department of Health and Human Services
Description of incident: A dishonest employee was arrested on suspicion of misusing client information to apply for credit cards. ë_The dishonest employee was able to pose as different clients seeking immunizations and other services. ë_She was charged with fraudulent use or possession of identifying information and credit card abuse. ë_UPDATEë_(01/31/2013): The employee was working for the Northeast Texas Public Health district when she was arrested for stealing the identities of patients at a clinic in Mount Pleasant. ë_She began working in the Texas Department of State Health Services clinic in 2008.

Company: Central Laborers' Pension Fund, Central Laborers' Welfare Fund, Central Laborers' Annuity Fund
Description of incident: A home burglary resulted in the theft of a CD that contained the information of over 30,000 beneficiaries. ë_The CD contained names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth and was taken from the home of an accountant at an unnamed counting firm. ë_The three funds sued the accounting firm for $200,000 to cover the cost of credit monitoring and insurance.ë_

Company: Los Angeles County Department of Public Social Services
Records Breached: 132 (64 individuals had fraudulent tax returns filed)
Description of incident: A dishonest employee pleaded guilty to using a Los Angeles County computer system to file fraudulent tax refunds. ë_The fraudulent activity occurred between July 2009 and the 2011 tax year. ë_The IRS found 44 pages of screen prints with the information of 132 assistance participants in the employee's home. The employee, her spouse, and three others were indicted in January of 2012. ë_ ë_

Six people who worked in tax preparation were charged with fraud and filing false tax returns in March of 2012. ë_Over 1,000 false tax returns were filed between October 2009 and April 2012. ë_The fraudulent returns totalled more than $1.7 million. ë_More Information: https://www.databreaches.net/alabama-woman-pleads-guilty-in-id-theft-and...UPDATEë_(01/29/2013): Two others were linked to the conspiracy and charged. ë_One of them was an employee of an unnamed Alabama state agency. She was able to access a state database of personal information and provide it to others in the identity theft ring.UPDATE (3/13/2013): "Bruce King, the founder and operator of Premier Tax, was 
sentenced today in Montgomery, Ala., to 70 months in prison and ordered 
to pay $781,305 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for
 orchestrating a tax fraud scheme at his business, the Justice 
Department and the IRS announced. King had previously pleaded guilty to 
charges of conspiring to defraud the United States and filing false tax 
returns.           According to court 
documents, Premier Tax was a tax preparation business operated by King 
that had several locations in Alabama and Georgia. King held training 
sessions in which he taught preparers how to falsify tax returns in 
order to fraudulently increase clients_Ñé tax refunds. Those he taught 
went on to work at Premier Tax and filed numerous false tax returns. 
According to court documents, the tax loss caused by these fraudulent 
returns exceeded $1 million. To date, seven return preparers trained by 
King have also pleaded guilty and been sentenced."More Information: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/owner-tax-preparation-business-sentenced-...UPDATE (4/15/2014): "The United 
States has requested that the federal district court in Montgomery, 
Ala., permanently bar Tonja Renee Toney and Jenika Williams from 
preparing federal income tax returns for others, the Justice Department 
announced today.    ë_    
    According to the complaint, which was filed yesterday in the U.S. 
District Court for the Middle District of Alabama, Toney and Williams 
each prepared tax returns as employees of Premier Tax in Montgomery in 
2007 and 2008, and both   pleaded guilty
     to charges related to their work at Premier Tax.ë_ The complaint 
further alleges that both prepared false and fraudulent tax returns 
after being interviewed by Internal Revenue Service (IRS) agents in 
connection with their activities at Premier Tax.    ë_    
      The complaint alleges that both defendants have knowingly prepared
 federal income tax returns for customers that understated the 
customers_Ñé tax liability by reporting false income in order to inflate 
the taxpayer_Ñés claim to an Earned Income Tax Credit."ë_More Information: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-sues-shut-down-alabama...

The New York Times' computer system was hacked after Chinese government officials warned the Times about consequences for investigating the wealth of government family members. ë_The Times began monitoring its system closely on October 24 and noticed unusual activity on October 25 when an article about the wealth of a Chinese official's family was published. ë_The breach began on September 13 and was allowed to continue until January so that the hackers' behavior could be studied. ë_It appears that the passwords of every Times employee were compromised and 53 Times employees had their personal computers accessed. ë_The 53 employees were located outside of the United States and appear to have been the ones who may have covered the Chinese stories.

Hackers in China were able to breach the computer system of the United States Chamber of Commerce. ë_The hackers had access to the information of roughly three million members from November 2009 to May 2010. ë_Though the breach was discovered in May of 2010, there is evidence that some systems were still compromised in March of 2011. ë_Email communications with no more than 50 of the Chambers' members were compromised. Company names, key company contacts, trade-policy documents, meeting notes, trip reports, and schedules were in the email communications.

Bashas' online systems suffered an online breach. ë_Customers in Lake Havasu City and Pinal County who entered their credit and debit card information online have been affected. ë_All customers are being warned to check their payment card transactions for suspicious activity.

River Falls Medical Clinic officials reported a burglary during the summer of 2012. ë_The equipment and paper documents that were stolen were recovered by police on November 28. ë_An employee of a cleaning service that subcontracted with the Clinic is the main suspect. ë_The items were found in the employee's home and he was charged with felonies associated with theft and drug possession. ë_It is believed that the documents were intended to be shredded. ë_They contained patient names, dates of birth, patient account and billing account information, diagnosis codes, insurance information, account numbers, medical chart numbers, and scheduling information. ë_An unspecified number of patients also had their Social Security numbers, home addresses, and phone numbers exposed.

Hackers were able to access customer credit card information stored on computer servers. ë_The cyber attack affected customers who made purchases on www.thorlo.com between November 14, 2012 and January 22, 2013. ë_Credit card numbers, credit card expiration dates, credit card security codes, names, and contact information were exposed.ë_

A vendor's mailing error resulted in the exposure of employee Social Security numbers. ë_Call for Candidacy letters were mailed sometime around January 16 that had Social Security numbers, names, and addresses visible through the address window of the letter. ë_

An unencrypted disc that contained patient information was lost in transit. ë_The disc had names, Medicare account numbers, and outstanding account balances from patients who visited the Honesdale hospital between 2007 and 2012. ë_A legal envelope that contained the disc was mailed on November 28 and arrived at Novitas Solutions in Pittsburgh in a cardboard box without the disc.ë_

Information related to over 4,000 American bank executive accounts was exposed by hackers. ë_Hackers placed an Alabama Criminal Justice Information Center spreadsheet with the login information, credentials, contact information, and IP addresses of bank executives online.

Customers were affected by an ATM hacking scheme. A skimming device is believed to have been placed on the bank's ATM at a food store. ë_A suspect was arrested after being seen using stolen card information at an ATM.

A cyber attack on two servers resulted in the exposure of employee information. ë_The servers were at the UNC Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center. ë_Employees, contractors, and visiting lecturers at the Lineberger Center may have had their Social Security numbers or passport numbers exposed. ë_The breach was discovered in May of 2012 and notifications were sent in December of 2012. ë_Fewer than 15 people who were subjects in research studies were also affected by the breach.

On September 6, 2012 it was reported that three computers that contained information from the Florida Department of Juvenile Justice were stolen from an apartment site earlier in the week. ë_A television was also taken at the time of the theft.UPDATEë_(01/12/2013): At least one of the devices was neither encrypted nor password protected and held the personal information of over 100,000 youth and employees.

A computer network attack resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_The cyber attack was discovered on December 13, 2012 and affected customer databases with names, Social Security numbers, credit and debit card numbers, payment card expiration dates, payment card security codes, addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and mothers' maiden names may have been exposed.

Company: Crafts Americana Group, Inc. (Knitpicks.com, ArtistsClub.com, ConnectingThreads.com)
Description of incident: Customers who had credit card numbers on file after using them at Knitpicks.com, ArtistsClub.com, or ConnectingThreads.com may have had their information exposed. ë_A file on the Crafts Americana Group, Inc. servers was accessible for a period of time before being removed on January 25, 2013. ë_The file contained names, credit card numbers, addresses, and phone numbers.

The Information Technology Department at Sierra View District Hospital detected unusual activity on its computer network. ë_Patient information may have been affected and the investigation is ongoing.

The theft of a password-protected laptop from an employee's car may have resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The theft occurred on January 4, 2013 and was reported immediately. ë_Patients who were treated between July 1, 2006 and January 3, 2013 may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, insurance policy numbers, diagnoses, visit notes, physician names, caregiver names, and advance directives exposed.

A computer virus was discovered on an employee's work computer account on December 14, 2012. ë_One of the files on the employee's computer contained patient names, addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, medical record numbers, names of health insurers, diagnoses, and other clinical information. ë_A limited number of Social Security numbers were also exposed.

Company: Sinai Medical Center of Jersey City LLC
Description of incident: A pediatrician misused patient information in order to defraud Medicaid of nearly one million dollars. ë_The pediatrician owned Sinai Medical Center and billed Medicaid for wound repairs and other procedures that were never performed. ë_Police arrested the dishonest pediatrician on January 16, 2013. ë_

A senior desk clerk was arrested for obtaining and releasing patient information for identity theft purposes. ë_The dishonest employee took home client lists with names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. ë_Patients born between 1991 and 1996 may have had their personal information misused.
A network server was stolen or discovered stolen on January 15, 2012. ë_The incident appeared on the HHS website in February of 2013.
A laptop was stolen or discovered stolen on October 11, 2012. ë_The incident appeared on the HHS website in February of 2013.

Five laptops were stolen during the weekend of November 17, 2012. ë_They did not contain Social Security numbers and did contain unspecified personal information of patients. ë_A notice about the incident was sent on January 18, 2013 and the breach appeared on the HHS website in February of 2013.

A server breach or other incident related to credit cards may have affected people who used their American Express cards at locations linked to Hotusa Group's servers. ë_Account numbers, names, credit card expiration date, and other credit card information may have been exposed for American Express and other cards. The incident occurred on August 24, 2012.

A Walgreens pharmacist used patient information to obtain prescriptions for powerful drugs. ë_The fraudulent activity occurred between April 2011 and January 2012. ë_The dishonest pharmacist pleaded guilty to aggravated identity theft, wire fraud, and fraudulently acquiring controlled substances on November 19, 2012.She was sentenced to 25 months in prison and one month of supervised release.

Central Hudson learned of a cyber attack that occurred over President's Day weekend. ë_Customers were notified the day after the holiday and encouraged to monitor their bank accounts and credit reports. ë_Customer banking information and other personal information may have been accessed during the attack.

An October 31 theft of a NASA laptop and sensitive NASA documents from an employee's locked car resulted in the exposure of employee information. ë_Contractors and other non-employees associated with NASA were also affected. ë_Employees are encouraged to be suspicious of communication from individuals claiming to be from NASA. It may take up to 60 days to send official notifications to those who were affected.UPDATEë_(12/14/2012): Up to 10,000 employees and people associated with NASA may have been affected. ë_

Company: Glenn Research Center - National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
Description of incident: Hackers managed to obtain staff details from Glenn Research Center. Home addresses and telephone numbers of more than 700 US government staff were stolen and published online. ë_Most of the uploaded data was unclassified material such as expense forms and details on flight missions by the US Civil Air Patrol. ë_

A dishonest employee misused patient information in order to claim them as her children and receive insurance compensation. ë_The dishonest employee was charged with insurance fraud and ID theft.UPDATEë_(02/22/2013): Orlando Health patient records were accessed. ë_The Orlando Health hospitals include MD Anderson Cancer Center Orlando, Orlando Regional Medical Center, Winnie Palmer Hospital for Women and Babies, Dr. P. Phillips Hospital, Arnold Palmer Hospital for Children, South Seminole Hospital, South Lake Hospital, and Health Center Hospital.

Students who paid tuition for education programs may have had their 1098T tax forms sent to the incorrect address. ë_Between 150 and 200 people out of 2,000 were sent to the wrong address because a group of the tax forms were placed in envelopes without being properly separated. ë_Some people received the forms of several people while others never got their tax forms. ë_The district implemented a new step of sampling some of the envelopes in order to review the process before completing an entire batch.

A hacker accessed Zendesk information that was online. ë_Three clients who use Zendesk to store information had user lists downloaded by the hacker. ë_Users who contacted those clients for support may have had their email addresses and the subject lines of those email addresses accessed.UPDATEë_(02/22/2013): Tumblr, Twitter, and Pinterest were the affected clients. Twitter let users know that emails, phone numbers, Twitter usernames, and any other information that was provided to Twitter may have been exposed. ë_Passwords were not compromised.

NBC's website was attacked by malware in the form of a Citadel Trojan. ë_The purpose of the attack was most likely to steal usernames, passwords, and other personal information. ë_NBC is unclear on how the malware entered their system.

Fraudulent activity on the accounts of DePauw University students was linked to Kork and Keg. ë_It is not clear how the store's payment system was compromised; however it was a common link among those who had their accounts breached. ë_Kork and Keg did not make a statement.

A partner at Ernst & Young is accused of sneaking into the headquarters of Express Scripts Holding Co. ë_It is not clear how the Ernst & Young partner got into the headquarters, but it is believed that he emailed over 20,000 pages of data to a personal account. ë_Express Scripts Holding Co. accused Ernst & Young of stealing the information in order to develop its health care division. Express Scripts Holding filed a lawsuit; the accused partner is no longer employed by Ernst & Young.

The U.S. Department of Energy discovered that unidentified malicious activity had been detected on 14 servers and 20 workstations in January. ë_The personal information of several hundred employees was exposed. ë_The U.S. Department of Energy had known about the need to patch computers, network ssytems, and servers since 2012.

Two men face charges of conspiracy to commit bank fraud, conspiracy to commit access device fraud, and aggravated identity theft after being indicted for attaching skimming devices to ATMs in New York, New Jersey, Illinois, and Wisconsin. ë_At least nine other people are believed to have participated in the bank fraud scheme. ë_Over 6,000 J.P. Morgan Chase and Capital One bank accounts were defrauded for over $3 million.

The Los Angeles Times learned that a segment of its website housed malicious code for six weeks. ë_The subdomain OffersandDeals.latimes.com redirected visitors to a malicious website. ë_The website then used code to receive compensation for web traffic. ë_The compromise appears to have occurred sometime before December 23, 2012. ë_An LA Times spokesperson initially responded to the breach by claiming that a glitch in Google's display ad exchange had caused a malicious script warning rather than actual malicious script.

The Emergency Alert Systems (EAS) of several TV stations nationwide were hacked and alerted people to a fictitious zombie attack. ë_The FCC ordered local broadcasters to change their passwords on EAS equipment and check the security of firewalls before resuming normal internet connections.

Anyone who made a purchase at the HÕ_agen-Daz inside the food court in International Plaza since April of 2012 may have been affected by identity theft. ë_A flash drive that contained key-logger software was connected to a register at the store. ë_It recorded payment card transactions and allowed thieves to make counterfeit credit cards. ë_Two men were arrested in June of 2012 for using fraudulent card information and that information was later linked to the HÕ_agen-Daz shop.

Hackers were able to access Jawbone's MyTALK customer accounts for several hours. ë_Names, email addresses, and encrypted passwords were exposed. ë_Any customers who were affected received an email warning them to reset their passwords.

The owner of Silver Star Motors was charged with seven counts of identity theft and may have been involved in 25 cases of identity theft. ë_Customer information was used to defraud lending companies associated with the used-car dealership.UPDATE (02/13/2013): At least 44 people have had their information misused. The dishonest owner also operated Edge Auto Sales at one time.

A February 7 or 8 office burglary at Mercedes-Benz of Walnut Creek resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Locked file cabinets that contained customer deal files were burglarized and customer files were taken from the Service Department. ë_The theft was discovered on the morning of February 8 and immediately reported. ë_Customer names, Social Security numbers, addresses, credit reports, driver's license information, insurance information, and credit card numbers may have been exposed.

Company: First National Bank of Southern California
Description of incident: A back-up tape that contained First National Bank of Southern California client information was stolen on February 1, 2013 from a data service provider. ë_Social Security numbers, taxpayer identification numbers, account balances, and account numbers were exposed.

Company: Stanford School of Medicine, Lucile Packard Children's Hospital
Description of incident: The January 9 theft of a laptop from a physician's car may have exposed sensitive information. ë_The laptop may have contained some combination of patient names, dates of birth, and contact information.UPDATEë_(01/22/2013): A total of 57,000 patients are being notified. Medical information and medical record numbers were exposed. ë_A limited number of patients had their contact information exposed. ë_Most of the information on the laptop was from 2009.

A privacy audit uncovered a breach caused by an employee. ë_The employee accessed health information for persons other than those with whom they provided care. ë_These inappropriate accesses date back to 2004. ë_Only affected patients received a letter notifying them of the breach and offering suggestions for personal security.UPDATEë_(03/02/2013): The employee was a registered nurse and will receive a hearing in June of 2013. ë_No prosecution has occurred.

Company: First Choice Home Health Care Services Inc., Reliance Home Care, LLC
Description of incident: A group of co-conspirators used Medicaid information from Medicare beneficiaries in and near Detroit to defraud Medicaid and file for $24.7 million in fraudulent claims. ë_The fraud took place between 2008 and May of 2012. ë_Hundreds of patients had their information misused so that co-conspirators could bill Medicare for psychotherapy, home health services, and other medical services.

Company: Bank of Hawaii, First Hawaiian Bank
Description of incident: An unnamed restaurant in Oahu experienced a computer system breach. ë_Customers who visited the restaurant during a period in February had their credit and debit cards blocked by Bank of Hawaii and First Hawaiian Bank when the breach was discovered. ë_Not all of the payment cards that were blocked had been compromised.

Hackers were able to exploit a vulnerability in a web application and use an SQL injection. ë_The breach occurred in July of 2012, however the server was shut down until January of 2013. Hackers then used Bit9's systems to attack other organizations who relied on Bit9 as a security platform vendor. ë_Three unnamed companies were affected. ë_The vulnerability was caused by Bit9 failing to install its own security software.

Two backup tapes with customer and customer dependent names, Social Security numbers, addresses, account numbers, debit card numbers, and credit card numbers went missing while being transported between two TD Bank office locations in March of 2012. ë_

Company: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, Unisys
Description of incident: An administrative error resulted in documents with sensitive information from Unisys members being emailed to an incorrect party associated with Unisys. The mistake occurred on December 13, 2012. ë_The document may have contained names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and salary information. The mistake was immediately noticed by the recipient and the information was deleted from their computer.

On January 7, 2013 Fabric Depot became aware of a breach that had occurred sometime around October 16, 2012. ë_Fabric Depot changed their online payment system and notified customers. ë_Customer names, credit card numbers, credit card verification codes, debit card numbers, and account billing addresses may have been exposed.

Company: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Convey Compliance Systems, Inc.
Description of incident: An error at Convey Compliance Systems, Inc. resulted in 1099 forms being mailed to incorrect addresses. ë_The 1099 forms contained names, Social Security numbers, tax identification numbers, and addresses. ë_The financial information of some Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company clients was exposed.

An employee accessed patient records for reasons unrelated to their job function. ë_The Heath Center became aware of an unauthorized access in January of 2013. ë_Patient names, addresses, dates of birth, and in some cases health information and Social Security numbers may have been exposed.

A hacker or hackers attacked and may have accessed Evernote's online system. Evernote reset all user passwords as a precaution. ë_User names, email addresses, and encrypted passwords may have been exposed.ë_UPDATEë_(03/09/2013): A total of 50 million users were told to reset their passwords.

A collection department employee sent sensitive information to a personal email account. ë_The incident was discovered on January 28 and the employee was fired. ë_A small group of learners may have had their names, Social Security numbers, and other information that was kept by Capella's collection department exposed.

The theft of an employee's laptop resulted in the exposure of information from employees and people who received checks from Stanley Black & Decker. ë_Names, and the account numbers and routing numbers associated with direct deposits may have been exposed.
