The laptop was stolen from a finance employee on January 28. ë_

Microsoft security discovered that a number of employee devices were affected by malware. ë_The employees had visited unsafe websites and downloaded material. It is unclear if the employee devices spread the infection to other areas of Microsoft's network, but Microsoft found no evidence of customer data being affected. Facebook, Twitter, and Apple were affected by a similar issue around the same time.

Facebook discovered that hackers had exploited a vulnerability and accessed unspecified data. ë_Facebook found no evidence that Facebook user data was compromised. ë_Malware was installed on a number of employee laptops after a small number of them visited a mobile developer website that turned out to be unsafe. Microsoft, Twitter, and Apple were affected by the same issue around the same time.

Online attackers were able to access the usernames, email addresses, session tokens, and encrypted passwords of 250,000 users. ë_Twitter notified affected users and told them to create a new password. ë_Anyone who used the same password and username or email combination for other sites is encouraged to change the password on other sites as well.UPDATEë_(03/11/2013): Facebook, Microsoft, and Apple were all affected by a similar breach around the same time.

Apple detected malware on employee computers. ë_A small number of employee computers had been affected after their users went to a website for software developers. ë_Facebook, Microsoft, and Twitter experienced the same breach around the same time.

A police activity log for the period of January 7 through January 13 was published on the Littleton department's website. Someone forgot to remove personal details from the log and the sensitive information was available online for 10 days. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses, were available between January 14 and January 24.

Company: Utah Department of Health, Goold Health Systems
Description of incident: An employee of Goold Health Systems lost an unencrypted USB memory stick that contained the information of around 6,000 Medicaid recipients in Utah. ë_Goold Health Systems is a contractor for the Utah Department of Health. ë_Medicaid recipient names, Medicaid identification numbers, ages, and recent prescription drug use were on the memory stick. ë_The memory stick was lost during travel between Salt Lake City, Denver, and Washington. ë_The loss was confirmed on Tuesday, January 15. ë_

An upgrade of MDwise's customer record computer system in February 2011 resulted in the leak of records from several organizations. ë_Anyone searching by name could have accessed the information online. ë_Members of Healthy Indiana Plan, Care Select, and Hoosier Healthwise may have had their names, addresses, Medicaid numbers, and doctors' names and addresses exposed online. ë_Administrators corrected the error as soon as it was detected. ë_

Protected patient information may have been available on the internet for one year.ë_ A patient's attorney contacted St. Jude officials to inform them that the information was available online. The patient health records included names, body mass index, blood pressure, lab results, smoking status, diagnoses lists, medication allergies, and demographic information such as gender, date of birth, language spoken, ethnicity, and race.ë_ The information was removed from online and co no longer be accessed by unauthorized parties. ë_A total of 6,235 patients from Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital, two from Petaluma Valley Hospital, 4,263 from Queen of the Valley in Napa, and an unknown number of patients from St. Jude Medical Center in Fullerton, and Mission Hospitals in Laguna Beach and Mission Viejo were affected.UPDATEë_(07/10/2012): The California Department of Public Health was still investigating Queen of the Valley Medical Center as of July 10, 2012. ë_Additionally, two patients who were treated at Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital, filed a class action lawsuit on behalf of the 31,800 patients who were affected. ë_They seek $31.8 million, or $1,000 per patient.UPDATE (10/18/2016): "St. Joseph Health (SJH) has agreed to settle potential violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules following the report that files containing electronic protected health information (ePHI) were publicly accessible through internet search engines from 2011 until 2012. SJH, a nonprofit integrated Catholic health care delivery system sponsored by the St. Joseph Health Ministry, will pay a settlement amount of $2,140,500 and adopt a comprehensive corrective action plan. SJH_Ñés range of services includes 14 acute care hospitals, home health agencies, hospice care, outpatient services, skilled nursing facilities, community clinics and physician organizations throughout California and in parts of Texas and New Mexico."More Information: http://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2016/10/18/214-million-hipaa-settlement-un...

An unauthorized electronic intrusion may have affected up to 6,300 patients from Carolinas Medical Center-Randolph. The intruder accessed a provider's email account and could have obtained patient names, dates and times of service, dates of birth, diagnosis and prognosis information, medications, results, and referrals. ë_The Social Security numbers of five patients who had their Social Security numbers sent through or received by the email account may have also been obtained.ë_The issue was discovered on October 8 and the intruder is believed to have accessed emails from the account between March 11, 2012 and October 8, 2012.

Company: McDonald's, Shogun Japanese Steakhouse, Krystal, Polished Nail Salon
Description of incident: Eleven people were charged with participating in an identity theft ring. ë_Some of the defendants obtained customer credit and debit card information by using skimmers at their places of employment. ë_Others used the stolen information to make fraudulent payment cards. ë_The ring was in action between June of 2009 and November of 2010.

Four managers who left AMD to work for Nvidia are being sued by AMD for intellectual property theft. ë_AMD accused the former employees of setting up a spying ring in the company before leaving to work for rivaling company Nvidia. ë_One of the managers is accused of using two external hard drives to download Microsoft Outlook email files, licensing agreements, and strategic plans from his work computer before leaving AMD in July of 2012. Another employee is accused of taking an AMD technical work and development database with over 200 files. ë_The four employees are accused of taking over 150,000 documents.

A former Intel employees pleaded guilty to stealing documents for competitive advantage. ë_The employee worked for AMD at the time of the theft and was able to retain access to some of Intel's processor designs and chip fabrication process documents. ë_He used his vacation time from Intel to begin working at AMD. ë_The dishonest employee was charged with one count of stealing trade secrets for stealing a stack of documents in 2008 and four counts of wire fraud. ë_Intel valued the documents at between $200 million and $400 million.

A server was found to be infected with a virus. ë_The University computer contained information related to paychecks distributed by the University. ë_Current and former employees who may have been students or staff may have been affected.

Police found Thomson CompuMark customer information in the home of a former employee. The information included names, addresses and credit card information. The employee processed customer payments between May and December of 2009.

Over 150 Subway franchises and at least 50 other small retailers had customer data hacked from their point-of-sale (POS) systems. ë_Four Romanian hackers were indicted for hacking and misusing the credit card information between 2008 and May of 2011. ë_Over $3 million in fraudulent charges on customer cards was obtained by scanning the internet for vulnerable POS systems and then easily breaking the passwords to these systems. Keyloggers and a backdoor were also installed to allow further access to the system. ë_Retailers who were hit had used a certain type or types of basic POS software and many had failed to change the default password for the software.UPDATEë_(01/08/2013): A Romanian national was arrested and sentenced for his role in the POS system hack of Subway. ë_Three other Romanians face charges related to the breach.UPDATEë_(03/19/2013): The scheme may have affected 150 restaurants and may have led to $10 million in fraudulent charges. ë_Two additional hackers were sentenced on conspiracy to commit computer fraud and conspiracy to commit access device fraud charges.

A former owner of a Subway franchise used software from his new job to access the computer systems of Subway restaurants. ë_The former owner sold point-of-sale software to Subway restaurants across the country and then worked with an accomplice to remotely hack into at least 13 Subway point-of-sale systems. ë_The fraud began in 2011. ë_Fraudulent Subway gift cards totaling at least $40,000 were created. ë_Two of the California participants were indicted on March 6.

A security breach has exposed iPad owner information. Dozens of CEOs, military officials, and top politicians may have been affected. They_ÑÓand every other buyer of the cellular-enabled tablet_ÑÓcould be vulnerable to spam marketing and malicious hacking. The breach exposed the most exclusive email list on the planet, a collection of early-adopter iPad 3G subscribers that includes thousands of A-listers in finance, politics and media, from New York Times Co. CEO Janet Robinson to Diane Sawyer of ABC News to film mogul Harvey Weinstein to Mayor Michael Bloomberg. It even appears that White House Chief of Staff Rahm Emanuel's information was compromised. It doesn't stop there. According to the data given by the web security group that exploited vulnerabilities on the AT&T network, 114,000 user accounts have been compromised, although it's possible that confidential information about every iPad 3G owner in the U.S. has been exposed.UPDATEë_(01/18/2011): Chat logs of the accused iPad hackersë_were turned over to investigators. ë_It appears that two men used an "account slurper" to conduct a "brute force" attack that lasted five days and extracted data from iPad users who accessed the Internet through AT&T's 3G network. ë_Each of the two men were charged with one count of conspiracy to access a computer without authorization and one count of fraud.UPDATEë_(06/23/2011): One of the people responsible for writing the malicious code used to breach AT&T's computer servers pleaded guilty to his part in the attack.UPDATEë_(11/20/2012): The second person responsible for discovering and exploiting a security weakness was found guilty. ë_AT&T iPad subscribers had their emails exposed because of the security issue.UPDATEë_(03/19/2013): One of the conspirators was sentenced to 41 months in prison for identity theft and conspiracy to gain unauthorized access to computers.

Company: Lawrence Melrose Medical Electronic Record, Inc.
Description of incident: An employee of Lawrence Melrose accessed patient information for reasons unrelated to their work. ë_It is unclear what type of patient information was exposed and how many patients were affected. ë_

A dishonest employee working at a Comfort Inn and Suites in Willard, Missouri during 2009 worked with a conspirator to misuse the information of hotel customers. ë_They were ordered to pay restitution of $23,000. ë_The dishonest employee was sentenced to three years of probation and her accomplice was sentenced to 42 months for aggravated identity theft and conspiracy to commit wire fraud.

A security breach allowed access to the personal records of at least 12,000 SRS workers. ë_The breach does not appear to be the result of a cyber attack. ë_Workers may have had financial information exposed.

GSA users may have been able to view the financial information and trade secrets of other GSA users due to a security vulnerability. ë_The specific database that was affected is called the System for Award Management (SAM). ë_Contractor and vendor registration records are cataloged by SAM. ë_It is not clear how GSA became aware of the issue or how long it was a problem. ë_Agency officials revealed that users could purposefully or inadvertently view the information of other users after following a series of steps.UPDATEë_(03/23/2013): ë_Users had Social Security numbers and tax identification numbers exposed.

Files of disability applicants 
            containing Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers of family 
            members, dates of birth, work history, and detailed medical information 
            were lost/stolen when a telecommuting employee abandoned them in a 
            locked filing cabinet at home after a threat of domestic violence. 
            Several of the files were mailed back to the local SSA office. Others were found in a dumpster months later. ë_Four were never 
            recovered.
Hackers targeted various websites owned by Ford and posted sensitive information online. ë_Usernames, passwords, and administrator information may have been exposed.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_A total of 30 names, usernames, email addresses, and passwords were exposed.

The FBI on Friday arrested a former Countrywide Financial Corp. employee and another man in an alleged scheme to steal and sell sensitive personal information, including Social Security numbers. The breach occurred over a two-year period though July. The insider was a senior financial analyst at Full Spectrum Lending, Countrywide's subprime lending division. The alleged data thief was said to have downloaded about 20,000 customer profiles each week and sold files with that many names for $500, according to the affidavit. He typically would e-mail the data in Excel spreadsheets to his buyers, often using computers at Kinko's copying and business center stores. Some, perhaps most, and possibly all the names were being sold to people in the mortgage industry to make new pitches. UPDATE (1/30/2009): Bank of America will pay Connecticut $350,000 as part of a settlement. The bank will also provide at least $25,000 to reimburse Connecticut residents forced to pay for freezing and unfreezing their credit reports.UPDATE (4/09/2010): Employees of Countrywide Financial stole and sold "tens of thousands, or millions" of customers' personal financial information, invading their privacy and exposing them to identity theft, according to class action claims in Ventura County Court, CA. Sixteen named plaintiffs sued Countrywide Financial, Countrywide Home Loans, and Bank of America, which bought Countrywide, the poster boy for the subprime mortgage crisis. UPDATE (5/08/2010): For information about the settlement, visit www.CWdataclaims.com or call (866) 940-3612.UPDATE (8/24/2010): Bank of America has settled over 30 lawsuits involving Countrywide Financial customer data theft.ë_ As many as 17 million customers who received a mortgage or used Countrywide to service a mortgage before July 1, 2008 will receive reimbursement and identity theft insurance.ë_ Identity theft claims can be filed after September 6.UPDATEë_(9/28/2011): A former employee responsible for the breach was sentenced to eight months in prison and ordered to repay $1.2 million in costs.UPDATEë_(7/13/2012): A small group of people objected to a proposed settlement and decided to split from a larger class action lawsuit. ë_A court dismissed their claim because they could not sufficiently prove an out of pocket loss.

Company: Massachusetts Executive Office of Labor and Workforce Development  (EOLWD)
Description of incident: A computer virus called W32.QAKBOT infected various computer terminals and individual computers at the Department of Unemployment Assistance, the Department of Career Services, and multiple One Stop Career Centers. The virus first infected the computers and network on April 20. ë_Though the virus was detected within a short period of time and stopped, it was later discovered that it had not been completely eradicated. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, email addresses, residential or business addresses, Employer Identification Numbers (EIN) and employer bank information may have been exposed. ë_Twelve hundred employers who manually filed with the EOLWD may be affected. If a staff member keyed in sensitive claimant information at a work station infected with the virus then that claimant's information may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(5/18/2011): Approximately 210,000 people were affected by the breach.

The Oregon DMV sold DMV database information to marketing companies prior to the late 1990s. ë_A man gained access to this information and used it to create fake Oregon identification cards and print fake checks. ë_He was charged with 26 counts of aggravated identity; this represents one count per victim for each letter of the alphabet. ë_The databases includes 1.6 million names, addresses, dates of birth, genders and ages of people who registered with the DMV. ë_The database of publicly available information is over a decade old. The Oregon DMV says it is not the first time one of their databases has been used illegally.

A dishonest employee working in the billing department used her position to access account information. ë_She scanned checks and identification information from the LSU hospital system database and passed them on to at least four women. ë_The scheme was discovered when the four women were allegedly caught on camera making purchases with fake checks. ë_Handwritten Social Security numbers, check and ID card printing items, computers, and copies of scanned checks were found when the womens' homes were searched.At least seven people face charges that include identity theft, conspiracy to commit identity theft, conspiracy to commit monetary abuse, and possession of fraudulent documents for identification purposes. ë_The dishonest employee was charged with 377 counts of identity theft.UPDATEë_(01/02/2013): LSU Health notified 416 patients after a hospital employee discovered fraudulent activity on her checking account.

Company: Surgical Associates of Utica, Quanterion Solutions, Inc.
Description of incident: The theft of a network server on or around September 18 may have resulted in the exposure of sensitive patient information. ë_A notification was sent to the US Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) on November 16.

Company: Forte Interactive, Children's Service Council of Palm Beach County, Ocean Reef Community Association
Description of incident: Information Forte Interactive inadvertently copied from web applications used by Children's Service Council and Ocean Reef Community accidentally became publicly accessible after a system upgrade. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and dates of birth of individuals whose information was contained in the web portal or web portals was publicly accessible between December 7, 2011 and February 3, 2012. The issue was discovered on January 30, 2012. ë_

Five MIdwest financial institutions have seen fraudulent charges show up on their customers' MasterCard-issued debit cards. ë_Soy Capital Bank and Trust is responding quickly to the breach; it appears to have occurred over the weekend of May 21. ë_Fraudulent charges that emptied the accounts of some customers have been appearing in places ranging from Australia to Texas. ë_Soy Capital is blocking transactions on old MasterCards and giving clients new debit cards. ë_Soy Capital expects minimal losses from the breach and will be able to reinstate customer funds within 10 days. ë_Customers who were affected could end up paying as much as $50. ë_

Company: Greenville Hospital System University Medical Center, Allen Bennett Memorial Hospital
Description of incident: Exposed boxes of patient information were reported to Greenville Hospital System on December 31, 2010 by someone wishing to remain anonymous. ë_The boxes were in a storage structure behind the building of an abandoned hospital. ë_The hospital was Allen Bennett Memorial Hospital; it closed in August of 2008. Greenville Hospital System collected the boxes and notified patients in February. ë_The 22 boxes contained information from Allen Bennett Memorial dating from 1990 to 1999. ë_The information in the boxes included patient names, reasons and dates for visits, amount paid, patient insurance information with diagnosis and treatment, and admission reports with patient dates of birth and some Social Security numbers. ë_An investigation revealed that the information in the boxes was probably not used for criminal purposes and that no one was sure how the boxes had gotten there.

Conor O'Neills' computer system was hacked. ë_Customers may have had their credit and debit card numbers accessed. ë_A number of the fraudulent charges came from Texas between April 22 and June 10 of 2011. ë_There is also a possibility that the hackers originated in Europe. ë_The date of the breach and the number of customers affected were not reported. ë_

A surgeon, had a palm pilot device stolen from his parked vehicle on or around the morning of July 13, 2011. ë_It held patient names, dates of birth, surgical procedures, diagnoses, and anesthesia. ë_Patients who had seen the surgeon between December 27, 2007 and June 24, 2011 were affected.

A camera from the Plastic Surgery Clinic was discovered missing in November of 2010.ë_ It contained Social Security numbers and graphic photos of female patients before and after surgery for breast cancer.ë_ The same investigation that uncovered the missing camera also revealed that laptops, televisions, thumb drives, microscopes, a hospital surveillance system, and other equipment had been lost or stolen within the past two years.ë_ One missing thumb drive contained additional patient information.

Federal investigators informed Tallahassee Community College that a hacker gained access to their main computer system. ë_The personal information of students who applied for financial aid may have been accessed. ë_It appears that an insider hacked into the computer system. Hackedë_2011 TCC financial aid recordsë_were misused to file fraudulent tax refunds. ë_Federal Investigators told TCC when they traced where the information came from.

This security breach affects all              of its 165 stores in the Northeast, 106 Sweetbay stores in Florida              and a smaller number of independent groceries that sell Hannaford              products. The company is currently aware of about 1,800 cases of reported              fraud related to the security breach. Credit and debit card numbers              were stolen during the card authorization transmission process. It's              unclear if personal information was exposed. UPDATE             (4/2/2009): An April 2, 2009, news story indicated that between Dec.              7, 2007, and March 10, 2008, hackers stole credit and debit card numbers,              expiration dates and PIN numbers from people shopping at Hannaford              supermarkets. About 1,800 fraudulent charges had been made. UPDATE             (5/14/2009): A federal appeals court has revived a Tampa class-action              suit seeking money for Florida shoppers whose credit and debit card              numbers were swiped in a data breach that hit 109 Sweetbay Supermarkets.              The suit seeks free credit monitoring, credit repair if necessary              and undetermined money damages to be split up among victims of the              breach, including those unaware they were victims. UPDATE             (5/22/2009): A Maine U.S. District Court dismissed most of a class              action lawsuit against Hannaford, finding that there is no way to              value the time and effort that consumers spent in correcting fraudulent              activity resulting from the breach. The case of one named plaintiff              was not dismissed. That plaintiff suffered actual monetary damages              for unreimbursed fraudulent charges.UPDATE (11/2/2011): Federal Appeals Court Holds Identity Theft Insurance/Credit Monitoring Costs Constitute "Damages" in Hannaford Breach Case (Oct. 24, 2011) http://tinyurl.com/3kxxmnb. http://tinyurl.com/3jkg489UPDATEë_(3/29/2013): A United States District Court for the District of Maine has denied a motion that would have allowed a lawsuit to proceed as a class action. ë_The plaintiffs originally moved to certify the proposed class on September 4, 2012. ë_http://tinyurl.com/bsg9xpu

Utah Medicaid clients have had their information exposed by a hack of an improperly protected Utah Department of Health computer server. ë_The breach was discovered when an unusual amountë_of data was found to be streaming out of the server on April 2. Medicaid clients who had not had their Social Security numbers transitioned into the system had their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_A majority of the affected individuals had medical claims, dates of birth, addresses, physicians' names, and other forms of medical information exposed, but not Social Security numbers. Two out of three of those who were affected were children. ë_The cost of working with the credit-reporting company Experian to contain the breach is estimated to be $460,000.UPDATEë_(04/10/2012): Though the number of affected individuals was originally reported as 181,604 with 25,096 Social Security numbers exposed, Utah Department of Health reported that nearly 280,000 people had their Social Security numbers exposed by the breach. ë_An additional 500,000 victims did not have their Social Security numbers exposed, but had some form of personal information such as date of birth, name, and address exposed. People who visited a health care provider in the past four months is likely to have been affected by the breach.UPDATEë_(05/15/2012): The governor of Utah fired the Director of the Department of Technology Services and appointed a new employee, an ombudsman, to shepherd victims through the process of protecting their identities and credit. ë_Two other members of the technology services department are under review. ë_The vulnerability that caused the breach was partly, if not fully, due to failure to change a default password. Additionally, data will now be encrypted while it is on Utah servers as well as when it is in transit.UPDATEë_(07/22/2012): Those who wish to learn more about the Utah Department of Health breach will be able to attend a series of statewide workshops running from July 26 until August 22. ë_Information on Utah's Data Breach Security Tour can be found here.UPDATEë_(03/25/2013): The state of legislature of Utah added an second year of free credit monitoring to those who were affected by the breach. ë_Additionally, a Utah health department official revealed that only 59,500 people had taken advantage of the first year of free credit monitoring service. ë_Those who did not enroll in 2012 may call 801-538-6923 or email ombudsman@utah.gov to sign up for the 2013-2014 term.

Company: National Institute of Aerospace, National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
Description of incident: A Chinese national who worked as a contractor for the National Institute of Aerospace had access to NASA's Langley Research Center. ë_He was caught boarding a plane with two external hard drives, two laptops, a memory stick, and an SIM card on March 16. ë_He originally did not reveal the second laptop, hard drive, and SIM card when detained. ë_The information he was attempting to steal was not revealed. ë_

Company: Oregon Health and Science University Hospital (OHSU)
Description of incident: The July 4 or 5 burglary of an OHSU empoyee's home resulted in the theft of a briefcase, a thumb drive, and several other items. ë_The thumb drive was used to back up data from OHSU computer systems and would normally be locked in a secure location on campus. ë_Pediatric patient information such as name, date of birth, phone number, address, OHSU medical record number, patient medical condition code, or family medical history was exposed. A total of 702 patients had additional information exposed that was more sensitive. ë_The thumb drive also contained a database of OHSU staff information that included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and employment-related vaccination information of 195 OHSU employees.

Company: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center (TTUHSC)
Description of incident: An administrative error caused the billing statements of around 700 patients to be sent to the mailing addresses of other patients. ë_Patient names, account numbers, invoice numbers, charge amounts, dates of service, department and provider names, adjustment amounts, payments from insurance companies, amounts due, and total account balances may have been exposed.

A physician's laptop was stolen            from a car parked at the doctor's home. Patient names,            treatment dates, short medical treatment summaries and medical record            numbers were stored on the computer. There were no home addresses, billing            information or Social Security numbers stored on the laptop.UPDATE (08/11/10): It seems that as many as 4,000 patients may have been affected and Social Security numbers were involved.

A laptop stolen in Chicago this 
          week contained health records. It was stolen from a hotel while an OHSU 
          employee was there on business. The data could include medical record 
          numbers, names, telephone numbers, dates of birth, gender, Social Security 
          numbers, addresses.medical diagnosis category and category of treatment 
           -  but not the specific treatments.
An administrative error caused the Social Security numbers and other personal information of Allen County employees to be available online for less than an hour.

An employee's laptop was stolen from a locked vehicle in June. ë_It contained billing information about Apria patients in California, Arizona, New Mexico, and Nevada. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and other personal or health information may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(09/29/2012): The laptop was stolen on June 14 and was password-protected. ë_Current and past patients were affected.UPDATEë_(04/03/2013): Billing information for 65,700 patients was stored on the laptop.

Desktop computer hardware was stolen from the Anaheim Billing Center of Crescent Healthcare, Inc. on December 28, 2012. ë_The theft was discovered on Monday, December 31 and reported to law enforcement. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, health insurance identification numbers, health insurance information, dates of birth, diagnoses, other medical information, disability codes, addresses, and phone numbers may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(04/03/2013): Over 100,000 people were affected.

Company: United HomeCare Services, Inc., United Home Care Services of Southwest Florida, LLC
Description of incident: The January 8 theft of a billing manager's laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_It was stolen from the manager's car. ë_It contained client names, Social Security numbers, health plan numbers, dates of birth, and addresses dating as far back as 2002. ë_Some patients may have also had treatment service codes or diagnostic codes on the laptop.

A hack affected less than 1% of Scribd's 50 million users. "A few hundred thousand" users had their passwords stolen. ë_Users who were affected received instructions for resetting passwords. ë_The passwords were encrypted and it is unlikely that hackers were able to decrypt and use the passwords before Scribd and Scribd users learned of the breach.

LexisNexis informed Sprechman & Associates that the unusual, excessive activity of an associate caused them to eliminate that associate's access to LexisNexis' database. ë_The associate was later found to have misused Social Security numbers in order to file over 11 million dollars in fraudulent tax refund claims. The dishonest associate was not immediately fired from Sprechman & Associates and was terminated in July 2012 when law enforcement used a warrant to search his home and office computers. ë_

A number of credit card terminals in 19 California and Arizona stores were affected by point-of-sale malware between January 25 and 29. ë_Credit card and debit card numbers were exposed. ë_Customer PINs associated with the payment cards were not affected. Sprouts identified the issue within a few days of the breach and updated customer information protection procedures in all of its stores.

A nursing supervisor of Rensselaer County Jail was found to have misused credentials to access patient records without cause. ë_The Rensselaer County Jail information is maintained by Samaritan Hospital. ë_The hospital learned of the breach in November 2011, disabled the employee's account, and notified the sheriff's office immediately. ë_Subsequently, the Hospital may have delayed notifying patients because of the ongoing investigation. ë_Notifications were sent out during the first week of March in 2013.UPDATEë_(04/01/2013): A total of 48 people have been notified. ë_Patients from as far back as 2006 may have been affected.

A caller contacted a local news team member and an investigation of mishandled medical documents began. ë_The documents were in an unlocked dumpster and contained Social Security numbers, bank account information, addresses, dates of birth, and health information. ë_The documents were associated with Family Intervention Services and an unnamed orthopedic office.
A hacker or hackers accessed and posted sensitive information online. ë_Usernames, email addresses, and MD5 passwords were exposed.

A total of 2,600 medical appointment records disappeared before they could be shredded. ë_The records contained patient names, dates of appointments, times of appointments, and reason for appointment. ë_No medical claim information, financial information, or Social Security numbers were exposed.

A former employee received a CD with the names and Social Security numbers of around 200 current and former employees when he requested his personnel file. ë_The disc may have held the information of employees who signed up for a specific dental insurance plan in 1996 and workers who joined the Utah Public Employees Association in 1999. ë_When the HR department realized their mistake they requested that the former employee return the CD. ë_He initially refused; he then gave the CD to the Tooele County Attorney's office. ë_

A hacker or hackers accessed patient information and posted it online. ë_The breach was discovered by a data privacy expert. Uniontown indirectly notified the public of the breach and breach containment after the privacy expert attempted to reach Uniontown Hospital for several days. ë_Names, encrypted passwords, contact names, email addresses, and usernames may have been exposed. ë_It is unclear how long the information was available.

A Schneck Medical Center employee gave a presentation that was later placed online. ë_People who searched through the files from the presentation could find the names of 3,000 Schneck Medical Center patients. ë_The presentation was removed from online and Google removed all cached information from the Internet.

The owner of Medical Solutions Management, Inc. was convicted of wrongful disclosure of private patient information and Medicare fraud. The owner stole private patient information from nursing homes in Long Island and used the information to submit fraudulent claims to Medicare over the course of four and a half years. ë_Over 1,000 people were affected. She faces a sentence of up to 10 years per count and could be fined up to $250,000 for each conviction count.UPDATEë_(04/11/2013): The dishonest owner was sentenced to 12 years in prison. A total of 1.3 million dollars was seized from the owner and she was ordered to forfeit it at her sentencing. She had submitted 10 million dollars in fraudulent Medicare billings.

Erlanger Health System sent notes to 87 families and apologized for an incident that left the patient records of children exposed. ë_The records contained names, Social Security numbers, phone numbers, and dianosis information. ë_Erlanger has not been made aware of the records being used in an unauthorized manner.

A computer intrusion resulted in the exposure of names, Social Security numbers, contact information, dates of birth, driver's license numbers, and financial account information. The breach occurred sometime around December 2, 2012.ë_

Confidential medical records were found under a freeway by a concerned citizen.ë_A local news team investigationë_traced the documents back to the insurance claims processor ICW.ë_ICW reported thatë_the issue occurred on February 28 when a bin with files broke open on the way to a disposal site. ë_An unnamed document destruction company responsible for the documents was replaced.ë_Names, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, and other sensitive and medical information were on the documents.ë_

A phishing attack affected an OCS America computer on March 4, 2013. ë_The computer contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, job titles, and salary information. ë_It appears that only one computer was affected.ë_

On January 15, 2013 TLO discovered that there had been limited fraudulent access to their system. ë_A hacker or hackers were able to access names, Social Security numbers, and driver's license numbers between August 2012 and January 2013.ë_

The January 11 theft of an employee's laptop resulted in the exposure of sensitive information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the employee's vehicle and contained names, Social Security numbers, and other information related to current and former Finish Line staff.

An administrative error caused a mailing distribution to contain the Social Security numbers of some people. ë_Rollins learned of the issue on March 12. ë_The Rollins TODAY quarterly issue mailed during the week of March 4 contained Social Security numbers within a number sequence on the mailing label.

Current and former parties involved in a bankruptcy proceeding for a Citi loan may have had their information exposed. ë_Citi filed legal documents that should have been concealed but were accidentally made available online. ë_The information, which included personally identifiable and loan related information, could be exposed and read by any person who accessed court records. ë_The issue was addressed and Citi is not aware of any ë_instances where information was accessed.

A hacker or hackers accessed Tennis Expresses computer network on or around December 19, 2012. ë_The breach was discovered in mid-February of 2013. ë_The issue was caused by a vulnerability in a third party vendor program. ë_Names, addresses, credit card numbers, verification value, and expiration dates may have been exposed.

A hacker may have accessed credit card information, names, and addresses associated with Shoplet accounts. ë_The breach was discovered on January 11, 2013. ë_A new firewall was installed and Ellison Systems, Inc. moved their database server to a more secure zone.

A thumb drive with information from the Medicare Exclusion Database was placed on a thumb drive. ë_The thumb drive was discovered to be missing from the CSC facilities in Raleigh, North Carolina in early March; it had most likely been lost in late February. ë_The thumb drive contained names, Social Security numbers, federal tax Employer Identification numbers, dates of birth, and other information.

An administrative error caused the personal information of some students to be exposed online. ë_The issue was discovered on February 27. ë_Authenticated users of Chapman's on-campus network could have viewed names, Social Security numbers, student identification numbers, and dates of birth. ë_The documents were blocked from access by unauthorized users once the breach was discovered.
Hackers were able to access and disrupt American Express' website. American Express was offline for two hours. ë_
JPMorgan Chase's website was taken offline by a hacker or hackers. The website was made unavailable by a denial-of-service attack. ë_Chase.com was down for around a day.

Customers who used a debit or credit card at any Works Bakery Cafe location are advised to check their payment cards for fraudulent activity. ë_A breach occurred when malware was introduced to the Works Bakery Cafe computer system. ë_Locations in Durham, Manchester, Keene, Concord, Brattleboro Vermont, and Portland Maine were affected.

On, January 19, Agincourt Wallboard notified employees of a breach of its payroll system. ë_Agincourt Wallboard became aware of the issue on January 17 when eight employees reported receiving a physical payroll check. ë_Someone had entered Agincourt Wallboard's payroll vendor and edited information without authorization so that the employees received a physical check rather than an electronic deposit. ë_The person who hacked into the payroll vendor also attempted to change the bank routing information for 10 of its employees. ë_Agincourt Wallboard is investigating how the hacker could have obtained the administrator's credentials and notified employees of the issue immediately. ë_Agincourt Wallboard also learned that five of the computers on its network were infected with malware called a Trojan horse.

A March 24, 2013 VUDU office theft resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Hard drives with customer names, addresses, email addresses, account activity, dates of birth, and encrypted passwords were stolen. ë_Customers who used their VUDU passwords for other sites should change the passwords on other sides as well.

Hackers accessed Kirkwood Community College's website and applicant database system on March 13. ë_Anyone who applied to a Kirkwood Campus may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, race, and contact information exposed. ë_People who applied to take Kirkwood college-credit classes between February 25, 2005 and March 13, 2013 were affected.

Company: Hospice Palliative Care of Alamance-Caswell, LifePath Home Health
Description of incident: The February 24 burglary of three laptops resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptops were stolen from the hospital in addition to needles, syringes, and miscellaneous items. ë_The unencrypted laptops contained emails that had sensitive patient information.

Company: Connextions, Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield of Indiana, Anthem Blue Cross Blue Shield of Ohio, Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield of Indiana
Description of incident: A Connextions employee used Social Security numbers from a number of other organizations for criminal activity. ë_At least four members of Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield were affected by the criminal activity. ë_The breach was reported on HHS as affecting 4,814 patients, but more were affected.

Lawyers working with Guantanamo Bay detainees had to pause their work after being told to stop using the Pentagon's computer system. ë_An unspecified issue left over 500,000 emails unsafe to access or deleted from a Pentagon common drive. The breach left defense files unsecured and it may have been possible for prosecutors to view confidential defense emails.

Customers who shopped at a Wawa on Salem Road in Burlington, New Jersey noticed fraudulent purchases on their credit cards. ë_Investigators were able to trace the fraud to four people and arrest them. The four men were charged with credit card theft, credit card fraud, identity theft, and having electronic devices for criminal use. ë_More victims are expected to be found.

Global Payments discovered a massive breach of their systems in early March 2012. ë_Global Payments processes credit and debit cards for banks and merchants and a number of credit and debit cards issued to businesses were determined to be compromised. ë_The breach was discovered when Global Payments' security systems detected unusual activity.UPDATE (04/02/2012): Global Payments created a breach information website for consumers. Global Payments claimed that only a few of their North American servers were affected by the breach. ë_They also claimed that around 1.5 million users had Track 2 data (card expiration date and credit card number) exposed. Media reports that up to 10 million consumers had their names, addresses, and Social Security numbers credit exposed were denied by Global Payments. ë_Visa has removed Global Payments from their list of compliant service providers as a result of the breach. ë_UPDATEë_(04/05/2012): The breach occurred sometime between January 21 and February 25 of 2012 (REVISED TO JUNE OF 2011). ë_Fraudulent activity has already been detected on around 800 cards.UPDATEë_(05/01/2012): It appears that a hacker or hackers were first able to access Global Payments Inc. in June of 2011. ë_Global Payments revised their initial estimate and believe that card holders and banks were affected at least as far back as June 2011. This could mean that at least seven million card accounts are vulnerable; though Global Payments still believe that only 1.5 million were affected.UPDATEë_(07/26/2012): In addition to being dropped from Visa and Mastercard's lists of compliant companies, Global Payments spent nearly $85 million on security repairs and upgrades.UPDATEë_(07/30/2012: Global Payments informed Comerica Bank in June that their ongoing investigation revealed a potential unauthorized access to its servers that contain merchant application data.UPDATEë_(01/10/2013): Global Payments has incurred $94 million in fees associated with the breach. ë_A total of $60 million was paid for professional fees and other costs associated with investigating the breach and remediation for its effects. ë_The $60 million was also used to cover incentive payments to business partners and the cost of providing credit monitoring and identity protection insurance. ë_An additional $35.9 million went towards estimated fraud losses, fines, and charges imposed on Global Payments by card networks. ë_Global Payments received $2 million from insurance recoveries.Global Payments also reported that it has now paid all fines related to non-compliance and has updated its systems and processes in order to be returned to the payment card network list of PCI-DSS compliant service providers.UPDATEë_(04/15/2013): An April 2012 class action lawsuit related to the breach was dismissed on March 6. ë_Global Payments also confirmed that the expenses associated with the breach totaled $92.7 million. ë_A total of $20 million in breach losses was recuperated through insurance recoveries. ë_In April 2013, Global Payments closed its investigation of the breach.

Company: Arizona Counseling and Treatment Services (ACTS), Cenpatico Behavioral Health of Arizona
Description of incident: The home theft of any employee's laptop and external drive resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The theft occurred sometime between March 18 and March 25; other items were stolen besides the laptop and hard drive. ë_Neither the laptop nor the hard drive were encrypted. Patients who visited either Cenpatico or its contractor ATS between 2011 and 2013 may have had their names, dates of birth, and treatment plans exposed.UPDATEë_(04/17/2013): More than 3,000 patients were affected by the breach.

Company: Portal Healthcare Solutions, Glens Falls Hospital
Description of incident: Two patients ran a google search of their names and were able to find their medical information online. ë_Doctors' reports with medications, medical treatments, lab information, future and past treatment plans, physical examination information, and lifestyle information could be downloaded by anyone who found the information online. ë_The documents were from November 2012 through January 2013 and discovered online in mid-March. ë_Portal Healthcare secured the sensitive information on its servers on March 14. ë_A lawsuit was filed against Glens Falls Hospital, Portal Healthcare Solutions LLC, and Carpathia Hosting in mid-April for patient privacy violations.

An employee was found to have installed backdoors on more than 2,700 company servers. ë_The issue was discovered the day after the dishonest employee was dismissed. ë_He worked for Hostgator from September 2011 to February 15, 2012. The dishonest employee was arrested and charged with breach of computer security.

A former employee revealed a password and username combination for Tribune Co. to hackers. ë_The hackers were part of anonymous and used the information to access Tribune Co.'s servers in 2010. ë_A number of online stories that had been published through Tribune Co. were defaced by hackers as a result. ë_The former employee of a TV station owned by Tribune Co. was indicted on charges of conspiracy to cause damage to a protected computer, transmission of malicious code, and attempted transmission of malicious code.UPDATEë_(04/23/2013): The former employee worked at Reuters as a deputy social media editor at the time of the cyber attack. ë_He was fired from Reuters in April of 2013.

An assistant manager was forced to open a Kmart safe and give a thief access to $6,000 in cash and an unencrypted backup disk with a day's worth of customer information. ë_The backup disk contained names, addresses, dates of birth, prescription numbers, prescription providers, insurance cardholder IDs and drug names. ë_The armed robbery occurred on March 17.

A man guessed or accessed the Social Security numbers of Macy's customers in order to exploit a Macy's policy for the purpose of making fraudulent purchases. ë_He then created ID cards that paired his picture with the customer information. ë_A Macy's policy allowed him to charge purchases to the accounts of other Macy's customers by using their Social Security numbers and showing his falsified IDs. ë_

An employee's car was the target of an April 1 break-in. ë_A company laptop and 10 patient files were taken during the car theft. ë_The paper files were recovered, but the laptop also contained patient information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, telephone numbers, health insurance information, names of providers, and the reasons for patients' appointments may have been included in emails stored on the laptop.

Social Security numbers and other personal information of students and faculty were accessible via Yahoo's search engine.  The information was removed from UVSC's servers.  Some Distance Education instructors and some students enrolled in UVSC courses between January 2002 and January 2005 were affected.

A portable electronic device was stolen from Upstate University Hospital on March 30 or 31. ë_It contained the names, hospital medical record numbers, dates of birth, and diagnosis information of patients.

A OneWest service provider suffered an unauthorized network intrusion during the first quarter of 2011. ë_OneWest client names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, driver's license numbers, and passport numbers may have been exposed.

An employee used an unsecured email to send sensitive patient information. ë_Two separate administrative violations occurred on December 27, 2012 and on February 22, 2013. The issue was discovered on February 25. ë_The information was secured on February 28, 2013. ë_Patient names, referral sources, Hospice admission and discharge dates, the names of insurance providers, and chart numbers may have been exposed.ë_

More than 50 reports of credit card fraud have been traced to people who were customers at Gomez Gasoline and Automotive. ë_Police suspect that a credit-card skimming device was placed on one or more gas pumps. ë_The skimming devices have been spotted at other gas stations.

Reputation.com experienced a hack that exposed customer names, email addresses, mailing addresses, date of birth, and employment information. Additionally, some customers had their encrypted passwords stolen. ë_Reputation.com immediately reset all customer passwords after learning about the breach. ë_Customers are encouraged to change their passwords on other sites if they reused their Reputation.com password.

A disgruntled employee announced his resignation and then was caught copying files from his computer to a flash drive. ë_Employees at Spellman began experiencing transaction and intranet disruptions after the disgruntled employee left even though his access to company servers was disabled after discovery of his suspicious activities. ë_The events began to occur sometime around January of 2012. ë_An investigation of the events led to the arrest of the former employee and federal prosecutors claim that he caused enough mayhem to cost Spellman over $90,000 by using his knowledge of Spellman's computer system and stolen passwords. ë_The former employee pleaded not guilty.

The Department of Labor's website was found to have been infected with malware that spreads to visitors using the web browser Internet Explorer. ë_Microsoft had already released a patch to address the Internet Explorer vulnerability and the malware targets users who have not taken advantage of the patch.

Company: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' National Inventory of Dams
Description of incident: Users of the National Inventory of Dams received notification that their information was reset after a hack may have compromised usernames and passwords. ë_Hackers obtained non-public information of around 8,100 major dams in the United States by breaching the database. ë_The information included dam vulnerabilities and could be used by cyber terrorists. ë_

The loss of an unencrypted flash drive exposed sensitive patient information. ë_The flash drive contained name, date of birth, weight, gender, telephone number, URMC internal medical record number, orthopaedic physician name, date of service, diagnosis, diagnostic study, procedure, and complications. ë_The flash drive is believed to have been destroyed after ending up in the medical center laundry. It was not found.

Company: Child and Family Services of New Hampshire
Description of incident: Someone took 23 files from a secure area in the Child and Family Services of New Hampshire main office sometime between March 15 and March 18. ë_The breach was discovered on March 19. ë_The files contained client names, dates of birth, addresses, Medicaid numbers, notes from home visits, and other health information related to home visits.

A server with client information was accessed by an unauthorized outside party between February 21 and March 6, 2013. ë_The attack was an attempt to use the server for spam emailing. ë_Client names, Social Security numbers, driver's license information, and FSC broker account numbers may have been accessed.

A ring of middle school students were able to gain access to and control of more than 300 computers by phishing for teacher administrative codes. ë_At least 18 students were involved. ë_The breach happened when students used software to imitate a legitimate software update on their computers. ë_The students then asked teachers to enter administrative account information so that they could complete the software updates or installations. ë_The phony software then stored teacher credentials. ë_The students were then able to control 300 laptops belonging to other students by using the administrative credentials. ë_The school believes that servers and sensitive information were not exposed. ë_The breach occurred around Friday, April 26 and was discovered on Monday, April 29 when students noticed that other students appeared to be controlling student laptops remotely and reported the issue.

Raleigh Orthopaedic Clinic contracted with a vendor in order to have information from X-ray films transferred into electronic format. ë_The X-ray film was actually sold by the unnamed vendor and melted harvest for silver by a recycling company in Ohio. Patient names and dates of birth were on the film. ë_The Clinic does not believe that personally identifiable information was on the film.

Hackers accessed Name.com servers and may have obtained usernames, email addresses, passwords, and credit card account information. ë_Customer passwords and credit card information were encrypted. ë_Customers were notified of the breach and received an email asking them to reset their passwords.

Hackers exploited an Adobe vulnerability and used it to access Linode Manager web servers. ë_One of Linode's web servers, parts of their source code, and their database were accessed. ë_No other components of the Linode infrastructure were accessed by the hackers. ë_Encrypted customer credit card numbers and passwords were obtained. ë_The group HTP claimed responsibility for the hack.ë_

Company: Department of Family and Support Services (DFSS)
Description of incident: Nearly $41,000 in computer equipment was reported stolen from the Department of Family Support Services on May 7. ë_The Division on Domestic Violence and a satellite senior center share the building where the theft occurred. ë_The types of information that may have been on the device or devices were not reported.

Company: Administrative Office of the Courts - Washington
Description of incident: A breach of the Administrative Office of the Courts' server resulted in the exposure of one million driver's license numbers between fall of 2012 and February of 2013. ë_It was confirmed that at least 94 people had their Social Security numbers accessed. ë_Up to 160,000 Social Security numbers could have been accessed.ë_In April the court was able to confirm that public records and confidential information were exposed. ë_People who were booked in a city or county jail within the state of Washington between September 2011 and December 2012 may have had their name and Social Security number accessed. ë_Anyone who received a DUI citation in Washington state between 1989 and 2011, had a superior court criminal case in Washington state that was filed against them or resolved between 2011 and 2012, or had a traffic case in Washington filed or resolved in a district or municipal court between 2011 and 2012 may have had their names and driver's license numbers exposed.

Company: Lutheran Social Services of South Central Pennsylvania
Description of incident: Lutheran Social Services became aware of a malware program that was on its software system. ë_Resident names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, Medicare numbers, medical diagnosis codes, payer names, and health insurance numbers may have been exposed. ë_The breach was discovered in March and Lutheran Social Services had not involved investigators or police as of May 9.

The theft of an employee's unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptop was stolen from an employee's car on April 9 and contained email records. ë_Patient names, medical record numbers, dates of birth, physician names, diagnoses, and dates of service may have been exposed.ë_

A reel containing images of 2,000 State of California Birth Records from May through September of 1974 was found in a publicly accessible location. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and certain types of medical information were in the birth record images. ë_People in Santa Clara, Santa Cruz, Shasta, Siskiyou, Solano, Sonoma, Stanislaus, Sutter, or Tehama counties and who were born or had a child born in 1974 between May and September were affected.

Some patients who were treated at an outpatient facility between May 1 of 2012 and January 31 of 2013 had their information attached to emails that went out to an unspecified organization or organizations. ë_Three emails that were not secure were sent on October 29 and November 1 of 2012 and February 4, 2013. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, account numbers, dates of birth, home phone numbers, and reasons for outpatient physical therapy services may have been exposed.

The theft of a surgeon's unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.UPDATE (07/6/2016): "The Department of Health and Human Services hit the University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC) with a $2.75 million fine over a health data breach, its second major privacy action in a week.The HHS Office for Civil Rights (OCR) is penalizing UMMC for a series of alleged privacy and security violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, also known as HIPAA. Theë_settlementë_relates to a password-protected laptop that went missing from the hospital_Ñés intensive care unit in March 2013. After an investigation, the medical center determined the computer was likely stolen by a visitor who had asked to borrow it."UPDATEë_(04/25/2013): The laptop was stolen from a surgeon's Hawaii rental home and was used for research purposes. ë_Any laptops used for patient care are required to be encrypted while laptops used for research are not required to be encrypted. ë_The laptop was used to access emails related to patient care such as patient names, medical record numbers, types of surgery and dates of surgery, times and locations of surgery, gender, age, and name of surgeon and anesthesiologist information. Nine patients had their Social Security numbers exposed.

A laptop used by UMMC clinicians was discovered missing on January 22. ë_The password-protected laptop contained information from patients who entered the hospital between 2008 and 2013. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, diagnoses, medications, treatments, dates of birth, and other personal information may have been exposed.UPDATE (7/26/2046): "The Department of Health and Human Services hit the University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC) with a $2.75 million fine over a health data breach, its second major privacy action in a week.The HHS Office for Civil Rights (OCR) is penalizing UMMC for a series of alleged privacy and security violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, also known as HIPAA. Theë_settlementë_relates to a password-protected laptop that went missing from the hospital_Ñés intensive care unit in March 2013. After an investigation, the medical center determined the computer was likely stolen by a visitor who had asked to borrow it."UPDATEë_(04/25/2013): The laptop may have been lost or stolen in November of 2012.ë_

Company: MedStar Good Samaritan Nursing Center, Mid America Health, Inc. (MAH)
Description of incident: A paper file was stolen from the car of a dental assistant who was treating residents at the MedStar Good Samaritan Nursing Center. ë_The file contained names, dates of birth, medical and dental evaluation information, medical and dental providers' names and license numbers, andë_the Social Security numbersë_of three residents.

The theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, residential facility names, and digital oral x-ray images may have been exposed. ë_Specific details of the case are being withheld until the breach investigation has concluded. ë_The location of the breach is listed as the corporate headquarters of MAH. ë_Those with questions or concerns may contact the MAH Compliance Department at 1-855-224-0004.

A former employee was indicted on charges related to misuse of applicant and employee personal information. ë_Employee names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, telephone numbers, email addresses, addresses, I-9 alien registration numbers, and other personal information may have been exposed. ë_The issue was discovered on April 3. ë_

A hack of Iberdrola USA's recruitment website may have exposed the information of anyone who applied for a job at Central Maine Power or any of its sister companies since January 2007. ë_Rochester Gas and Electric Corp and New York State Electric and Gas Corp. were also affected.
An unencrypted laptop was stolen from an employee's car. ë_It may have contained names, Social Security numbers, and personal information related to people who worked at OptiNose.

A media group who regularly collects public employee salary and benefit information released Social Security numbers after they were mistakenly included in a file that the City of Berkeley provided. ë_The information was sent by Berkeley in March and the mistake was discovered in early April. ë_Around 2,000 active staff members and 9,000 retirees were affected. ë_mistakenly released the Social Security numbers of the employees as well. ë_

An administrative error led to the personal information of 10,200 patients being emailed to 200 patients. ë_Names, addresses, date of last appointment, visit type, primary care physician, referring physician, email addresses, and whether or not the patient was actively receiving treatment were in an Excel attachment of an email that was sent to unspecified parties. The recipients were called and instructed to delete the email.

A flaw in Coinbase's systems cause the information of some merchants to be exposed. ë_Any merchant who created a "buy now" button, donate button, or hosted a payment page using Coinbase's Merchant Tools and posted a public link to it online had the page publicly visible on the internet. ë_The page contained the company name, website, phone number, email address, and mailing address. ë_Additionally, anyone could search for public Coinbase merchant payment pages and collect the email addresses of merchants. At least one phishing attack targeted merchants with an email that appeared to come from Coinbase.

El Centro Regional Medical Center is claiming that they were defrauded by an unnamed company. ë_The company was responsible for digitizing El Centro Regional's x-rays, but never returned the digitized version. ë_The process should have been completed by the end of July. ë_The original x-rays were most likely taken and destroyed to extract silver.UPDATEë_(05/18/2013): The information on the records was as recent as February 2011. ë_El Centro Regional Medical Center learned of the issue on March 22, 2013. ë_Patients were notified on May 13.

An administrative error caused the information of patients flown by Life Flight helicopters to be available online. ë_Patients flown during April, May, and June of 2004 may have had unspecified information exposed. ë_It was confirmed that 107 patients had their Social Security numbers exposed. ë_It is unclear how long the information was available and if patients flown during additional months may have been affected. ë_The information was moved to a secure server to address the breach.UPDATEë_(05/17/2013): The sensitive information was available online as early as October 12, 2009.
The March 20 loss of paper records may have exposed the information of patients. ZDI lost the records of their associate Delta Dental of Pennsylvania.

Company: Public Health - Seattle and King County
Description of incident: A custodian improperly disposed of client medical information on March 7. ë_The records were from the Refugee Screening, WIC, and Needle Exchange programs. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, phone numbers, addresses, medical record numbers, appointment dates, and medical condition or treatment may have been accessed.
The February 27 theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of patient information.

The March theft of radiology films resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The films were most likely stolen from the Hospital's storage room in order to be stripped of their silver. ë_The films contained patient names, medical record numbers, dates of exams, and in some cases, dates of birth. ë_The thieves posed as recycling subcontractors. ë_

Company: The Guidance Center of Westchester, Inc.
Description of incident: On February 22, 2013, the Guidance Center of Westchester discovered that a central processing unit (CPU) had been removed form a staff member's office. ë_The CPU was removed on February 21 and contained, names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, dates of admittance to the Center, names of insurance carriers, home addresses, diagnoses, outpatient treatment authorization request, doctors' names, case numbers, and whether or not a patient was prescribed medication.
The December 24, 2012 theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Company: Community Health Network, Community Health Medcheck
Description of incident: A dishonest employee of Community Health Medcheckë_accessed the medical records of up to 180 people between mid-March and mid-April. ë_Social Security numbers, dates of birth, credit card numbers, and other information may have been exposed.

A total of 55 current and former Weather Shield employees across the country discovered that someone had stolen their identities and filed fraudulent tax refunds. ë_Several employees who were victims of identity theft in 2012 discovered that they had been affected again when filing their taxes in April of 2013. It is unclear how the 2012 or 2013 breaches occurred.

Bloomberg News reporters were able to monitor clients' usage of data terminals leased from Bloomberg LP. ë_Goldman Sachs is one of the companies that has complained publicly while JP Morgan Chase, the Federal Reserve, and the United States Treasury Department have started investigations. It is unclear how many other organizations may have been affected. ë_Reporters may have routinely retrieved login and contact information from data-services clients over the past 20 years. ë_Some reporters had access to information on when and how often clients logged into their terminals, their most frequently used functions and contact information.

Company: Lifeline (Federal Communications Commission), TerraCom Inc., YourTel America Inc.
Description of incident: Around 44,000 application forms and 127,000 supporting documents for Lifeline were posted online. ë_Lifeline is a federal program that provides discount internet and phone service for low-income Americans. ë_Information such as name, Social Security number, scans of food-stamp cards, driver's licenses, tax records, pay stubs, and parole letters was available online. the information had been available since at least March and was removed April 26.UPDATEë_(05/23/2013): The story was originally released by Scripps Howard News Service when a reporter found completed Lifeline applications by searching Google for TerraCom-related information. ë_Terracom and Yourtel are threatening to hold Scripps accountable for costs associated with the breach. ë_These alleged costs include potentially complying with more than 20 state data breach notification laws.

An employee of Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) shared nonpublic voting data in exchange for $15,000 in concert tickets and $20,000 in meals. ë_From 2007 through early 2012 an ISS employee provided nonpublic information on how over 100 ISS clients were voting on proxy ballots to a firm that gathers shareholder votes. ë_ISS will pay The Securities and Exchange Commission $300,000 to settle civil charges and penalties. ë_ISS neither admitted nor denied Securities and Exchange Commission allegations that it violated financial adviser rules designed to prevent misuse of non-public consumer information.

Company: Department of Homeland Security (Customs and Border Protection, Immigration and Customs Enforcement)
Description of incident: Department of Homeland Security employees working in the headquarters office for Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Customs and Border Protection between 2009 and 2013 may have had their names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth exposed. ë_Tens of thousands of employees were affected. Though one or more unauthorized users had access to the information, there is no evidence that any employee data was stolen or lost. Law enforcement officials discovered a vulnerability in an unnamed vendor's system that is used for processing background investigations.

A dishonest employee working at University of Florida Health Pediatrics at Tower Square is suspected of participating in an identity theft ring. ë_The former employee had access to pediatric patient records that included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth. The University of Florida learned about the issue on April 11.

Company: Pocatello Family Medicine, Idaho State University
Description of incident: The firewall protecting computerized records was accidentally left inactive for nine months. ë_It was disabled during maintenance in August of 2010, but was never restored. ë_The problem was discovered when IT staff assisted an employee on May 18, 2011. ë_It appears that an electronic medical record for the clinic that was stored on the server was never accessed during that time. ë_Other information on the server included scanned images of drivers licenses and insurance cards. ë_There is also no evidence that these records were accessed, downloaded or printed. It does appear that someone downloaded movies and a television program onto the site in order to use the storage space and illegally sell access to the material. ë_UPDATEë_(05/22/2013): The information of 17,500 patients was exposed. ë_The Department of Health and Human Services released a resolution agreement on May 21 for HIPAA violations related to the breach. ë_The release can be found here:ë_http://www.hhs.gov/ocr/privacy/hipaa/enforcement/examples/isu-agreement.pdfUPDATEë_(05/30/2013): The University of Idaho agreed to pay $400,000 and upgrade security procedures in the settlement agreement.

Company: Bon Secours Hampton Roads Health System, Bon Secours Mary Immaculate Hospital
Description of incident: An April 2013 audit revealed that a patient's medical record had been accessed in a way that was inconsistent with hospital policy. ë_A further investigation revealed that two team members of the patient care team had accessed the records of multiple patients in ways that were inconsistent with their job function. ë_The employees were fired. ë_ Patient names, dates and times of service, provider and facility names, Social Security numbers, internal hospital medical records and account numbers, dates of birth, diagnosis, medications, vital signs, and other treatment information may have been accessed.
A hacking incident resulted in the exposure of 111 records. ë_Names, phone numbers, addresses, email addresses, and company names were exposed.

Company: Office of Dr. Lee D. Pollan, DMD, PC.
Description of incident: The theft of the doctor's laptop may have exposed patient information. ë_The theft occurred sometime between November 6, 2012 and November 15, 2012. ë_Information related to patient names, dates of birth, addresses, Social Security numbers, diagnose and surgery billing codes, dates of service, and person responsible for the billing was on the laptop. ë_
Stacks of patient and billing records were left in an unsecured and abandoned office in March of 2012. Credit card and Social Security numbers may have been exposed.

An April 12, 2012 office burglary resulted in the theft of a laptop with sensitive information. The computer assigned to the receptionist was stolen and contained a spreadsheet with client name, client status (active, discharged, etc.), internal client identification number, date of birth, and assigned staff person. ë_However the document was not labeled as a D.A.P. document. If someone saw the spreadsheet by itself they would not know it was linked to D.A.P.UPDATEë_(05/30/2013): Approximately 4,400 patients were affected.

Company: Hewlett, Packard, California Department of Social Services
Description of incident: Around 700,000 caregivers and care recipients had their information lost or stolen during transit between Hewlett Packard and the State Compensation Insurance Fund in Riverside, California. ë_A package that originally contained microfiche with payroll data entries and possibly other sensitive information arrived via U.S. Postal Service damaged and missing thousands of payroll data entries. Names, wages, Social Security numbers, and state identification numbers were exposed. A total of 375,000 In-Home Supportive Services workers were affected and 326,000 recipients of In-Home Supportive Services care were affected.UPDATEë_(05/30/2013): A total of 748,902 elderly home care recipients and their caretakers were affected.

An employee at North Los Angeles County Regional Center left a work laptop, a personal laptop, and an iPhone in their car overnight. The items were stolen during the night. ë_The employee worked for a program that served disabled infants and toddlers. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and other personal information were on the unencrypted work laptop. ë_The theft occurred in November and patients were notified in January of 2013.ë_
DENT Neurological Institute accidentally emailed the private information of more than 10,000 patients. ë_No sensitive medical files or Social Security numbers were involved.

Company: Erie County Department of Social Services
Description of incident: An audit revealed that several employees had not been following correct protocol for patient record disposal. ë_Employees had inadvertently exposed Social Security numbers, copies of birth certificates, personal medical records, tax returns, bank account information, inmate records, payroll information, court records, and passports. ë_Employees should have been using locked disposal totes for shredding and were discarding documents in recycling totes instead.

The information of almost 1,700 clients of the Center for Language, Speech, and Hearing may have been exposed. ë_A computer workstation was found to be infected by a malicious software program. ë_Client Social Security numbers, addresses, names of health insurers, and primary health care or referring doctors may have been accessible because the computer was compromised.UPDATE (11/22/2016): "The University of Massachusetts Amherst (UMass) has agreed to settle potential violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules.ë_ The settlement includes a corrective action plan and a monetary payment of $650,000, which is reflective of the fact that the University operated at a financial loss in 2015."More information: http://www.hhs.gov/about/news/2016/11/22/umass-settles-potential-hipaa-v...

Company: Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, MassMutual Financial Group
Description of incident: The 401(k) retirement plan information of certain clients was inadvertently exposed when a MassMutual account manager sent an email on May 8. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, investment elections, and account balances were included in the email. ë_A third party provider received the email and confirmed that the information was deleted without being saved or copied. The employee who accidentally sent the sensitive email received training on proper security procedures.

An independent contractor with access to Primedia's network operations group was found to have stolen hardware. ë_The issue was discovered on June 20, 2012. ë_Applicants, employees, and former employees may have had several different types of personal information stolen. Approximately 56,000 Social Security numbers were discovered among the various types of information. ë_Approximately 30,000 former employees, employees, and applicants were identified and notified of the breach. ë_The other 26,000 have yet to be identified.
