A hacker or hackers exploited a vulnerability in a third-party software and used it to access accounts on drupal.org.ë_The hackers were able to upload files to the association.drupal.org and compromised Drupal's serer.ë_Accounts on groups.drupal.org may have also been exposed. Usernames, email addresses, hashed passwords, and country information may have been exposed.

Anasazi Hotel learned that it was a common link in a number of fraudulent credit card activities. ë_An investigation revealed that Anasazi's network had been accessed and customer credit card information had been accessed. ë_Malware that could transmit customer names and credit card information was on Anasazi's system. ë_Anyone who used a credit card at Anasazi between June 18, 2012 and March 21, 2013 may have been affected.

The Target Marketing website was accessed by unauthorized parties on May 14. ë_People who used debit or credit cards on the online e-commerce platform may have had their names, email addresses, payment card numbers, expiration dates, and CVV codes accessed.UPDATEë_(05/29/2013): Shumsky in Dayton, Ohio was also affected. Shumsky customers may have had their names, addresses, email addresses, credit/debit card numbers, payment card expiration dates, and CVV codes accessed.

Hackers accessed Beachbody's Powder Blue website. Beachbody learned of the incident on April 17 and found that customer credit card numbers, email addresses, mailing addresses, telephone numbers, full names, and CVV numbers may have been accessed.

Hackers breached the servers of IHS and may have been able to access credit card, customer, and nuclear information. ë_IHS does not believe that confidential information was compromised. ë_However, the hacker group claimed to have obtained the records of 8,500 customers. The hacker group is known to attack sites in order to further their goal of revealing sensitive nuclear data to pressure the Israeli government and others into disclosing their nuclear activities.UPDATEë_(05/13/2013): The unauthorized parties acquired the relevant data from the IHS Jane's environment on or about November 22, 2012.
Unauthorized activity was detected on the 80sTees.com website. ë_Customers may have had their credit or debit card information exposed.

An unauthorized third party accessed Equity Trust Company's computer network. ë_The breach was discovered at the end of January 2013 and notification letters were sent on April 15. ë_Equity Trust customers may have had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and other information viewed by online intruders.

Sensitive documents could have been viewed electronically by authenticated users of the on-campus network. ë_The issue was discovered on February 27. Names, Social Security numbers, student identification numbers, and dates of birth may have been viewed by people who could log into Chapman's system, but shouldn't have been able to access the information.

A law enforcement employee made a clerical error that caused the Social Security numbers of 78 ambulance workers and beneficiaries to be available on the town website for five days. ë_The information was accidentally attached to a resolution. ë_A very similar error had occurred before and this one was caused by a failure to click on the "no public access" check box in the computer system to privatize the information.

Two men claimed to be from a recycling company and stole over 200 pounds of x-ray film that contained sensitive patient information. ë_The men transported the x-rays from the hospital without incident by using a moving truck. The breach occurred in 2012 and affected less than 500 patients.

The Orlando Police Department notified Wyndham Vacation Ownership that a Wyndham employee had been arrested for participating in fraudulent credit card purchases. ë_The dishonest employee was fired the next day and may have obtained customer credit card numbers. ë_Wyndham learned of the issue on January 18.

Between May 2 and May 8, a non-functional laptop computer was stolen from a secured area of the hospital. ë_The laptop was password protected and contained names, ages, medical record numbers, telephone numbers, scheduled surgical procedures, and names of physicians involved in procedures between 2009 and 2012. ë_

Optical shop consultation reports were placed in a publicly accessible recycling bin over a period of three months rather than properly disposed. ë_The documents contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and prescriptions. ë_The issue was discovered on April 17 and most likely started in January of 2013.

Company: Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford University
Description of incident: A former employee took a hospital desktop computer with patient records home around January 11 of 2010. In February it was determined that the computer could not be recovered and patients were notified of the incident.ë_ The hospital was fined $250,000 by the California Department of Public Health for the delay in reporting the incident. As of September 9 2010, the hospital was in the process of appealing the fine.UPDATE(9/10/10): The desktop did contain patient Social Security numbers, medical record numbers, names, insurance information, diagnoses and treatment information.

Records Breached: 167,000,000 (No SSNs or financial information). Updated as of 5/18/2016
Description of incident: A file containing 6,458,020 encrypted passwords was posted online by a group of hackers. It is unclear what other types of information were taken from Linkedin users. ë_LinkedIn recommends that users change their passwords.UPDATEë_(08/30/2012): Four potential class actions against LinkedInCorp. were consolidated. ë_The consolidated suits allege that LinkedIn violated its user agreement and privacy policy by failing to properly safeguard digitally stored user data. LinkedIn is also accused of not publicizing the attack in a timely manner.UPDATEë_(03/06/2013): A lawsuit that was filed in a federal court in San Jose, California in 2012 was dismissed. ë_The lawsuit was based on negligence claims, California consumer protection statutes, and breach of contract. The judge dismissed the lawsuit because the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that any alleged misrepresentation by Linkedinë_was connected to the harm the plaintiffs suffered.UPDATEë_(06/17/2013): A second class-action lawsuit against LinkedIn is in the making. ë_Linkedin is accused of of failing to use basic encryption techniques to secure personally identifiable information. ë_LinkedIn is trying to stop the second lawsuit form proceeding in federal court because the lead plaintiff has been able to show that she suffered an injury.UPDATE (05/23/2016): Cory Scott, LinkeIn's Chief Information Security Officer posted that the company was notified of additional emails and passwords compromised of more then 100 million members. More Information: http://fortune.com/2016/05/18/linkedin-data-breach-email-password/

Information on personal drug prescriptions from the Florida Department of Health somehow ended up in the hands of prosecution lawyers. ë_Names, addresses, phone numbers, pharmacies, and drug dosages were obtained by lawyers involved in six prescription-drug fraud cases. The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida began an investigation into how the records were exposed.

Hackers obtained police officer and non-police related civilian information from the Salt Lake City Police Department. ë_The attack was in response to a proposed Utah bill that would have criminalized the possession of graffiti tools with the intent to deface property. ë_The hackers did release the names, phone numbers, usernames, titles, email addresses, and hashed passwords of over 1,000 police officers. ë_The information of civilians was never released and the hackers eventually deleted their copies. ë_The never released data was from people who had provided crime tips or other information to the Salt Lake City Police Department.UPDATEë_(06/12/2013): A member of Anonymous was charged in 2012 for using SQL injections on multiple law enforcement and public agency websites. ë_He agreed to a plea bargain in April and will serve 36 months in prison for violating a section of federal law addressing computer fraud. ë_He will also pay nearly $230,000 in restitution to a number of agencies that were hacked.

Company: Adobe, Washington Administrative Office of the Courts
Description of incident: Up to 160,000 people may have had their information exposed by a breach. ë_Anyone who was booked into a city or county jail int he state of Washington between September of 2011 and December of 2012 may have had their Social Security number exposed.Additionally, three classes of people may have had their names and driver's license information exposed. ë_First, people who received a DUI citation between 1989 and 2011 in the state of Washington may have had their names and drivers' license numbers exposed. Anyone who had a traffic case filed or resolved in a district or municipal court between 2011 and 2012 may have been affected. Finally, anyone who had a criminal case in Washington filed against them or resolved between 2011 and 2012 may have had their name and driver's license number exposed.ë_

An employee inappropriately accessed patient information. ë_The incident or incidents were discovered on April 16. Patient clinical and other medical information may have been exposed. No Social Security numbers were exposed.

Yolo was notified by Visa that there may have been a breach at several merchant locations. ë_Yolo was not the sight of the breach, but customers were issued new payment cards. ë_The issue was reported to Yolo on May 31. ë_

Anyone who used Vendini for ticket purchases may have had their financial information exposed during a March breach. ë_A hacker accessed Vendini's server and may have obtained customer names, addresses, email addresses, credit card numbers, and credit card expiration dates. ë_A total of 22,900 customers from Augusta, Maine may have been affected. ë_It is unclear if people from other states were also affected.UPDATEë_(06/12/2013): The unauthorized intrusion was first detected on April 25. ë_

Two comScore panelists filed a lawsuit in August of 2011 after downloading comScore software. ë_Allegedly, comScore collected and sold consumers' Social Security numbers, credit card numbers, financial information, retail transactions, and other personal information. ë_The action may have violated the Stored Communications Act, the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, the Electronics Communications Privacy Act, and the Illinois Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Practices act. The lawsuit might cover tens of millions of people who have downloaded comScore software since 2005. ë_In June of 2013, the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago denied comScore's request to overturn a lower court's decision that had allowed the suit to proceed as a class action suit.

Two comScore panelists filed a lawsuit in August of 2011 after downloading comScore software. ë_Allegedly, comScore collected and sold consumers' Social Security numbers, credit card numbers, financial information, retail transactions, and other personal information. ë_The action may have violated the Stored Communications Act, the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act, the Electronics Communications Privacy Act, and the Illinois Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Practices act. The lawsuit might cover tens of millions of people who have downloaded comScore software since 2005. ë_In June of 2013, the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals in Chicago denied comScore's request to overturn a lower court's decision that had allowed the suit to proceed as a class action suit.

After breaking into FIS's network and gaining access to FIS's database, a group of criminals obtained 22 legitimate ATM cards. ë_Copies of the cards were made and shipped to Greece, Russia, Spain, Sweden, Ukraine and the United Kingdom. ë_The criminals altered the cards so that they could be used to withdraw an unlimited amount of cash. ë_A total of $13 million was taken from accounts between the evening of Saturday March 5 and Sunday evening.UPDATEë_(06/04/2013): An additional 7,170 pre-paid accounts may have been at risk. ë_It appears that approximately 100 client financial institutions also had sensitive data exposed during the breach.

Facebook discovered a bug that may have allowed unauthorized users to view the personal contact information of Facebook users. ë_The people who could have used the information would have had some kind of connection to them or some kind of contact information, but users may have thought their email and phone numbers were hidden from these connections. ë_People who used the Download Your Information (DYI) tool may have been able to access the contact information. ë_The issue was discovered by an external group of security researches involved with the White Hat program. The breach began sometime in 2012.

During the weekend of June 3, a hard drive was discovered to have been misplaced. ë_The device had been left unattended in a computer lab for about two days in March. ë_The hard drive contained names, Social Security numbers, and other information related to admissions and financial aid for the Fall 2010 through the February 2013 school terms. ë_Some graduate and continuing professional studies students may have also been affected.
The April 27 office burglary of two password-protected laptops resulted in the exposure of sensitive client information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and addresses may have been involved. ë_

A code change in the prepaid cardholder website impacted the security features that authenticate cardholder logins. ë_Anyone who logged into the prepaid cardholder website between June 2 and June 13 was affected. ë_The issue was remediated and it does not appear that unauthorized charges have occurred on any of the affected accounts.

Company: Lakeshore Mental Health Institute, Middle Tennessee Mental Health Institute
Description of incident: Patient records were found on the floor at an abandoned hospital building named Waterside. ë_The woman who discovered them was a former Lakeshoreë_employee and she alerted a local news station. ë_Names, Social Security information, case numbers, dates of birth, and other patient information were exposed.UPDATEë_(06/27/2013): At least 20 boxes of patient records were found in an abandoned building at the Clover Bottom Campus of the Middle Tennessee Mental Health Institute. ë_The records dated back to the 1980's and had been reviewed to confirm which had sensitive information that needed to be destroyed.

Company: Baptist Health South Florida, West Kendall Baptist Hospital
Description of incident: An employee of West Kendall Baptist Hospital sold patient information to a man who used the information to file fraudulent tax returns. ë_Patients may have had their names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth exposed. ë_The man who purchased and used the information was sentenced to 31 months in federal prison after pleading guilty to possessing 15 or more Social Security numbers.

Company: North Lincoln Community Health Center Clinic
Description of incident: An April 17 burglary resulted in the possible exposure of patient information. ë_Someone entered locked rooms and cabinets in order to take money. ë_No records or electronic devices were taken; however the room where client medical charts were stored was accessed. ë_Social Security numbers, health information, and other personal information may have been exposed.

The May 7 home burglary of an employee's home resulted in the theft of a laptop that contained patient information. ë_Fewer than 60% of the affected members had their names, zip codes, and Independence Care System (ICS) Member ID numbers exposed. ë_Approximately 40% of those affected also had their street address, phone number, Medicaid ID number, and enrollment and/or disenrollment date exposed. ë_ICS plans to implement a two-factor authentication system for network access by September of 2013 to prevent the issued from occurring again.

A counselor's file cabinet was burglarized sometime between December 10 and December 21. ë_It contained client files with names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, diagnosis, treatment information, insurance information, and emergency contact information.

On April 14, 2013 staff members discovered that their location had been burglarized. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, diagnosis information, types of treatments, classes attended, court information, services provided, or insurance information of persons served by the location could have been accessed during the burglary. ë_Notifications were sent during the week of May 20.ë_

Company: Integrity Oncology, Baptist Medical Group, North Atlantic Telecom
Description of incident: Integrity Oncology's business associate North Atlantic Telecom discovered a breach incident on March 5. ë_
A laptop that contained protected health information was lost between the dates of April 4 and April 19. ë_

The April theft of a faculty laptop resulted in the exposure of current and former student information. ë_The laptop was stolen from a locked room in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. ë_It contained a file with the names, emails, and Social Security numbers of up to 6,300 University of South Carolina students who had taken one of four physics courses between January of 2010 and the fall 2012 semester.

Greensboro ABC stores and Triad ABC stores discovered that the software used by cash registers had been hacked. ë_The malware was discovered after customers complained about fraudulent charges on their debit and credit card accounts. ë_The ABC stores stopped accepting credit and debit cards while investigating the issue.

A laptop and portable hard drive were stolen from the truck of an undercover officer in March of 2013. ë_The devices were not encrypted and contained Social Security numbers, drivers license numbers, and personal information about victims, suspects, witnesses, and police officers. The officer received disciplinary action for leaving the laptop unattended in the backseat of a truck.

Company: Gulf Breeze Family Eyecare (Sight and Sun Eyeworks Gulf Breeze)
Description of incident: Sight and Sun learned of a patient privacy breach on May 17. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, medical record numbers, and other personal information may have been exposed. ë_An employee accessed and copied patients' electronic medical records without legitimate purpose.UDPATEë_(06/26/2013): A total of 9,000 patients were affected. ë_It appears that the records were accessed to target patients for other medical service offerings.

Company: Florida State University, Florida Department of Education
Description of incident: The information of 47,000 Florida teachers was publicly accessible for 14 days after a data transfer at Florida State University. ë_The information was from teachers participating in state prep programs. ë_The Department of Education used Florida State University as the contractor for the transfer of teacher data.UPDATEë_(06/26/2013): People who participated in Florida teacher preparation programs during the 2009 -2010 and 2011-2012 academic years were affected.
Client information may have been compromised by an intrusion that took place around April 3. ë_Client email addresses, passwords, credit card numbers, and other information may have been exposed.

Company: Indiana Family and Social Services Administration (FSSA), RCR Technology Corporation
Description of incident: A computer programming glitch resulted in the exposure of client health, financial, and employment information. ë_Personal and private documents that belonged to certain clients were accidentally made available to other clients between April 6 and May 21 when FSSA contractor RCR Technology Corporation made a programming error. ë_The issue was discovered on May 10 and addressed on May 21. ë_Patients of clients may have had their names, addresses, dates of birth, demographic information, contact information, types of benefits received, monthly benefit amount, employer information, monthly income and expenses, bank balances and other assets, medical providers, medical conditions, and information about household members exposed.

Malware infected an employee's desktop computer. ë_Roy's restaurants in Ko'Olina, Waikiki, Kaanapali, Poipu, and Waikoloa were affected. ë_Anyone who used a debit or credit card at those locations between February, 1, 2013 and February 25, 2013 may have had their payment card information compromised.

Company: Texas Health Harris Methodist Hospital Fort Worth, Shred-it
Description of incident: A concerned citizen alerted police to a situation on May 11. ë_Old microfiche records were discovered in a park even though they should have been destroyed by the Hospital's contractor Shred-it. ë_The records contained names, addresses, dates of birth, and health information and were from 1980 to 1990. Some records also contained Social Security numbers. ë_

An unauthorized individual accessed the network of a BAR service provider between May 2012 and March 2013. ë_The bank routing information of Smog Check stations licensed with the BAR was exposed. ë_Those who may have had their accounts accessed are encouraged to close their old accounts and open new accounts with new PINs or passwords.UPDATEë_(07/11/2013): Approximately 7,500 Smog Check stations had bank account and routing numbers associated with the businesses exposed.

Company: Guildford County Schools, Page High School
Description of incident: A Guildford County Schools employee accidentally emailed a PDF file that contained Page High School student personal information. ë_Student names, addresses, phone numbers, course enrollments, grades, school district identification numbers, and other transcript data were in the PDF file. The information was emailed to a single guardian on July 2, 2013.

More than 200,000 Anthem Blue Cross customers this week received letters informing them that their personal information might have been accessed during a security breach of the company's website. Only customers who had pending insurance applications in the system are being contacted because information was viewed through an on-line tool that allows users to track the status of their application. Social Security and credit card numbers were potentially viewed.ë_ Anthem Blue Cross merged with WellPoint in 2004.UPDATE (6/29/2010): Around 470,000 customers in 10 states were notified of the breach.ë_ The original story states that only applicants were affected, but existing customers also received notification of a possible breach of their information.UPDATE (7/12/2010): 20,000 Louisville, Kentucky residents received notification that a security mistake online resulted in the exposure of their Social Security numbers and financial information.ë_ It is unclear whether these residents are included in the original 470,000 customers.ë_ Only customers who were self insured were affected. WellPoint is claiming that this and other recent breaches were committed by an attorney or attorneys attempting to gain information for a lawsuit against WellPoint.UPDATE (9/17/2010): An Anthem applicant whose information was exposed by the breach filed a lawsuit against Anthem at the Los Angeles County Superior Court. The lawsuit claims that the breach exposed applicants and clients to identity theft.ë_ An applicant behind the lawsuit is seeking class action status.UPDATE (10/29/2010): The office of the Attorney General of Indiana is suing WellPoint Inc. because of the company's delay in notifying customers of the breach. WellPoint is accused of violating an Indiana law that requires 
businesses to provide notification of breaches in a timely manner and 
faces $300,000 in fines.ë_ State officials believe WellPoint was aware of the exposure in late February, but waited until June to notify customers.ë_UPDATEë_(7/5/2011): WellPoint Inc. will pay Indiana a $100,000 settlement for violating a 2009 data breach notification law. ë_Customer data was accessible between October 23, 2009 and March 8, 2010. ë_One or more consumers informed WellPoint of the problem on February 22, 2010 and again on March 8, 2010. ë_WellPoint began notifying consumers on June 18, 2010.UPDATEë_(07/13/2013): About 612,000 individuals may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, telephone numbers, health information, and other electronic protected health information exposed. ë_WellPoint paid HHS $1.7 million in fines. ë_

Patients who visited emergency departments of three Central Florida county Florida Hospitals between January 1, 2010 and August 15, 2011 may have had their information improperly accessed by one or more employees. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and insurance information were exposed. ë_Several employees were fired for misconduct, but one employee was fired for viewing patient information without authorization for the purpose of identifying motor vehicle accident victims. ë_The hospital launched an investigation after a car-accident victim felt that a soliciting attorney had somehow obtained his medical information.UPDATE (10/19/2011): The FBI is now investigating the disclosure of patient information.ë_ It appears that three employees sold accident victim data to an attorney referral service.ë_ Former patients have also been contacted by funeral homes and at least one patient became an identity theft victim.UPDATEë_(08/18/2012): One dishonest employee who worked at Florida Hospital Celebration allegedly viewed the emergency room records of 763,000 patients. A total of 12,000 patients from the group of 763,000 were contacted by the Hospital and notified of the risk of identity theft.UPDATEë_(10/22/2012): The former employee worked at Florida Hospital from July 2006 until July 2011 and was responsible for registering emergency patients. ë_The scam involved patient phone referrals to a lawyer or chiropractor who knew details about car accidents and hospital treatments. The dishonest employee had illegally gathered the patient information during emergency visits. He pleaded guilty to conspiracy to obtain health information and wrongful disclosure of health information.ë_UPDATEë_(01/07/2013): A man associated with Metro Chiropractic and Wellness Center and City Lights Medical Center pleaded guilty to charges related to illegally obtaining patient information from two spouses who worked at Florida Hospital Celebration. He was charged with one count of conspiracy to defraud the United States and four counts of makingë_a payment to a non-licensed physician.UPDATEë_(04/12/2013): One former patient affected by the breach has brought a lawsuit against Adventist Health System/Sunbelt, Inc. ë_Florida Hospital Celebration and 36 other hospitals compose the Adventist network. The former patient is alleging that their privacy rights as a patient were violated when Adventist Health System/Sunbelt Inc. failed to prevent emergency room works from selling access to their medical records.UPDATEë_(07/12/2013): The lawsuit that was filed in April was dismissed by a judge on July 3. Another lawsuit was then filed in Orange County Circuit Court in Orlando.

Patients who received treatment between September 2012 to June 2013 may have had their information exposed by a breach related to an employee. ë_Names, sex, dates of birth, home addresses, phone numbers, account numbers, insurance information, and the reason for admission were exposed. ë_There is currently no reason to believe that the information was used in a malicious manner.

Company: Office of the Medicaid Inspector General (OMIG)
Description of incident: An OMIG employee sent an email that contained sensitive records to their own email account on October 12, 2012. ë_Medicaid paitient first and last names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and Medicaid client information numbers may have been compromised.ë_

The City of Akron's website and internal systems were hacked by a foreign group. ë_Files with 47,452 entries were posted online. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, account numbers, credit card numbers, credit card expiration dates, addresses, and other information were in the files. ë_The hacking attack appears to be part of an organized international effort to hack into various U.S. government websites.

A number of inappropriate security practices may have exposed the information of people who called Monroeville's 911 dispatch center, police department, fire department, or EMS department in 2012 or 2013. ë_Monroeville is being investigated for possible violations of federal health privacy laws. ë_An August 2012 complaint to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' Office for Civil Rights stated that protected health information may have been given to a former police chief via email and that weak and poorly managed usernames and passwords were used to access a database of 911 callers' medical information.UPDATEë_(07/18/2013): Monroeville 911 records from August 2010 through February 2013 were available to volunteer firefighters and former and inacitive emergency responders. ë_There was no protocol in place for removing the former personnel from the list of people who received 911 dispatch data.

A dishonest hospital employee misused patient records that were dated from June 2011 to February of 2012. ë_Patients may have had their names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth exposed.UPDATEë_(03/15/2013): A respiratory therapist provided Social Security numbers, dates of birth, patient names, and other patient data in exchange for payment. The patient data was then used to file fraudulent tax returns. ë_The dishonest employee now faces charges for selling the information to two others.UPDATEë_(04/26/2013): Two women who purchased patient information from a Hospital employee were sentenced for their roles in the breach. ë_One woman was sentenced to 26 years and five months in federal prison in addition to being ordered to pay over $1.9 million in restitution. ë_She was convicted of 33 fraud and identity theft charges in January. ë_The other was sentenced to 10 years and one month in prison after pleading guilty to conspiracy to defraud the government and aggravated identity theft. ë_The fraud ring produced fraudulent income tax refunds totalling $11.7 million.UPDATEë_(07/18/2013): A respiratory therapist who engaged in the theft of patient information between June of 2011 and February of 2012 pleaded guilty. ë_She faces up to seven years in federal prison and is scheduled to receive a lightened sentence for cooperating with authorities in the investigation of the tax fraud ring's leaders.

Public.Resource.org received 990-T forms with sensitive information during a request for information from the IRS. ë_The IRS acknowledged the mistake and Public.Resource.org became curious about where else the information could be found. ë_Public.Resource.org found multiple incidents of Social Security numbers being exposed on the IRS website and wrote a letter that pointed out the issues to the IRS. ë_The IRS was able to remove some or all of the sensitive files from public view over the course of a few days.

Apple's website for developers was accessed by unauthorized parties. ë_Registered developer names, mailing addresses, and email addresses may have been accessed on Thursday, July 18. ë_Encrypted customer information was not affected.

Company: University of Virginia, Aetna Health Care
Description of incident: A mailing error by a third-party mailing vendor used by Aetna Health Care resulted in the Social Security numbers of students being exposed in open-enrollment brochures.

Hackers were able to steal passwords from a NASDAQ Community forum. ë_It is likely that only passwords ë_and non-financial inforimation was stolen. ë_NASDAQ alerted users to the issue and took the website offline to upgrade its security. ë_There is concern that the hackers will use the email and password information to send phishing messages and obtain access to various financial accounts.

A computer vulnerability allowed the information of students, student families, and other people affiliated with the University to be exposed. The records covered a 13 year period and included Social Security numbers. ë_High school students who had associations with the University may have had their SAT scores exposed as well. ë_The issue existed between April 2009 and September 2012. ë_

A warehouse that was not owned by Henry Ford Health System was raided for old X-rays. ë_X-rays can be stripped for silver and these medical X-rays also contained the names, addresses, and dates of birth of patients of Henry Ford Health System. ë_The X-rays dated between 1996 and 2003. ë_Henry Ford Health System learned about the issue on May 24.

Company: William Jennings Bryan Dorn VA Medical Center
Description of incident: The February 11 theft of an unencrypted laptop from the respiratory department resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Veterans who were patients may have had their name, Social Security number, age, race, weight, and medical test results on the laptop. ë_The laptop was taken during regular clinic hours.UPDATEë_(05/01/2013): A lawsuit has been filed by two veterans on behalf of people who were affected by the breach.UPDATEë_(07/22/2013): The Dorn VA has motioned to dismiss the case. ë_On July 16 the Dorn VA said that it has not been proven that the records were improperly disclosed. It also argued that the plaintiffs never asserted that the records had been shown to another or unauthorized person.

NYC Bike Share discovered that customer credit card numbers, names, and addresses had been posted on a publicly accessible page of its website. ë_The glitch was corrected after being active between April 15 and late May. ë_Customers who initially entered their information incorrectly had their information posted online for 24 hours. ë_The data was cleared every 24 hours between April 15 and late May.

Malware was installed on servers between November of 2008 and October of 2010. ë_This allowed one or more hackers to execut commands to delte, change, and steal data from the computers used by NASDAQ. ë_A total of five foreign hackers were charged for involvement in a series of financial incidents. ë_They were all collaborating in a scheme to target major corporate networks and were able to steal more than 160 million credit card numbers across corporations.

Citigroup exposed the Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and other sensitive information of customers by not properly redacting the information for court records. ë_Consumers who went into bankruptcy between 2007 and 2011 were affected. ë_The incident was discovered by the bank on April 2011. ë_Roughly 146,000 consumers were notified of the breach in July of 2013.

Tinder advertises to users that their physical location information is never shown to other users. ë_An outside engineer discovered an issue with the Tinder app that allowed the locations of users to be available for at least two weeks. ë_Last known locations, Facebook IDs, dates of birth, gender, and names were available. ë_

Tinder advertises to users that their physical location information is never shown to other users. ë_An outside engineer discovered an issue with the Tinder app that allowed the locations of users to be available for at least two weeks. ë_Last known locations, Facebook IDs, dates of birth, gender, and names were available. ë_

Records Breached: 2,000 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The July 15 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of student information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the car of a school nurse and contained school, health and other confidential information. ë_Student names, school identification numbers, allergies, and other medical conditions were on a spreadsheet on the health-department-issued laptop.

During a credit card fraud scheme, a man obtained and misused customer information. ë_His scheme involved using customer information to impersonate customers and open new lines of store credit in their names.ë_ë_Total loses amounted to $781,571.80.

Two men were indicted for their role in a skimming plot. ë_They are accused of fraudulently obtaining $400,000 by placing skimming devices at gas pumps at Wal-Mart stores for up to two months at a time. ë_The then created counterfeit cards by using hte legitimate card information obtained through skimming. ë_The skimming ring ran from April 2012 through January 2013.

People who used Stanford University's computer network have been asked to reset their passwords. Stanford released few details but stated that it does not appear that Social Security numbers and financilai nformation were accessed or exposed.

Patient data could have been accessed due to a storage error. ë_The information of patients admitted between January 2011 and July 3 of 2013 was placed on Google's cloud computing system. ë_The information was password-protected, but could have still been used for promotional and other purposes because OHSU does not have a contract with Google. ë_OSHU removed the information from the cloud.

A July 8 letter warned current and former employees that SEC employee data had been found on the networks of another federal agency. ë_The outside federal agency was not named. It appears that a former SEC employee inadvertently and unknowingly downloaded the names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth of SEC employees onto a thumb drive and then transferred them to another agency. ë_The employee wanted a template of the document rather than the actual employee data that it contained. ë_The accidental upload of sensitive information occured in April of 2012 and again in June of either 2012 or 2013. ë_Employees who were with SEC before October of 2009 were affected. The breach lasted for 10 months before being noticed. The SEC confiscated the flash drive when the breach was uncovered.

After being alerted by Visa and MasterCard of suspicious activity surrounding processed card transactions, the company last week found evidence of malicious software that compromised card data that crossed Heartland's network. This incident may be the result of a global cyberfraud operation. UPDATE (01/26/2009): Heartland Payment Systems has been sued. The lawsuit seeks damages and relief for the inexplicable delay, questionable timing, and inaccuracies concerning the disclosures with regard to the data breach, which is believed to be the largest in U.S. history. UPDATEë_(02/12/2009): According to BankInfoSecurity.com, the number of financial institutions that have come forward to say they have been contacted by their credit card companies Visa and MasterCard in relation to the breach has jumped from fewer than 50 to more than 200. UPDATE (06/04/2009): While it's hard to get a handle on just how many consumers were affected by the Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) data breach, the total number of institutions now reporting card compromises is at 656. UPDATE (06/16/2009): Heartland lawsuits to be heard in Texas. The Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation in Louisville, KY issued its decision to consolidate the class action suits. The lawsuits will be heard in the Southern District Court of Texas in Houston. Thirty-one separate lawsuits, on behalf of consumers, investors, banks and credit unions, have been filed against Princeton,N.J.-based Heartland. UPDATE (07/06/2009): Heartland Payment Systems successfully completed the first phase of an end-to-end encryption pilot project designed to enhance its security. UPDATE (08/20/2009): Albert Segvec Gonzalez has been indicted by a federal grand jury in New Jersey - along with two unnamed Russian conspirators - on charges of hacking into Heartland Payment Systems, the New Jersey-based card processing company, as well as Hannaford Brothers, 7-Eleven and two unnamed national retailers, according to the indictment unsealed Monday. Gonzalez, a former Secret Service informant, is already awaiting trial over his involvement in the TJX hack.Total records breached: 100 million transactions per month. It is unclear how many account numbers have been compromised, and how many are represented by multiple transactions. The number of records breached is an estimate, subject to revision. UPDATE (08/20/2009): According to the court document, hackers stole more than 130 million credit and debit card numbers from Heartland and Hannaford combined.UPDATE (05/12/2010): The costs to Heartland Payment Systems Inc. from the massive data breach that it disclosed in January 2009 appear to be steadily adding up. Quarterly financial results released by Heartland last week show that the card payment processor has accrued $139.4 million in breach-related expenses. The figure includes a settlement totaling nearly $60 million with Visa, another of about $3.5 million with American Express and more than $26 million in legal fees. That total also includes $42.8 million that Heartland has set aside to fund proposed settlements with several other litigants over the breach. One example of what the fund is set up for is Heartland's offer to settle several consumer class action lawsuits against it for four million. So far, Heartland has recovered about $30 million from insurance companies.UPDATE (06/02/2010): Heartland Payment Systems has made a third settlement deal, this time with MasterCard, related to a massive data breach two years ago at the card payments processor. As part of the deal, Heartland has agreed to pay as much as US$41.1 million to MasterCard issuers that lost money as a result of the data breach. The deal is contingent on financial institutions representing 80 percent of the affected MasterCard accounts accepting the offer by June 25. MasterCard is recommending that issuers accept the offer.UPDATE (09/01/2010): Heartland Payment Systems has agreed to settle with Discover for five million dollars.ë_ Discover will use the money to cover costs of fraud incidents and reissuing cards.UPDATE (09/19/2010): Jerome Abaquin Gonzales is expected to surrender to police and serve jail time for participating in a credit card forgery ring which used information from the Heartland breach.ë_ The information came from the 4.2 million Discover credit card customers who used their cards at Hannaford Brothers.UPDATE (09/22/2010): Thomas Michio Taniguchi was sentenced to prison for his role in the forgery ring in which Jerome Abaquin Gonzales also participated.UPDATE (12/07/2011): Heartland legal representatives were able to successfully argue that most of the claims against Heartland that were filed by nine banks should be dismissed. All but one claim was dismissed.UPDATEë_(02/12/2012): The nine banks may have had their claims against Heartland dismissed because Heartland reported that sharing a contractual relationship with the banks defeats their appeal. However, the credit-card-issuing banks are arguing that a New Jersey economic loss rule only bars claims for foreseeable economic losses when the parties are in a contractual relationship and does not bar their negligence claim against Heartland.UPDATEë_(07/25/2013): Five more foreign hackers were charged for their role in stealing information from Heartland Payment Systems, NASDAQ, Dow Jones, JetBlue, and J.C. Penney.

Current and former members may have had their Social Security numbers, transaction records, and other personal information exposed due ot malware that was found on an employee's office computer. ë_The malware was discovered on May 26 and St. Mary's began mailing letters on July 12. ë_The malware could have been on up to 23 work stations as early as February. ë_There has been no evidence of names, Social Security numbers, addresses, account numbers, transaction records, or other sensitive information being accessed by an unauthorized individual so far.

Two backup tapes containing personal information have gone missing.  The hospital does not suspect theft and does believe that there is a very low probability that the personal information on the tapes can be misused.  However, credit monitoring services are being offered to those who were affected.  The hospital gave up looking for the tapes on May 7th and began notifying patients in late June.ë_ Per phone interview with University Hospital, Social Security number were involved but they are unaware of any financial data involved in this breach.

A third-party mailing error resulted in the exposure of patient health information. ë_Billing statements with names, dates of service, insurance information, billing information, and financial status were mailed to incorect addresses.

An employee in the billing department was fired for sending sensitive patient information to their personal email. The incident occurred in June and it does not appear that the email was sent with malicious intent.

A programming error at Advanced Data Processing (ADP) caused employee names, Social Security numbers, and total taxable W-2 wages for the tax years 2010, 2011, and 2012 to be exposed. ë_A group of other US Airway employees were able to download the payroll information of their colleagues. ë_ADP corrected the issue in early May and notified US Airways in early June.

An individual contact Godiva sometime around April 15 and informed them that a flash drive with Godiva employee information had been found. ë_The information included employee ID numbers, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, phone numbers, resumes, and photos for people who worked at or applied to Godiva sometime prior to August 5, 2010. ë_The flash drive was once used by an employee with access to human resources data and an investigation revealed that there was nor eason to suspect that the information had been misused. ë_A total of 2,638 California residents may have been affected. It is not clear how many people were affected nationwide.

Company: Auburn University - School of Forestry and Wildlife Sciences
Description of incident: Spreadsheets with donor and alumni information were accidentally uploaded to a publicly accessible server after an administrative error. ë_The error was discovered on June 19 and Auburn's IT office removed the information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, maiden names, mailing addresses, first year at Auburn, graduation year, alumni status, email addresses, and phone numbers were exposed.

A candidate for student body president was accused of tampering with University computers in order to access student ID numbers and passwords. ë_The information could have been used to alter election results. ë_The University isolated and monitored the compromised accounts and rescheduled the election. ë_The student was arrested in March on suspicion of election fraud, identity theft, and unlawful access to a computer. ë_The student was released and no chargers were filed.UPDATEë_(04/20/2012): The student was first arrested after allegedly being caught with a password stealing device at a campus computer.UPDATEë_(03/22/2013): The student pleaded guilty to wire fraud, access device fraud, and unauthorized use of a computer. He faces between 27 and 33 months in federal custody.UPDATEë_(08/06/2013): The former student received a one-year sentence and is scheduled for a restitution hearing on August 12.

US Airways customers with Divident Miles accounts may have had their information compromised. ë_Dates of birth, security question answers, last four digits of credit card numbers, and frequent-flier miles may have been accessed and compromised.UPDATEë_(08/02/2013): Names, email addresses, and Known Traveler numbers were exposed. ë_in some cases mileage was stolen from the accessed accounts.

A number of member identification cards were mailed to incorrect addresses. ë_The problem occurred because of a programming error. ë_The member identification cards contained names, dates of enrollment, addresses, telephone numbers of primary care physicians, issue dates of cards, and Medi-Cal client identification numbers. ë_

Company: South Central Los Angeles Regional Center
Description of incident: The July 6 theft of an employee's vehicle resulted in the exposure of client information. ë_The stolen car contained an Ipad with client names and UCI numbers. ë_

Current and former Oracle employees may have had their 401(k) information viewed by a plan administrator at the firm of another Fidelity client. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, compensation, and other 401(k) savings and investmant plan information was briefly viewed by accident. ë_The issue was discovered on July 10, 2013. ë_

An employee lost dental records while outside of California Correctional Health Care Services on June 19, 2013. ë_The records contained patient names, CDCR numbers, dates of birth, and dental treatment plan information.

An employee error caused patient information from surgeries to appear on the internet. ë_Names, dates of service, procedures, surgeons, hospital charges, and names of insurance companies were accidentally uploaded. ë_The breach occurred on February 14 and was discovered on April 17. ë_UPDATEë_(07/10/2013): Surgical services covering information from July 1, 2011 to June 30, 2012 was posted on the Sonoma Valley Hospital website.

A credit card breach resulted in the exposure of information. Customers who made online purchases at Quayside Publishing Group had their information exposed sometime around April 29. ë_Names, addresses, and credit card numbers were exposed until June 17.

Company: Michigan Department of Community Health, Michigan Cancer Consortium
Description of incident: A server for the Michican Cancer Consortium that housed names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, cancer screening test results, and testing dates was hacked. ë_The Michigan Department of Community Health claimed that the breach should not fall under strict HIPAA regulations because testing records, rather than medical records, were affected.

Company: Income and Capital Growth Strategies Inc.
Description of incident: An employee was the target of a computer network intrustion sometime between July 12 and July 15. ë_Information about clients and their dependents may have also been exposed. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, drivers' license numbers, and bank account information may have been accessed. ë_

The theft of one or more pieces of company electronic equipment exposed client information. ë_The theft was discovered on July 30 and names, Social Security numbers, financial account numbers, addresses, and dates of birth may have been exposed.

Records Breached: 757 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: Health information stored on a computer server was accidentally made available to the public online between August and September of 2011. ë_Patients who were seen by a former faculty member of the school were affected because of a configuration error that occurred on August 12. ë_The issue was discovered on September 9 and had been corrected by September 10. ë_Patients seen by a certain doctor between January of 2007 and June of 2011 at clinics in Carmel and Indianapolis, Indiana were affected. ë_Some hospital inpatients seen between August 2007 and August 2008 were also affected.

Thousands of current and former Baltimore City employees are at risk after a box was found with Baltimore City personnel information. ë_Records been discarded in a publicly accessible place for trash. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, drivers' license information, and other vital and personal employee information was contained in the records. The Department of Public Works obtained the box of information and is attempting to contact people based on lists of class attendants that were among the records.

The information of current and former Harris County employees was found on electronic files in Vietnam. ë_Names, Social Security numers, and dates of birth were exposed. ë_The files were from 2005 and 2007 and appear to have been created before Harris County put in place stricter identity theft regulations.

Records Breached: 3,700 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The health information of disabled patients was accidnetally released in an email on the night of August 19. ë_A survey was sent via email to supporters of HCR. The email also contained names, dates of birth, guardians and parents, addresses, and other patient information.

Anyone with an Emory University netID/username is being advised to change their account password due to a breach. ë_Emory University stated that it appears the attack on their information technology infrastructure is similar to attacks that similar organizations have seen in the past few months. ë_Emory University also stated that it does not appear that sensitive information was accessed. ë_

Company: United States Federal Reserve, Grand Banks Yachts
Description of incident: The hacking group known as Anonymous claimed responsibility for a hack of the Alabama Criminal Justice Center and indicated that they had access to US Federal Reserve servers. Some internal documents were also exposed. ë_The hack attack was a response to the US Federal Reserve's reaction, or failure to react, to the February 4 hack of the Alabama Criminal Justice Center. ë_Anonymous released a document showing that they had extensive access to US Federal Reserve servers and internal documents. ë_Anonymous hacked into the Grand Banks Yachts website and used it to host a file that contained the document.UPDATEë_(08/23/2013): Federal Reserve employee data was posted on a website. ë_Phone numbers, emails, and other Federal Reserve employee information was placed on a publicly accessible spreadsheet. ë_Anonymous claims to have full details of every Federal Reserve Bank of America employee. ë_The information may have been from the breach in February. ë_

Blizzard's security team found an unauthorized party or parties had accessed the Blizzard internal network. ë_Blizzard immediately addressed the security issue and found no evidence that credit card, billing address, or name information had been accessed. Players using North American servers may have had scrambled versions of Battle.net passwords, answers to personal security questions, and information relating to Mobile and Dial-In Authenticators accessed. ë_Users are encouraged to change their passwords immediately and to change the passwords of other accounts if they are similar to the compromised Battle.net passwords. ë_A list of email addresses for global Battle.net users outside of China was also accessed.UPDATEë_(11/12/2012): Two people have filed a suit alleging that Blizzard's $6.50 protection charge is inadequate and that Blizzard did not take the necessary measures required to secure the private information of customers that was stored online. The lawsuit also alleges that Blizzard continues to fail to disclose to consumers that additional security products must be acquired after buying games in order to ensure that information stored in online accounts is secured.UPDATEë_(07/11/2013): The U.S. District Court for the Central District of California dismissed most of the claims that were brought against Blizzard Entertainment.UPDATEë_(08/23/2013): At least six out of eight claims from the lawsuit against Blizzard have been dismissed. ë_Blizzard still faces litigation for failing to fully disclose the importance of an authenticator to users.

An administrative employee sent the names and Social Security numbers of 500 Hill Air Force Base employees to a personal email account. The administrative employee planned to finish a project at home but transferring the information to an unprotected email address may have resulted in the exposure of information. The employee's actions were against Hill Air Force Base policy.

Affinity Health Plan, a New York managed care service, is notifying more than 400,000 current and former customers employees that their personal data might have been leaked through the loss of an unerased digital copier hard drive. Some personal records were found on the hard drive of a copier found in a New Jersey warehouse. The copier had previously been leased by Affinity and was then returned to the leasing company. Affinity Health Plan says it has not had a chance to review the data found on the copier. The figure of 409,262 notifications includes former and current employees, providers, applicants for jobs, members, and applicants for coverage.UPDATEë_(08/15/2013): Affinity Health Plan will pay more than $1.2 million in HIPAA violations as a result of the breach.

Up to 3,100 BPA employees were affected by a cyber attack. ë_The attack appears to be related to the attack on the Department of Energy's website. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth were distributed as a result of the Department of Energy breach.

An employee of the University of Mississippi Medical Center accidentally attached a spreadsheet with sensitive information to an email that went out to students. ë_The email was sent on August 21 and the spreadsheet contained student names, Social Security numbers, GPAs, race, gender, dates of birth, mailing addresses, and phone numbers. ë_The breach was discovered within hours and the University used a combination of asking students to delete the email and manually removing the email from students' webmail accounts. ë_The email was meant to alert students to changes being made to the school's health insurance.

The Health and Human Services website of medical breaches reports the loss of a portable electronic device by Orthopedics and Adult Reconstructive Surgery. ë_The breach occurred between March 1 and March 13. ë_AssuranceMD is named as a business associate.

Customer information may have been exposed when Osprey Packs' Pro Deal website was hacked. ë_Customer names, phone numbers, email addresses, billing and shipping addresses, and credit card information may have been exposed. ë_Osprey Packs learned of the issue on August 7, 2013 when a customer discovered unauthorized activity on their credit card and connected it to Osprey Packs. ë_Other customers have also noticed fraudulent charges. ë_The attack may have happened as early as July 9, 2013.

Seven contract baggage handlers were arrested for stealing valuables from customer luggage. ë_The thefts were caught on camera between April 1 and August 28. ë_Items such as iPads, iPhones, cash, and jewelrey were discovered in the defendants' homes and cars.

A lawsuit was filed against Schnucks Markets Inc. after customers learned that Schnucks failed to warn customers about a data breach within two weeks. ë_On March 15, Schnucks learned that a portion of their loyalty cards were affected, but waited until March 30 to send a press release. ë_ Customer payment card numbers and expiration dates were exposed through a magnetic strip swiping security breach. No customer names were exposed.UPDATEë_(04/15/2013): The breach affected about 2.4 million customer debit and credit cards at 79 Schnucks locations. ë_Payment cardholders' contact and identifying information were not exposed. ë_Customers who visited a Schnucks between December of 2012 and March 29, 2013 may have been affected.UPDATEë_(05/24/2013): A class action lawsuit was filed against Schnuck Markets in early May. ë_Schnuck Markets claims that the the lawsuit belongs in federal court because of the case's scope and damages. ë_The lawsuit sought damages from Schnucks for time and effort that affected individuals had to put into monitoring and managing compromised credit card information. ë_The lawsuit also alleges Schnucks of willful and wanton neglect, a charge for which punitive damages are available under Illinois law. ë_However Schnucks states that the "time and effort" claims for Illinois alone easily exceed the $5 million threshold for federal consideration.UPDATEë_(06/21/2013): A new estimate from Schnucks states that 500,000 unique credit or debit cards may have been involved.UPDATEë_(07/11/2013): After a review, the Missouri Attorney General's office has stated that Schnuck Markets did not violate state data security law.UPDATEë_(08/31/2013): Liberty Mutual Insurance Co. is suing Schnuck Markets Inc. Liberty Mutual claims that it should not be held liable for eight lawsuits filed against Schnucks.

Company: University of Texas, Texas Health Science Center at Houston Medical School
Description of incident: An unencrypted laptop that was housed in a locked closet was discovered missing on August 2. ë_The computer contained names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, and hand and arm image data taken between February 2010 and July 13. ë_The laptop had not been used since July 19.

A file with customer information was accidentally published on Missouri Credit Union's website on August 5. ë_The names, Social Security numbers, account numbers, teller and call in passwords, and addresses of Missouri Credit Union members were accessed. ë_The file was accessed 10 times before the issue was discovered and it was taken off of the website.

Company: The New York Times, Melbourne IT
Description of incident: A domain or domains belonging to The New York Times was attacked after activist hackers found a way to access the login credentials of service provider Melbourne IT. ë_Melbourne IT is an Australian domain name registrar that provides hosting and data services for The New York Times and other media sites. ë_The New York Times website was shutdown for approximately six hours.

Customers who used credit or debit cards at United States Journeys, Journeys Kidz, Johnston and Murphy, Shi by Journeys and some Underground Stations stores may have had their information gathered during a criminal intrusion of Genesco's computer network.  It is possible that credit and debit card numbers, expiration dates and card verification codes were accessed.UPDATEë_(01/17/2013): Genesco has spent $2.1 million on consulting and legal fees related to the breach.UPDATEë_(03/08/2013): Genesco also owns Lids. ë_Genesco sued VISA for $13 million in unnecessary fines associated with the data breach. ë_VISA fined banks for their role in failing to comply with industry-wide credit card security standards. ë_The banks then took money from Genesco to address fines and breach recovery.

A security breach has resulted in the usernames, email addresses, first and last names, and encrypted passwords of League of Legends users to be exposed. ë_About 120,000 transaction records from 2011 may have been accessed. ë_The transaction records contained hashed and salted (encrypted) credit card numbers. The information was stored on a system that had not been used since 2011.

Company: San Francisco State University - College of Extended Learning
Description of incident: A server that contained the personal information of students was breached on March 25, 2013. ë_Federal law enforcement notified San Francisco State University of the breach on June 11. ë_The College of Extended Learning notified students of the issue on August 12. ë_An unspecified number of names, Social Security numbers, and other personal information was exposed.

Students and staff members may have had their information exposed during a hacking incident. The hacker or hackers were able to exploit a vulnerability in software acquired by a vendor. ë_Names, addresses, Social Security numbers, and university ID numbers were exposed.UPDATEë_(08/19/2013): An additional 2,000 people were affected. ë_They were not employees but had received payment from the University of Delaware.

People who were linguists or applied to be linguists within Northrop Grunman Technical Services, inc. Balkans Linguist Support Program may have had their personal information exposed. A database that contained names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, blood types, contact information, and additionaly types of government-issued identification numbers was accessed by unauthorized parties. ë_The breach occured sometime between November 2012 and May 2013 and was discovered on July 26.UPDATEë_(08/15/2013): Over 70,000 people, including thousands of linguists, were affected.

The theft of an employee's Netbook on July 20 resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The Netbook was stolen from the employee's home and contained Social Security numbers and other protected patient information.ë_

A customer received a package from Banana Republic that contained documents with employee Social Security numbers, tax forms, resignation letters, legal notices, doctors' notes, and performance reviews. ë_The package was meant for HR administration and contained the information of around 20 sales support associates who work at Gap. ë_The customers were expecting a tie and pocket square. ë_it appears that the package had been mislabeled.

Company: City of Houston, Automatic Data Processing
Description of incident: A software code error caused W-2 information to be exposed. ë_Approximately 1,300 classified Houston Police Department employees and 5,000 other local government workers were affected. ë_Names and Social Security numbers were exposed.

Company: Troy Regional Medical Center (TRMC), Southern Records Management Inc.
Description of incident: TRMC discovered that someone had removed paper records that contained the information of approximately 880 patients. ë_The unauthorized access and removal happened in early 2011 and was reported to TRMC by law enforcement on May 20, 2011. Affected patients had their names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth and medical record numbers exposed. ë_It appears that some of the personal information was used to file fraudulent income tax returns with the IRS.UPDATEë_(06/13/2012): A woman was arrested on felony charges for allegedly conspiring with others to steal the information of 880 patients while she worked with Southern Records Management at TRMC. ë_The 22-count felony indictment includes allegations of fraud against the U.S. government as part of a tax fraud scheme. ë_UPDATEë_(10/26/2012): A former Southern Records Management employee working for Troy between June 13, 2010 and March 25, 2011 pled guilty to one count of conspiring to defraud the government regarding claims, one count of fraud in connection with identification documents, a count of fraud in connection with computers, and a count of aggravated identity theft.UPDATEë_(02/07/2013): The dishonest employee was sentenced to 65 months in prison.UPDATEë_(05/24/2013): A second co-conspirator pleaded guilty to the theft of government money, fraudulent use of debit cards, and aggravated identity theft. ë_She received 10 years in prison. ë_A total sum of $1,198,063 was fraudulently obtained through fake tax refunds.UPDATEë_(06/13/2013): Another conspirator was convicted of ID theft and tax fraud after pleading guilty to theft of government money, fraudulent use of debit cards, and aggravated identity theft. ë_The court ordered a 10-year prison sentence for the conspirator.

A finance department employee contacted ADP for troubleshooting and an ADP representative removed the firewall of Calvert Internal Medicine Group during the service call. ë_The firewall was not restored after the call and employees began receiving spam emails from the finance department employee's email account. ë_Malware was also detected in the spam inbox of the employee's computer. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and other payroll information of current and former employees may have been exposed.

Personnel records were discarded in a public dumpster after Academy Studios. The non-profit closed in April and many of its assets were sold in an online auction on May 21. ë_The personnel paperwork included names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, copies of passports, copies of drivers' licenses, I-9 forms, and other employee information.

Customers who made purchases between March 19-25, April 14-15, or April 20-21 may have had their credit or debit card information compromised. ë_Tennessee and six other Southern states may have been affected by the breach. It is not clear if the payment card information was taken inside the stores or outside of the stores at gas pumps.UPDATEë_(06/10/2013): The accounts of consumers who used payment cards at 373 Mapco Express stores may have been affected. Two additional locations in Tennessee were affected on April 14 and 15. There are unnamed stores that may have been affected on April 20 and 21.UPDATEë_(07/08/2013): Three lawsuits have been filed as a result of data stolen in three MAPCO breaches that occurred in March, April, and June.

An employee of the Utah Division of Motor Vehicles was fired in March for releasing confidential, personal information from DMV databases. ë_The former employee was a customer service clerk who had worked for the division for 14 years. ë_Investigators also took the former employee's work hard drive, computer, printer, and other items that might have contained sensitive data. ë_The items will be investigated in a forensics lab.

Company: Jackson Health System, Jackson South Community Hospital
Description of incident: Approximately 1,200 photo records of 566 patients were publicly posted on November 30. ë_The information was removed and two managers resigned as a result of the breach.

A box that contained patient medical records was determined to have been missing since January. ë_Patient medical diagnoses, surgical procedures, and other personal health information may have been exposed. The missing records were either on their way to be electronically scanned or returning from being scanned.

A July 4 burglary resulted in the exposure of guest information. ë_The names, addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, and credit and debit card numbers of guests were on a computer hard drive that was stolen. ë_The hotel learned of the possibility of a breach of guest data on July 14 and alerted guests around August 8.

The July 29 car burglary of a laptop computer and flash drive resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, and other information contained in medical records were exposed.

Hackers have managed to access the information of approximately 1% of Citibank's 21 million users. U.S. Customer names, account numbers, and contact information were exposed. ë_Security codes and dates of birth were not exposed. ë_The breach occurred sometime in May. ë_UPDATEë_(6/13/2011): Citibank released an official statement on the Citigroup website.UPDATEë_(6/14/2011): It has been revealed that hackers obtained customer names, account numbers and transaction information by logging into the customer credit card site and guessing the account numbers of other customers. ë_Since the account number appeared in the web address browser bar, simply altering an account number allowed the hackers to access a different account. ë_The hackers also utilized an automatic computer program to guess account numbers quickly. This incident appears to have occurred in early May.UPDATEë_(6/14/2011): Connecticut Attorney General George Jepsen asked Citigroup Inc. to provide more information about the data breach. ë_Jepsen feels that more information about the types of account information exposed, the cause of the breach, the steps taken to notify affected individuals and the steps to prevent future breaches is needed. ë_He requested the additional information by June 22.UPDATEë_(6/16/2011): The number of affected individuals has been raised from 210,000 to 360,000. ë_Further investigation of and information about the breach revealed that the breach was discovered on May 10. ë_By May 24, Citigroup officials concluded that the data thieves had captured names, account numbers, and email addresses of about 360,000 customer accounts. ë_Social Security numbers, expiration dates, and three-digit security passwords found on the back of credit cards were not exposed.UPDATEë_(6/24/2011): At least 3,400 of the customers whose credit card information was stolen have suffered a combined loss of $2,700,000.UPDATEë_(09/03/2013): Citibank has agreed to pay $15,000 in civil penalties to Connecticut's Privacy Protection Guaranty and Enforcement Account and $40,000 to the General Fund of Connecticut. ë_Citibank will also hire a third party to conduct an information security audit of the Account Online section of Citibank's website.

The July 22 office theft of several computers resulted in the exposure of patient health information. ë_Names, addresses, X-rays, photos, and diagnostic findings were exposed.UPDATEë_(09/04/2013): Two desktops were stolen. ë_Social Security numbers were also exposed.

An unspecified number of current and former employees were affected by the theft of a laptop. ë_The laptop was stolen from an employee's home on August 10. ë_The laptop contained names and Social Security numbers.UPDATEë_(09/03/2013): As many as 82,160 current and former employees may have been affected.

A website breach that occurred on June 1 and was discovered on July 22 resulted in the exposure of customer informaiton. ë_Names, addresses, phone numbers, unencrypted credit card information, and other information stored on temporary data files may have been accessed due to malicious code on the website.

PIN pad devices used to process credit and debit card information in stores were compromised. ë_The breach was discovered around September 14 during maintenance and inspection of the devices. ë_Anyone who used a credit or debit card at a Barnes & Noble may have been affected by a sophisticated criminal effort to steal that information. ë_Names, payment card account numbers, and PINs may have been exposed. ë_Barnes & Noble removed all PIN pads. Fewer than 1% of the inspected PIN pads had been affected.UPDATEë_(10/24/2012): A total of 63 Barnes and Noble stores in nine states had at least one compromised PIN pad device. ë_Malicious code was installed on the PIN pads.UPDATEë_(09/05/2013): A federal judge ruled that customers failed to show that their personal information was stolen in the data breach.

Employees of the state of Virginia who are enrolled in the Commonwealth's 2014 Flexible Spending Account had their information exposed. ë_Conexis erroneously sent summary reports of Blue Cross/Blue Shield Flexible Spending Account Services to 11 state human resources and payroll employees. ë_The reports included participants from across the state rather than from specific locations related to the human resources and payroll employees' work. ë_The human resources and payroll employees who received information that was not intended for them signed a certification confirming that they had deleted or destroyed the information.

Company: Sony Pictures, Sony Corporation of America
Description of incident: Hackers called LulzSec obtained over one million Sony customer passwords. ë_The hackers located data that included passwords, email addresses, phone numbers, home addresses, and dates of birth. ë_The information was not encrypted and was posted on LulzSec's website. ë_People wishing to enter online sweepstakes entered their real or fake information. ë_Anyone who used their Sony Pictures sweepstakes password for another account should immediately change their passwords so that they do not match each other.UPDATEë_(08/28/2012): A second suspect has been arrested for his alleged role in a computer breach at Sony Pictures Entertainment. ë_He faces one count of conspiracy and once count of unauthorized impairment of a protected computer. Sony claims that 37,500 of the one million users affected had personal information exposed.UPDATEë_(04/18/2013): One of the hackers involved in the breach was sentenced to one year in prison. ë_He was also sentenced to 13 months of home detention and 1,000 hours of community service after release.UPDATEë_(08/08/2013): The hacker who was sentenced on April 18 was also ordered to pay $605,663 in restitution.

Company: Boston Public School (BPS), Plastic Card Systems
Description of incident: Boston Public School students across 36 schools may have had their information compromised by the loss of a flash drive. ë_The flash drive was misplaced sometime around August 9 by BPS's ID card vendor Plastic Card Systems.

A hacker was able to access the computer system Smartphone Experts used to process online payments on June 13. ë_Customer names, addresses, credit and debit card account numbers, CVV codes, and payment card experiation dates were accessed. ë_The credit card information was encrypted, but the hacker may have used a decryption feature within the online payment processing system to access customer information.UPDATEë_(09/06/2013): The breach occurred on June 13. ë_This entry originally listed it as having occurred on July 12.

A website breach exposed an unspecified number of customer names, addresses, credit card numbers, credit card expiration dates, and CVV codes. ë_Hackers put malware on Outdoor Network's Boats.net and Partzilla.com websites and were able to access information from credit card transactions between December 2012 and July 2013.

An unspecified incident occurred on or around July 26 that may have exposed the confidential information of current and former employees. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and bank account information may have been exposed. ë_Current employees were sent notification on August 6.

An unauthorized individual accessed a database of employee information used for COBRA. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and other benefit plan information of employees and their dependents may have been accessed on the Ceridian database. ë_The breach was discovered when a Bridgewater consultant reported that their password for the Ceridian database had been changed and someone else had used the credentials to access the database on three separate occassions. ë_The breach occurred sometime before April 12, 2013.

Two hackers claimed responsibility for hacking the website of the city of Springfield, Missouri. ë_The breach occurred on February 17, and the databases on the server contained over 300,000 entries. ë_It appears that not all databases were accessed as the total number of citizens affected was reported as 2,100. ë_Hackers claimed to have acquired 6,071 entries related to the date of birth, weight, height, race, hair color, skin tone, phone number, address, and Social Security number of people listed in online police reports. A total of 15,887 entries related to warrants that included age, date of birth, address, employer, eye color, hair color, race, sex, weight, height, and other details were obtained. ë_Databases with 1,041 vehicle descriptions from online police reports and details related to 284,618 summons were also obtained. ë_The hackers posted a significant amount of information, but voluntarily removed any sensitive information that could cause problems for consumers.ë_UPDATEë_(06/12/2013): A member of Anonymous, John Anthony Borell III, was charged in 2012 for using SQL injections on multiple law enforcement and public agency websites. ë_He agreed to a plea bargain in April and will serve 36 months in prison for violating a section of federal law addressing computer fraud. ë_He pleaded guilty to five charges related to hacking and will also pay nearly $230,000 in restitution to a number of agencies that were hacked.
