Investigators are fairly certain that people who used their credit or debit cards at Natural Provisions Market may be the targets of payment card fraud. ë_Anyone who used a debit or credit card at the store before July 2, and possibly as early as January 2012, should check their bank statements for phony charges. ë_It appears that hackers accessed Natural Provisions' credit card processors.UPDATEë_(09/11/2013): The Attorney General of Vermont reached a settlement with Natural Provisions. The store will pay $15,000 to the state and agreed to spend $15,000 to upgrade its computer security system.

Five laptops were stolen during a July 16 office burglary. ë_The laptops contained confidential information and were password-protected but unencrypted. ë_Current and former employees and their beneficiaries and dependents, contractors, and job applicants were affected. Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, drivers' license numbers, benefits information, bank account information, and health information were exposed.

A human error resulted in the exposure of client information. ë_A client found a file with Social Security numbers on the website. ë_The site was shut down while the file was removed. ë_It is unclear how long the information was available and the error was caused by a former employee.ë_

Police searched the car of a University custodial employee and found USF Physicians Group patient billing information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth had been exposed. ë_The employee no longer works for the University and patients were sent a notification letter in late July.

An employee accidentally emailed a document with the names and Social Security numbers of 4,457 Cobb-Cherokee Career Center customers to 1,000 people. ë_Recipients were notified and instructed to delete the email immediately without reading it.UPDATEë_(09/06/2013): The employee who accidentally sent the email attachment was suspended. The Georgia Department of Labor is also reviewing its internal policies for handling sensitive information.

Rockland Federal Credit Union is sending customers new debit cards with new PINs as a result of a merchant who discovered a breach in their computer system. ë_All old debit cards will be deactivated on September 26.

A volunteer allegedly stole the names and Social Security numbers of 106 patients and used the information to file $550,000 worth of fraudulent tax returns. ë_The volunteer had a co-conspirator and the breach began in late January of 2012. ë_

Participants in a Wellness Screening competition pilot may have had their information exposed. ë_A Kaiser Permanente employee accidentally included confidential information in an email sent to a member of the pilot planning team. In addition to a summary of the competition, it included names, Kaiser Permanente medical record numbers, phone numbers, email addresses, names of employers, department names, and dates and times of health screenings. ë_The pilot planning team member was not authorized to receive the confidential information.

Customer names, addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, credit card numbers, expiration dates, and security codes may have been exposed after Midwest Supplies' website was hacked. ë_All affected customers were offered a $25 coupon for future purchases.

Company: United Shore Financial Services, Shore Mortgage
Description of incident: The servers of an unnamed Shore Mortgage vendor were affected by a computer intrusion. ë_The incident may have began on June 2 and client information was accessed on August 15. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, contact information, dates of birth, drivers' license information, and financial account information were accessed.

On April 9, 2012, Phoebe Putney Home Health Care (PPMH) learned from law enforcement officials that a former employee had improperly accessed patient information with the intent to file fraudulent tax returns. ë_The dishonest employee may have accessed the names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth of patients some time between June 2010 and April 2012. ë_Patients who were treated through PPMH between July 2005 and April 2012 may have been affected.UPDATEë_(09/03/2013): The dishonest former employee pleaded guilty to embezzlement of government property and aggravated identity theft on August 23, 2012. She was sentenced to 70 months in prison and ordered to pay $110,431 in restitution to the IRS on August 12, 2013.
A box of hundred of employee records was found in a publicly accessible recycling dumpster. ë_The box was later recovered by an employee, but the records were still left behind. ë_

Company: Retinal Consultants Medical Group (Vitreo-Retinal Medical Group)
Description of incident: The theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptop was stolen from the medical group's offices sometime between June 5 and June 6. ë_Patient names, dates of birth, gender, race, and medical images were exposed. ë_UPDATEë_(08/28/2013): The breach affected 1,837 patients.

Company: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation, Centinela State Prison
Description of incident: A file containing staff names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth was saved to a Centinela State Prison server that was accessible to all staff. ë_It was on the server between July 26 and July 29 before being removed.
An office burglary resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_A laptop was stolen from the office of Janna Benkelman, a licensed professional counselor. ë_The laptop was password-protected.ë_

Company: Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center
Description of incident: The May 24 loss of a portable device resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_

Company: Standard Register, Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center
Description of incident: The exposure of patient paper records resulted in a breach that was reported in August 2012.

Company: Health Plus Amerigroup, Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center
Description of incident: An accidental exposure of protected health information affected patients. The information was accidentally disclosed to other facilities. ë_The breach was reported in September of 2012.
The June 12 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.

An employee was found to have accessed physician notes without a work-related reason. ë_The breach began on November 9, 2011 and lasted until June 17, 2013. ë_Names, dates of service, medical record numbers, clinical information were exposed.

Customers who placed an order online or by phone between March 1, 2013 and July 15, 2013 may have had their information exposed. ë_Customer names, debit and credit card numbers, addresses, phone numbers, expieration dates and CVV codes may have been accessed by hackers.
An August 24, 2012 breach resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Company: Minne-Tohe Health Center/Elbowoods Memorial Health Center
Description of incident: An October 1, 2011 breach resulted in the exposure of protected health information.

A data management firm discovered that Chrome browser users may have had their personal information stored on the hard drives of their computers without their knowledge or consent. ë_Google Chrome regularly stores names, street addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, bank account numbers, credit card numbers, and Social Security numbers in web browsers for later use. ë_It was not known that Chrome's cache also stores the information in plain text.

Six skimmers were found on registers in one Nordstrom store in Aventura. ë_Six people were seen tending to the devices on the afternoon of October 5. They came in groups of three and distracted sales people while tampering with the registers, twice. ë_Skimmers and tiny cameras were installed to collect credit card information. ë_The information can be used to make fraudulent credit cards.

The August 4 theft of an unencrypted laptop from an employee's home may have resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Current and former patients may have had their names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and billing addresses exposed. ë_The information came from financial records, patient account information, and billing records dating back to 2005.

The July 18 theft of a laptop from an employee's car resulted in the exposure of employee information. ë_The laptop contained personnel spreadsheets with employee names, Social Security numbers, and employee identification numbers.

The theft of an unencrypted laptop from the audiology department of Santa Clara Valley Medical Center resulted in the exposure of patient names, medical record numbers, dates of birth, ages, sex, dates of service, and brainwave tests. ë_The theft was discovered on September 16.

Company: R.T. Jones Capital Equities Management Inc.
Description of incident: R.T. Jones learned of a cyber attack that occurred on July 22, 2013. ë_On August 7, 2013, it was discovered that an unauthorized party was able to access a database that contained names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. ë_At least 800 people were affected in Maryland. ë_It is unclear how many were affected nationwide.

Company: Minnesota Department of Natural Resources, Minnesota Department of Motor Vehicles
Description of incident: An employee working as an administrative manager in the Enforcement Division viewed the DMV information of around 5,000 people outside of work hours and for no job-related reason. ë_His activities between January 2008 and October 2012 were discovered and he was discharged on January 11, 2013. ë_It is believed that the driver's license and other motor vehicle record information was viewed for curiosity and not malicious purposes.UPDATEë_(05/01/2013): A group of people who had their driver's license information accessed filed lawsuits against Minnesota. ë_The state asked the federal judge hearing the case to dismiss the motions and argued that the state isn't liable under a federal law that protects the privacy of driver's license data. ë_The employee responsible for the breach is facing criminal charges; though the breach may not have been for malicious purposes.UPDATEë_(08/07/2013): The lawsuit was filed against other state employees as well as the employee responsible for the breach.UPDATEë_(9/25/2013): A district court dismissed the lawsuit. ë_The judge ruled that state agencies are not liable for a rogue employee's actions. ë_The case against the dishonest employee is still active. ë_The liability of the employee's supervisors has been limited and they will not pay damages for the breach.

Nearly 9,900 former Holy Cross Hospital patients were affected by a breach that involved a dishonest employee filing fraudulent tax returns. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and addresses were exposed between November 2011 and August 2013.

An Excel file with the names and Social Security numbers of 407 medical students was accidentally attached to an email that was sent to medical students interested in a residency match list. ë_The Excel column that contained the Social Security numbers was hidden and still accessible. ë_The issue was discovered in March for the 2013 list and it was later discovered that the same issue had occurred in 2008 and 2009.

Stanford University ID holders (SUNet) users had their account passwords and other information exposed. ë_The breach occurred sometime during the summer of 2013 and continued into the fall. ë_The full extent of the breach was not revealed. ë_SUNet users were instructured to change their passwords before accessing the system again.

Two men pleaded guilty to one count each of conspiracy to commit wire fraud. ë_They placed skimming devices on gas pumps at Murphy USA station in Conway and Little Rock, Arkansas as well as Durant, Oklahoma. ë_This allowed them to collect credit card information and create fraudulent credit cards. ë_The breach occurred between April 2012 and January 2013 and led to fraudulent charges of about $400,000. It's estimated that between 50 and 500 people were affected.

Company: South Carolina Health and Human Services, South Carolina Medicaid
Description of incident: An employee was fired and arrested after he sent the names, addresses, phone numbers, and dates of birth of Medicaid patients to his private email. ë_It was discovered that he had compiled and emailed the information of South Carolina Medicaid patients over a period of several months. He was charged with five misdemeanor counts of violating the confidentiality of medical indigents and one count of disclosing confidential information. ë_At least 22,600 patients had their Medicaid ID numbers emailed. It is unclear how many of those patients had their Social Security number used in place of a Medicaid ID number. Patients were warned not to give any personal information to anyone contacting them and claiming to be from the Medicaid agency.UPDATE (02/20/2013): A dishonest employee and another individual have been charged with criminal conspiracy. ë_The employee was also charged with willful examination of private records by a public official, public member, or public employee.UPDATEë_(10/09/2013): The former employee pleaded guilty to four counts of willfull examination of private records by a public employee and one count of criminal conspiracy. ë_The dishonest former employee faces up to 25 years in prison.

Company: Saint Louis University, Tenet Healthcare Corporation, SSM Health Care
Description of incident: On August 8, Saint Louis University learned that about 10 employees had their direct deposit information changed after several malicious phishing emails were sent to employees on July 25. ë_About 20 phishing emails were sent and several employees provided their account information. No unauthorized transactions have occurred because of the email scam. ë_Additionally, patients who were treated or reviewed at facilities owned by the Tenet Healthcare Corporation or SSM Health Care may have had their information exposed.

The University of Oklahoma began warning students of a security breach after its IT department noticed unusual internet activity on a laptop associated with its network. ë_The laptop was infected with a virus and it contained student names and Social Security numbers. ë_Students were advised to check bills and credit card transactions to make sure that no fraud had occurred. ë_

Records Breached: 1,310 (No Social Security numbers of financial information reported)
Description of incident: An email with patient information was sent to an unauthorized person. ë_Names, dates of birth, addresses, diagnoses, and medications were exposed.

A number of sales agents were affected when a data backup of PayJunction's internal business system was inappropriately accessed. ë_The unauthorized access occurred in July and was discovered in late September. ë_

Company: Legal Aid Society of San Mateo County
Description of incident: The August 12 office burglary of 10 laptops resulted in the exposure of client information. ë_The laptops were used by Legal Aid Society attorneys to assist individuals in getting services. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, medical information, and health information may have been exposed.

Company: Monterey County Department of Social Services
Description of incident: A Monterey County computer was compromised during the evening of March 17. ë_It was connected to the California State Network and contained the information of individuals who received public assistance benefits through Monterey County Department of Social Services between 2002 and 2009. ë_First and last names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, and dates of birth were exposed. ë_

Company: Washington Department of Social and Health Services
Description of incident: A private contractor working for the Department of Social and Health Services discovered that their laptop had been stolen on February 4. ë_The laptop was recovered in a pawn shop on February 14. ë_It contained the names, ID numbers, psychological evaluations, dates of birth, diagnoses, dates of services, addresses, and last four digits of Social Security numbers of clients.UPDATEë_(10/14/2013): The private contractor was a psychologist who had his license suspended as a result of the incident. ë_The Washington State Department of Health suspended the license after a history of being charged with unprofessional conduct. ë_He is accused of misrepresenting the number of people who could be affected by the breach and failing to report it to the Department of Social and Health Services until five days after the breach.

A breach at a Walgreens in Anaheim resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Thieves stole a computer and paper records in December of 2012. ë_The theft was discovered on December 31 and occurred on December 28. ë_The burglary occurred in Crescent's billing center. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, health insurance information, dates of birth, and medical information were exposed. ë_

Company: University of California Los Angeles (UCLA) Health System
Description of incident: A September 6 home theft resulted in the loss of an external computer hard drive. It contained the first and last names, birth dates, medical record numbers, addresses, and other medical record information of patients.ë_ The information dated from July 2007 to July 2011 and belonged to an individual who maintained the information in order to fulfill job duties.ë_ Other items were taken during the theft, but none have been recovered.UPDATE (12/20/2011): A class action lawsuit was filed on December 14. It alleges that the UCLA Health System violated California's Confidentiality of Medical Information Act.ë_ Since the act provides for statutory damages of $1,000 per person, the UCLA Health System could owe nearly $16.3 million to the 16,288 patients who were affected.ë_ UPDATE (12/22/2011): A total of 16,288 people had some type of information on the laptop, but 2,761 had enough information on the laptop to cause "more than a minimal amount of financial, reputational, or other harm" if accessed.UPDATE (10/17/2013): A state appellate court dismissed the class action lawsuit. ë_The ruling was that health care providers are not necessarily liable when medical information is misused or stolen unless the information is accessed by unauthorized parties.

Company: California State University Sacramento (Sacramento State University)
Description of incident: In August, Sacramento State University was notified that a computer server had been hacked. It contained the Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, and other personal information of staff members. ë_The cause and extent of the breach were determined in late September and staff members were notified in mid-October.

Datapak Services discovered that its online systems had been infected by malware since March 5, 2013. ë_Customer names, addresses, payment card numbers, expiration dates, and CVV codes may have been accessed by an unauthorized party.ë_

Records Breached: 3,000 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: An employee working as a child support officer is accused of making more than 4,000 queries without legitimate cause in a driver and vehicle services database between 2010 and 2011. ë_Photographs, addresses, and driving records may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(10/04/2013): A $2 million settlement has been proposed to end a class action lawsuit. ë_An insurance trust representing Minnesota counties will pay $500 to the named plaintiffs who initially brought the suit and those who had their information viewed for illegitimate purposes will receive a share of the money "based on the number of times they were illegitimately searched."

Between July 22 and July 28, an unauthoried party accessed a website that contained sensitive information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, drivers' license numbers, and Payroll Card numbers may have been accessed. ë_The website was shutdown once the breach was discovered. Paymast'rServices, PaycheckPLUS! Payroll cards issued by MetaBank were affected.

A woman found two bags of personnel records in her backyard in mid-August. ë_The woman called the cops after discovering the sensitive information. ë_Social Security numbers, driver's license photos, addresses, phone numbers, medical information, dates of birth, emergency contacts, payroll history, and tax documents were exposed. ë_The breach occurred after the building was abandoned and the files were not checked before being discarded. ë_An estimated 400 people were affected.

Hackers were able to access Ouidad's customer database between June 30 and July 4 of 2013. ë_Ouidad account information, names, credit card numbers, credit card security codes and expiration dates, billing addresses, email addresses, and phone numbers were exposed.ë_

Ticket vending machines associated with Long Island Rail Road were discovered to have been compromised. ë_Customers who used their debit and credit cards at the machines may have had their information recorded and used to create fraudulent payment cards. ë_Tiny cameras were placed on the machines and hidden in thin black strips. ë_A total of seven machines in Bayside, Garden City, Great Neck, Greenvale, and Merillon Avenue were compromised.

South Carolina Department of Revenue's website was hacked by a foreign hacker. ë_The hack most likely began on August 27, was discovered on October 10, and was neutralized on October 20. ë_Around 3.6 million Social Security numbers and 387,999 credit card and debit card numbers were exposed. A total of 16,000 payment card numbers were not encrypted.UPDATEë_(10/31/2012): Tax records dating back to 1998 were exposed. ë_A lawsuit alleging that South Carolina failed to protect citizens of South Carolina and failed to disclose the breach quickly enough was announced on October 31.UPDATEë_(11/05/2012): Trustwave was named as the data security contractor who handled the South Carolina website and added to the group being sued over the breach. ë_Trustwave is an international company based in Chicago.UPDATEë_(11/15/2012): Over 4.5 million consumers and businesses may have had their tax records stolen by hackers. ë_It appears that Trustwave focused on helping the Southern Carolina Department of Revenue comply with regulations regarding how credit card information is handled. ë_Neither Trustwave nor the Southern Carolina Department of Revenue detected the breach.UPDATEë_(11/29/2012): The total number of people or businesses affected was updated to 6.4 million. Approximately 3.8 million taxpayers and 1.9 million of their dependents had their information exposed. ë_Additionally, 3.3 million tax payers had bank account information obtained. ë_It is unclear how much overlap there is between the 3.8 million taxpayers and the 3.3 million tax payers who had bank account information obtained.UPDATEë_(01/11/2013): A State IT division director reported that the SCDOR's former chief information officer and current computer security chief were notified on August 13 that 22 computers were infected with malicious code. ë_The State's division of IT recommended that passwords be reset after the discovery, but they were not reset.UPDATEë_(03/01/2013): A lawsuit brought against TrustWave and SCDOR by a former state senator has been dismissed by a judge. ë_The former senator accused the agencies of conspiring to hide the fact that a massive breach had occurred and failing to adequately protect taxpayers from a potential hack.UPDATEë_(04/02/2013): About 1,448,798 people signed up for free individual credit monitoring and 41,446 signed up for free family credit monitoring.UPDATEë_(10/25/2013): It is estimated that South Carolina taxpayers will pay at least $8.5 million to pay for one year's worth of free credit monitoring to those affected by the data breach. ë_Over 650,000 businesses had their tax information exposed.

A computer security breach resulted in the exposure of Social Security numbers, bank routing numbers, and home addresses. ë_A total of 5,100 current employees and 2,700 other individuals had their information exposed by the unspecified computer breach that occurred in March. Notification was sent around the end of July.UPDATEë_(10/28/2013): An England national was charged in New Jersey with one count of accessing a U.S. department or agency computer without authorization and one count of conspiring to access a U.S. department or agency computer without authorization. ë_He is being investigated for illegally accessing U.S. government computer systems associated with the U.S. Army, U.S. Missile Defense Agency, Environmetnal Protection Agency, and National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

A laptop stolen from 
              a nurse's car on October 8 contains the names and SSNs of individuals 
              in approximately 17,000 households participating in the Allina Hospitals 
              and Clinics obstetric home-care program since June 2005.

Roughly 3,800 patients were affected by a breach that involved a former employee at the Inver Grove Heights clinic. ë_The employee worked as a certified medical assistant and viewed patient records without permission between February of 2010 and September of 2013. ë_Patients who were seen at any location within Allina Health's system may have had their demographic, clinical, and health insurance information viewed. ë_The employee also had access to the last four digits of patients' Social Security numbers. ë_

The August 24 theft of two laptops resulted in the exposure of personal information. ë_The laptops were stolen in Northern California and it is unclear whether employees, clients, or general consumers were affected. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, driver's licence numbers, and dates of birth were exposed.

HealthFitness informed Gerdau of a laptop theft that exposed the information of Gerdau employees and employee dependents. ë_HealthFitness administors Gerdau's health management and wellness program. ë_The laptop contained Social Security numbers, employee names, spouse names, dates of birth, and health plan elections.

The October 12 office theft of two laptops resulted in the exposure of patient information from a number of facilities. ë_Authorities believe a well-known transient was responsible for the thefts. ë_San Gabriel Valley Medical Center, Garfield Medical Center, Moneterey Park Hospital, Whittier Hospital Medical Center, Greater El Monte Community Hospital, and Anaheim Regional Medical Center patients were affected. Names, Social Security numbers, diagnosis and procedure codes, insurance identification numbers, and insurance payments were exposed.

An unauthorized user was able to modify employee banking information. ë_The breach was discovered on October 18 when two employees reported receiving email confirmations of changes to their direct-deposit designations. ë_The unauthorized user may have obtained valid payroll credentials by using a phishing attack. ë_The HR/Payroll systems were taken offline on Friday, October 18 and were expected to become active again on October 21.
A hacker published approximately 1,500 Michigan State University names, email addresses, user IDs, encrypted passwords, and mailing addresses.

MongoHQ's internal system was compromised. ë_The system allowed certain administrative users to appear as other users. ë_MongoHQ reset all employee accounts and will enable devices, email, and internal applications after a credential reset and audit. ë_

An employee was found to have accessed Social Security numbers, dates of birth, medical diagnoses, prescribed treatments, and other health information without cause. ë_A patient contacted Boone Hospital Center on September 16 and said that her personal health information had been accessed. ë_An investigation revealed the breach and the employee's access was terminated on September 19.

Someone broke into a University van and stole campus keys. ë_The keys could give them access to nearly 50 Portland and Gorham campus buildings. ë_The University is in the process of replacing locks of the affected buildings. ë_Student, personnel, and other records may be accessible. ë_Faculty, staff, and students were notified of the incident and encouraged to shut electronic devices down when leaving them unattended. ë_They were also advised to not leave sensitive information or belongings in campus buildings without additional locks.

The July 15 office theft of four unencrypted desktop computers resulted in the exposure of patient information. Approximately four million patients who were seen by Advocate Medical Group physicians between the early 1990s and July of 2013 were affected. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth were exposed. ë_Diagnoses, medical record numbers, medical service codes, and health insurance information was also exposed in some circumstances.UPDATEë_(09/06/2013): A class-action lawsuit on behalf of patients in the Chicago area has been filed. ë_It claims that Advocate Medical Center should have done more to protect patient information.

An unauthorized person gained access to the school's computer network. ë_Campus ID numbers, names, and possibly other information of staff and students were exposed. ë_In addition to the 39,000 people who had their files with Social Security numbers exposed, 19,000 more indidviduals were notified of the breach.UPDATEë_(10/22/2013): It is estimated that 62,000 people were affected and $380,000 was spent investigating the breach. ë_This number includes providing services to those who were affected.

The July 27 or 28 office theft of an unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of current and former employee information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and employee ID numbers were exposed.

Company: US Airways, McKesson, City of Houston, Automatic Data Processing (ADP), AlliedBarton Security Services
Description of incident: A programming error at ADP resulted in the exposure of employee names, Social Security numbers, and other information on W-2 forms. ë_Employees could have inadvertently downloaded the W-2s of other employees. ë_The error was corrected on May 4 and involved W-2 forms for tax years 2010, 2011, and/or 2012. ADP alerted US Airways to the issue on June 6, 2013.UPDATEë_(09/13/2013): McKesson and the city of Houston were also affected by the breach.UPDATEë_(09/30/2013): AlliedBarton Security Services was also affected. ë_It appears that 206 ADP customers were affected. ë_Two of the customers affected have at least 4,500 employees.

Company: Sentry Life Insurance, Department of Labor
Description of incident: Sentry Life Insurnace discovered that several forms sent to the Department of Labor contained an attachments with names, Social Security numbers, and in a few cases, 401k account balances. ë_The Department of Labor uploaded the forms to a public website before Sentry's discovery. ë_The discovery was made on July 2 and a letter was sent on July 11 to the Maryland Attorney General's Office on behalf of Sentry.

Job applications from a Denny's in Phoenix were found in a dumpster behind the Denny's. ë_The paperwork dated back to August of 2012. ë_The information included addresses, Social Security numbers, and other information normally found on job applications. ë_The manager said there was a mistake and that similar paperwork is usually shredded.

Customer usernames and encrypted passwords were accessed and taken by hackers on or after March 8, 2013. ë_Hackers may have had access to the news release services of companies that use PR Newswire. ë_The breach is related to the Adobe hack that was revealed in early October of 2013. ë_

Radiant Systems accidentally transmitted Fisherman's Restaurant employee information to another Radiant Systems restaurant customer. ë_The error occurred from May 3, 2013 through September 24, 2013. ë_Radiant Systems learned of the issue on September 23 and notifications were sent in early October. ë_Full names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, gender, marital status and number of dependents, addresses, telephone numbers, and personnel information were exposed.

An unauthorized user or users accessed at least one U.S. system that hosts traveler information. ë_The type of information that may have been accessed was not reported and International SOS is still investigating the incident.UPDATEë_(10/23/2013): The breach occurred on August 24 and was confirmed on August 28. ë_Names and passport numbers were exposed. ë_Some travelers also had their Social Security numbers exposed.

Anyone who has shopped at Harbor Freight within the last three months (June, July, and August of 2013) may be at risk for credit or debit card fraud. ë_Online and in store customers were affected. ë_Tens of thousands of dollars were taken from between 300 and 600 member accounts.UPDATE (11/04/2013): Customers who made purchases in stores between May 6, 2013 and June 30, 2013 may have had their card account numbers, expiration dates, and card verification numbers exposed. ë_

A dishonest employee accessed and misused patient information sometime between January of 2009 and March of 2012. ë_Social Security numbers and dates of birth were taken to file fraudulent tax returns. The former employee pleaded guilty to one count of theft of government property and one count of aggravated identity theft.

Company: Samaritan Family Medicine Resident Clinic, Samaritan Health System
Description of incident: A patient discovered a stack of unshredded medical documents in a publicly accessible dumpster near the medical offices on Samaritan Drive. ë_Prescriptions, diagnoses, and other sensitive medical information could have been accessed. ë_The breach occurred in July and an employee removed the information soon after the incident.The Oregon Department of Consumer and Business Services fined Samaritan $1,000 for the breach. ë_Samaritan will pay a full fine of $5,000 if it fails to comply with Oregon's confidential records laws during the next five years.

Eleven computer screen printouts of personal information and seven credit cards of Mount Sinai patients were found in a vehicle that was searched after a motorist was stopped for reckless driving. ë_An employee of Mount Sinai was linked to patient personal information that was found during the traffic stop. She was arrested and accused of accessing and printing the names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth of 340 patients for identity theft purposes.

An unnamed contractor misplaced a University Hospitals hard drive after taking it for a computer system upgrade. ë_The hard drive was stolen from the car of an employee of the contractor on August 8. ë_It contained patient information such as names, birth dates, addresses, medical record numbers, insurance provider information, and health information. ë_

Records Breached: 500 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: Children's Healthcare of Atlanta fired and sued an executive for allegedly taking proprietary information that included patient health information, state license numbers for more than 500 health care providers, and other health care provider information. ë_The executive announced her resignation on October 16 and on October 18 the Hospital discovered that she had emailed sensitive information to her personal email account. ë_The executive had planned to leave on December 20 but was fired for exposing the Hospital's sensitive information.

An investigation uncovered sensitive information from Emerald Garden and Tampa General Hospital patients. ë_A dishonest Emerald Garden employee was arrested in May and sentenced to 37 months in prison for conspiring to misuse the information to file tax refunds. ë_A contact at Tampa General Hospital also supplied patient information. ë_
Two former employees used patient records to make lists of names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth. ë_The information was created for tax fraud purposes.

An unencrypted laptop was stolen from an employee's vehicle sometime around September 23. ë_It contained a spreadsheet with payroll deduction information for former and current Yusen Logistics Americas employees. ë_It contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and payroll benefit deduction amounts from the period of July 2013 to September 2013.

The US Federal Trade Commission filed a complaint against Aaron's over their practice of monitoring customer activity through software called Detective Mode. ë_It was determined that customers who rented computers were put at risk for identity theft by Aaron's practice of recording customer keystroke activity, screen shots, and images taken from webcams. ë_Aaron's may only use tracking technology with the consent of the renter and may not use technology that captures keystrokes, screenshots, images, or sounds on the devices it rents. ë_

Records Breached: 960 (Last four digits of Social Security numbers exposed)
Description of incident: Federal and local officials discovered a breach that involved the records of 960 patients treated at Broward Health between October of 2012 and December of 2012. ë_The patients were treated at 1600 S. Andrews Ave. Their names, addresses, dates of birth, insurance policy numbers, and reasons for visits were exposed when an employee took patient documents out of the medical facility. ë_The last four digits of patients' Social Security numbers are recorded at Broward Health for insurance purposes and were also exposed.ë_

ë_A July 29 breach of the University of Arizona's College of Law website allowed intruders to access class rosters and applicant lists. ë_University of Arizona law students and applicants may have had their names, Social Security numbers, usernames, and passwords exposed.ë_

Company: Eagleton School, Castro School, Munroe School
Records Breached: 100 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The theft of a nurse's suitcase resulted in the exposure of student medical information. ë_The suitcase contained a thumb drive. ë_The theft occurred on October 5 and about 100 parents received notification of the breach. ë_Medications and other health-related information were on the thumb drive. ë_Addresses and Social Security numbers were not included in the compromised data.
An unencrypted backup tape was discovered missing. It contained the names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, and medical information of patients.

An employee who was working at Mt. Sinani Medical Center through a temp agency was found with patient information during a traffic stop. ë_Police uncovered a bag that contained over 100 printouts with patient names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth. ë_Photocopies of checks that had been written to Mt. Sinai Medical Center and corresponding billing statements were also found during the February 27, 2013 traffic stop. ë_Additional information that could be used for fraud was also found at the temporary employee's residence.The dishonest employee was convicted for involvement in the identity theft and tax refund scheme. It was later discovered that the temp agency gave Mt. Sinai Medical Center false background information about the temporary employee. ë_Mt. Sinai Medical Center no longer does business with the staffing agency.

One of Standard Insurance Company's vendors accessed a file that was inadvertently disclosed on the vendor's system. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and dates of birth could have been accessed between October 7 and October 18. ë_The issue was discovered when an insurance policyholder noticed they had access to the information and contacted Standard Insurance Company.

The theft of an unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of patient and employee information. ë_The laptop was stolen from an employee's vehicle and contained names, insurance information, diagnoses, and dialysis treatment information. ë_Approximately 375 patients also had their Social Security numbers exposed.

A contractor who worked for Baltimore County between December of 2011 and July of 2012 was found to have saved the personal information of 12,000 county employees to computers for reasons unrelated to work. ë_The information was discovered during an investigation in Florida and came from payroll files dated between January and March of 2007. ë_Employees who had their paychecks direct deposited were affected and the bank account information of 6,633 employees was exposed. ë_Baltimore county employees are no longer allowed to download personal information to county computers and more than 5,000 county hard drives will be cleared of related data.

Company: North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services
Records Breached: 1,300 (No Social Security numbers or financial information was involved)
Description of incident: Over 1,300 people who received payment from state hospitals had their information exposed online. ë_Names, addresses, payment dates, name of facilities that made the payments, and dollar amounts paid were posted on North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services' transparency website "NC OpenBook." ë_The error was discovered when an individual complained. ë_The information had been available for years.

Company: Payday Loan Stores of Illinois, PLS Financial
Description of incident: Payday Loan Stores (PLS) was fined $1,107,000 for failing to protect consumer information.ë_ In April of 2010, three boxes of documents were found by police at a dumpster near a Payday Loan Store. According to the Illinois Department of Financial and Professional Regulation, "the discarded documents contained personal customer information, including Social Security numbers and copies of driver's licenses."UPDATEë_(11/08/2012): The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) settled charges with PLS Financial Services and The Payday Loan Store of Illinois regarding their violation of FTC's Disposal Rule and the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act's Privacy Rule and Safeguards Rule. ë_The two companies agreed to pay $101,500. The companies must also implement a comprehensive information security program that will be assessed for compliance for the next 20 years.

Records Breached: 700 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: FTC fined TrendNet for having inadequate security practices and marketing their products to consumers as secure. ë_TrendNet's website was breached by a hacker or hackers. ë_This allowed them to bypass users' login credentials and access wireless camera feeds. ë_At least 700 people who purchased TrendNet security cameras had their live camera feeds hacked. Some of their feeds were published online by hackers.

A glitch in the Department of Economic Opportunity's website caused Social Security numbers of people who registered for unemployment to be exposed. ë_The information was mistakenly sent to businesses and the Department of Economic Opportunity alerted businesses to the issue. ë_Those who were affected were sent letters.

The October 11 theft of two external hard drives may have exposed the information of students, current employees, and former employees. ë_Administrative and financial information such as Social Security numbers may have been exposed.

City vendors and other businesses were alerted to a breach of information that dates back to 2001. ë_Names, addresses, and in some cases Social Security numbers, were sent to city employees in a monthly email about vendor payments. ë_The issue was noticed when a recent software change made the information easier to spot. ë_Jeffersonville's information technology staff deleted the emails from city employee inboxes.

The June 15 hack of Ektron resulted in the exposure of current and former employee information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, immigration visas, passport numbers, and employee authorization cards were exposed. ë_Ektron learned of the breach in July and hired a third party firm to investigate the scope of the breach in August.

Greencastle Community School Corporation notified parents of a security issue involving improprer access by students. ë_Several students from Greencastle High School found a list of student network passwords and were able to access a limited amount of confidential student files on the school network. ë_Students in grades three through 12 may have had breakfast or lunch expenses falsely charged to their names and students with unauthorized access may have been able to access the network under other students' accounts.

An FTC complaint states that a LabMD spreadsheet with insurance billing data of over 9,000 customers was discovered on a public file sharing network.ë_Social Security numbers, insurance information, medical treatment codes, and dates of birth were exposed by the cyber security issue. ë_Identity thieves were found to have acquired the personal information of at least 500 LabMD customers.UPDATEë_(11/15/2013): LabMD disputed the FTC probe and alleged that the government funded the breach to retaliate against LabMD.

Company: Milwaukee Public School District, Express Scripts
Description of incident: Social Security numbers were printed on the outside of letters that were sent to a third party vendor. ë_As many as 6,000 letters were sent to MPS Medicare D recipients.ë_

Company: St. Mary's Janesville Hospital, SSM Health Care
Records Breached: 629 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: The August 27 car theft of an SSM Health Care employee's unencrypted laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Patients who were treated in St. Mary's Janesville Hospital's emergency room between January 1 and August 26 of 2013 were affected. ë_Names, dates of birth, medical record numbers, account numbers, providers, departments of service, bed numbers, room numbers, dates and times of service, history of visits, complaints, diagnoses, procedures, test results, vaccines, and medications were exposed.

Hackers stole and stored information online related to customers who used limousine and other ground transportation. ë_The online information included plain text archives of credit card numbers, expiration dates, names, and addresses. ë_Many of the customers were wealthy and used credit cards that would be attractive to identity thieves.

Company: Office of Dr. Paul G. Klein, DPM
Records Breached: 2,500 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The October 1 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Records Breached: 610 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The August 1 theft or loss of a portable electronic device resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Records Breached: 1,586 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: Patient records were improperly disposed of on August 6. ë_

Records Breached: 606 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: Patient records were improperly disposed of sometime between June 28 of 2013 and July 16 of 2013.

Company: ICS Collection Services, Inc, University of Chicago Physicians Group
Description of incident: University of Chicago Physicians Group's former contractor ICS Collection Services discovered that website users were able to view sensitive information of other users. ë_At least one user was able to view the names, addresses, dates of birth, insurance payments and dates, insurance company names, insurance policy numbers, procedures, diagnosis codes and descriptions, dates of service, treating physician names, and sometimes even Social Security numbers associated with University of Chicago Physicians Group patients. ë_ICS Collection Services learned of the issue on July 9.

Company: Office of Dr. Carol Patrick, Ph.D
Description of incident: The August 8 office theft of several computers resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The computers contained names, Social Security numbers, addreses, and dates of birth that were encrypted. ë_They also contained letters, reports, evaluations, and session notes that were not encrypted.

Company: Seton McCarthy Clinic, Seton Healthcare Family
Description of incident: The clinic theft of a laptop on October 4 resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The stolen laptop contained names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, Seton medical record numbers, patient account numbers, diagnosis information, immunization information, and insurance information of patients who visited the Seton Total Health Partners program, Seton McCarthy, Seton Topfer, and Seton Kozmetsky community health centers.

Records Breached: 2,350 (No Social Security numbers or financial information involved)
Description of incident: A former employee removed paper copies of daily patient schedules from Rothman Institute on August 11. ë_The paper copies were taken without permission and were not used for malicious purposes. ë_Patients who were seen between March 18 and May 10 may have had their names, telephone numbers, dates of birth, locations, staff or physician seen, codes for insurance companies, copay amounts, dates and times of appointments, reasons for visits, and internal-use chart, and code numbers exposed. ë_Social Security numbers and credit card information were not exposed. The information was not shared with unauthorized parties.UPDATEë_(11/08/2013): A total of 2,350 patients were affected.

Records Breached: 7,035 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: An employee emailed spreadsheets with sensitive patient information to a personal account in order to work from home. ë_Names, ages, dates of service, diagnoses, and medical record numbers were in the spreadsheets. ë_The breach was discovered on August 8 and initially suspected to have been caused by a computer intrusion. ë_Hospice of the Chesapeake investigated the breach for two months before revealing it to patients.UPDATEë_(11/08/2013): Hospice of the Chesapeake notified HHS and stated that 7,035 patients were affected.

Company: Paragon Benefits Inc, TSYS Employee Health Plan
Description of incident: An employee of a temporary staffing agency who was working at Paragon Benefits Inc. emailed personal information to his own Gmail account for fraudulent purposes. ë_The information came from TSYS employees. The dishonest employee was arrested and charged with felony identity theft. ë_Two spreadsheets that contained names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and home addresses were sent. ë_At least 1,000 TSYS former employees and 11 family members had their information exposed.

Records Breached: 2,182 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: A June 17 office burglary resulted in the theft of two laptops. ë_One of the laptops contained names, telephone numbers, dates of birth, visit dates, health complaints, physical examination notes, diagnoses, testing information, medication information, and other medical record information. ë_The thief or thieves were able to get into the office by opening an unlocked door. ë_No identity theft protection services are being offered to affected patients.UPDATEë_(11/08/2013): HHS received a report stating that 2,182 patients were affected by the breach.

Company: North Country Hospital and Health Center
Records Breached: 550 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: A former employee refused to return a laptop that contained unspecified patient health information. ë_North County Hospital first learned of the issue on September 18. ë_The Newport Police Department was contacted and all administrator-level computer system user codes and passwords that the employee had access to were changed. ë_The laptop was also password-protected and will be remotely locked out if someone attempts to use it to access the Hospital systems.

Records Breached: 949 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The August 22 office theft of a computer resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_Names, dates of birth, age, gender, radiology images, radiation therapy dose planning, diagnoses, and Texas Health Presbyterian medical record numbers were on the computer.

Records Breached: 1,360 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The August 3 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.

A briefcase was stolen from an employee's car sometime between the evening of August 22 and the morning of August 23. ë_The case files of seven clients were inside of the briefcase. Additionally, the briefcase contained a computer with files that included names, partial Social Security numbers, dates of birth, addresses, and clinical notes related to all clients.

Records Breached: 1,067 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: A breach of patient records occurred between July 3 and July 11 of 2013. ë_In a breach that may be related, a former employee was sued for stealing confidential health information and trade secrets in October.

Records Breached: 10,228 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: A hacker obtained the passwords to several employees' emails on July 29. ë_The email accounts may have contained the health information of patients.

Records Breached: 2,810 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The August 7 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_

Records Breached: 3,512 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
Description of incident: The August 27 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of patient information.

Three people were sentenced to prison for their roles in a scheme to defraud Medicare and Medicaid. ë_Two of the people owned RGV DME and a third worked for them. ë_Between early 2004 and late 2011, the three submitted fraudulent claims to Medicare and Texas Medicaid for DME supplies.

Company: Alta Bates Summit Medical Center, AverMedia Technologies
Description of incident: Two women are accused of misusing the information of over 115 people in the Bay Area for identity theft purposes. ë_At least 15 Atla Bates Summit Medical Center patients had their information misused and at least 35 had their information collected. ë_The two women were arrested on November 5 and also had a payroll sheet from AverMedia Technologies in their possession.
A July cyberattack resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Customers were required to change their log in credentials. ë_It is unclear what kind of customer information was exposed.

Anonymous/#AntiSec has claimed responsibility for the hack of a global intelligence company named Stratfor.ë_ Hackers were able to obtain tens of thousands of credit card numbers and other personal information from Stratfor.com.ë_ In addition to credit card numbers with security codes, addresses, and names, the hackers obtained 200GB of emails.ë_ The hackers also claim to have used the credit card information to make over $1 million in donations to charities. Hackers later revealed that the information was even easier to use since it had not been encrypted. Stratfor took the website down within an hour after it was hacked and defaced, but sensitive information had already been leaked.UPDATEë_(1/04/2012): A total of 68,063 unique credit card numbers, 859,311 unique email addresses, 860,160 hashed passwords, 50,569 phone numbers and 50,618 U.S. resident addresses were posted. ë_Of the 68,063 credit card numbers, about 36,000 were not expired. ë_UPDATE (2/15/2012): Hackers posing as officials from Stratfor have started emailing infected links to government subscribers whose email addresses were stolen during the breach.UPDATE (2/27/2012): Wikileaks published more than five million emails that were obtained by hackers during the breach. Some of these emails could contain sensitive information that would unmask sources, reveal security information that the intelligence-gathering company had collected, and reveal information about many Fortune 500 companies that subscribe to Stratfor.UPDATE (5/03/2012): Four Irish and British men were charged for their involvement with Anonymous's faction Antisec and the Stratfor breach. These men were also charged with involvement in hacks of Fox, Sony Pictures, and the Arizona Department of Public Safety.UPDATEë_(7/02/2012): Stratfor agreed to settle a class action lawsuit filed on behalf of customers. ë_Stratfor will offer members of the class action lawsuit one month of free access to its service, worth $29.08, and an electronic book published by Stratfo called "The Blue Book," priced at $12.99. ë_These two offers may cost Stratfor $1.75 million. ë_Additionally, Stratfor agreed to pay for a credit monitoring service for any members of the class action lawsuit who request the service. ë_Stratfor will also pay a $400,000 lump sum for plaintiff attorneys and various fees.UPDATEë_(08/11/2012): Emails with data about the implementation of the domestic surveillance programë_TrapWire were also exposed. TrapWire gathers surveillance data from major cities in the US, encrypts it, and sends it to a secretive central database center.UPDATEë_(05/28/2013): A member of Anonymous pleaded guilty to playing a part in hacking Stratfor Global Intelligence Service, Arizona Department of Public Safety, the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, the FBI's Virtual Academy, and the sheriff's office of Jefferson County, Alabama. ë_His charges are related to stealing emails and credit card data as well as hacking Stratfor and several other websites. ë_He faces up to 10 years in prison and is scheduled to be sentenced on September 6.UPDATEë_(11/15/2013): The member of Anonymous was sentenced to 10 years in prison and three years of probation.

Company: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University (Virginia Tech)
Records Breached: 144,963 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: The computer server of Virginia Tech's Department of Human Resources was accessed on August 28. ë_The information of people who applied online to Virginia Tech between 2003 and 2013 may have been accessed. ë_No Social Security numbers or financial information was exposed. A total of 16,642 job applicants had their driver's license numbers exposed. ë_The remaining job applicants had not submitted this information.
A hacker or hackers compromised some of the user accounts of GitHub. ë_The hackers used a brute force attack to expose passwords. ë_GitHub reset the passwords of users who were affected.

State Farm became aware of fraudulent charges on a customer's credit card a few days after the card was used to pay for insurance policies. ë_A former employee at an after-hours call center was found to have misused the credit card information of at least 11 customers. ë_The dishonest employee had also worked with 687 other customers.

Company: ICG America (Amazing Clubs, Games2U, Flying Noodle, Monster Brew, Texas Irons, California Reds)
Description of incident: ICG America Learned that its payment processing system was the target of a cyber attack. ë_The attack began on January 2, 2013 and continued until August 2, 2013. ë_Customers who made purchases from companies operated by ICG America may have had their names, credit card and debit card numbers, expiration dates, CVV codes, addresses, and email addresses exposed.
Unique Vintage's website was accessed by malware between January of 2012 and September 14, 2013. ë_Customer names, emails, credit card numbers, and phone numbers may have been accessed.

McHenry County College's software vendor Ellucian accidentally sent the personal information of current and former McHenry County College students and staff to three other junior colleges. ë_Social Security numbers and other information were sent to Morton, Prairie State, and Triton.

JP Morgan Chase customers received a privacy notification in early September. A labeling error caused the Social Security numbers of customers to be printed on the outside of the notification letter. ë_A lawsuit was filed against JP Morgan Chase on behalf of affected customers. ë_The lawsuit claims that JP Morgan did not immediately notify its customers and should have prevented the breach from happening. ë_The case is Alexander Furman et al v JP Morgan Chase & Co et al, No. 13-cv-06749, U.S. District Court, Northern District of Illinois.

Windhaven Investment discovered a breach of their server in August of 2013. ë_Client names, account numbers, custodians, investment positions, and other account information may have been accessed by an unauthorized party. ë_The breach may have occurred earlier than August. ë_At least 419 New Hampshire residents were affected. ë_The total number of people affected nationwide was not revealed.

Records Breached: 25 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: An unencrypted hard drive was discovered missing on January 14, 2013. ë_It held the names, health plan beneficiary numbers, diagnoses, medical record numbers, and account numbers of 25 Mercy Health Systems patients. ë_The hard drive was last seen by Mercy Health Systems' transcription contractor, Allscripts. Mercy Health Systems learned of the issue on February 14, 2013.

An unauthorized staff member provided a physician with the information of 433 patients on July 18. ë_The information included names, Social Security numbers, addresses, phone numbers for home and work, dates of birth, sex, languages spoken, employers, emergency contacts, emergency phone numbers, emergency contact relationship, guarantor information, and insurance information.
The June 27 car theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of customer information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and bank account information were exposed.
An unencrypted backup tape was discovered missing. ë_It contained patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, home addresses, and medical information.

A programming error that occurred on July 11, 2013 allowed 34 visitors to PLS Financial Services' website to view the names, Social Security numbers, addresses, and email addresses of PLS Financial Services customers. ë_The error was discovered on July 26 and quickly fixed.

On July 3, Bell Helicopter learned that some people who attended Bell Helicopter Training Academy were receiving phishing emails from a source claiming to be Bell. It appears that Bell's database of attendee information was accessed by a cyber intruder. ë_Attendees may have had their email addresses and credit card numbers exposed.

A breach was discovered on August 8 during the course of a routine audit. ë_It was discovered that a contractor accessed UnityPoint's EMR system without a legitimate reason. ë_An employee gave computer passwords to an employee of another company that provides care to patients. ë_Names, medical insurance account numbers, home addresses, dates of birth and other health information was accessed between February of 2013 and August of 2013. ë_

The September 25 car theft of a physician's laptop may have resulted in the exposure of patient information. ë_The laptop may or may not have been encrypted and the physician is based in the Division of Gastroenterology at UCSF's School of Medicine. Patient names, Social Security numbers, dates of birth, and medical record numbers were on the laptop. ë_

Malicious software was installed on the USI website on or around October 2, 2013.ë_ A hacker may have been able to view information stored in the USI system.ë_ Client names, usernames, passwords, and mailing addresses were exposed.

Records Breached: 6,284 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: New Health and Human Services Commission ID numbers were sent on Superior ID cards to CHIP members on October 4. ë_It was discovered that a computer error caused some Superior CHIP ID cards to be sent to incorrect addresses. Names, CHIP ID numbers, and doctors' names and phone numbers were exposed. ë_All members who were affected were notified.

Records Breached: 1,015 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: Group Health member identification numbers and chronic conditions were accidentally printed on the outside of letters that were mailed on September 16. ë_The issue was discovered on September 23.

Company: Ferris State University - Michigan College of Optometry
Description of incident: Michigan College of Optometry learned on July 23, 2013 that their network had been compromised in December of 2011. ë_A malware program could have accessed the names, Social Security numbers, demographic information, and a limited amount of clinical information of patients that were on the server. ë_Former and current patients were mailed letters on September 24.

Records Breached: 1,009 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: A routine security audit at Sierra View District Hospital revealed that an employee had inappropriately accessed protected health information. ë_An investigation revealed that the information was not disclosed externally. ë_The breach occurred between July 1 and August 2. ë_
A cyber attack occurred during the period between March and April 2013. ë_Dun & Bradstreet hold information for business marketing and other businesses may have been affected.ë_

A virus was discovered on The Flamingo Resort and Spa payroll computer. ë_Employee names, Social Security numbers, bank routing numbers for those who used direct deposit, dates of birth, phone numbers, and home addresses may have been exposed.

Company: Orange County Anaheim Medical Center, Kaiser Foundation Hospital
Description of incident: A flash drive that contained patient information was discovered missing on September 25, 2013. ë_It contained names, dates of birth, and medical record numbers. ë_

An employee was found to have accessed patient records without legitimate cause. ë_The employee worked in a unit coordinator position for about a year and her supervisor was aware of the issue. ë_Patient names, Social Security numbers, medical records, dates of birth, contact information, treatment information, and diagnosis information were accessed. ë_The employee was fired.
Crown Castle determined on October 31 that their payroll information may have been accessed by hackers. ë_Employee names, Social Security numbers, and compensation may have been exposed.

Company: City of Wichita  - Electronic Procurement Website
Description of incident: Hackers accessed the city of Wichita's electronic procurement website. ë_Current and former vendors who had worked with the city and employees who had been reimbursed for expenses ë_since 1997 were affected. ë_Social Security numbers, taxpayer ID numbers, and bank account information may have been exposed.UPDATEë_(11/22/2013): This breach was a result of the Dun & Bradstreet Credibility Corp. breach. ë_Nearly 29,000 local vendors and employers were affected by the hacking incident that occurred during the weekend of October 5.

Records Breached: 1,039 (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: An unencrypted flash drive from Redwood Memorial Hospital's Cardiopumlonary Services Department was discovered missing on November 8. ë_The flash drive had been missing since at least November 6 and contained patient names, report ID numbers, test indications, ages, heights, weights, test recording and analysis dates and times, facility and address where services were rendered, and clinical summaries of test findings. ë_Some patients who were seen at Redwood Memorial Hospital between 2001 and 2013 may have had their information exposed. ë_

The October 12 theft of a laptop resulted in the exposure of current and former employee information. ë_Current and former employees of Clarity Media Group's subsidiaries and of Freedom Communications were also affected. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, mailing addresses, email addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, salaries, and 401(k) balances were on the laptop. ë_The dependents of employees may have also had their information exposed.

The Social Security numbers and tax identification numbers of around 24,500 California doctors were accidentally posted in Anthem's online provider directory. ë_The information was available online at the end of October for about 24 hours.

Two breaches in the summer of 2013 and November of 2013 resulted in the exposure of student information. ë_The sensitive information that was exposed in July may have been accidentally exposed through an administrative error. ë_A second breach was discovered on November 8 when the Superintendent learned that student information had been posted on a publicly accessible webpage. ë_The investigation of the November breach is ongoing. ë_Student names and ID numbers were the primary types of data that were exposed in both incidents.UPDATE (11/23/2013): A student of Sachem North High School pleaded not guilty to computer trespass and was released without bail.ë_ The student may have also accessed information in 2012.ë_ A list of 15,000 students' information that dated back to the early 2000s was discovered online. A list of 130 students who received instructional services in an alternative setting in the 2010-2011 school year was also discovered online.

Company: Dynacare Laboratory, Froedtert Health Workforce Health, City of Milwaukee
Description of incident: A Dynacare Laboratory employee's car was stolen on October 22. ë_The car held a flash drive with employee names, Social Security numbers, addresses, dates of birth, and genders. ë_Dynacare Laboratory is one of Froedtert Health Workforce's contractors and Froedtert Health Workforce was handling health information for the City of Milwaukee Wellness Program. ë_The City of Milwaukee Department of Employee Relations learned of the incident on November 15.UPDATEë_(11/18/2013): A Dynacare laptop that contained no personal information was also in the employee's car. ë_The car and laptop were recovered; the flash drive remains missing.UPDATEë_(11/21/2013): The City of Milwaukee filed a complaint against Dynacare with the Federal Office of Civil Rights.UPDATEë_(11/29/2013): A total of 9,414 people were affected including about 6,000 city employees and 3,000 city employee dependents. ë_The Milwaukee Professional Firefighters Association Local 215 was also affected and a lawsuit against Dynacare Laboratory and Froedtert Health was filed.

Company: University of Nebraska, Nebraska Student Information System, Nebraska College System
Description of incident: A University technical staff member discovered a breach on May 23. ë_Staff took steps to limit the breach and there was no clear evidence that any information was downloaded. ë_The Social Security numbers, addresses, grades, transcripts, housing and financial aid information for current and former University of Nebraska students may have been accessed. ë_The database also included the information of people who applied to the University of Nebraska, but may have not been admitted, and alumni information as far back as Spring of 1985. The University of Nebraska was still investigating the extent of the breach as of May 25, 2012.UPDATEë_(05/29/2012): The University of Nebraska created a webpage for information about the breach. ë_Close to 21,000 people had bank account information that was linked to the student information system and exposed. ë_The University of Nebraska's computer database also held 654,000 Social Security numbers, though it is unclear if that number completely overlaps the number of individuals who had their bank account information exposed. ë_Current and former students of the University of Nebraska campuses in Lincoln, Omaha, and Kearney were affected; as well as anyone who applied to the University since 1985.UPDATEë_(06/01/2012): The Nebraska College System began using a shared student information system called NeSIS in 2009. ë_This resulted in data from Chadron State, Peru State, and Wayne State colleges being exposed.UPDATE (09/10/2012): Police seized computers and related equipment belonging to a University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) undergraduate student who is believed to be involved in the incident.UPDATEë_(12/11/2012): The former UNL student has been charged with intentionally accessing a protected computer system and causing damage of at least $5,000.UPDATE (06/22/2013): The hacker now faces an additional nine charges of exceeding his authorized access to a computer and two charges of knowingly transmitting a program that damaged computers owned by the University of Nebraska and Nebraska State College Systems.UPDATEë_(12/03/2013): The hacker and former UNL student pleaded guilty to one count of intentionally damaging a protected computer and causing loss in excess of $5,000. ë_His sentencing was scheduled for March 21, 2014.

Washington banks and credit unions noticed fraudulent activity on the debit and credit cards of grocery store customers. ë_The breach was traced to Yoke's Fresh Markets, Rosauers stores, and other grocery stores associated with URM stores. ë_The hacking incident occurred sometime between September and October. ë_Customers were encouraged to use cash, check, or an alternative form of payment card processing to pay in stores until the breach was resolved.UPDATEë_(12/03/2013): Over 24 stores in Montana and an unspecified number of stores in Oregon were also affected. ë_URM believes the breach that allowed fraudulent copies of customer payment cards to be created has been contained. ë_Customers were encouraged to check their bank statements after URM allowed normal payment card purchases to resume.

MadeInOregon's website may have been accessed by unauthorized parties. ë_The credit card transaction information of customers may have been accessed between mid-October and mid-November. Seven customers confirmed that they were affected by fraudulent credit card activity after making purchases on MadeInOregon's website.

Company: ADP, Facebook, Gmail, LinkedIn, Twitter, Yahoo, YouTube
Records Breached: 2 million (No Social Security numbers or financial information reported)
Description of incident: A breach that involved keylogging software affected at least 93,000 websites. ë_The virus may have originated on a server located in the Netherlands. ë_It first started collecting passwords and usernames on October 21. Approximately 860 computers in the United States were affected. More than 99% of the computers that were affected were outside of the United States.

Company: Adobe, PR Newswire, National White Collar Crime Center
Records Breached: 2.9 million (38 million user emails and passwords exposed)
Description of incident: Hackers obtained the customer information of nearly 3 million Adobe custoemrs who used Photoshop, InDesign, Premiere, and other Adobe software products. ë_Customer IDs, encrypted passwords, names, encrypted credit or debit card numbers, expiration dates, and other information related to customer orders were exposed. ë_Anyone who bought software directly from Adobe's website is advised to change their Adobe account passwords.UPDATEë_(10/11/2013): Hackers kept the source code on a hidden, but unencrypted server.UPDATEë_(10/21/2013): A second breach related to the initial one in early October caused Adobe to reset client passwords.UPDATEë_(10/29/2013): An investigation revealed that the encrypted passwords of approximately 38 million active users were also exposed. ë_Adobe IDs were also compromised and were reset by Adobe after the breach.UPDATEë_(11/20/2013): Around 42 million passwords for the Australian-based online dating service Cupid Media were also found on the same server that contained stolen Adobe, PR Newswire, and National White Collar Crime Center information.UPDATEë_(11/25/2013): Some estimate that 152 million Adobe ID accounts were in a file that began circulating the internet in late October. ë_Adobe systems Inc has encountered delays in trying to notify all customers of the issue since it was discovered 10 weeks ago.ë_ë_

Company: B&G Foods North America, Inc., Maple Grove Farms
Description of incident: On November, 16, B&G Foods North America, Inc. discovered that an unauthorized party accessed Maple Grove Farms' website. ë_Customers who made online purchases may have had their names, addresses, telephone numbers, and payment card numbers exposed. ë_

Company: Lincoln Credit Center, National Debt Defense, SmartPath
Description of incident: Personal information related to client accounts may have been compromised at a physical location. ë_The breach occurred sometime between October 20 and November 15. Lincoln Credit Center is monitoring client accounts for suspicious activity.

An unspecified number of Discover customers had their account numbers changed and were issued a new card. ë_It is unclear what type of security breach prompted the notification and when it may have occurred. Several customers in California received the notification letter; residents of other states may have been notified as well.

An unspecified number of Discover customers had their account numbers changed and were issued a new card. ë_It is unclear what type of security breach prompted the notification and when it may have occurred. Several customers in California received the notification letter; residents of other states may have been notified as well.

Sometime around April 11, 2013, Dr. Whisman learned of a breach that involved patient information on a computer recovered during an identity theft ring investigation. ë_The patient information included full names, Social Security numbers, addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, and insurance plan information for patients who were seen in 1998 and 1999. ë_The information likely came from a stolen computer and Dr. Whisman was encouraged to delay notification until the investigation was completed.

Company: LexisNexis, Dun & Bradstreet, Kroll Background America
Description of incident: Hackers were able to access an underground database of stolen consumer information. ë_It was discovered that the network was set up to receive information from internal systems at several large data brokers. ë_LexisNexis was one of the data brokers that was affected and discovered that their networks may have been compromised for at least five months. ë_Dun & Bradstreet discovered that their systems had been compromised as far back as March 27, 2013. ë_The breach of Kroll Background America, Inc. had began as far back as June 2013.UPDATEë_(11/26/2013): Kroll Background America informed California that 548 California residents were affected by the breach.
The December 5 theft of an encrypted laptop and files resulted in the exposure of transplant patient information. ë_Names, Social Security numbers, and dates of birth may have been exposed.

Records Breached: 860,000 (No Social Security numbers or financial information exposed)
